headline: German Economy Unexpectedly Grew in the Fourth Quarter
abstract: German economy grew unexpectedly in fourth quarter, expanding 2.2 percent from the quarter a year earlier; Government says gross domestic product expanded one-tenth of 1 percent from prior three months, or at the 2.2 percent annual pace; for all of 1996, economy grew only 1.4 percent (L)

headline: Queen of Cyberspace Gossip
abstract: Interview with Susan Mulcahy, former newspaper gossip columnist and now publisher and editor in chief of Mr Showbiz and Celeb Site, two Starwave Corp World Wide Web sites devoted to entertainment industry celebrity news; photos (M)

headline: German Drug Company Doubled Profit in 1996
abstract: Gehe AG posts 1996 net income of 440 million marks ($261 million), up from 211 million marks in 1995 (S)

headline: A Scene From Pages Of Tolstoy: At the Ball
abstract: Russian Nobility Association holds its Winter Ball in rented theater in Moscow; photo of Marina Katina, 17-year-old belle of ball (M)

headline: Where a Dog Can Be a Pet, or a Dining Experience
abstract: Even though many middle-class South Koreans currently keep dogs as pets, others still regard them as old-fashioned delicacy, butchering them for meat; some Government officials dislike custom of eating dogs out of fear that it may harm nation's image, while many young people sometimes object simply because they see dogs as animals to be petted, rather than sold as meat; photo (M)

headline: Greenspan Speaks and Stocks Plunge
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes down 55.03 points at 6,983.18 after Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan warns of possible interest-rate increase and cautions that current stock market environment might be characterized by 'excessive optimism'; Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks loses 6.42 points, to close at 805.68; Nasdaq composite index is off 7.14, or about one-half percent, to close at 1,340.55 (L)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   9.00        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.13   5.18   5.71        3-MO. headline: The Super Bowl predicts the market, and vice versa.
abstract: Market Place column explores observed--and probably irrelevant--correlations between stock market performance and results of Super Bowl (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Sears, Roebuck & Co., Hoffman Estates, Ill., signed a multiyear sponsorship agreement with the Women's National Basketball Association, which begins play in the summer.

headline: Analysts Say 1990's Bull Market Faces Its Toughest Test
abstract: Many analysts see new hurdles for stock market and possibility of significant downturn, with potential to end semingly miraculous bull run of 1990's; many expect what Wall Street calls a correction, when stocks fall 10 percent to 20 percent after big run-up; others say outlook for economy and stock market remains healthy and expect only minor, near-term setback; Dow Jones industrial average has gone six years without a 10 percent correction, longest such period in history; it is in midst of its biggest decline since last summer, down nearly 5 percent since March 11 (M)

headline: Stocks Lower in Japan
abstract: Stocks trade lower in Tokyo on Feb 3; Nikkei index of 225 issues closes down 244.06 points, at 18,085.95 (S)

headline: Letter-Bomb Hunt Stepped Up on 3 Continents
abstract: Law enforcement authorities on three continents intensify their investigation into mysterious letter-bomb campaign in which 18 greeting cards booby-trapped with high explosives were sent to Al Hayat, Arabic newspaper and Federal prison; first bombs were discovered in early Jan at paper's offices in Washington, DC, at Federal prison in Levenworth, Kan, and at post office in that city; letter bombs were also received in Saudi Arabia; all were disarmed without incident; second wave of bombs arrived on Jan 13; four were addressed to United Nations office of Al Hayat and four were received at its headquarters in London, including one that seriously wounded mail clerk (M)

headline: U.S. Again Vetoes a Move By U.N. Condemning Israel
abstract: Clinton Administration casts its third Security Council veto in defense of Israel and blocks latest and most moderate resolution calling on Israel to halt construction of Jewish housing project in predominantly Arab East Jerusalem; Security council issues statement expressing members' 'revulsion' at bombing in Tel Aviv, which leave four dead and dozens wounded (M)

headline: Can Its Private Pension Plan Offer Lessons to the U.S.?
abstract: Chile's 'defined contribution' private pension system has been such a success that it is being studied carefully by other Governments in Latin America, as well as in Britain and United States; system makes individuals responsible for financing their own retirement, requiring that they deposit 13 percent of their wages in retirement accounts; accounts move from job to job with their owners, and are managed by 20 private mutual fund groups; administrators are strictly limited in their discretion to take investment risks; observers are intrigued at way pension reform has meshed with Chile's goal of moving economy to fast growth track; privatization has made it impossible to paper over Government budget deficits with current cash flow from pension system; resulting fiscal austerity raised savings rate to 28 percent; this has great interest to US, but question remains whether what works for poor but rapidly developing economy would work in America and Europe; photos; charts (L)

headline: Southwestern Bell to Sell Lucent Products
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc announces agreement under which Southwestern Bell Telephone Co will market Lucent products to its business customers; beginning in April, 170 Lucent salespeople are to begin working with Southwestern Bell's sales staff to sell corporate telephone systems labeled with names of both companies (S)

headline: United Technologies Earnings Are Up 23%
abstract: United Technologies Corp says its earnings increased 23 percent in fourth quarter, to $229 million, from year earlier; revenue was up to $6.14 billion from $5.97 billion (S)

headline: Dollar Rises vs. Mark and Yen; Foreign Stock Prices End Mixed
abstract: Dollar continues to rise against German mark and Japanese yen; Nikkei index of 225 Japanese stock issues drops 279.90 points on Tues, Feb 18, to 18,470.75 (S)

headline: U.S. to Auction Bills and Notes
abstract: The Treasury's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills will be postponed until tomorrow because of Martin Luther King Jr. Day. Two- and five-year notes will be auctioned Wednesday and Thursday.     By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.00 percent and on the six-month bill, 5.05 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a rate to yield 5.96 percent and a five-year note, 6.30 percent.

headline: Serbs' Eyes on Milosevic: Crackdown or a Coup?
abstract: Sixth week of mass demonstrations in Belgrade finds Serbs waiting to see if Pres Slobodan Milosevic will carry out crackdown and arrest opponents, or declare state of emergency that could be prelude to coup; immediate question is his response to finding by Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe that municipal election results should be reinstated; opposition leaders see cracks in police and military ranks in face of economic collapse and endemic corruption; many in Montenegro talk of secession, and Orthodox Church, longtime Milosevic supporter, condemns ruling Socialists for election fraud; photos of demonstrators and Patriarch Pavle (S)

headline: CALIBER TO REVAMP DIVISION AND CUT 4,000 JOBS
abstract: Caliber System Inc says it will reorganize its Viking Freight Inc division because of steep losses; move will result in elimination of 4,000 jobs and $150 million charge against previously reported 1996 earnings (S)

headline: Edgy Market Tumbles for a Third Day as Dow Loses 59.27
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 59.27 points to close at 6,696.48, capping late week plunge that leaves index up 3.9 percent for the year; graph (L)ÿ

headline: After Accident, Japan Rethinks Its Nuclear Hopes
abstract: Recent fire and explosion at Japan's only nuclear waste processing plant at Tokai have raised public concern about safety of atomic power and cast cloud over nation's already controversial program to harnesss deadly plutonium as source of energy; photo; map (M)

headline: U.S. Vetoes U.N. Criticism of Israel's Construction Plan
abstract: United States uses its Security Council veto to block resolution that strongly criticizes Israeli Govt's plan to build new Jewish settlement in mainly Arab East Jerusalem; but all 14 other Council members vote for measure, which portrays Israeli plan as violation of international law and threat to peace in Middle East; American repr, Bill Richardson, repeats Pres Clinton's opposition to housing plan, but asserts that Israel and Palestinians must resolve their differences themselves and that interference by United Nations tends only to provoke mistrust between them, and harden each side's position; photo (M)

headline: U.S.-China Textile Trade Pact Signed in Time for Albright Trip
abstract: American officials say broad agreement reached by US and China on textile trade is likely to further increase sector of cross-Pacific commerce already worth billions; portray agreement as breakthrough that allows American textile-sellers better access to China, in exchange for loosening restrictions on volume of textiles and garments that China exports to US, its largest market (M)

headline: Greenspan Calms Market and Stocks Soar
abstract: Alan Greenspan, chairman of Federal Reserve, offers slightly more soothing comments about future of stock market and investors latch onto them to drive stock and bond prices sharply higher, speech to National Association of Business Economists and testimony before House Banking Committee; Greenspan says he does not know which way stock prices are headed and that the market will be overvalued only if analysts' projections for substantial earnings increases in few years prove wrong; Dow Jones industrial average closes up 93.13 points, or 1.36 percent, at 6,945.85; Greenspan does not provide any new indications that Fed will raise interest rates anytime soon; graph (L)

headline: WAL-MART SETS STOCK REPURCHASE AND RAISES DIVIDEND
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores Inc will buy back additional $2 billion of stock in next 12 to 18 months in open market and raise its quarterly dividend 29 percent (S)

headline: Rebels Free a High-Ranking Captive
abstract: Peruvian guerrillas holding scores of hostages in Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima release Luis Valencia Hirano, official of Peru's antiterrorist police unit; Red Cross says he was freed on medical grounds (S)

headline: Nasdaq's New Rules: Step 1 Starts Tomorrow
abstract: New trading rules on Nasdaq, designed to improve chances of investors getting better price, discussed; 50 stocks are included in new rules, which will cover complete list of 6,384 stocks by August; 50 initial stocks noted (M)

headline: Deaths in the Workplace: Looking Beyond the Numbers
abstract: Letter by Dr Howard Frumkin on Dec 22 article examing deaths of 13 American workers on single day last fall (M)

headline: German Concern To Pay Ex-Chief
abstract: Metallgesellschaft AG says it will pay its former chief exec, Heinz Schimmelbusch, 1.5 million marks ($920,000) as part of out-of-court settlement concerning his dismissal in Dec 1993 (M)

headline: The Executive Pay Escalator
abstract: In a year when average workers got 3.3 percent raises and profits climbed 11 percent, pay of many chief executives rose 20 percent or more. The main reason: Bigger grants of stock options to chief executives like these three.    Money & Business, Section 3.

headline: Credit Lyonnais Shares Jump on Expectations
abstract: Shares of Credit Lyonnais SA jump after financial newspaper Les Echos encourages expectations state-owned bank will report 'spectacular rebound' in profit this year; newspaper says bank will post profit this year of between 3.4 billion francs ($596.79 million) and 3.7 billion francs (S)

headline: Economic Calender
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: A Grisly Assassination That Will Not Stay Buried
abstract: People of Burkino Faso mark 10th anniversary of assassination of Thomas Sankara, charismatic leader, even though he lies in a commoner's grave and his onetime friend and successor as President, Blaise Compaore, has done everything to erase his memory; Campaore, who strenuously denies any connection with Sankara's killing, also denies involvement in October 1996 disapperance of Yacinthe Kafando, the feared presidential security chief who is widely suspected of leading the hit squad that killed Sankara; photo; map (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: A chart last Sunday about the performance of different types of mutual funds during bear markets omitted the percentage returns of the best- and worst-performing fund groups. A corrected version appears today on page 7.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Rubbermaid Inc says its Little Tykes unit will close its third toy-making plant, eliminating total of 725 jobs since November because of slow sales and stiff toy industry competition (S)

headline: Ford to Lift Stake In Chinese Truck Maker
abstract: Ford Motor Company plans to invest $40 million in Jiangling Motors Company, China, raising its stake to 33 percent (S)

headline: Notes and Bills Set for Auction During Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week comprises today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills; two-year and five-year notes being sold tomorrow and Wednesday, and a 52-week bill being auctioned on Wednesday.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.24 percent and on the six-month bill, 5.34 percent. The rate on the 52-week bill was 5.51 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.30 percent, and the five-year note at 6.61 percent.

headline: A Sri Lankan Priest Is Excommunicated For His 'Relativism'
abstract: Rev Tissa Balasuriya, 72-year-old Sri Lankan priest, is excommunicated by Vatican for allegedly deviating from integrity and truth of Catholic faith; is accused of challenging such basic Roman Catholic beliefs as original sin and Immaculate Conception through advocacy of religious relativism, which holds no faith has unique claim to truth and no spiritual figure can claim to be only savior; he remains defiant; says his four-year battle with defenders of Catholic orthodoxy has made him more Catholic than ever; efforts of Vatican to quash rising tide of relativism, described by top church official as gravest threat to dogmatic faith since Marxism, discussed; disciplining of other errant theologians by Pope John Paul II noted (M)

headline: National Semiconductor Reports Strong Growth in Earnings
abstract: National Semiconductor Corp reports strong growth in revenue and earnings for its third fiscal quarter, ended on Feb 23, exceeding Wall Street analysts' estimates; reports earnings of $42.8 million, up 86 percent from $23 million in comparable period a year earlier; sales rose 13 percent, to $680.5 million (M)

headline: German Economy Unexpectedly Grew in the Fourth Quarter
abstract: German economy grew unexpectedly in fourth quarter, expanding 2.2 percent from the quarter a year earlier; Government says gross domestic product expanded one-tenth of 1 percent from prior three months, or at the 2.2 percent annual pace; for all of 1996, economy grew only 1.4 percent (L)

headline: Queen of Cyberspace Gossip
abstract: Interview with Susan Mulcahy, former newspaper gossip columnist and now publisher and editor in chief of Mr Showbiz and Celeb Site, two Starwave Corp World Wide Web sites devoted to entertainment industry celebrity news; photos (M)

headline: German Drug Company Doubled Profit in 1996
abstract: Gehe AG posts 1996 net income of 440 million marks ($261 million), up from 211 million marks in 1995 (S)

headline: A Scene From Pages Of Tolstoy: At the Ball
abstract: Russian Nobility Association holds its Winter Ball in rented theater in Moscow; photo of Marina Katina, 17-year-old belle of ball (M)

headline: Where a Dog Can Be a Pet, or a Dining Experience
abstract: Even though many middle-class South Koreans currently keep dogs as pets, others still regard them as old-fashioned delicacy, butchering them for meat; some Government officials dislike custom of eating dogs out of fear that it may harm nation's image, while many young people sometimes object simply because they see dogs as animals to be petted, rather than sold as meat; photo (M)

headline: Greenspan Speaks and Stocks Plunge
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes down 55.03 points at 6,983.18 after Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan warns of possible interest-rate increase and cautions that current stock market environment might be characterized by 'excessive optimism'; Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks loses 6.42 points, to close at 805.68; Nasdaq composite index is off 7.14, or about one-half percent, to close at 1,340.55 (L)

headline: The Super Bowl predicts the market, and vice versa.
abstract: Market Place column explores observed--and probably irrelevant--correlations between stock market performance and results of Super Bowl (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Sears, Roebuck & Co., Hoffman Estates, Ill., signed a multiyear sponsorship agreement with the Women's National Basketball Association, which begins play in the summer.

headline: Analysts Say 1990's Bull Market Faces Its Toughest Test
abstract: Many analysts see new hurdles for stock market and possibility of significant downturn, with potential to end semingly miraculous bull run of 1990's; many expect what Wall Street calls a correction, when stocks fall 10 percent to 20 percent after big run-up; others say outlook for economy and stock market remains healthy and expect only minor, near-term setback; Dow Jones industrial average has gone six years without a 10 percent correction, longest such period in history; it is in midst of its biggest decline since last summer, down nearly 5 percent since March 11 (M)

headline: MANAGERS AT LESLIE'S POOLMART TO BUY COMPANY
abstract: Leslie's Poolmart says its board has approved agreement under which investment group involving company's management would buy Leslie's for about $109 million (S)

headline: G.M. Says Profits Fell Throughout 1996
abstract: General Motors Corp reports earning $786 million in fourth quarter, down from $1.6 billion in 1995 period; reports 1996 earnings fell to $4.96 billion, down from $6.88 billion in 1995; puts strike-related after-tax losses at $1.2 billion for year; table (M)

headline: COCA-COLA EXPECTS RISE IN WORLDWIDE SALES
abstract: Coca-Cola Co says it expects worldwide case sales to rise from 7 percent to 8 percent in first quarter compared with corresponding period a year ago; also expects worldwide gallon sales to rise from 5 percent to 6 percent in three months ending on March 31 (S)

headline: Albright Struts Across a World Stage, Radiating Star Quality
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright appears to be enjoying her grueling 9-nation, 11-day tour of the world; Albright is thought to have star quality, and she tries to use it to further her aims; she has made no noticeable changes in Pres Clinton's essentially reactive foreign policy, but she is already asserting her role as his chief foreign-policy spokeswoman and player, in marked contrast to her reticent predecessor, Warren Christopher (M)

headline: G.E. of Britain Wins Submarine Contract
abstract: General Electric Co PLC and partners that include Rolls-Royce PLC win pact worth almost $2 billion pounds ($3.2 billion) to build three British nuclear missile submarines, ending 15 months of talks over price (S)

headline: Both Sides Fail to Show At Hostage Talks in Peru
abstract: Talks between leftist rebels holding 72 hostages and Peruvian Government fail to resume as planned on March 10, with commission overseeing talks waiting at negotiating table and neither side showing up (S)

headline: Gandhi's Ashes Rest, but Not His Message
abstract: In a mood of reproachful retrospection, India turned the clock back nearly half a century today with an emotional ceremony at a sacred Ganges site to scatter some of Mohandas K. Gandhi's ashes, long left forgotten in a provincial bank vault.     For a few hours, this city was host to events that seemed borrowed from the days after a Hindu nationalist assassinated Gandhi in New Delhi on Jan. 30, 1948.

headline: J. C. Penney Income Off Despite Sales Increase
abstract: J C Penney Co says net income and operating earnings declined in fourth quarter despite 23 percent increase in sales; net income fell 71 percent, to $94 million from $326 million; sales rose to $8.16 billion from $6.63 billion; table (M)

headline: Rivals Put the Market Before the Standard To Sell 56K Modems
abstract: Proponents of two rival standards for high-speed modems are rushing to gain market toehold before first meeting of committee that is to decide industry-wide standard (S)

headline: Sexual Harassment, In Uncertain Terms
abstract: Article by Herbert Barchoff, former member of Council of Economic Advisers, discusses perplexing anomaly of living in most open sexual society ever, while at same time society is expected to adhere to stringent puritancial code of behavior in workplace, where complaints and lawsuits involving sexual harassment can be brought on most trivial grounds; sketch (M)

headline: Wassall to Sell Shares In U.S. Cable Maker
abstract: Shares of Wassall PLC rise after company says it will raise $350 million by selling 70 percent in American cable manufacturing unit, General Cable Corp, and will pay shareholders a bonus dividend; Wassall says it will transfer $240 milion in debt to General Cable, which it bought for $270 million in June 1994; Wassall will use 150 million pounds ($245 million) of proceeds from sale to pay bonus dividend of 76 pence ($1.22) a share (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: THREE CITIES RESEARCH FUNDS CORP., a venture capital and leveraged buyout investment group based in New York, said it planned to acquire 48 to 52 percent of Family Bargain Corp. of San Diego for about $32 million.    DIXIE YARNS INC.,  Chattanooga, Tenn., a maker of floor coverings and textiles, acquired the business and operating assets of Danube Carpet Mills Inc., a subsidiary of Shelter Components Corp., for $18.2 million in cash.    LCC INTERNATIONAL INC.,  Arlington, Va., acquired European Technology Partner A.S. of Oslo, Norway, a provider of network information and quality-of-service systems for wireless operations, for $13 million.    RAYTHEON CO.,  Lexington, Mass., the manufacturer of diverse electronic equipment and components, said it had received six Army contracts worth about $390 million.

headline: EASTMAN KODAK TO COMBINE SALES FORCES OF 2 UNITS
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co will combine sales forces of its Consumer Imaging and Qualex film processing units as part of reorganization of its photofinishing operations; jobs will probably not be cut but realignment of sales force is likely (S)

headline: With Hard Times, Bulgarian Protesters Demand Elections
abstract: Tens of thousands of angry anti-Government demonstrators stage protest in Sofia, Bulgaria, demanding early elections and end of worst economic crisis in Eastern Europe since end of Communism; governing Socialist Party, outgrowth of former Communists, declined to defuse situation by accepting appeals by Pres Zhelyu Zhelev and Speaker of Parliament to agree immediately to earlier elections; has been in power for past two years as country has slid into virtual bankruptcy; map; photo (M)

headline: Amphenol Agrees to Fee if Deal Fails
abstract: Amphenol Corp agrees to pay Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company $37.5 million if proposed $1.05 billion leveraged buyout of Amphenol by Kohlberg Kravis fails; penalty would be set off if Kohlberg Kravis's acquisition was not completed by June 30, if Amphenol shareholders voted against it, or if another buyer purchased more than 20 percent of Amphenol's stock (S)

headline: Renault Layoffs Test French Commitment to European Unity
abstract: When French automotive giant Renault SA, which was nationalized in 1946 and is still 46 percent owned by French state, decided that slumping car sales and mounting losses necessitated layoffs and dismissals, it picked assembly plant across the border in Belgium, one that employs 3,100 mostly Flemish-speaking workers, to bear the brunt of them; it announced on Feb 27 that it would close the plant in July; decision has caused storm of protest in Belgium and has raised questions--even at home--about France's commitment to the idea of European unity when its own economic interests are at stake; Renault, which has 140,000 workers worldwide, discloses that it will also eliminate 2,764 jobs in France this year; though those cuts wil be more widely dispersed than in Belgian move, French unions have reacted angrily, planning work stoppage for later this week, and announcement does not appear to have mollified the Belgians (L)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: Advanta Corp names James W John Advanta International president; Don R Clarke resigns as Caldor Corp chairman and chief executive; Warren Feldberg, president and chief operating officer, will replace him; Lehman Brothers names Joseph Amato head of United States equity research; Planet Hollywood International Inc names Brian Woods president of its Planet Hollywood division; SCB Computer Technology Inc names Gary E McCarter senior vice president for finance and adminstration (S)

headline: The $1 Trillion Dogfight
abstract: Boeing Co and Airbus Industrie are locked in high-stakes marketing battle for lion's share of estimated $1 tillion or more in orders for passenger planes over next 20 years; industry forecasts suggest more than 13,500 planes will be built to replace aging fleets and accommodate growing demand for air travel; photos; chart (L)

headline: In Columbus's New World, a New Day for Barrios
abstract: Dominican Pres Leonel Fernandez revokes edict of predecessor Joaquin Balaguer, under which residents of slums around capital of Santo Domingo were being forced from humble dwellings in shadow of $70 million tower built to honor Christopher Columbus; new Government is allowing residents to remain and is improving living conditions in barrios (M)

headline: U.A.W. WORKERS AT INDIANA G.M. PLANT RATIFY PACT
abstract: General Motors Corp says that United Auto Workers had ratified agreement that ends 13-day strike at company's pickup truck plant in Fort Wayne, Indiana; under agreement, GM will hire 276 workers; new workers, though full time, will be used mainly to fill in for people who are on vacation, in training or otherwise temporarily absent (S)

headline: INVACARE OFFERS TO BUY HEALTHDYNE TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: Invacare Corp offers to buy Healthdyne Technologies Inc for $160.4 million cash (S)

headline: The Dollar Declines, Then Recovers, in Tokyo
abstract: Dollar rebounds from sharp selloff at opening of Asian trading; Nikkei index of 225 Japanese stock issues rises 314.13 points, to 18,181.17 (M)

headline: What's in a Name? Apparently a Lot
abstract: Annual survey of corporate name changes conducted by Anspach Grossman Enterprise finds there were 1,471 name changes in 1996, up 27 percent from 1995; primary reason was corporate revamping (S)

headline: CREDIT SUISSE FIRST BOSTON TO TAKE STAKE IN VOLPE
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston will take 25 percent stake in Volpe Brown & Whelan & Co, boutique investment bank specializing in technology and health care, to increase its business in those industries (S)

headline: Stocks Slip a Bit as Wall Street Braces for Data on Employment
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes down 1.15 points, to 6,944.70; Nasdaq composite index loses 13.66 points, to 1,315.43 (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Earnings Rise at Kodak, And It Plans Job Cuts  Eastman Kodak said operating profits in the fourth quarter rose by 21.5 percent. Wall Street was pleased, and Kodak stock rose 5 percent.

headline: Happier Motoring: Choices in Buying Insurance
abstract: Economic Scene column contends that proposal from New Jersey Gov Christine Todd Whitman to allow motorists to buy no-frills, no-fault auto insurance that could pare premiums by as much as one-fourth is seen as spark for move nationally to lower auto insurance policies (M)

headline: Secretaries Go From 'Take a Letter' to Taking Charge
abstract: Secretaries have emerged from days of being just helpers who keep boss's calendar straight and take dictation to increasingly taking on duties of middle managers; reasons for change are varied, ranging from executive downsizing to use by executives of E-mail and other electronic tools, thereby relieving secretaries of some of their time-consuming clerical jobs and making them available to tackle other tasks; in most cases, however, authority given to secretaries has lagged behind that of former managers whose duties they are assuming; so have their salary levels: average pay for secretaries is about $8,000 less a year than average pay for white-collar workers in private industry; photo (M)

headline: Australian Fishermen, Warned of Peril, Remain on the Rocks
abstract: Fishing from rocks and cliffs along coast of New South Wales, Australia, remains hazardous pastime, and is perhaps most deadly sport in world; officials say some casualties seem to forget most basic elements of common sense and misjudge tides and power of waves; say others prefer to fish from most isolated and inaccessible spots that make rescues difficult or impossible; 14 people died in fishing accidents along coast in 1996, compared with nine in 1995 (M)

headline: Unocal Signs Burmese Gas Deal; U.S. May Ban Such Accords
abstract: As the Clinton Administration weighs whether to impose a ban on new American investment in Myanmar because of its human rights abuses, the Unocal Corporation has signed a deal with the Burmese Government to greatly expand its rights to explore and develop gas fields off the coast.    The agreement was announced by Unocal on Thursday, the same day the State Department, in its annual human rights review, condemned the killing and torture of dissidents and ethnic minorities in Myanmar, formerly Burma. Though Unocal's statement made no mention of it, company officials confirmed today that the Burmese Government was paid a signing bonus of several million dollars.

headline: ITT Board Votes Unanimously To Reject Hilton Takeover Bid
abstract: Board of ITT Corp unanimously rejects $6.5 billion hostile takeover bid by Hilton Hotels Corp; says offer is inadequate and that it intends to remain independent; says combined company could have problems with antitrust and gambling laws; says it will fight hostile takeover in Federal court in Nevada, where Hilton filed lawsuit to block it from using anti-takeover measures (M)

headline: Agencies vie for accounts worth $250 million as consumer goods companies step up reviews.
abstract: Advertising column discusses various agencies vying for accounts worth $250 million (M)

headline: VITRO OF MEXICO IN DEAL TO SELL ANCHOR GLASS UNIT
abstract: Vitro SA of Mexico agrees to sell its Anchor Glass Container Corp to Consumers Packaging Inc and Owens-Brockway Glass Container Inc for $392.5 million, plus assumption of debt; says bankruptcy court approved accord (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AIR 21, Fresno, Calif., a commuter airline, said it would convert its Chapter 11 bankruptcy case into Chapter 7 and liquidate and distribute its assets to creditors.

headline: Oracle Seeks Public Views On Possible Bid for Apple
abstract: Oracle Corp chairman-chief executive Larry Ellison is seeking public views on possible bid for Apple Computer Inc; Ellison has mused publicly about taking over Apple on various occasions since April 1995, and does so again in recent newspaper interview (M)

headline: GTE Dismisses Its Ad Agency; Hires Shop Linked to Nynex
abstract: GTE Corp dismisses DDB Needham Worldwide, which handled its advertising account for 33 years, and hires Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of WPP Group, which works for competitor Nynex Corp (M)

headline: Conoco Says It Wants To Invest More in Poland
abstract: Conoco, oil unit of Du Pont Co, says it is prepared to invest up to $1 billion in Poland by building more service stations and taking stakes in nation's two largest refineries (S)

headline: Growth Exceeds Forecasts As Expansion Starts 7th Year : Low U.S. Inflation Fuels Market Hopes
abstract: NEW YORK—  The American economy is entering its seventh fat year with few worries that inflation will threaten what is seen as sustainable growth of 2 percent to 3 percent a year, data released Friday showed.

headline: Delta Picks Boeing in Exclusive Deal
abstract: In the kind of deal that is likely to become more frequent as the global aircraft manufacturing industry settles around two major poles, Delta Airlines announced Thursday that it would buy its planes exclusively from Boeing Co., starting with a firm order for 106 aircraft worth $6.7 billion to be delivered by 2006.

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/   A drop in Canandaigua Wine's stock may drive some investors to drink. But the glass may be half full, not half empty. By Sana Siwolop.    MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 9/   After nearly 20 years of annual bonuses, the managers of Fidelity's Magellan fund may be disappointed this year. By Carole Gould.    SPENDING IT /Page 10/   What happens when parents fail to tell insurers about teen-age drivers? By Roy Furchgott.    SPENDING IT /Page 10/ Is Inflation dead? Maybe, but as Valentine's Day approaches, remember this: the costs of courting have risen fast over the last 10 years.

headline: FIRSTFEDERAL FINANCIAL IN DEAL FOR SUMMIT BANCORP
abstract: Firstfederal Financial Services Corp says it will acquire Summit Bancorp for $17.3 million in stock to increase its business in Ohio (S)

headline: Doing Homework on Taxes Before Lending to a Child
abstract: Potential tax problems with Internal Revenue Services stemming from complex rules involving no-interest loans by parents to their children discussed; photo (M)

headline: Nuccio Bertone, 82, Designer Of Sports Cars, Dies in Italy
abstract: Nuccio Bertone, designer of some of world's most exotic sports cars, dies in Turin, Italy, at age 82; photos (M)

headline: EUROPE POSTPONES CHALLENGE TO U.S. ON HAVANA TRADE
abstract: European officials, in last-minute bid to avoid breach with United States, ask World Trade Organization to delay for week naming panel to rule on validity of US law that imposes sanctions on non-American firms doing business with Cuba; delay follows week of frenzied and sometimes bitter talks, in which US threatened to envoke 'national security' exemption, move that threatens organization's future; European Union aide Sir Leon Brittan scores

headline: Accused Mexican Says Chaos Led Him to Ship Out Money
abstract: Mario Ruiz Massieu, who deposited $9 million in Texas bank while serving as Mexican deputy attorney general, says he assembled money in suitcases for fear that his country was sliding into chaos; testifies at trial in Houston, where Federal prosectors want to confiscate money on grounds it came from drug traffickers; says lavish bonuses are paid to senior officials, including his brother, Jose Francisco, who allegedly stored millions of dollars in duffel bags in his home (S)

headline: Prices for Crude Oil Increase; Soybeans Fall for Second Day
abstract: Crude oil prices rise on New York Mercantile Exchange on expectations that seasonal rise in US refinery demand will absorb recent increase in stockpiles; soybean prices fall for a second day (M)

headline: Racial Bias Suit Against Citibank
abstract: Brenda Curtis and Alvin Williamson, Citibank employees, file racial discrimination lawsuit against bank. contending that racist messages that were sent through company's electronic interoffice mail system had caused them emotional distress; suit, which seeks class-action status, lists 21 Citicorp employees, including 8 vice presidents and 3 assistant vice presidents, as being involved in sending or receiving the messages; Citibank says it began investigation on Feb 3 (S)

headline: Arthur Metcalf Dies at 88; Educator and Industrialist
abstract: Arthur G B Metcalf, aeronautical engineer, electronics industrialist and chairman emeritus of Boston University board of trustees, dies at age 88 (M)

headline: One Club to Honor 2 Executives
abstract: One Club for Art and Copy to induct Lee Clow and Jim Durfee into its Creative Hall of Fame (S)

headline: GATEWAY 2000 TO ADD AMIGA TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: Gateway 2000 Inc agrees to buh Amiga Technologiesm, whose Amiga computer was a PC multimedia pioneer decade ago (S)

headline: A Scorecard Doesn't Help In the Money-Fund Game
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission has been unsuccessful in trying to get money market funds to provide portfolio information electronically each quarter, rather than twice-a-year reports now required; Investment Company Institute argued that quarterly reports would be costly and burdensome; given rapid turnover in money market portfolios, nothing short of daily disclosure would provide truly accurate picture; chart (M)

headline: True North, resuming its drive to expand in Europe, agrees to acquire Wilkens International.
abstract: True North Communications, in first moves to expand in Europe since dissolution of worldwide cooperative agreement with Publicis SA, will acquire Wilkens International for undisclosed sum (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Jet Order to Bombardier
abstract: Bombardier Inc gets 12 firm orders, valued at over $240 million, and 36 options for Canadair Series 200-ER regional jets from Atlantic Coast Airlines Inc (S)

headline: Stocks Race Past New Milestone As Dow Breaks 7,000 Barrier
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average surges past 7,000 points for first time, climbing 60.81 points to close at 7,022.84 on Feb 13; it is fastest 1,000-point sprint ever on Wall Street, coming just 82 trading days after Dow had reached 6,000-point level; Dow has gained over 574 points, or 8.9 percent, since beginning of year (M)

headline: DIARY
abstract: LAWSUITS  Big Tobacco, Divided  Imagine this headline: ''Map Maker Admits That Earth Is Round.'' An odd revelation, you say? Well, it's only a small leap to Liggett's admission that smoking is addictive and causes cancer -- long accepted by most people as scientific fact. In the Great Tobacco Wars, though, a lot comes down to what you admit, and this is the first such concession by a tobacco company. Why did Liggett break ranks? Basically, it's a company in trouble -- its sales are infinitesimal compared with Philip Morris's -- and those state lawsuits could have been fatal. And by promising to pay 25 percent of its profits to 22 states, it could be promising 25 percent of nothing; Liggett is in the red already, and when it adds warning labels about addictiveness and cancer -- that's part of the deal -- it could sell even fewer cigarettes. Some tobacco foes had high hopes that documents promised by Liggett would help in the larger battle. ''We will break the back of this conspiracy of lies and deceit,'' one said. But the next battle will be over whether those documents really emerge.     UTILITY RATES  A Gift for Long Island  There's a certain odd pleasure in being at the bottom of any particular barrel, a strange pride in getting the shortest of all sticks. But Long Islanders, alas, will soon lose one complaining right: that they have the nation's highest power bills. They will, that is, if Gov. George E. Pataki's deal for a partial state takeover of Lilco becomes reality. The problem, of course, has been the billions spent on the disastrous Shoreham plant, but Mr. Pataki's solution, as Lilco heads toward a merger with Brooklyn Union Gas, is to have the state issue bonds and take over the Shoreham debt. Skeptics derided it as a political gift to consumers, but it's such a resoundingly popular idea that most politicians fell all over one another to get on board.     ANNUAL REPORTS  Puzzled? Just Click  Face it. Few people consider annual reports bedtime reading. What you get, basically, is a bunch of feel-good pictures telling you how warm and wonderful the company is (even if it has just been caught poisoning people or is on the verge of bankruptcy), followed by page upon page of numbers indecipherable to anyone lacking an advanced accounting degree. I.B.M. is out to change that, and it just posted its snazzy new on-line annual report (www.ibm.com/AnnualReport/1996). For the financially savvy, it offers all sorts of goodies you can't get in the paper copy: you can, say, click on two or more categories together, like hardware and software sales, and combine them in a single chart. But I.B.M. also says it has made the report accessible to all. You don't know what ''revenues'' means? Keep clicking, and you'll wend your way to a fourth-grader's definition. Here's another I.B.M. number out last week: Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the chairman and chief executive, made $20.2 million last year, up 30 percent from 1995. Strangely, though, all the clicking in the world won't turn that up on the Web site.    AUTO SAFETY  Car Meets Truck; Car Loses  They're everywhere. Explorers, Grand Cherokees, monster Suburbans -- all engaged in the death-defying task of moving kids and groceries. Some drivers, of course, watch all this with mounting amusement -- they'd never be caught dead in these hulking gas-guzzlers. They'd better stop laughing; when it comes to safety, no car is remotely an island. Look at it this way: your sedan weighs a ton and a half; that leather-lined, CD-equipped tank coming at you weighs two tons. Your bumper is 16 inches off the ground; the other one is 21. Who gets hurt? You do. Only a third of vehicles on the road are light trucks, but more Americans die when car meets light truck than when car meets car. In crashes involving cars and light trucks, 80 percent of those killed are in cars. What to do? Make cars heavier? Make light trucks lighter? Ban cars? Ban light trucks? No, far simpler: just create extra lanes. One for cars, one for car pools, one for light trucks -- littered, of course, with boulders and tree stumps to climb over, to make the drivers feel powerful.    AIR BAGS  One Size Saves Some  On another auto safety issue, an odd debate is raging. In hearings in Washington last week, one safety official said air bags kill children because ''the dose is too big.'' If you make them less potent and save some children, though, you lose some adults -- a grisly calculus. An added twist: the less-potent air bags might save people who are wearing seat belts but not those who aren't. So assuming that all these tradeoffs have been calculated correctly -- and assuming that another solution is not at hand -- it comes down to a choice between saving children or saving adults without the sense to buckle up. That one's easy.    CELL PHONES  Digital Privacy? Not Quite  If only Newt Gingrich had had one of those new digital cellular phones, everyone said, he'd never have gotten into trouble talking ethics in a technological fishbowl. That was one of digital's big selling points -- safety from eavesdroppers. Last week, though, some security pros said it was pretty simple to crack into digital calls after all. Never mind.    PLASTIC UNLIMITED  Have Credit, Will Spend  Did credit-card companies think Americans wouldn't use all that plastic? Fat chance. They bombarded people with card offers -- a staggering eight billion or so in three years -- and now, naturally enough, Americans are charging things like crazy. And, increasingly, not paying their bills. A recent report showed that 3.72 percent of card holders were behind on their payments late last year, up from 3.34 percent a year earlier. Last week, in fact, one fast-growing card issuer, Advanta, said it would lose money this quarter because 7.5 percent of its loans had gone bad. The solution, as many card companies see it, is to tighten lending standards, but if that crimps spending, it could hurt the economy, making credit delinquencies even more likely. The good news, though: you might not get so many credit-card solicitations in the mail.    AN ENERGY ANSWER  It's Blowing in the Wind  Are solar and wind power the stuff of fuzzy-headed visionaries? That's been the conventional wisdom. They'll always be fanciful drops in the bucket, critics say; they can never compete. Last week, though, the idea looked downright mainstream. Enron, the Houston energy giant, said it's building the world's largest wind-power project -- a huge endeavor involving 150 turbines in Iowa, each 15 stories high, with 25-ton rotors. Competitive? Absolutely. They'll provide power for 50,000 homes at an efficient 4 to 4.5 cents a kilowatt-hour. And when the multiple-choice new utility world arrives, allowing people to pick their power, some environmentally conscious types might just go for renewable sources even if does cost a bit more.

headline: USA WASTE TO BUY COMPANY THAT FILED FOR BANKRUPTCY
abstract: USA Waste Services Inc says that it has agreed to pay about $180 million for assets of Mid-American Waste Systems Inc, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: Albright Will Warm Up to Iraq if Hussein Goes
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright, speaking at Georgetown University, says US is going to continue to try to isolate Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein and is ready to move quickly to develop normal relations with successor (M)

headline: WHAT HAPPENED: Europe Downsizes
abstract: European companies faced more shareholder accountability and laid off thousands of workers in an effort to become competitive in the global marketplace. Jobs were cut at Volkswagen, Daimler-Benz, Siemens and Grundig in Germany, at Olivetti in Italy and at Credit Lyonnais in France. The biggest single wave of jobs cuts ever to hit the Netherlands occurred when Fokker, the Dutch aviation poineer, collapsed, putting 5,600 people out of work.

headline: Albanians Restless in Neighboring Land
abstract: Fear grows that unrest in Albania will spread to neighboring Macedonia; leaders of ethnic Albanians, who make up 25 percent of Macedonia's population, say they are becoming more assertive in demands for greater civil rights protection despite increased pressure on them to curb demands; Macedonian nationalists, alarmed by chaotic violence in Albania, oppose demands; map (M)

headline: Equity Issues To Be Offered During Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Apollo Biopharmaceutics Inc., Cambridge, Mass., an initial public offering of 1.2 million units, consisting of one common share and one redeemable warrant. First United Equities Corp.

headline: Islamic Group Condemns Hebron Accord
abstract: Militant Islamic organization Hamas condemns Israeli-Palestinian agreement on Hebron; map (M)

headline: Rising Optimism for French Consumers
abstract: Unedic, the French agency that pays unemployment benefits, says economy will add 170,000 private-sector jobs in 1997, a 1.2 percent rise, mostly in service industry; another report shows consumers' morale rose in February; confidence index was up for third straight month, as households said their standards of living and expectations for future employment improved (S)

headline: Despite a Sluggish Beginning, Dreamworks Is Viewed as a Potential Hollywood Power
abstract: Dreamworks SKG, entertainment company that debuted 26 months ago with much fanfare, is still waiting to make its first big splash; studio will not release its first live-action feature film until next fall; it has three television series on air, but only one has strong chance of generating enough episodes to produce profits from rerun sales; Dreamworks' first major record has had lackluster reception; but analysts and investors are confident that Dreamworks' team has respectable chance of pulling it off; company has strong capital base and experienced management; three founding partners, Jeffrey Katzenberg, Steven Spielberg and David Geffen, have had incredibly successful track records; diagrams. photos (L)

headline: Switzerland and Banks Agree to a Fund for Holocaust Victims
abstract: Swiss Government and leading banks and businesses agree to establish memorial fund for Holocaust victims after months of pressure from American Jewish groups (M)

headline: At Lunch With the Saudis, F.B.I. Director Complains
abstract: US State Sec Madeleine K Albright holds private lunch in honor of Prince Sultan, Saudi Arabian Defense Minister; Saudi delegation renews pledges of cooperation with United States in investigation of truck bombing that killed 19 US airmen last June; at luncheon, FBI Dir Louis Freeh expresses frustration that Saudis are not doing more to help (M)

headline: Technology Issues Hardest Hit as Stocks Fall
abstract: Stock prices declined on New York Stock Exchange on March 19; Dow Jones industrial average lost 18.88 points, closing at 6,877.68; Nasdaq Composite Index, heavily weighted with technology stocks, lost 20.05 points, to close at 1,249.29 (M)

headline: The Marketing of an Ancient Capital's Mysteries
abstract: Tourism officials in Zimbabwe hope to attract attention to Great Zimbabwe, huge stone structure built in 12th century that gave its name to nation formerly known as Rhodesia; Great Zimbabwe is thought to have housed 20,000 inhabitants and been capital of far-flung network of 150 villages built by people who traded gold and ivory and took slaves out of interior of Africa and exported them to Arab-run ports; walls are 35 feet tall and 15 feet thick, and held together with nothing but their own weight; mystery is that when European explorers reached area it was a deserted ruin, and there was no civilization around that built with stone; photo; map (M)

headline: U.S. Balloonist Over Africa; Sets Long-Distance Record
abstract: Steve Fossett, hoping to circle world non-stop in his balloon, is forced to divert to south to avoid Libyan airspace after being denied permission to fly over that country; Col Muammar el-Qaddafi later grants him permission, but 12-hour diversion may have cost Fossett enough propane to thwart his goal; map (M)

headline: News Corporation Said to Pursue Pointcast
abstract: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, still groping for on-line strategy, is negotiating to buy Pointcast Inc, Internet information distributor, but two sides reportedly remain far apart on price; has reportedly offered Pointcast approximately $400 million, but executives of Pointcast are reportedly demanding far more (M)

headline: Rival Suitors May Split Up Conrail Parts
abstract: Conrail is close to $10.3 billion agreement with CSX Corp and Norfolk Southern Corp that would split Conrail's railroad network between the two carriers, bringing to an end four-month battle for control of rail freight in the East; under tentative plan, CSX--possibly with Norfolk Southern--would buy Conrail for about $115 a share in cash and then sell about half of Conrail's rail lines to rival Norfolk Southern, giving both companies roughly equal freight routes throughout the Northeast and providing them each with access to New York; Norfolk Southern would pay CSX about $4.2 billion; CSX, in turn, would be required to sweeten its existing offer for Conrail by almost $1 billion, thereby matching Norfolk Southern's $10.3 billion hostile offer for Conrail and allowing both companies to claim victory (L)

headline: Mrs. Lenin's Palace Survives to Serve the Fittest
abstract: Moscow's Palace of Young Pioneers, world's largest recreational complex conceived by Lenin's wife and built by Bolsheviks, is transformed into high-tech and trendy health club, catering expressly to rich; facility, renamed Gold's Gymn, charges $2,000 annual membership fee, has 500 members and flies in coffee beans each week from Seattle to serve espresso and latte in its snack area; photo (M)

headline: MOTOROLA COMPUTER BUSINESS SPLITS INTO TWO DIVISIONS
abstract: Computer unit of Motorola Inc says it reorganized into two divisions; one will sell Macintosh clones, portables and servers, while other will sell components to other manufacturers (S)

headline: Utility Deal Aims to Cut Cost of Power
abstract: AES Corporation, developer and operator of power plants, says GPU Inc, which owns utilities in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, has agreed to buy electricity from AES in unusual arrangement; under plan, AES will build 720-megawatt gas-fired power plant in southeastern Pennsylvania at cost of approximately $300 million, which would be one of largest independent power plants built in nation (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table shows key interest rates

headline: On Divided Isle of Cyprus, Missile Deal Widens Rift
abstract: Hopes for breakthrough in crisis in Cyprus have faded since Greek Cypriot Government announced plans to buy antiaircraft missiles and Turkey, protector of Turkish part of island, threatened to react militarily if missiles were deployed; some political analysts suspect that Greek Cypriot Government sought to stoke tensions, indicating its increasing impatience with efforts to resolve standoff that has existed since 1974; map (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Pepsico's Profit Falls, Causing Drop in Stock  Pepsico's earnings fell 85 percent in the fourth quarter, hurt by unexpectedly large losses in the company's international beverage business and by sluggish profits at two of its three fast-food chains.    The company's stock, which had risen after the announcement of Pepsico's plan to spin off the fast-food businesses, fell on the news of the lower earnings. $(Page D2.$)    Apple Makes Small Changes at Top  Apple Computer shifted its top management, but company officials conceded that they were still not ready to say whether they would lay off more workers or sell units. $(D8.$)

headline: Yeltsin Hospitalization News Sends Crude Oil to 6-Year High
abstract: Crude oil jumps to six-year high on fears of short supplies and news that President Boris N Yeltsin of Russia has been taken to hospital with signs of pneumonia; February crude oil rises 39 cents, to $26.62 a barrel on Nymex; activity in other futures markets also noted (M)

headline: Dow Gains On Favorable Price Report
abstract: Stock prices rebound after disastrous performance on Thursday, helped by economic data that show few signs of inflationary pressure; Dow Jones industrial average rises 56.57 to close at 6,935.46; table shows favorite stocks (M)

headline: Copyright Pacts Are Still Facing Foes in Congress
abstract: Battle is looming in Congress over two international copyright treaties governing digital copying and transmission of art and information over computer networks; Clinton Administration won international approval of the two treaties in Geneva in December, 1996, buts concedes that Congressional approval is far from assured (M)

headline: Dow Surges 84.66 Points, Reversing Five-Day Slide
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 84.66 points, to 6,740.74; table (M)s

headline: Sellers in Search of Buyers in a Global Marketplace
abstract: Just try to find a news release or an earnings report from a major United States consumer-products company that does not cite international growth as the panacea for future profits.

headline: To the Battlements at Fortress Fidelity
abstract: Profile of Fidelity Investments as it seeks to recover from one its most disappointing years in its half-century of existence; for first time in years, Fidelity's share of all mutual funds sank from 13.6 percent in late 1995 to 13.4 percent at end of last year, according to Dalbar Inc, research firm; while some of decline is attributed to Americans' growing in index funds, Fidelity executives plan several steps they hope will shake company's business from yearlong stupor, including adding index funds to handful that it now runs, cut fees on bond funds to make them more competitive, and market stongly its Funds Network supermarket; strategy is seen more remarkable for what it lacks; for example, management seems to have little desire for scaling back its effort to dominate evey nook and cranny of investment business; photos (L)

headline: Facing Unrest, Bulgaria Party Makes Offer
abstract: Bulgaria's ruling Socialist Party, in apparent attempt to remain in power, says it is ready to enter into 'wide dialogue' with opposition, which has been holding mass demonstrations daily; opposition leader Ivan Kostov says he is unwilling to trust proposals from Socialists, whom he accuses of ordering police to beat demonstrators; is demanding early elections (M)

headline: Magazine Ad Pages Declined in 1996
abstract: Publishers Information Bureau in New York reports that magazine advertising pages declined slightly in 1996, despite strong finish for December; says ad pages for 1996 totaled 213,781, compared with 214,030 in 1995 (S)

headline: NORTHERN TELECOM SELLS 25% OF INTERNET COMPANY
abstract: Northern Telecom Ltd says it sold 25 percent of its newly formed Internet security company, Entrust Technologies Inc, to group of institutional investors for $26 million (S)

headline: Cellular One is taking the phone out of the briefcase and putting it in the backpack.
abstract: Cellular One launches new $6 million television advertising campaign that humourously suggests unusual uses for cellular phones; drive reflects increasing competition expected in wake of law making it easier for new carriers to enter market (M)

headline: Dollar Soars vs. Yen as Tokyo Hints Central Bank Won't Act
abstract: Dollar reaches its highest point against yen in almost four years as Tokyo stock market tumbles and expectations grow that Bank of Japan will not move to prop up yen; dollar also jumps to two-and-a-half-year highs against German mark and Swiss franc (M)

headline: Omnicom again expands its health care advertising by buying Cline, Davis & Mann.
abstract: Omnicom Group is acquiring Cline, Davis & Mann, a New York advertising agency with nearly 170 employees and billings estimated at $170 million from pharmaceutical marketers like Pfizer Inc and Parke-Davis division of Warner-Lambert Co; terms undisclosed; deal marks third time in four years that Omnicom has bought large New York agency devoted to drug and health care advertising (L)

headline: ISRAELIS DEMAND PALESTINIANS ACT TO HALT VIOLENCE
abstract: Israeli Government demands that Palestinian Authority take measures against further acts of terrorism, but stops short of threatening to halt peace negotiations; statement is accompanied by blitz of public declarations from Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and security chiefs, who charge Palestinian leaders with giving indirect support for terror attacks and to street violence; Palestinian officials angrily reject accusations; violence continues in Hebron, where Palestinian youths pelt Israelis with stones; Palestinian policemen succeed in restraining protestors; Israeli security forces maintain high alert against possibility of another terrorist strike by Palestinian militants, following March 21 suicide bombing of Tel Aviv cafe, in which three women were killed (M)

headline: BANPONCE TO ACQUIRE ANOTHER PUERTO RICAN BANK
abstract: BanPonce Corp agrees to acquire closely held Roig Commercial Bank for $120 million in cash and stock, bringing together two of Puerto Rico's two largest banks (S)

headline: How Business Can Preserve The Ideals of Affirmative Action
abstract: Comment by Howard P Greenwald on how business can preserve the ideals of affirmative action in light of California Civil Rights Initiative, referendum known as Proposition 209; says California measure may signal beginning of the end of government affirmative action mandates, but it can also help start new culture of affirmative action in the private sector (L)

headline: Rug Pulled From Stocks In Last Hour
abstract: Stock market drops sharply in sudden late-afternoon selloff, on busiest day of trading in history of New York Stock Exchange; Dow Jones industrial average plummets 94.28 points in last hour of trading, to close at 6,755.75; record volume is 685.1 million shares traded; analysts cite selling on futures market or slump in bond market as possible reasons, but they are not sure for sudden turn; some say market needed timeout after rising nearly 7 percent this month (M)

headline: 2 CNA Executives Quit in Sex Harassment Case
abstract: CNA Life Insurance Co announced on March 4 resignations of Jack Kettler, president of CNA Life, and Robert Teske, his deputy, who is chief administrative officer, saying Kettler made 'offensive comments' toward two female employees, which it did not describe, and that Teske failed to act (L)

headline: Shell, Texaco to Merge Some U.S. Refining
abstract: Shell Oil Co and Texaco Inc will merge refining and marketing operations in Midwest and West, forming new company that would control nearly 15 percent of nation's gasoline sales; Shell would own 56 percent of limited liability company and Texaco 44 percent; companies report progress in talks to combine refining and marketing operations in East with those of Saudi Refining Inc (S)

headline: 2 Radio Deals For $1.6 Billion To Create Giant
abstract: Hicks Muse Tate & Furst Inc, leveraged buyout firm, and Evergreen Media Corp agree to form Chancellor Media Corp, nation's largest independent radio broadcaster in $593 million swap of Evergreen stock; combined company will then buy 10 stations owned by Viacom Inc for $1.075 billion, assuming $900 million in debt and borrowing entire price of Viacom purchase; will initially include 103 stations with presence in nation's top 12 markets, including four stations in New York City; merger reflects ongoing consolidation in radio industry, resulting from decision by Congress to raise limits on how many stations one company can own; map (M)

headline: Georgia Senate Intervenes To Stop a Hostile Takeover
abstract: Healthdyne Technologies, which is fighting hostile takeover offer from Invacare, gains possible ally when Georgia Senate votes to require that Georgia-incorporated companies have staggered boards of directors; measure, if enacted into law, would appear to protect Marietta-based Healthdyne from prospect of losing proxy fight at this year's annual meeting (S)

headline: Sales to SFX Broadcasting
abstract: SFX Broadcasting Inc agrees to buy radio station WRFX-FM in Charlotte, NC, from EZ Communications Inc for $20 million and radio station WDSY-FM in Pittsburgh; SDX Broadcasting says it is buying WDSY-FM from Secret Communications; acquisition also includes John Boy and Billy Syndication Network, whose morning show is heard on 37 radio stations (S)

headline: HUIZENGA'S COMPANY ADDS 3 CAR DEALERSHIPS IN FLORIDA
abstract: Republic Industries says that it has acquired Carlisle Motors for $35 million (S)

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS : Architecture Students Live Close to Nature
abstract: Frank Lloyd Wright believed powerfully in the importance of a well-rounded education, rooted in experience; he also believed in living close to nature. Thus it is that the desert foothills near Scottsdale, Arizona, are dotted with more than 60 odd shelters, built over the years by students at the Frank Lloyd Wright School of Architecture, who sometimes live for more than a year in shelters they design or adapt, some with just enough room for a bed, a radio and a few candles.

headline: I.R.A. Leader Denies Talk of Killing Rival
abstract: Gerry Adams, political leader of Irish Republican Army, denies reports in British newspapers that former IRA guerrilla Sean O'Callaghan accused him of discussing murdering John Hume, most prominent mainstream Roman Catholic leader in Northern Ireland; dismisses reports as 'rubbish;' photo (M)

headline: Spanish Judge Shot to Death; Police Blame Basque Rebels
abstract: Spanish Supreme Court judge, Rafael Martinez Emperador, is shot to death outside residence in Madrid; police blame Basque separatists (S)

headline: Ecuador Chief, the Populist, Is Anything but Popular
abstract: Pres Abdala Bucaram's economic program for Ecuador costs him support of the poor who elected him six months ago but also fails to impress country's opinion makers and business leaders; plan would eliminate guarantees of job security, promote privatization, restructure foreign debt and restrict public sector borrowing from Central Bank, and its capstone would be manadatory currency conversion; proposals for helping poor with subsidized milk and bread, lower-cost generic drugs and low-income housing are met with skepticism; critics assail proposals for extending presidential term from four years to five and allowing a President to seek re-election; photo of Bucaram singing (M)

headline: COLONY CAPITAL TO INVEST IN TRUMP'S CASTLE CASINO
abstract: Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts Inc says it will establish joint venture with Colony Capital, real estate investment firm, which will invest $125 million in Trump's Castle Casino Resort in Atlantic City; Colony Capital will hold 51 percent stake and Trump Hotels will retain 49 percent interest and continue to manage the property; venture will more than double number of rooms at Trump's Castle, which will be renamed Trump Marina (S)

headline: Judge Defers Ruling on Texaco Settlement
abstract: Federal Judge Charles L Brieant tells dozens of black Texaco workers he will rule on fairness of $176 million racial bias settlement, under which 1,348 black employees will receive average of $64,000 each to settle class-action suit against company (S)

headline: Another Mexican General Is Arrested and Charged With Links to Drug Cartel
abstract: Mexican Army Brig Gen Alfredo Navarro Lara is arrested and charged with offering multimillion-dollar bribe to top Mexican law enforcement official on behalf of notorious cocaine cartel; is second high-ranking military officer to be jailed on drug-related charges in month; arrest is new proof that traffickers have succeeded in corrupting highest levels of Mexican armed forces (M)

headline: Renault Plans to Close Belgian Plant in July
abstract: Renault SA says it will close its Belgian car-making operations on July 31 and report 'very significant loss' for 1996, its first in 10 years (S)

headline: Despite a Slow Final Month, Year's Auto Sales Were Up
abstract: American auto industry ends year with 4 percent drop in sales; even with December slowdown, auto makers sold 15.1 million cars, mini-vans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles in 1996, up from 1995 sales of 14.8 million vehicles; economists expect sales in 1997 to continue their steady, relatively strong pace for fourth year in row; charts (M)

headline: British Tycoon Woos Right, Waving Stop Sign at Europe
abstract: Sir James Goldsmith, 63-year-old binational billionaire, makes typically combative return to British political scene with campaign to halt Britain's integration into European Union; creates Referendum Party and pledges $30 million and more to elect candidates opposed to union, in belief that countries on continent restrict kind of unfettered business practices championed by Margaret Thatcher; party recruits, from socialites and old school chums to Battle of Britain pilots and disgruntled Tories, raise concern in Conservative Party, because even modest showing could tip election to Labor; Goldsmith's aggressive, strong-willed career building huge fortune in Britain and France recounted, along with tumultuous marital history in both countries (M)

headline: British Leave Hong Kong In Sour Kind of Grandeur
abstract: British face resentful and suspicious Chinese successors when Hong Kong returns to Chinese control on July 1; prosperous community that emerged under British rule is arguably most successful colony ever, but that legacy has been undermined by disillusionment over impasse between China and Britain in recent years; British must swallow humiliation of knowing that Chinese will crush London's last-minute attempts at fostering civil liberties; growing impotence of Britain in Hong Kong has been pointed up by China's defiant decision to scrap British-sponsored constitutional reforms and by rebukes from leadership in Beijing to British claims of right to 'monitor' Hong Kong agreement after transfer of sovereignty; maps; graphs (M)

headline: French Medical Group Asks Doctors With H.I.V. to Halt Surgery
abstract: Organization overseeing French medical profession will ask surgeons and other physicians who are infected with AIDS virus to stop performing operations; decision follows recent announcement by Health Ministry that French surgeon with AIDS had accidentally infected patient (M)

headline: With its canned soup turning 100, Campbell has begun a campaign for soups sold in glass jars.
abstract: Campbell Soup Co is commemmorating 100th anniversary of its soup in cans by blitzing marketplace with advertisements about new ready-to-serve soup sold in glass jars (Advertising) (M)

headline: Company to Buy Europe Property
abstract: TrizecHahn Corp agrees to buy commercial real estate in Britain and Germany from Advanta Management AG for about $147 million in stock and assumed debt; as part of transaction, TrizecHahn names Dieter Bock, who controls Advanta, president of its new European business and vice chairman and director (S)

headline: Slump in Tech Stocks: Vigorous Correction or Bad Case of Nerves?
abstract: Technology stocks continue protracted slump, even as Dow Jones industrial average and Standard & Poor's 500 continue to reach new highs; little consensus exists among analysts over whether decline represents healthy correction or bad case of nerves; with stocks trailing other indexes for 1996 and first three months of 1997, perhaps only remaining question about bear market is its duration; graphs (M)

headline: FIREMAN'S FUND TO BUY CROP GROWERS FOR $81.6 MILLION
abstract: Fireman's Fund Insurance Co agrees to buy Crop Growers Corp, crop insurer in Overland Park, Kan, for $81.6 million in cash; acquisition will allow Fireman's Fund to expand in the business of selling Federal insurance against crop damage to weather-related perils (S)û

headline: Doubts on Monetary Union Buoy Mark Against the Dollar
abstract: US dollar falls against German mark as fresh doubts that European monetary union will start on time buoys German currency (M)

headline: Coffee Prices Close Higher As Colombia Trims Forecast
abstract: Coffee prices surge after Colombian growers lower their forecast for this year's crop by 5.5 percent; Colombia is second-largest coffee producer after Brazil (M)

headline: Two Deals Extend the Financial Frontiers of Gene Therapy
abstract: Continuing the consolidation of nascent gene-therapy industry, Novartis AG, Switzerland, to buy 26.8 percent it does not already own of Systemix Inc for $75.8 million; Cell Genesys Inc says it will acquire Somatix Therapy Corp in stock swap valued at about $80 million; although gene therapies have yet to produce any products or profit, and may not for decade, potential power of the technology makes it strategic asset for any major pharmaceutical company (M)

headline: Nissan Plans to Add Production in Britain
abstract: Nissan Motor Co will build new midsized car at its Sunderland plant in England (S)

headline: Drugs Connect Mexico Leaders To Abductions
abstract: Evidence is emerging to tie many of abductions in Mexico that seemed to involve Government security forces to military-led drive against powerful drug traffickers; majority of victims have no proven links to drug traffickers or other criminal activities; number of families of missing Mexicans have come forward since arrest of Gen Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo, former anti-drug agency head, on charges of collaborating with cocaine baron; map; table; photos (M)

headline: In Helsinki, U.S. Wants Yeltsin Nod On NATO
abstract: American officials hope Pres Clinton's meeting with Pres Boris N Yeltsin, Helsinki, Finland, following month of intensive bargaining and diplomatic courtship, will lead to grudging Russian tolerance of plan to expand NATO eastward; cite campaign of military reassurances and economic inducements; do not expect Yeltsin to make any final decision on NATO at meeting (M)

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS
abstract: Joel Berger, a conservation biologist at the University of Nevada at Reno, had no idea his research into moose habits would get quite this, well, hairy.

headline: CBS to Buy One-Third Stake in Sportsline
abstract: CBS plans to invest $100 million to acquire one-third stake in Sportsline USA Inc, a leading on-line sports service; move comes as Walt Disney Co is negotiating to buy a stake in Starwave Corp, which runs other leading sports site on World Wide Web, ESPNet Sportszone; that site is joint venture with Disney's ESPN cable television sports channel (M)

headline: Drug Therapy At Diet Centers Raises Fears
abstract: More than half-dozen national and regional weight-loss chains, including Jenny Craig Inc, are enlisting doctors to dispense pills through 'medically supervised' programs they are promoting along with their traditional fare of prepackaged entrees and weekly weigh-ins; switch to dispensing drugs is generating so much new business that revenues for $1.9 billion industry are expected to grow 5.5 percent this year after several years of stagnation or decline; industry's new role as drug dispenser is raising alarms; critics fear doctors at some centers will be pressured to prescribe pills to people who simply want to drop a few pounds; they also wonder whether physicians, most working at diet centers part time, will be familiar enough with customers' medical histories to turn away those who should not take drugs; companies brush off the criticism; tables; charts; photos (L)

headline: The Bad Boys Start Watching Their Pockets
abstract: Members of rock band Kiss talk about mistakes they made managing their money in early days of their celebrity, in 1970's, and their determination to do better this time; photos (L)

headline: DELTA AIR LINES TO REALIGN ITS ROUTES
abstract: Delta Air Lines Inc says it will increase its New York City service by one-third and cut back on its European service, resulting in a $60 million pretax charge in the current quarter; says it expects to save $62 million a year as result of revamped service; will cut between 600 and 800 jobs (S)

headline: BRE PROPERTIES ACQUIRES 400-APARTMENT COMPLEX
abstract: BRE Properties Inc, real estate investment trust based in San Francisco, acquires Promontory Point Apartments, 400-unit garden apartment complex in San Ramon, Calif, for $43.7 million (S)

headline: Morton Edell, 88, Cosmetics Executive
abstract: Morton Edell, executive in cosmetics and vitamin industries, dies at age 88 (S)

headline: Rights Group Suspects Yugoslav Army May Have Chemical Arms
abstract: Human Rights Watch Arms Project warns that Serb-dominated Yugoslav army may still possess huge stores of chemical weapons; quotes 1993 report in which Croatian general said that tons of chemicals needed for making nerve gas were moved into Serbia after breakup of Yugoslavia in 1991 (S)

headline: AT&T and Ameritech Agree to Drop Lawsuits
abstract: Ameritech Corp and AT&T Corp agree to settle three legal disputes and instead battle each other in the marketplace; terms of agreement are not disclosed; one settlement involves lawsuit Ameritech filed in December against AT&T, after a company official made statements to a meeting of analysts that Ameritech said were defamatory; Ameritech also sued AT&T in May, contending that company was using proprietary information about Ameritech's credit calling card customers for marketing purposes, which Ameritech said violated agreement between two companies; AT&T filed counterclaim; third settlement concerns complaint AT&T made against Ameritech with Michigan Public Service Commission; AT&T contended that company had lengthened time between intervals that it allowed access to its system; two companies agree to set access standards (M)

headline: Dissenters on NATO Growth Becoming Vocal
abstract: With opposition to NATO enlargement mounting among a vocal minority in the U.S. foreign-policy establishment, the issue has emerged as the most immediate diplomatic challenge for the second Clinton administration. Some critics want President Bill Clinton, freed of the necessity of facing the electorate again, to abandon the NATO initiative or at least fold it into a wider, slower program for European stability.

headline: Sea Change Down Under: Drifting to the Orient?
abstract: Wave of Asian immigration is causing wave of racism in Australia; although Asians make up less than 5 percent of Australia's population of 18 million, they account for 40 percent of its current immigrants; social researcher Hugh MacKay says Australians have been plunged into period of unprecedented social, cultural and economic change; photo (M)

headline: De Beers Ending Agreement To Sell Russian Diamonds
abstract: De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd says it will end marketing agreement with Russia, world's largest diamond producer, because Russian Government has not ratified new agreement; De Beers blames politics and bureaucracy for the delayed ratification; analysts say lapse in agreement could take months, if ever, to affect diamond prices, because Russian producers have been selling diamonds outside the agreement for three years; De Beers has complained for months that Russian producers were flouting agreement and causing 'substantial leakage' that could destabilize diamond prices; price stability is crucial to De Bers, which sells about 75 percent of world's diamond production (M)

headline: A Lion of B Movies To Sell Company To an Independent
abstract: Roger Corman, prolific B movie producer, agrees to sell Concord New Horizons Corp to Elliott Kastner; will retain Concord name, with new entity to be called New Horizons; plans to release 12 films now in production through New Horizons (S)

headline: Greenspan Is Upbeat On Economy
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan gives upbeat assessment of economy in testimony before Senate Budget Committee; says after nearly six years of uninterrupted growth it has retained considerable vigor, with few signs of imbalances and inflationary tensions that have disrupted past expansions; warns, however, that long period in which relatively small wage increases helped hold down inflation may running its course; high-points of wide-ranging testimony discussed; comments spark rally in financial markets, sending Dow Jones Industrial Average up 40.03 points, to record 6,883.90; photo (M)

headline: Newmont Wins Santa Fe, With Further Gold Deals Expected
abstract: Newmont Mining Corp announces agreement to acquire Santa Fe Pacific Gold Corp for $2.43 billion in stock, securing position as the top gold-mining company in North America; Newmont outbids rival Homestake Mining Co; analysts expect more mergers in rapidly consolidating industry (L)

headline: Recovering Overpaid Tax Overseas
