abstract: American investors in overseas stocks are overpaying foreign governments much more than necessary in income taxes than investors actually owe; overseas tax rates are often much higher than tax rates set out in treaties that govern foreign investors; while treaties allow person to recover significant portion of taxes withheld, process can takes years; some suggestions to investors on dealing with problem; chart on money withheld in some foreign countries (M)

headline: Young & Rubicam Dissolves Waring Unit
abstract: Young & Rubicam Inc will dissolve Waring & LaRosa, New York advertising agency purchased in May that had operated as stand-alone unit (S)

headline: Darcy Ribeiro, 74, Expert On Brazilian Indian Culture
abstract: Darcy Ribeiro, anthropologist who was expert on Brazilian Indian culture, dies at age 74; photo (M)

headline: Treasury Prices End Mixed After Strong Building Data
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities finish mixed, as strong-than-expected construction report leads to concerns about Federal Reserve tightening; 30-year bond rises 1/32, to price of 97 1/32, to yield 6.73 percent, unchanged from Jan 2 (M)

headline: Peru Guerrillas And Hostages Face the Press
abstract: Marxist rebels allow cameramen and photographers to enter Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima, Peru, where they film and interview rebels and some of remaining hostages; guerrillas of Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement then free Honduran Ambassador, Jose Eduardo Martell, and Argentine Consul Gen, Juan Antonio Ibanez; releases leave 81 hostages in residence; photos (M)

headline: Nokia Reports 76% Profit Surge in Quarter
abstract: Nokia says pretax profit climbed 76 percent in fourth quarter of 1996; pretax profit rose to 1.67 billion markkaa, or $341 million; operating profit increased to 1.74 billion markkaa from 1.02 billion, and sales grew 16 percent, to 12.67 billion markkaa from 10.96 billion; pretax profit for all of 1996 fell 21 percent, to nearly 3.9 billion markkaa from 4.93 billion; full-year sales increased about 7 percent, to 39.32 billion markkaa from 36.81 billion (M)

headline: A Hint on Rates By Fed Official
abstract: Laurence Meyer, Federal Reserve governor, suggests that economy is growing slowly enough to keep Federal Reserve from raising Federal funds rate on overnight bank loans anytime soon (S)

headline: Zaire's Entire Political Class Is Target of the Rebel Army
abstract: Zaire's Government is being humiliated in war against rebel forces, and it has been months since Parliament has produced any laws; combination of corruption, back-room maneuvering and inexperience with democracy have made country's bloated assembly, like most of its institutions, almost completely irrelevant to life of nation in collapse; most people see Zaire's armed rebellion, led by Laurent Kabila, as attack on decrepit power of cancer-stricken Pres Mobutu Sese Seko, but it is no less assault on entire political class; in seven years of sporadic effort, political insiders and opposition alike have shown themselves incapable of fashioning workable future for Zaire; with failure of politics, many have warmed to idea of transformation by gun; map; photo (M)

headline: Coffee Prices Jump as Strike In Colombia May Cut Exports
abstract: Coffee futures prices jump on New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange on Febraury 11 as strike in Colombia threatens to delay exports from world's second-largest grower (S)

headline: Bondholders Planning to Control Marvel by Electing New Board
abstract: Marvel Entertainment Group bondholders led by Carl C Icahn say they will elect new board to take control of company; move reflects failure of negotiations between bondholders and banks that lent money to Marvel when it was controlled by Ronald O Perelman (S)

headline: Turkey Finds European Union Door Slow to Open
abstract: Turkey, secular Islamic country which straddles East and West and has adopted mostly Western-syle values, is suffering from worsening identity crisis as it remains refubbed by European Union in attempts to attain membership; accuses Europeans of being prejudiced against Muslims; is angered by fact that many countries of former Eastern bloc, which have never had relationship with European political or economic values, are being considered for membership; European ambivalence toward Turkey dates back hundreds of years to era when 'Turk' was European architype; maps; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Beer Shipments Show Surprise Gain
abstract: M Shanken Communications, which collects information about alcoholic-beverage industry, reports that American beer market grew unexpectedly last year for first time since 1990; estimates that beer shipments in 1996 rose eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 187.1 million barrels (S)

headline: Reader's Digest breaks with a four-decade tradition by selling space on its back cover.
abstract: Reader's Digest is selling advertising space on its back cover for first time ever; shift is indicative of Digest effort to update sales strategy and shake off image as fusty, musty marketer (M)

headline: Axa Sells Stake In the Reinsurer Scor
abstract: Axa, world's second-largest insurer, says it sold its minority stake in reinsurer Scor as part of string of share sales totaling 2.16 billion French francs ($390 million); sells all of its 7% stake in Scor to Goldman, Sachs, J P Morgan and Fox Pitt, Kelton for 780 million francs (S)

headline: Frankel and Visa Win a Super Reggie
abstract: Promotion marketing campaign for Visa USA division of Visa International takes top honors at 14th annual Reggie Awards competition sponsored by Promotion Marketing Association of America (S)

headline: Kmart's Cost-Cutting Moves Reduced 4th-Quarter Loss
abstract: Kmart Corp, citing cost-cutting efforts to offset decline in sales, says that its net loss for fourth quarter narrowed and that results from its continuing operations swung into the black; Kmart had earnings from continuing retail operations of $235 million in quarter, which ended Jan 29; a year earlier, it had earnings from retail operations of $32 million; charges of $150 million related to accounting change left Kmart with loss on its continuing operations in quarter a year earlier of $118 million; posts net loss of $164 million, down from net loss of $420 million in fourth quarter a year earlier; sales fell 2.2 percent, to $9.68 billion from $9.9 billion; table (L)

headline: Bozell Worldwide Acquires Kamstra
abstract: Bozell Worldwide acquires Kamstra Communications; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: CD-ROM Stars to Play in Other Media
abstract: CD-ROM characters trademarked by Humongous Entertainment will be licensed to Lancit Media Entertainment Ltd for use in television, video and motion pictures (S)

headline: Bombings in Lagos Jolt Nigeria's Relations With U.S.
abstract: Nigeria's relations with US deteriorate sharply in wake of series of unexplained bomb attacks in Lagos that have been aimed at military personnel and property; Government blames country's largest opposition group, National Democratic Coalition, or Nadeco, many of whose members live in US; Nadeco, whose leadership is largely under arrest, denies any connection with bombings (M)

headline: The Crimson Crop Is Plenty Green
abstract: Harvard M.B.A.'s, presumably well trained to go out and manage things, instead are increasingly inclined to get jobs where they tell other people how to manage things. And manufacturing is continuing to decline as a source of employment for new M.B.A.'s.

headline: Yeltsin Tells Russians That Bending on the NATO Issue Paid Off
abstract: Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin, answering critics who accuse him of capitulating to West on NATO expansion, defends his conciliatory stance at his summit meeting in Helsinki with Pres Clinton (M)

headline: Gruntal Executives to Lead Leveraged Buyout of Firm
abstract: Restless to pursue growth more aggressively, Robert P. Rittereiser, the chairman of Gruntal & Company, said yesterday that he was leading a group of senior managers in a leveraged buyout of the firm worth $235 million.    Mr. Rittereiser said in an interview that the parent company, the Home Insurance Company, had approved of the deal. It will be issued $225 million in preferred stock with another $10 million being issued to a group of eight senior manangers at Gruntal, including Mr. Rittereiser, who are participating in the deal.

headline: DEAL FOR CARTER-CROWLEY ASSETS WORTH $383 MILLION
abstract: Crescent Real Estate Equities Inc to pay $383 million for Carter-Crowley Properties Inc assets, including 12 percent stake in Dallas Mavericks basketball team (S)

headline: QUICK & REILLY TO ACQUIRE JERSEY CITY SECURITIES DEALER
abstract: Quick & Reilly Group Inc agrees to acquire Nash Weiss & Co for undisclosed sum (S)

headline: Religious Right Assails China Trade Status
abstract: Several leaders of religious right say that they will oppose extending most-favored-nation trade status to China because of human-rights abuses; Gary Bauer, president of Family Research Council, asserts that human rights abuses in China have reached point where Congress should reconsider renewing China's special trading status (S)

headline: Leaders Meet But Can't Lift Hebron Crisis
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat meet covertly in Gaza with US Middle East envoy Dennis Ross, but fail to reach agreement on withdrawal of Israeli forces from Hebron; Israeli and Palestinian officials say remaining disputes are less over Hebron than over blueprint for subsequent Israeli troop pullbacks from West Bank outlined under existing Israeli-Palestinian agreements; Netanyahu voices disappointment that meeting was leaked to public; says such meetings are necessary to build trust and working relations (M)

headline: Intel to Purchase Stake in Xircom
abstract: Intel Corp agrees to buy 12.5 percent equity stake in Xircom Corp for about $52 million in cash, and companies will cooperate on developing new PC Card-based network connectors (S)

headline: AULT FOODS IS SELLING SOME ASSETS TO AGROPUR
abstract: Ault Foods Ltd, based in Toronto, agrees to sell milk and cultured products assets to Agropur cooperative for about $145 million (US) (S)

headline: Real Estate Investor Convicted of Insider Trading
abstract: Real estate investor Thomas Warde has been convicted of illegal insider trading and could face a fine of up to $2.85 million for his role in 1987 incident that involved Milton Weinger, former top broker with Oppenheimer & Co; SEC says jury reached decision on civil action against Warde after four-day trial that ended on Jan 27; SEC accused Warde of making $950,000 in illicit profit after trading Kidde Inc warrants on several occasions in June and July 1987 before two significant announcements that led Kidde being acquired by Hanson Trust PLC; Weinger is sentenced to 10 months in prison and ordered to pay $6,650 fine and forfeit $316,497 in trading profits for his role in the transaction (M)

headline: A Rock and a Hard Place in Hebron
abstract: Palestinian police are facing wrath of own people in efforts to restrain roaring, surging crowd of Palestinians youths hurling stones at Israeli soldiers guarding homes of Jewish settlers in Hebron; clashes, set off by start of work on new Jewish neighborhood in East Jerusalem, have severely tested delicate security cooperation between Palestinian and Israeli forces in Hebron and throughout West Bank; maps; photo (M)

headline: A Top Canadian Visits Cuba, Nettling Washington
abstract: Canadian Foreign Min Lloyd Axworthy briefly visits Cuba to sign human rights and foreign investment declarations and meets with Pres Fidel Castro and other aides; United States scores visit, questioning Cuba's readiness to move to democratic rule; Axworthy comments, interview; photo (M)

headline: Another Day of Haggling Delays Mideast Accord
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian negotiators work with American mediators on drafts of accord governing withdrawal of Israeli forces from Hebron and West Bank, delaying again agonizingly elusive agreement; stalemate centers on final haggling over wording of documents to accompany Hebron agreement, which lists unfulfilled obligations of both sides under existing treaties and timetable for further Israeli withdrawals (M)

headline: A Woman's Shooting of Attacker Rivets Mexico
abstract: Case of Claudia Rodriguez Ferrando, charged with murder for fatally shooting sexual attacker at Mexico City train station, has rallied Mexican women across wide spectrum; women in capital city feel especially vulnerable because of virtual breakdown of police system and rise in violent crime; Rodriguez, denied bail, is completing year in jail as trial proceeds; case sheds light on web of biases surrounding rape issue in Mexico and has spurred feminist movement; photo (M)

headline: Korean Air Records Its First Yearly Loss
abstract: Korean Air, world's 10th-largest airline, loses money for first time in its 34-year history last year, buffeted by rising fuel costs and the won's slump against the dollar; reports net loss for year was $244 million (S)

headline: Lord, Dentsu Now the Lord Group
abstract: Lord, Dentsu & Partners, joint venture between Dentsu Inc and Young & Rubicam Inc, changes its name to Lord Group (S)

headline: U.S. Mediation Fails to Achieve Accord on a Pullback in Hebron
abstract: US mediator Dennis Ross fails again to conclude agreement on partial Israeli pullback in Hebron, as Palestinians dig in on demands for deadlines and guarantees of further withdrawals; map; Yasir Arafat's position may have hardened following incident in which Israeli soldier with history of mental problems opened fire in Hebron market; Israeli police detain second soldier, Yuval Jibli, for allegedly knowing about Noam Friedman's intention and failing to report it; 22-year-old Friedman, Orthodox Jew from West Bank settlement, is remanded for ten days; he tells court he regrets not killing any Arabs, objects to 'secular' court and female judge and says he acted to prevent 'surrender' of Hebron; major question is why he was drafted and given weapon, considering his mental history (M)

headline: Chase Manhattan Promotes an Executive
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp promotes James B Lee Jr to post of vice chairman, with responsibility for global investment banking (S)

headline: Pay Us in Advance
abstract: Letter from Abigail R Esman comments on Jan 19 article on freelance writers not getting paid (S)

headline: France Moves to Crush Corsican Separatists
abstract: French Government has jailed leaders of most powerful separatist group on Corsica following bombing of Bordeaux city hall in Oct (M)

headline: Heroin Is Proving a Growth Industry for Colombia
abstract: Drug Enforcement Administration says while Colombia produces only 1.5 percent of world's heroin, it has come to dominate market in parts of US in recent years; sample purchases by agency suggest 91 percent of heroin sold on streets of New York, Newark, Philadelphia and Boston comes from South America, mainly Colombia; photo; map (M)

headline: $875 Million Deal Widens G.E.'s Role in Jet Engine Servicing
abstract: General Electric Co agrees to buy Greenwich Air Services Inc and UNC Inc for $875 million in cash and stock, a move that analysts say would effectively double GE's share of $28 billion market for servicing jet engines; GE would pay $530 million, or $31 a share, for Greenwich Air; GE also obtains rights to complete Greenwich Air's acquisition, announced in February, of UNC for $345 million, or $15 a share (L)

headline: First Bank System to Buy U.S. Bancorp of Oregon
abstract: First Bank System says it has agreed to buy US Bancorp of Portland, Ore, for $9 billion in stock; First Bank will assume US Bancorp name; it will become nation's 14th-largest banking company, with $70 billion in assets; each US Bancorp share will be exchanged for 0.755 share of First Bank; First Bank has agreed to pay stock worth 3.4 times US Bancorp's book value, a phenominally high price for a bank; merger will eliminate 4,000 jobs, mostly in Portland; First Bank plans to close US Bancorp branches to encourage customers to do business by telephone and automated teller machines; map (M)

headline: Grey to Handle Anacin Work Again
abstract: Whitehall-Robins Health Care division of American Home Products Corp has named Grey Advertising to handle Anacin analgesic, which had been at Lois/EJL unit of Lois/USA; for a year; billings estimated at $8 million (S)â

headline: Payrolls Swell by 271,000, But Inflation Stays in Check
abstract: Buoyant economy creates more jobs in January than economists expected, but growth in labor costs slows, calming Wall Street's jitters about inflation; Labor Department figures show that strong demand for workers swells payrolls by 271,000 in January, although analysts say that increase does not imply additional pressures on Federal Reserve to raise interest rates; reports also shows that number of Americans with jobs rose to record in January; one sign of job equilibrium is that unemployment rate edged up by 0.1 point, to 5.4 percent, as large number of people--509,000--entered job market, and all but 75,000 of them found jobs; average hourly earnings inched up just 1 cent, to $12.08, last month after increases totaling 15 cents in November and December (M)

headline: Swiss Bank Shreds War-Era Data But a Suspicious Guard Halts It
abstract: Christopher Meili, security guard at Union Bank of Switzerland, halts destruction of some documents from World War II era, including papers that appear to deal with 'forced auctions' of property in Berlin in 1930's; bank, one of Switzerland's largest and focal point for investigators seeking to trace Jewish assets deposited in Swiss accounts during war, says it 'regrets the incident'; Swiss Government has ordered its banks to preserve any remaining records of their dealings with Nazi Germany (M)

headline: In Separate Studies, Costs Of Hospitals Are Debated
abstract: Study by Dr Steffie Woolhandler and Dr David U Himmelstein, published in New England Journal of Medicine, says investor-owned hospitals have significantly higher administrative costs than nonprofit hospitals, in part because they are less efficient; American Hospital Association and the Federation of American Health Systems, which represents investor-owned hospitals, reject findings; Federal advisory panel, in separate study, says hospitals of all types have radically reduced growth of their total costs; new data from Federal panel, the Prospective Payment Assessment Commission, which advises Congress on Medicare payments to hospitals, show remarkable reductions in growth of hospital costs in last three years (L)

headline: Albright Offers Russia Plan To Ease Concerns on NATO
abstract: Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright presents Kremlin with new arms control proposal that would freeze military forces near Russia's European periphery, in West's first detailed response to Russian anxieties about NATO expansion; new plan would not require reductions in NATO forces or dramatically alter military balance on European continent; main aim is to ease Moscow's fear that NATO is trying to take advantage of Russia at time of weakness; to address Russian concerns, new proposal would update 1990 treaty slashing conventional forces with Europe, which was hammered out between NATO alliance and old Soviet-led bloc (M)

headline: Caribbean Seeks to Attract More Airlines
abstract: Threat of strike at American Airlines, which controls some half of market for air travel between United States and Caribbean, was scary reminder for tourism-dependent islands that their reliance on single airline could prove economically devastating; Caribbean governments and tourism officials seek to attract more airlines (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FIRST ENTERTAINMENT INC., Denver, a multimedia entertainment company, signed a letter of intent to acquire Online Casinos Inc. for $26 million, including debt. The company said it would offer gambling over the Internet within 60 days.    NATIONAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC., Minneapolis, agreed to buy Virtual University Enterprises, Bloomington, Minn., for 582,000 shares of common stock, or about $13.5 million.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Consumer Confidence And Home Sales Surge  Exceeding economists' expectations and boding well for a strong 1997, consumer confidence surged to a seven-year high in December, and sales of new homes showed their steepest advance in three and a half years during November.    The Conference Board said its consumer confidence index rose 4.3 points, to 113.8. The Commerce Department said home sales surged 14.2 percent. $(62.$)    Concern over the possibility of an overly robust economy, as well as end-of-the-year selling by investors, caused stocks to plunge. The Dow Jones industrials fell 101.10 points, or 1.54 percent, to close at 6,448.27. But the index still rose 26 percent for the year. $(65.$)    Bond prices fell sharply, ending a year in which they dropped during much of the first six months, recovered most of their losses and then turned down again. The 30-year bond yield rose to 6.64 percent from 6.54 percent. The yield ended the year nearly three-quarters of a percentage point higher than the level, 5.96 percent, at which it started the year. $(64.$)    Underwriting Roars Back in Quarter  Stock and bond underwriting roared back in the year's final quarter, despite a somewhat hesitant beginning, to end a year that left many on Wall Street rubbing their eyes in disbelief. During the quarter, the securities industry underwrote $251.6 billion worth of domestic debt and equity issues, Securities Data said. That was a 22.5 percent rise from the third quarter and a 29.2 percent gain from a year earlier. $(64.$)    Lilco Stock Windfall Possible  Long Island Lighting shareholders will get a stock price bonus if the state takes over $4.5 billion in debt for the company's defunct Shoreham nuclear plant, according to Lilco's merger agreement with Brooklyn Union Gas. If the bonus is included, analysts said, Lilco owners are likely to see their long-troubled stock rise a third in value. $(45.$)    Northeast Utilities has mismanaged its nuclear plants for a decade, and if the company cannot turn its operations around in the next year, it may not survive, an audit ordered by Connecticut indicated. $(45.$)    Heating and Crude Oil Prices Up  With freezing temperatures and snow blanketing much of Europe, the prices of heating oil and crude oil jumped in a shortened session on expectations that higher European prices could reduce American supplies. Natural gas and copper prices also rose. $(71.$)    British Pound at Four-Year High  Demand surged for the British pound, which hit a four-year high of $1.7125. The dollar's rally against the Japanese yen faltered in thin trading, with the dollar settling at 115.93 yen, down from 116.15 yen on Monday. $(71.$)    Fraud Accusation Against Schott  Marge Schott, whose ethnic comments have undermined her position as managing partner of the Cincinnati Reds baseball team, faces potentially more serious trouble over accusations of fraudulent sales reports that General Motors has lodged against her concerning actions at her Chevrolet-Geo dealership. $(58.$)    Travel Costs Expected to Rise  Travel industry consultants see higher 1997 costs. They expect hotel rates to climb 5 percent, domestic air fares to go up 5 percent, international fares 7 percent, and car-rental rates to rise 4 percent to 5 percent. They also see more women and more upper-echelon executives on the road. Business Travel. $(63.$)    A Call for Belt-Tightening  French and German leaders urged their restive citizens to keep making sacrifices so their countries could meet increasingly tough global economic competition. $(4.$)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TRIANGLE PACIFIC CORP., Dallas, agreed to acquire Robbins Inc.'s Residential Flooring division and its Search Flooring Inc. affiliate for about $10 million in cash, $40 million to $45 million in short-term capitalized leases and obligations and about $10 million in debt.    GEOWORKS INC., Alameda, Calif., a software company, said it planned to acquire Eden Group Ltd. of Manchester, England, another software company, for $30 million in stock.

headline: Paying Fund Managers With Carrots and Sticks
abstract: Carole Gould reports on incentive fee structures for mutual fund managers that are in place at some mutual fund companies; under mutual fund regulations, incentive fees must work both ways, as reward for good performance and as penalty for poor performance; example cited of Fidelity's Magellan Fund, which had tough time last year; this year, Magellan's management will not only not get a bonus, it will be penalized for trailing its chosen benchmark, Standard & Poor's 500-stock index; charts (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DELL COMPUTER CORP., Austin, Tex., the personal computer maker, will buy back an additional 18 million common shares, raising its existing repurchase plan to 50 million shares.    COLGATE-PALMOLIVE CO., New York, the consumer products company, declared a 2-for-1 common stock split and increased its quarterly dividend by 17 percent, to 55 cents a share from 47 cents.

headline: Fund Family Shows Pitfalls of Statistics
abstract: *Each of three mutual funds managed by Garrett R Van Wagoner beat stock market averages in 1996, gaining 24 percent to 27 percent; for its efforts overseeing $1 billion invested in the funds, Van Wagoner Capital Management earned $8.7 million in fees; despite performance record implied by funds' percentage gains, Van Wagoner lost more than $105 million of investors' money--about $1 of every $10 entrusted to him; those losses mounted as poor performance by the funds in second half of year outweighed, in dollar terms, gains made in early 1996, when funds' assets were far less; to millions of Americans who have started to invest in mutual funds in last few years, Van Wagoner's tale serves as a reminder that making money in stocks is by no means a sure thing--even when investing in hottest of bull markets with one of country's most widely hailed mutual fund managers; graphs; tables; photos (L)

headline: Bank of Korea Moves to Strengthen Won
abstract: Bank of Korea moves to strengthen won against surging dollar (S)

headline: Lam Announces Deal and Predicts Loss
abstract: Lam Research Corp to buy Ontrak Systems Inc for $225 million in stock; Ontrak chairman and chief executive James Bagley will become chief executive of combined company and share office of chairman with Lam chief executive Roger Emerick; Lam expects to report $1.40 a share loss in third quarter ended Mar 31 (S)

headline: For frequent-stay awards, the two Hiltons join forces in an agreement aimed at the bottom line.
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp joins forces with its international subsidiary in agreement aimed at increasing profits from its frequent-stay program; British Airways is offering new London for Less tourist package suitable for business traveler for $547.57, which includes air fare from New York or Boston and three-night hotel stay; El Convento hotel in San Juan, PR, which was hit with island's social set and many business travelers in 1960's is restored and re-opened after more than two decades of near-neglect; Ford Motor Co is testing real-time departure monitors at Hartsfield International airport for travelers who rent its cars from its Hertz unit; concern of many business travelers about airline accidents may not be alleviated by release of data on safety by National Transportation Safety Board and Federal Aviation Administration; El Al is offering first- and business-class customers toilet kit with suction cup that affixes it to lavatory mirror, above detritus usually found around bathroom sinks (Business Travel) (M)

headline: MONTGOMERY WARD MOVE PORTENDS POWER SHIFT
abstract: Montgomery Ward Holding Corp has given two board seats to Roger Goddu, its new chief executive, in a move that could give GE Capital Corp control over department store company; two seats were taken from Montgomery Ward's chairman Bernard F Brennan (S)

headline: No HAL Yet: Artificial Intelligence Visions Underestimated the Mind
abstract: Stanley Kubrick, director of 1968 movie 2001: A Space Odyssey, used best available science to project thrilling future within lifetime of much of its original viewing audience; plausibility of film made supercomputer HAL seem attainable; but scientists overestimated nimbleness of the computer brain, which today can retrieve information but cannot organize it into systems of knowledge; photos (L)

headline: Peru Rebels Free an Ailing Hostage but No Sign of Talks Is Seen
abstract: Tupac Amaru guerrillas holding Japanese ambassador's residence, Lima, Peru, free ailing hostage, police aide Gen Jose Rivas Rodriguez; there are no signs that talks with rebels will begin any time soon (M)

headline: Canada Called Haven for Nazi Criminals
abstract: Recent news accounts of Canada's lax pursuit of accused Nazi war criminals after World War II stirs painful memories and raises troubling questions about Government's policies in post-war period; recent television documentaries by Canadian Broadcasting Corp and NBC-TV on accused war criminals who have lived freely in Canada since end of war discussed; Canadian Jewish Congress spokesman calls disclosures airing for first time of Canada's 'dirty little secret' (M)

headline: STAKES IN 5 CANADIAN SHOPPING CENTERS TO CHANGE HANDS
abstract: Cambridge Shopping Centers Ltd will sell interests in five shopping centers to Ontrea Inc for $229.4 million (S)

headline: Corporate Security: Beyond the Badges
abstract: Letter by Prof David M Schulman of Northeastern University on Dec 8 article on theft by employees; says security must be recognized as management function and responsibility; says old notion that security is mere extension of policing into private sector, and that security directors are only company police chiefs, denies employers secutity benefits they need and deserve (M)

headline: Retail Sales For December Well Below Expectations
abstract: Retailers report their sales for December were well below gains of 5 to 9 percent that Wall Street had hoped for; Goldman, Sachs & Co same-store sales index shows retail sales were up only 2.9 percent in December, compared with same month a year earlier; that figure puts 1996 Christmas season among worst in more than decade; reasons cited include shortened selling season, significant weakness in consumer electronics and inability of many retailers to stand out from their peers; but many retail analysts and consultants contend that Christmas only reflects themes that went on all year; most striking was how every major category offered equal number of winners and losers; this indicates that there are stil far too many merchants offering same products; graph (M)

headline: Borland Secrets Suit Ends
abstract: Borland International Inc said last week it had settled its trade secrets lawsuit against Symantec Corp, a rival software maker; Borland and Symantec said they agreed to dismiss the lawsuit and all related counterclaims (S)

headline: North Korea Agrees to Take Taiwan Atom Waste for Cash
abstract: North Korea agrees to accept up to 200,000 barrels of nuclear waste from Taiwan, in exchange for tens of millions of dollars; deal has enraged South Korea, which is less than 40 miles from disposal site in North Korea; Taiwan and North Korea do not belong to international treaties governing disposal of nuclear waste; experts say that if deal goes through, it could pave way for other countries seeking refuge sites for their nuclear waste (M)

headline: Martin Slate, 51, Director of Federal Pension Benefit Agency
abstract: Martin Slate, the executive director of the Government corporation that insures the pensions of 41 million Americans and a civil servant repeatedly honored for innovative solutions to regulatory problems, died on Sunday night, the White House announced yesterday. He was 51.    His wife, Dr. Caroline Poplin, an internist, said her husband had died of cardiac arrest at their home in Bethesda, Md.

headline: MCI BEGINS TO CUT WORK FORCE NATIONWIDE
abstract: MCI Communications Corp begins cutting about 1,200 jobs, less than 3 percent of payroll (S)e

headline: INVESTCORP OF BAHRAIN TO BUY FALCON BUILDING PRODUCTS
abstract: Investcorp agrees to acquire Falcon Building Products Inc for $365 million in cash and assumption of $225 million in debt (S)

headline: Senate Backs Clinton on Endorsing Mexico's Anti-Drug Efforts
abstract: Senate votes, 94 to 5, to support Pres Clinton's certification of Mexico as ally in war on drugs, but only after criticizing Mexico's efforts and extracting promise from Administration to press Mexico to do more (M)

headline: EXTENDED STAY AMERICA BUYING STUDIO PLUS HOTELS
abstract: Extended Stay America Inc will buy Studio Plus Hotels Inc for about $290 million in stock (S)

headline: Investors Put $24 Billion In Equity Funds
abstract: Investment Company Institute reports mutual fund investors poured estimated $24 billion into equity funds in January 1997, fourth-largest total on record; says more than half of amount was invested in money market funds, generally safest type of mutual fund (M)

headline: TOP EXECUTIVE TO LEAVE ANDERSEN
abstract: Andersen Worldwide says its managing partner and chief executive, Lawrence A Weinbach, will leave the firm when his term expires at end of August (S)

headline: Those Vicious Business Cycles: Tamed but Not Quite Slain
abstract: Sweeping changes may have better equipped economy to maintain its long-run equilibrium, diminishing severity of business cycles; most business economists see sustainable growth and low inflation ahead as economy enjoys long recovery; more moderate business cycle, which some argue results in lost growth and opportunity, does not necessarily spur progress in dealing with income inequality, other deep-rooted problems; graph (M)

headline: Expect top studio heads to roll if some of 1997's many blockbusters fail.
abstract: Movie studio executives are apprehensive as new year begins; 12 to 15 blockbusters costing $100 million or more each will be released; never have so many movies been released in single year that cost so much; some top-level jobs in Hollywood may be at stake if, as is inevitable, some of these movies fail; drawing (M)

headline: Another Record as Dow Closes Above 6,800
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes at 6,833.10, eighth record of year, on trading volume of 534.6 million shares (S)

headline: Medical Savings Plans: The Experiment Begins
abstract: Government officials, health care economists and insurance analysts will be watching as self-employed and companies with 50 or fewer employees begin making tax-deductible contributions into sort of medical IRA; Congress hopes to determine how such medical accounts fit into objectives of health care changes and how they compare with traditional indemnity health insurance or managed-care plans; qualifications for participation in such plans and details of how they operate discussed; photo (M)

headline: Even Bullish Analysts Are Looking Sheepish
abstract: Surge of Dow Jones industrial average past 7,000 has been so swift this year that it has even left bullish analysts in its dust; Hugh Johnson, chief investment strategist of First Albany Corp, predicted that the Dow would end the year at 6,900; David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, sees Dow falling to 5,750 by year's end (L)

headline: Palestinians Strike Over Israeli Building Plan
abstract: Palestinians widen protests against Israeli plans to build new Jewish neighborhood in East Jerusalem; stage five-hour general strike in Jerusalem, as well as across West Bank and Gaza; Israeli officials confirm reports that it has set in motion other plans to build 1,500 homes for Jews and 3,000 hotel rooms that would link settlement town of Maaleh Adumim east of Jerusalem to city; photo (M)

headline: Entergy Agrees to Manage Troubled Maine Nuclear Plant
abstract: Entergy Corp, large New Orleans-based utility that is aggressively moving into the business of running nuclear plants for other electricity companies, says it agreed to manage Maine Yankee, state's troubled nuclear plant; says deal, first in industry, is expected to be followed by similar arrangements with other utilities; some energy-industry experts say Maine Yankee management arrangement could be model for other utilities that have costly, troubled plants, many in Northeast (M)

headline: Renault Drive to Raise Europe Market Share
abstract: French auto maker Renault, smallest of Europe's Big Six car companies, aims to capture 10 percent to 10.5 percent of Western European car sales in 1997; Renault's market share fell in 1996 to 10.1 percent from 10.3 percent in 1995 (S)

headline: Art Smuggling At Sotheby's: Executives Suspended
abstract: Sotheby's, world's oldest and best known auction house, says it has suspended senior executives in connection with smuggling of protected works of art from Italy; smuggling charge is made in book, Sotheby's: Inside Story, written by Peter Watson; Sotheby's refuses to say how many staff members have been suspended or to identify them (M)

headline: Auto Stocks: Beneath the Metallic Glow
abstract: Wall Street analysts disagree on how to value stocks of Big Three automobile manufacturers, even though they periodically suggest that investors could get something for nothing by buying low-priced issues; stocks may not be such clear bargains since values of industry assets may be overstated to compensate for taxes that might have to be paid on any spin-offs or divestitures (M)

headline: Quaker to Sell Snapple for $300 Million
abstract: Quaker Oats Co to sell Snapple Beverage Corp drink business to Triarc Companies for $300 million, $1.4 billion less than Quaker paid for Snapple in 1994; analysts say deal leaves Snapple with low enough cost base to be immediately profitable for Triarc (L)

headline: Mandela Rival Takes Over (At Least for a Few Days)
abstract: South African Pres Nelson Mandela appoints his archrival, Zulu Chief Mangosuthu G Buthelezi, to stand in as Acting Pres when he goes out of country; photo; announcement provokes uncertain laughter in legislature but is considered artful gesture of reconciliation at time when Buthelezi seems to have dug in heels in peace talks to end years of bloody conflict between his Inkatha party and African National Congress; F W de Klerk is, at same time, struggling to extend National Party's support beyond Afrikaner and mixed-race households (M)

headline: NOODLE KIDOODLE TRIMS EXPANSION PLANS
abstract: Educational toy retailer Noodle Kidoodle will scale back planned store openings in 1997 and cut 15 workers from its administrative staff (S)

headline: New Battle of Normandy Rages Over U.S. Memorial : The Wall That Never Went Up
abstract: WASHINGTON—  When Ameri-cans visit the D-Day beaches of France, thousands head each year to Le Memorial, a war museum and garden taking shape in Caen to honor the soldiers who took part in the liberation of Normandy.

headline: Saudi Detained by Canadians Reveals Link to Blast Suspect
abstract: Hani Abd Rahim al-Sayegh, Saudi arrested in Canada and suspected of role in 1996 bombing of US military barracks, says he belongs to Saudi Hezbollah, which has ties to pro-Iranian Hezbollah in Lebanon; deportation papers describe frequent travels to fundamentalist countries, and link to Jaafar Chueikhat, suspected conspirator in Saudi bombing (S)

headline: Zairian Military Jets Bomb Civilians in Rebel-Held Town
abstract: Embattled Zairian Government uses air strikes to punish civilians in rebel-held city of Bukavu; rejects entreaties by United Nations, several Western countries and opposition leaders for peace talks with rebels; accuses UN of ignoring plight of Zairians displaced by fighting; photo; maps (M)

headline: N.A.S.D. Restores Purged Broker Data
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers says it has restored all 596 items of adverse broker data mistakenly purged from data bank of brokers' disciplinary histories; data are used by investors and regulators seeking background information on problem brokers (S)

headline: Mexico Says Major Drug Suspect Escaped as U.S. Weighed Status
abstract: Mexican officials report escape from police custody of Humberto Garcia Abrego, who is accused of being top money launderer for one of Mexico's major drug trafficking cartels; incident was not disclosed until after Pres Clinton certified Mexico as full ally in war on drugs; this is second embarrassing disclosure withheld by Mexican officials during intense two-week lobbying campaign that preceded certification decision; Humberto Garcia Abrego is brother of Juan Garcia Abrego, convicted cocaine trafficker imprisoned in United States (M)

headline: G.I.'s Set for Zaire Evacuation
abstract: Pentagon announces that 'several hundred' American troops will be sent to central Africa to prepare for possible large-scale evacuation of Americans from Zaire (S)

headline: INTUIT TO ACQUIRE JAPANESE SOFTWARE DEVELOPER
abstract: Intuit Inc says it agreed to acquire Nihon Micon KK for $39 million (S)

headline: CCB TO PAY $325.1 MILLION FOR AMERICAN FEDERAL
abstract: CCB Financial Corp will acquire American Federal Bank FSB for $325.1 Million (S)

headline: Banc One uses promotional tie-ins to a movie about Selena to reach out to the Hispanic market.
abstract: Advertising column says Banc One Corp, country's 10th-largest bank, has become financial services sponsor of Selena, biogaphical film about singer who died in 1995, in effort to reach out to Hispanic market; says other mainsteam marketers involved with film include American Honda Motor Co and J C Penney Co; photo (M)

headline: Tajiks Talk of Peace Between Battles
abstract: Tajikistan, former Soviet republic, has been shorn of much of cultural legacy after four years of civil war, and has crumbled into unruly country swarming with rival factions; every important official, from President down, seems to be warlord, or is beholden to one, or both; local and foreign analysts say in unlikely event Pres Emomali Rakhmanov wishes to bring about peace and erode his already tenuous power, he probably lacks influence to do so; photo; maps (M)

headline: Despite Pact, Buses Face Border Barrier
abstract: While North American Free Trade Agreement gave United States and Mexican bus lines right to carry passengers across border and throughout each other's lands, Mexican Government requires all bus lines to use central terminals; Mexican position means it is not yet possible to buy Greyhound Lines ticket to cities in Mexico because central terminals there are controlled by Greyhound's Mexican rivals; Greyhound executives say that after several requests, company has not received applications for using those terminals or for starting new routes; American bus operators say Mexican officials are holding them hostage to stalemate over rights trade pact granted Mexican truckers; map of route Greyhound will run between Los Angeles and Ciudad Obredon (M)

headline: LIZ CLAIBORNE INC. (LIZ,N)
abstract: Liz Claiborne Inc reports fourth-quarter 1996 net of $40.9 million, compared with $33.6 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: Delta in Deal With AT&T
abstract: Delta Air Lines says it signed 7-year contract worth $341 million for AT&T Corp to provide worldwide long-distance voice and data communications services (S)

headline: Korean Chip Maker Is Branching Out
abstract: LG Semicon Co, world's seventh-largest memory chip manufacturer, will invest $1 billion to start making liquid crystal displays in its first move away from violatile chip business; move will help South Korean company better weather slumping chip prices; benchmark prices fell 81 percent last year because of excess capacity (S)

headline: Swiss and Their Burden of Nazi Gold
abstract: News analysis of Swiss Pres Arnold Koller's proposal of $4.7-billion investment fund, profits of which would be used equally inside and outside Switzerland to compensate victims of genocide and abuse, including those of Holocaust; suggestion was broadly welcomed by American and Swiss Jewish groups as turning point after months of opprobrium over Switzerland's wartime history, but would also force Swiss to see their past in something less than heroic light of moral superiority; Christoph Blocher, tycoon who is leading figure in small conservative Swiss People's Party, says Swiss should be proud of their wartime history, and not pay any money (S)

headline: Pete's Brewing Goes to Black Rocket
abstract: Pete's Brewing Co in Palo Alto, Calif, changes advertising agencies for second time in seven months, replacing Gotham Inc in New York with Black Rocket in San Francisco; billings estimated at $7 million to $10 million (S)

headline: A genetic mutation among people with salt-sensitive hypertension is reportedly identified.
abstract: Myriad Genetics researchers identify genetic mutation common among people who have salt-sensitive hypertension; patent test that screens for presence of mutation; Dr John Kabal patents way to measure and analyze hypertension patient's blood flow by plugging blood pressure, other data into series of equations that are analyzed by computer (M)

headline: Station Bets on Business-Sports Mix
abstract: Cable station WBIS, Channel 31 in New York, broadcasts business, financial, consumer and life-style programs during day, and switches to being sports channel at night, showins games and news; station is co-owned by Dow Jones & Co and ITT Corp, which also co-owns Madison Square Garden (M)

headline: SIERRA RECONSIDERS OFFER FOR PHYSICIAN CORPORATION
abstract: Sierra Health Services Inc, which has made takeover offer for Physician Corporation of America, says it is 'seriously evaluating' its options after report that Physician will take $60 million charge against earnings for the fourth quarter (S)

headline: Setback Dealt To Owners Of Barney's
abstract: New York State Supreme Court Justice Herman Cahn orders Barneys Inc, upscale clothing retailer that filed for bankruptcy protection in 1996 in dispute with Japanese partner, Isetan Co, to pay Isetan $197 million in loans; rejects arguments by Bob and Gene Pressman, owners and co-chairmen of Barneys, of being tricked into personally guaranteeing loans, which were to be used for expansion and have since accrued $30 million in interest; loans were made by Isetan following payment for most of costs associated with building flagship Barneys stores in New York City and Beverly Hills, Calif; Barneys filed for bankruptcy amid cash squeeze and in dispute with Isetan over nature of company's financing of Barneys, to which it originally lent more than $600 million (M)

headline: Retirement Planning for Too Much of a Good Thing
abstract: Accountants are advising taxpayers over age 59 1/2 to be cautious about new tax break, which allows them to take excess distributions from tax-deferred retirement plans for next three years without paying 15 percent excise tax; note clients must still pay ordinary income tax on any money withdrawn and lose out on continued tax-deferred growth; graphs (M)

headline: Dispute Arises Over Proposal For Wiretaps
abstract: An old quarrel about the F.B.I.'s plan to modernize its system for eavesdropping on telephone conversations has flared anew.    After a contentious meeting earlier this week with the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington, telephone companies and industry associations are arguing that the new system will be far more intrusive and expensive than the industry had first thought. They said it would give law-enforcement officials sweeping new power to monitor tens of thousands of conversations and data transmissions simultaneously in a metropolitan area.

headline: Merrill Lynch Reorganizes Into 4 Groups
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co says it is reorganizing into four business groups to help sales of stocks and bonds; units will be corporate and institutional client group, asset management group, international client group and United States private client group (S)

headline: HFS Agrees to Pay $175 Million to Acquire Value Rent-a-Car
abstract: HFS Inc agrees to buy Value Rent-a-Car from Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America Inc for $175 million in cash, thus adding a car rental company that caters primarily to leisure travelers in Sun Belt states to its ownership of Avis Rent a Car (M)

headline: Price Soars and Yield Falls To 6.62% on 30-Year Bond
abstract: Bond investors shrug off mediocre Treasury auction and go on buying spree; benchmark 30-year bond surges 1 2/32, to price of 98 14/32; yield tumbles to 6.62 percent, from 6.71 percent on Feb 12, reaching lowest yield in nearly six week; graphs (L)

headline: Corrections
abstract: A picture last Sunday with an article about a planned buyout of a Sunbeam Corporation textile plant in Biddeford, Me., was published in error. It showed part of the former Bates textile operations in Saco, across the Saco River from Biddeford.    A picture caption misidentified two men involved in negotiations for the buyout. At left at the head of the table was Michael Cavanaugh, assistant manager of the regional board of the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, not Rene Boisvert, the former top executive of the Biddeford mill. Next to Mr. Cavanaugh was Wally Szumita, business agent for Local 1856 of the union.    The article also misstated the party affiliation of the Mayor of Biddeford, James M. Grattelo. He is a Democrat, not a Republican.

headline: Fidelity Will Take Its Case Directly to Its Fund Investors
abstract: Fidelity Investments, stung by criticism in last year over the performance of its mutual funds and rash of departures from the ranks of its highly respected portfolio managers, decides to take its case directly to people by having three of its top executives and several portfolio managers travel to six cities to meet with retail customers and representatives of companies whose employees invest in Fidelity retirement programs; extensive action is highly unusual for mutual fund company (M)

headline: Drug makers test Thalidomide as a treatment for inflammations that accompany serious diseases.
abstract: Celgene Corp wins patent for Thalidomide derivatives that it says enhance drug's power to suppress overreaction of immune system that can cause inflammations; changes name of its family of Thalidomide drugs to Selcid; wheelchair whose seat can be raised and lowered is patented by five inventors in Louisiana; Jennifer Daniello patents container lid for spice jars that measures out the exact amount required (M)

headline: Stocks Surge, With Several Indexes at Records
abstract: Stock prices rise on New York Stock Exchange on January 14 as market stages another broad rally; Dow Jones industrial average gains 53.11 points, closing at record 6,762.29, on volume of more than 531 million shares; Standard & Poor's 500 gains 9.35 points, to close at record 768.86; Nasdaq Composite gains 15.45 points, to 1,346.36 (M)

headline: Mideast Impasse
abstract: Serge Schmemann analysis of impasse between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat over the more fundamental questions about Israeli-Palestinian peace process that should follow an Israeli withdrawal from Hebron, the details of which have reportedly been resolved; Palestinian are insisting on written guarantee from US that Israel will abide by existing agreements to withdraw from additional West Bank areas in three stages, ending in September 1997; Netanyahu's right-wing constituents believe that would mean surrendering Jewish lands and a critical bargaining lever in even more difficult issues ahead, such as what to do about Jerusalem or Israel's borders; photo (M)

headline: AT&T Suffers Another Defection From Its Executive Ranks
abstract: Richard W Miller is latest executive to resign from AT&T; he has been chief financial officer at AT&T since 1993; analysts say Miller deserves credit for structuring so-called trivestiture in way that unlocked shareholder value; some industry experts say Miller's departure is setback for AT&T, which cannot afford to lose any more senior managers during difficult period (M)

headline: Table Is Set for Competition
abstract: Former-Sen Larry Pressler letter on Feb 23 article on telecommunications reform (M)

headline: C. R. ANTHONY IN MERGER NEGOTIATIONS WITH STAGE STORES
abstract: C R Anthony Co says it is in merger talks with Stage Stores Inc; two retailers together operate 550 stores (S)

headline: Stocks Lower in Japan
abstract: Stocks prices declined on Tokyo Stock Exchange on February 5; Nikkei average lost 128.36 points, to close at 18,185.97 (S)

headline: More Grandparents Grab the Tuition Tab
abstract: People who would like to help pay the college tuition of their grandchildren several options for stretching their donated money and should keep various considerations in mind when they choose among them; photo (M)

headline: Club Med Has Loss and Hires a New Chief
abstract: Club Mediterranee SA posts surprise loss and hires Euro Disney SA's chief executive, Philippe Bourguignon, to improve its flagging fortunes; Bourguignon, who is given credit for turning around Euro Disney, will replace Club Med's chairman and chief executive, Serge Trigano; Club Med reports unexpected loss of 743 million French francs ($130.35 million) for fiscal year that ended Oct 31; Euro Disney says that Gilles Pelisson, its chief operating officer, will replace Bourguignon (S)

headline: Intel is using star power and funky music to entice Super Bowl viewers to a new kind of chip.
abstract: Advertising column describes Intel Corp's Super Bowl television advertising campaign, developed by Havas Advertising, to promote new version of popular Pentium chip, introduced on January 8 (M)

headline: King Hussein Rebukes Netanyahu For 'Intent to Destroy' Peace Plan
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan writes Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu personal and forceful letter contending that he cannot continue as Israel's partner and friend; Hussein accuses Netanyahu of decisions and actions that amount to 'deliberate humiliation' of Palestinians; says if Netanyahu proceeds with construction of Jewish settlement in East Jerusalem, it would amount to pushing Palestinians to 'inevitable violent resistance'; Netanyahu, in letter to Hussein, contends that he is reviving, not killing, peace efforts; photos (M)

headline: Holder Expected to Buy Rest of Belgian Utility
abstract: Powerfin SA delays earnings report and sets joint news conference with Tractebel SA, which holds 63 percent of Powerfin; move spurs speculation that Tractebel plans bid for remaining Powerfin shares (S)

headline: Sao Paulo to Sell Stake in Gas Gompany
abstract: 20 percent stake in Cia de Gas de Sao Paulo to be sold tomorrow by the City of Sao Paulo, which expects to raise at least 74 million reals ($71.1 million US) (S)

headline: Could Pixar Make It Without Disney?
abstract: Rush of Hollywood studios into animation puts Pixar Animation Studios in a good position to demand bigger share of new films it makes with Walt Disney Co; are drawn by the year-after-year profits that animated films generate at box office and in videos, computer games and merchandising; Pixar illustrates challenges facing any new entrant in the animation field; photos; drawings illustrate differences between digital animation employed by Pixar in Toy Story and its next film for Disney, code-named Bugs, and the hand-drawn animation in Disney's forthcoming Hercules (M)

headline: U.S. Judge Approves 1980's Insider Settlements
abstract: Federal Judge Milton Pollack approves seven class-action settlements that will pay $68.9 million to investors who say they were defrauded by Ivan F Boesky, Martin A Siegel, Robert Freeman and others involved in insider-trading scandals of the 1980's; investors charge three manipulated stock prices by colluding with former Drexel Burnham Lambert aide Michael R Milken; have also won settlements with Drexel, Milken and related parties; will get total of $260.5 million from all Boesky-related suits (S)

headline: MERCURY FINANCE IS GIVEN REPRIEVE ON A $50 MILLION LOAN
abstract: Mercury Finance Co says BankAmerica Corp agreed to extend due date of its $50 million loan by four days, until March 14 (S)

headline: QUEBECOR PRINTING ACQUIRES PETTY CO.
abstract: Quebecor Printing (USA) Corp acquires Petty Company of Effingham, Ill, provider of direct marketing printing services (S)

headline: TBWA UK to Merge With Simons Palmer
abstract: TBWA UK and Simons Palmer Clemmow Johnson agency say they will merge by end of March to form TBWA/Simons Palmer (S)

headline: Wrapping Their Dreams Around Their Wrists
abstract: Swiss watchmakers re-establish themselves at high end of luxury watch market by relying on status, collectibility and mechanical wizardry to attract buyers; experts note that few such watches appreciate in value; photo (M)

headline: MERRILL LYNCH TO BUY REST OF SOUTH AFRICAN FIRM
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company agrees to acquire remaining 49 percent of Smith Borkum Hare (Pty) Ltd, South African securities firm; names Jeffrey L Humber chief executive; Humphrey Borkum, former chairman of Johannesburg stock exchange, will become chairman (S)

headline: PATRIOT AMERICAN BUYS MAJORITY STAKE IN 5 HOTELS
abstract: Patriot American Hospitality Inc to buy majority stakes in five Doubletree luxury hotels from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co for $153 million in cash and assumed debt (S)

headline: U.S. and Mexico Differ Over What They Negotiated on Drugs
abstract: US and Mexican officials, in days since Clinton Administration certified that Mexico is fully cooperating in fight against illegal drugs, have offered conflicting accounts of what--if anything--was agreed to in last-minute talks (M)

headline: Southwest Airlines Combines Account
abstract: Southwest Airlines has consolidated its advertising account, with billings estimated at $60 million, at GSD&M; account had been divided regionally on project basis between GSD&M, a unit of GGT Group, and Cramer-Krasselt (S)

headline: Vladimir A. Yamnikov, 56, Premium Russian Vodka Maker
abstract: Vladimir A Yamnikov, manager of Kristall distillery, one of largest vodka makers in Russia, dies at age 56 (M)

headline: Triton Energy Settles Indonesia Bribery Case for $300,000
abstract: Triton Energy Corp, international oil and gas development company based in Dallas, Tex, agrees to pay $300,000 to settle Federal charges stemming from bribes that a subsidiary, Triton Indonesia, paid to Indonesian Government officials in 1989 and 1990; unusual complaint was brought by Securities and Exchange Commission, which contends that Triton officials not only made payments that violated Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, but also falsified records to make bribes appear to be routine business payments; Triton will not face criminal charges in bribery matter; since the Indonesian events, Triton has brought in an entirely new management and has restructured its operations, which SEC noted in announcing settlement; in 1988, Triton Indonesia became operator of oil and gas project in Sumatra under contract with Indonesia's national oil company, Petramina; SEC's complaint states that Triton executives in Indonesia paid an agent named Roland Siouffi a total of $300,000 with understanding that money would go to Government officials (L)

headline: Jacques Foccart Dies at 83; Secret Mastermind in Africa
abstract: Jacques Foccart, who masterminded clandestine military coups in French-speaking Africa for Charles de Gaulle and three French presidents after him, dies at age 83; photo (M)

headline: New President of the N.A.S.D. Is Named
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers names Frank G Zarb president; votes to make it harder to get listed on Nasdaq Stock Market; weighs controversial new rules to revise arbitration system for settling customers' disputes with brokers (M)

headline: U.S. Is Selling Missiles It Once Banned
abstract: United States, which once zealously opposed sale of advanced medium range air-to-air missiles (Amraams) outside of NATO, is now competing with Russia to sell missiles in Southeast Asia as inducement to buyers of advanced fighter aircraft; relaxed ban on sales is in response to Thailand's threat to buy jets from Russia (M)

headline: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES TO PURCHASE GERSTENSLAGER
abstract: company news: worthington industries to purchase gerstenslager**Worthington Industries says it agreed to buy Gerstenslager Co from JMAC, investment company controlled by Worthington's chairman emeritus, John H McConnell, for $113 milion in stock (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Tower Air, Jamaica, Queens, to Romann & Tannenholz, New York, to handle its account in the United States, previously handled by Baldin, Bloom & Whelan, New York. Billings were estimated at $5 million.    * Swatch USA, Weehawken, N.J., a division of SMH Inc., to PGR Media, Providence, R.I., to handle media planning and buying for the watch maker. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million. Toth Design and Advertising, Concord, Mass., and New York, was named to handle the creative part of its account earlier last week.

headline: German Cabinet Backs Selling Lufthansa
abstract: German Government will sell remaining stake in Lufthansa; approves legislation to keep carrier in German hands (S)

headline: Fiat, Mediobanca and Marzotto Creation Could Rule Europe's Fashion Industry : An Italian Powerhouse Mixes Money and Style
abstract: MILAN—  Three of Italy's most powerful business empires — Fiat, Mediobanca and the Marzotto clothing group — will pool a range of activities to create a $5 billion-a-year conglomerate that could change the face of Europe's fashion and clothing industry.

headline: U.S.-Canadian Split on Cuba Tangles Wal-Mart's Pajamas
abstract: Canadian Government opens inquiry into Wal-Mart's decision to stop selling Cuban-made pajamas in its Canadian stores; Wal-Mart pulled pajamas because it did not want to violate Helms-Burton Act, US law that tries to force foreign companies and governments to join in US embargo of Cuban products; Wal-Mart may have violated Canadian law that bars companies from obeying US law; Wal-Mart could be fined as much as $1.5 million (Canadian) if found guilty (M)

headline: Philip Morris Names New No. 2 Officer
abstract: Philip Morris Companies names its top international tobacco executive, William Webb, chief operating officer, making him prime candidate to succeed Geoffrey C Bible as chairman and chief executive; names general counsel, Murray H Bing, vice chairman (S)

headline: A Place Where Language Knocks Down the Walls
abstract: George Zucker article discusses role of pidgin English in uniting Hawaii's diverse population for generations in light of debate over role of black English; notes pidgin is neither taught in schools nor scorned (M)

headline: Helen Foster Snow, 89, a Founder Of Industrial Co-ops in China
abstract: Helen Foster Snow, who helped bring social change to China in 1930's, witnessed revolution and war and throughout wrote to promote American-Chinese understanding, dies at age 89 (M)

headline: Krupp Drops Thyssen Bid; They Will Link Steel Operation
abstract: Fried Krupp AG drops $8 billion hostile bid for Thyssen AG as firms instead plan to combine steel operations; move follows protests by steel workers, who fear merger will lead to thousands of job cuts, and German Government pressure; is defeat for Krupp chairman Gerhard Cromme and big German and American banks that planned to finance merger; Thyssen says it will run combined steel venture; photo (M)

headline: Danish Company to Buy ABB Refrigeration Unit
abstract: ABB Group, ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd unit, to sell its refrigeration business to Sabroe Refrigeration AS for $93 million (S)

headline: An Unbalanced Loner With a Rifle
abstract: Profile of Israeli Army Pvt Noam Friedman, who opened fire in crowded Arab market in Hebron, wounding six people; maps (M)

headline: Political Undertones: As Handover Nears, Hong Kong Designers Speak Out
abstract: HONG KONG—  With the shift to Chinese sovereignty almost upon them, Hong Kong fashion designers are asserting their views on the handover via the catwalk. Jackets bearing the Chinese flag, transparent cheongsams and dresses covered with anti-colonial calligraphy are among their latest statements.

headline: G.M. Is Speaking Out on the Dollar and Other Issues
abstract: General Motors Corp is becoming much more active on public policy issues as it builds new factories around world and rising dollar spurs sales of foreign cars in United States; has stepped up lobbying against rise in value of dollar, other issues; chairman John F Smith Jr, while still visibly uncomfortable discussing public policy, says firm must take more public stands as it expands overseas (M)

headline: Revamping With Technology, Competition and U.S. Aid
abstract: Europe's rail freight industry is being modernized, with help from American railroad companies; currently there are seven electrical standards, jumble of signal systems and three track gauge widths, creating bottlenecks at borders; European planners and government leaders preparing for unification are breaking up old inefficient state rail monopolies into commercially viable pieces; they are even opening door to outside competition, including Wisconsin Central Transportation Corp, American specialist in turning around troubled freight companies, and CSX Corp, whose subsidiary is in joint ventures to introduce American-style freight shuttles; Americans are bringing new infusion of capital and also rich trove of expertise from painful shakeout that reshaped American freight industry in 1980's; maps, charts (L)

headline: Russia Vows to Remove Georgia Nuclear Fuel
abstract: Russia, responding to repeated American appeals, promises to remove cache of nuclear material from former Republic of Georgia by March '97; supply of highly enriched uranium and spent fuel at research reactor outside Tblisi has been major worry for American officials, who fear it could fall into hands of aspiring nuclear powers or terrorists (M)

headline: Women Buy Fiction in Bulk And Publishers Take Notice
abstract: Book world view that women buy more books than men, perhaps up to 70 or 80 percent of fiction, is leading publishers to demand works by female authors or stories by men with strong female central character; current generation of leading female editors and authors helps reinforce view, little publicized and hard to document, that fiction publishing is being feminized; male authors continue to have more books than female authors on hardcover fiction best-seller list, but most of books feature female central characters; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Apartheid's Feared Police Prove Inept and Corrupt
abstract: South African Government of Pres Nelson Mandela, in effort to remake police force from one that specialized in political suppression and riot control to one that one that can solve crimes and respect human rights, is wrestling with other, less obvious effect of apartheid; police force left behind by National Party is deeply corrupt, barely literate and lacks some of most basic skills needed in conventional police work; about third of force's members lack high school diplomas, and only 27 percent of detectives have been trained to do such work; more than 40 percent of officers in Johannesburg do not have driver's licenses, and managemnent skills are lacking at all levels (M)

headline: The recreational vehicle industry rolls out a campaign to lure baby boomers.
abstract: GO RVing Coalition, made up of recreation vehicle makers, dealers, suppliers and campground owners, has begun $15 million advertising drive to attract babyboomers; responds to aging of its core market (M)

headline: Cyril F. Hetsko, 85, an Executive At American Tobacco Company
abstract: Cyril F Hetsko, lawyer and executive who was instrumental in transforming American Tobacco Company into American Brands Inc, dies at age 85 (S)

headline: U.S. WILL PROPOSE ARMS REDUCTIONS IN CENTRAL EUROPE
abstract: Sec State Madeleine K Albright will take to Russia new proposals to sharply reduce conventional arms in Central and Eastern Europe; proposes joint NATO-Russian unit that could be used for peacekeeping, speech to NATO ministers, Brussels; proposals are part of larger offer to win Russian acquiescence in NATO's expansion and to negotiate NATO-Russian charter to govern their ties (M)

headline: Stocks Surge On Remarks By Greenspan
abstract: Stock prices surge on January 21 on stronger-than-expected earnings reports and remarks by Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan on health of US economy; Dow Jones Industrial Average gains 40.03, closing at 6,883.90; Standard & Poor's index gains 6.02, to 782.72, and Nasdaq Composite Index gains 12.69, to 1,376.97 (M)

headline: Albright Learns That She Lost 3 Ancestors in the Holocaust
abstract: Recently-confirmed US Sec of State Madeleine K Albright, whose family fled to America to escape Nazis and Communists during and after World War II, learns grandparents she never knew may have been Jewish and that at least three of them died in Holocaust, two at Auschwitz (M)

headline: 4 Partners in Airbus Industrie Reach Accord on Revamping It
abstract: Four partners in Airbus Industrie reach accord about how to restructure airplane manufacturer to make it more competitive, but Airbus says it will not release details of agreement for several days; Airbus is marketing vehicle for commercial aircraft made by partners--Daimler-Benz Aerospace AG, unit of Daimler-Benz AG of Germany, Aerospatiale of France, British Aerospace PLC and Construcciones Aeronauticas SA of Spain--each of which has its own assets (M)

headline: MITSUBISHI BUYS REMAINING SHARES OF ROCKEFELLER GROUP
abstract: Mitsubishi Estate Co buys all shares in Rockefeller Group Inc that it does not already own; Mitsubishi buys 20 percent stake in American real estate developer for $151 million from Rockefeller Family Trust (S)

headline: Durables Post Surprise Gain; 2d Big Month
abstract: Commerce Department reports orders for consumer durables jumped sharply again in February, by 1.5 percent, suggesting that economy os gaining momentum in its seventh year of expansion; disclosure lends after-the-fact support to Federal Reserve's decision to raise short-term interest rates to avert inflationary imbalances; graph (M)

headline: Economist Wins Top Medal for Pay Study
abstract: Kevin M Murphy, 39-year-old professor of business economics at University of Chicago, has been chosen as winner of John Bates Clark Medal from American Economic Association; Murphy is honored for his 'extraordinarily original' study of 'wages, wage inequality and relationship between wages and labor force participation'; photo (L)

headline: Mexico Accuses Top Businessman of Fraud
abstract: Mexican Government has charged Carlos Peralta Quintero, leading businessman who is partner in big cellular-telephone venture with Bell Atlantic Corp, with criminal tax fraud; Peralta has been indicted on charges of defrauding Government of the equivalent of $5 million by underreporting his personal income from 1992 through 1995; along with his family, he owns 48 percent of Grupo Iusacell SA de CV, in which Bell Atlantic owns 42 percent stake (L)

headline: For Philosophy Majors, a New Lease on the Meaning of Life
abstract: Bioethics, other issues raised by social and scientific developments are creating new career opportunities for graduate philosophy students; changes are occuring in business, technology, computer communications and law; several top business schools have special ethics programs and many Federal research programs include ethics jobs; job market is still tight for doctors of philosophy; photo (M)0

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Westinghouse Electric Corp completes purchase of Infinity Broadcasting Corp for about $4 billion in stock and $1 billion of assumed assets (S)

headline: Computer software to recognize and sensibly render human speech.
abstract: Technology column explores efforts to get computers to understand and parse documents written in real human language, not the clipped, arcane commands usually used with computers; describes Microsoft Word's Auto Summarize document filter (M)

headline: And the winner of the 'Worst Software Patent of the Year' is, hmm, a certain William H. Gates.
abstract: Gregory Aharonian, editor of Internet Patent News Service, will officially announce his annual Worst Software Patent of the Year award on Feb 17; winner for 1996 is number 5,552,982, a 'method and system for processing fields in a document processor' invented by William H Gates 3d, better known as Bill Gates, chief executive of Microsoft Corp; Peter J Jackson and Bryan Loofbourrow are also listed as inventors; patent itself is assigned to Microsoft (L)

headline: Tide of Albanian Refugees Again Floods Italian Port
abstract: Albanian refugees again flood into Brindisi, Italy, fleeing chaos in their country; Italians fear repeat of 1991, when ferries crammed with thousands of people slipped past authorities and fled to other cities; Italians are keeping close track this time; about dozen Albanian naval vessels have pulled into port, flying flags of surrender and asking asylum (S)

headline: France to Auction Thomson-CSF
abstract: French Government says Thomson-CSF will be auctioned to companies rather than sold to individuals on the stock market (S)

headline: Apple Chief Executive Seeks More Time to Aid Company
abstract: Gilbert F Amelio gives best speech of his one-year tenure as chief executive of Apple Computer Inc, persuading frustrated shareholders to give him more time to turn around troubled computer company (L)

headline: Pennsylvania Bank Deal
abstract: Susquehanna Bancshares Inc agrees to acquire smaller Pennsylvania rival, Founders Bank, in stock swap valued at about $15 million (S)

headline: On Eve of U.N. Rwanda Trials, Reports of Misconduct
abstract: Administrative lapses and misconduct, which UN has been reluctant to face and slow to correct, may endanger outcome of trials by International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda; employees and consultants to tribunal accuse its administrative officers of giving jobs to relatives, friends and lovers who have no qualifications, of discriminating against non-Africans, of making questionable use of tribunal's resources and of delaying disbursing of funds; other allegations cited (M)

headline: Welcoming Arafat, Clinton Rebukes Israel
abstract: Pres Clinton and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat meet at White House, where Clinton delivers mild but relatively rare rebuke of Israel for decision to proceed with construction of thousands of new homes for Jews in East Jerusalem; Clinton says action has created mistrust that could damage peace effort in region; Arafat meets with Sec of State Madeleine K Albright, Treas Sec Robert E Rubin and Brian Atwood, director of Agency for International Development (M)

headline: NORTHWEST IN TALKS TO BUY REGIONAL CARRIER
abstract: Northwest Airlines Corp says it is in talks to buy Express Airlines I Inc, one of its two major regional carriers, from closely held Phoenix Airline Services Inc (S)

headline: ULTRAK ACQUIRING MAKER OF ACCESS CONTROL SYSTEMS
abstract: Ultrak Inc plans to buy Monitor Dynamics Inc for about $25 million (S)

headline: Big Board Record in Short Sales
abstract: New York Stock Exchange reports that number of shares borrowed and sold short has risen above three billion for first time ever; American Stock Exchange says its short position also set record (S)

headline: A CVS-Revco merger would create a drugstore giant
abstract: Market Place article on CVS Corp talks on acquiring Revco DS Inc (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: KMART CORP., Troy, Mich., the discount retailer, said it had completed repaying a $1.2 billion, three-year term loan that was not due until 1999.    ADVANCED NMR SYSTEMS Wilmington, Mass., a provider of diagnostic imaging and rehabilitation services, announced that it now wholly owned MVA Rehabilitation Associates, having purchased the remaining 25 percent of the minority shareholders' interest. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Bankruptcies Up 31% In Buenos Aires in '96
abstract: Credit risk agency Fidelitas SRL says number of companies declaring bankruptcy in Buenos Aires climbed nearly 31 percent, to 1,168, in 1996, compared with 893 in 1995 (S)

headline: Tractebel of Belgium To Buy All of Powerfin
abstract: Tractebel SA, Belgian utility, says it will buy 37 percent share of Powerfin SA it does not already own in transaction valued at $3.42 billion (S)

headline: Correction
abstract: A chart on Dec. 29 with an article about compulsive shoppers referred incorrectly to the incidence of gambling disorders in the United States and used an outdated name for an organization that helps people with gambling problems. Five percent of Americans are thought to be problem gamblers or probable pathological gamblers at some point in their lifetimes; the percentage is not an annual rate. The organization is the National Council on Problem Gambling, formerly the National Council on Compulsive Gambling.

headline: Best Western Narrows Review
abstract: Best Western International Inc has narrowed a review of its account, with billings estimated at $18 million to $20 million, to four finalists; account had been handled for four years by Rogge Effler & Partners in Los Angeles until agency declined to participate in the review (S)

headline: A simple breathing system for do-it-yourselfers and others who deal with noxious fumes.
abstract: John E Kippax receives patent for face mask that filters out noxious vapors from solvents used in the home by hobbyists and do-it-yourselfers; Thomas Gettinger receives patent for device that can be used by cooks to spray viscous substances such as salad dressing and marinades (M)

headline: The Bond Fund Ratings That Ads Can't Trumpet
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers has sided--twice--with Investment Company Institute, mutual fund industry's trade association, in rejecting Standard & Poor's market risk ratings for bond funds largely on basis that ratings might be viewed as predicting fund's behavior, which fund companies are not allowed to do; however, under pressure from Securities and Exchange Commission, NASD is once again taking up the issue; new ratings could well be legitimized and spread beyond small number of fixed-income mutual funds that already have them (M)

headline: Trade Pacts By Regions: Not the Elixir As Advertised
