abstract: Economic analysis of regional trade pacts, which Washington has been promoting since efforts to liberalize world trade stalled in early 1980's; thinking was that regional agreements would prod reluctant nations like Japan and France to drop their opposition to open markets, and also help developing countries lock in free market initiatives and improve climate for foreign investment; there is evidence that regional trade pacts can have harmful effects on those excluded from zone, and may divert substantial trade from more efficient producers outside the region; and some economists worry that Pres Clinton's casual but often repeated equation of trade and warfare is tilting American policy toward economic nationalism, a subtle form of mercantilism that threatens to undermine efforts to knit global economy together (M)

headline: Taiwan Awards Licenses For Cellular Phones
abstract: Taiwan, in bid to make communications market more competitive, awards six cellular telephone licenses to groups backed by some of world's leading telecommunications companies, such as AT&T and Deutsche Telekom; biggest winners are groups led by Pacific Electric Wire & Cable Co, which is backed by GTE Corp, and Far Eastern Textile Ltd, which is backed by AT&T (S)

headline: 'Fed Up' With Criticism, Netanyahu Lashes Out
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, in news conference in Moscow, says he is 'fed up' with accusations that everything he does violates Israeli-Palestinian peace accords (M)

headline: St. Mary's Siberian Sale
abstract: St Mary's Land and Exploration Co completes sale of its stake in Siberian oilfield to Ural Petroleum Corp for as much as $17.2 million (S)

headline: TIDEWATER TO ACQUIRE O.I.L. AND RELATED UNITS
abstract: Tidewater Inc says it has agreed to purchase Ocean Group PLC's O.I.L. Ltd unit and its related international marine operating companies for about $525 million (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Novartis, Basel, Switzerland, to Ruder-Finn, New York, as first creative agency for company formed by merger of Ciba-Geigy and the Sandoz Pharmaceuticals Corp; billings were estimated at $45 million (Advertising column)

headline: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES BUYING SOUTHWEST CAR DEALER
abstract: Republic Industries to buy Grubb Automotive Inc,, an auto dealer, for $100 million in stock; deal continues the plan by Republic to own car dealerships in markets where it is developing its Auto Nation USA chain of used-car lots (S)

headline: A Weakened Yen Also Worries Japanese Industry
abstract: Big Japanese companies, which once complained that strong yen was hurting exports and choking economy, are now concerned that fall of yen to 122 to dollar will have negative impact on economy; would prefer exchange rate between 100 and 110 yen to dollar, level they called unprofitable in 1993; are concerned about link between falling yen and falling stock prices; graph (M)

headline: Jailed Serbs' 'Victims' Found Alive, Embarrassing Bosnia
abstract: Two Muslim brothers whose supposed murders were used as evidence in highly publicized war crimes trial to condemn two Bosnian Serbs to death are found living in Sarajevo suburb; revelation is major embarrassment for Bosnian Govt; finding of brothers raises questions about how guilty verdict was reached; trial of two Serbs, Sretko Damjanovic and Borislav Herak, in March 1993 was first attempt by Sarajevo legal system to try Bosnian Serbs for genocide and other war crimes; case reviewed; photo of Kasim Blekic, one of two Bosnian Muslims for whose 'killing' two Bosnian Serbs were condemned to death (M)

headline: RCN Narrows Review to 3
abstract: RCN, telecommunications services company owned by C-TEC, narrows review of its account to three agencies from eight (S)

headline: Offstage in the Lima Drama, Fearful Families Pray
abstract: In Lima, there are 73 people still being held hostage at residence of Japanese envoy; captives' families wait anxiously for word; former hostages have reported publicly that they had been treated well, even politely, by the guerrillas, but harsher picture has emerged in privatetalks between former hostages and some families; photos (M)

headline: Rebel Forces in Zaire Are Closing on a Crucial City
abstract: Rebels are now poised to capture Kisangani, unofficial capital of eastern Zaire; photo; map; Western diplomat predicts 'victorious road trip' after that, as Pres Mubutu Sese Seko's army collapses; rebel official say they want transitional government for year, and then elections; attacks around Tingi Tingi refugee camp send thousands of Hutus scrambling about; rebels are said to include Rwandan Tutsi fighters bent on revenge for Hutu massacres of 1994; military analysts say unidentified rebel commander is well-schooled strategist who is methodical and impressive in cutting off army (S)

headline: Giant Food Stores Narrows Review
abstract: Giant Food Stores Inc narrows review on its advertising account (S)

headline: South Africa's Foreign Policy: A Tough Balancing Act
abstract: South Africa's foreign policy appears to run on dual tracks, official one in which events are weighed in cold light of history and African National Congress policy, and second one, which consists of whatever Pres Nelson Mandela decides to announce; Mandela usually adheres to Government goals but sometimes pulls abrupt switches; examples include dropping diplomatic recognition of Taiwan in favor of China and lashing out at Nigeria for execution of environmentalists; advocacy of human rights also conflicts with need for money from anywhere; Mandela, commenting on tough line on Nigeria, notes that his moral authority has limits (M)

headline: Peru Police Arrest 2 for Interviewing Rebels
abstract: Peruvian counterterrorism police oficers arrest two Japanese television journalists who slipped around police cordon to interview Tupac Amaru rebels holding 74 hostages in residence of Japanese Ambassador in capital of Lima; Pres Alberto K Fujimori returns to normal routine despite crisis; vows not to give in to terrorist blackmail; photo (M)

headline: Painful Nazi Era Legacy: Hidden Personal Histories of Survivors
abstract: State Sec Madeleine K Albright's discovery that she was of Jewish background and had lost relatives in Holocaust casts light on poignant legacy of Nazi era; thousands of adults in Europe, United States and Russia are discovering, 50 years after war's end, that parents hid Jewishness from children; experts comment (M)

headline: FISERV TO BUY BHC FINANCIAL FOR $211 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: Fiserv Inc agrees to buy BHC Financial Inc, provider of securities processing and other services for financial companies, for about $211 million in stock (S)

headline: Saab Executive Sees Profitability in '99
abstract: Joel K Manby, president of Saab Cars USA Inc, says Saab Automobile AB is relying on introduction of two new models, improvements in way its dealers treat customers and marketing refinements to increase its sales and bring it back into the black; Manby says company should be profitable by 1999, but probably not before then; Saab Automobile lost $170 million last year for its joint owners, General Motors Corp and Investor AB (S)

headline: 6 Years in the Plus Column for the U.S. Economy
abstract: US economic expansion of 1990's, six years old this month, is displaying resilience uncharacteristic of earlier periods of such sustained growth; pace of the economy--surging in some months, faltering a bit in others--has reached annual growth rate of 4 percent in recent months, well above average; unemployment has held below 5.5 percent for better part of a year, an experience that in 1970's and 1980's helped cause wages and prices to escalate; consumer spending remains strong, much of it on credit; industrial production is on the upswing, advancing at nearly a 5 percent annual rate; home construction and auto sales, two pillars of economy, were strong last year; none of renewed strength has led to shortages and inflation that prompted Federal Reserve to bring down past expansions by raising interest rates high enough to starve the economy for credit; what makes this expansion different is that even in its strongest moments inflation has remained quiescent, leaving Fed with little provocation to act; charts (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: In Fine Print, Americans Are Losing Ability to Sue   Americans are increasingly giving up their right to sue, often without realizing that they have done so.

headline: Stocks Retreat Once Again On Rate Fears
abstract: Stock prices decline, as once-buoyant bull market continues to falter on fears of higher interest rates and uncertain earnings growth; Dow Jones industrial average falls for fourth consecutive session, closing down 15.49 points at 6,804.79; for week, Dow loses nearly 2 percent; tables (M)

headline: BOEING PLANS TO REDUCE EFFORTS TO CREATE A LONGER 747
abstract: Boeing Co says it plans to scale back efforts to develop longer version of 747 passenger jet due to insufficient market demand; says it will instead focus on building enhanced versions of its midsize jets; company announces that China Yunnan Airlines has ordered two 737-300 aircraft valued at $68 million (S)

headline: Pilots Reject American Air Labor Pact
abstract: Pilots at American Airlines, in move that catches Wall Street analysts and company by surprise, vote down tentative contract agreement that their union's leaders reached with company in September; deal would have given union members cumulative 5 percent wage increase through year 2000; decision puts on hold huge order for Boeing jets that American announced in November; airline had said at time that order was contingent on approval of contract by membership of Allied Pilots Association (M)

headline: New Name, New Style, But Why?
abstract: Smith Barney Strategic Investors was recently renamed Smith Barney Concert Social Awareness; company says this reflects fund's new policy of investing in socially responsible manner, avoiding tobacco companies, military contractors and nuclear power companies; over all, socially responsible fund investing has been poor choice for long-term investors (M)

headline: Debt Crisis Adds to Woes Of Car Lender
abstract: Bookkeeping scandal at Mercury Finance Co pushes used-auto-loan giant further into financial straits as banks balk at providing new short-term financing to cover $17 million in company's debt that is coming due; shares of Mercury, which had not traded since Tuesday, before accounting irregularities were disclosed, plunge 86% (M)

headline: Do Sales Multiply After a Split?
abstract: Carole Gould (Market Watch) column; items discussed include decision by Michael F Price to slash prices in three popular Mutual Series funds next Friday by splitting stock at close of business that day, creating appearance of bargain; notes Price, not his shareholders, stands to be the big winner; says because fund transactions are usually specified in dollars, split could be nonevent for many investors and split will not affect total value of an investment; Price recently sold Mutual Series to Templeton Fund with whom he has contract (M)

headline: German Insurer Allianz Has 10% Earnings Rise
abstract: Allianz AG says its 1996 profit rose 10 percent, to $1.3 billion, from year ago (S)

headline: Yaohan Unit Plans Sale Of Assets for $79 Million
abstract: Yaohan International Holdings plans to raise $79 million by selling shopping center to its parent, Yaohan International Co, and by selling some other assets elsewhere (S)

headline: Job Insecurity of Workers Is a Big Factor in Fed Policy
abstract: Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan has held off raising interest rates because of job insecurity; in his testimony to Congress, Greenspan clearly elevated this insecurity to major status in central bank policy; he said that workers have been too worried about keeping their jobs to push for higher wages, and this has been sufficient to hold down inflation without added restraint of higher interest rates; graph (L)

headline: Huge Indonesia Gold Strike May Have Been Exaggerated
abstract: Bre-X Minerals, small Canadian company claiming to have made world's righest gold strike in jungles of Indonesia, concedes it may have overestimated size of find; tells its prospective American partner, Freeport-McMoran Copper & Gold, that estimates of between 70 million and 200 million ounces of gold in Busang area of Indonesia may have been inflated because of invalid geologic sampling; Canadian and US stock markets suspend trading in Bre-X's shares, which have soared in price since 1995; disclosure represents additional twist in saga with high political intrigue and fierce corporate power struggles; graph; map (M)

headline: Newly Popular Corporate Investment Banned as Tax Dodge
abstract: Internal Revenue Service bans corporate financing maneuver known as 'fast pay' or 'step down' preferred stock that has exploded in popularity in last month, calling it a tax dodge that threatened a major loss of revenue for the Treasury; action halts billions of dollars of transactions that dozens of companies had hoped to use to borrow money at extremely low cost; anonymous Treasury Department official estimates that as much as $20 billion in such deals had been completed or were underway, arranged by such major investment bankers like Morgan Stanley and Bear, Stearns; Treasury estimates nearly $7 billion in Federal tax revenue would have been lost over 10 years if IRS did not shut down deals already completed or in the works; in 'fast pay' or 'step down' preferred stock deals, companies set up real estate investment trusts to which they arrange to pay tax-deductible interest; the trusts, which are legally entitled to take tax deduction for dividends they pay, are then used to pay dividends to investors, typically tax-exempt organizations; chart (L)

headline: Soybean Prices Are Highest Since 1988 on Supply Worries
abstract: Soybean prices soar to their highest point since 1988 on expectations that Government will report that US reserves will be pushed below seriously depleted level that was forecast last month (M)

headline: Treasury Securities Fall in Price
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities fall; 30-year bond drops 14/32, to price of 97 6/32, pushing yield up to 6.85 percent, from 6.81 percent on March 10; graph (M)ÿ

headline: Thorn to Close Stores and Cut Jobs in Britain To Stop Slide
abstract: Thorn PLC moves to reduce costs as its sales slump; says it will close 90 Radio Rentals stores and cut 360 jobs in Britain and step up promotional efforts in United States aimed at retaining customers at its outlets there (M)

headline: APPLE SOUTH TO PURCHASE TWO RESTAURANT CHAINS
abstract: Apple South Inc is buying two restaurant chains--McCormick & Schmick's and Hops Grill and Bar--for total of about $124.5 million in cash, stock and assumed debt (S)

headline: Tax Court Rejects 'Phantom Loss' by Colgate
abstract: Federal Tax Court rejects as a sham elaborate maneuver devised by Merrill Lynch & Co that enabled Colgate-Palmolive Co to avoid paying taxes on $98 million of gains it made in selling a subsidiary; Colgate maneuver involved setting up partnership, owned by it, ABN-Amro Holding NV, a Dutch bank, and Merrill Lynch; partnership bought some Citibank notes in 1989, then sold most of them later that year; using section of the tax law, it allocated only part of the cost of the notes to the ones sold, thus creating a large paper profit, most of which was allocated to ABN-Amro (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Bridgestone Corp to acquire Fedstone Ltd for $62.3 million; McCormick Canada Inc acquires Canadian Dry Sauce Mix, Gourmet Collection, Potato Flavors and Hamburger Fixin's business from Reckitt & Colman Canada Inc; Union Camp Corp says its Flexible Packaging division will close its plant in Denton, Tex, on March28 and lay off about 128 employees (S)

headline: Offering by France Worth $8.82 Billion
abstract: France Telecom SA says French Government will sell shares in company in May, worth as much as $8.82 billion, in nation's biggest initial public offering ever (S).

headline: Group to Buy A BBC Network
abstract: Group led by Castle Tower Corp, a television antenna manager, and Telediffusion de France win bid to buy British Broadcasting Corp's transmission network for 200 million pounds ($326 million); US-French group beats out bid by International Cabletel Inc (S)

headline: Drop Reported In Companies' Fourth-Quarter Profit Margins
abstract: Commerce Dept reports that profit margins of American companies, reversing course, declined in final months of 1996 as compensation took a slightly bigger bite; although profitability fell only modestly--to 10.4 percent of total output from 10.7 percent in third quarter--it is first decline in year and focuses attention on warning by Federal Reserve chmn Alan Greenspan, who has been cautioning that investors in stocks seem to have been betting on an expanding profitability that probably cannot be achieved; chart (L)

headline: A Quick Guide to Big Ideas, if You Didn't Get to Davos
abstract: *Guide to some of 'big ideas' discussed at World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, for benefit of those who were unable to attend; photo (M)

headline: Frenchman to Be Tried For Nazi War Crimes
abstract: France's highest court orders ex-Government minister Maurice Papon to trial on charges that during German occupation of Bordeaux in World War II, he knowingly deported more than 1,500 Jews to certain death in Nazi camps (S)

headline: The old-media dinosaurs seem to be having a rebirth. Don't blame cloning.
abstract: Technology column notes that old-media companies are looking increasingly attractive as partners to some of more popular sites on World Wide Web; cites CBS's recent purchase of 22 percent stake in Sportsline USA, in exchange for advertising, promotion and programming over five years; says even most successful Internet media companies need backing of established media companies to enlarge their audience and build profitable on-line businesses; drawing (M)

headline: Soybeans Hit 5-Month High As Global Demand Is Strong
abstract: Soybean prices rallied to five-month highs yesterday as strong exports and increased demand from domestic processors threaten to erode lean reserves in the United States.    On other markets, crude oil rose and copper fell.

headline: Israeli Soldier Portrays Himself as Unrepentant Avenger
abstract: Israeli police say that Noam Friedman, 22-year-old military conscript who fired into Hebron marketplace, says he sought to avenge killing of classmate killed by Palestinians and deaths of Rabbi Meir Kahane and Baruch Goldstein, settler who killed Muslims at prayer in Hebron; second soldier, Yuval Jibli, is arrested on suspicion of complicity; Friedman tells court he wanted to prevent surrender of Hebron, burial place of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob; also protests hearing in secular court, before female judge; photos; Israeli army investigates why Friedman was recruited and given weapon, despite history of mental instability; former yeshiva teacher recalls strange behavior; parents express anguish at his actions (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Listing of advertising account changes (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AMERICAN HOMESTAR CORP., Houston, a producer and retailer of manufactured homes, will purchase Brilliant Holding Corp. for about $17.5 million in stock and assumed debt.

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article last Sunday about distributions from retirement plans referred incorrectly to the tax benefit known as five-year forward averaging. A lump-sum distribution is treated as if the income were received over five years, thus lowering the tax owed, but the tax is paid in one year, not five.

headline: WBT HOLDINGS INCREASES ITS BID FOR AMERICAN FILTRONA
abstract: WBT Holdings LLC raises bid for American Filtrona Corp by 8 percent, to about $172 million (S)

headline: Albright and Her French Counterpart Say Glass Is Half Full
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright and Foreign Min Herve de Charette of France meet in Paris and pronounce working truce in differences between both countries; Albright says US wishes to see full integration of France within NATO; says US is respectful of European defense identity within NATO and wishes to work problem out (M)

headline: China Lifts U.N. Veto on Guatemala Monitors
abstract: China lifts veto of plans to send UN military observers to monitor Guatemalan peace accord, allowing Security Council to authorize operation; dispute centered on Guatemala's longstanding ties to Taiwan; Guatemala reportedly agrees to stop pressing Taiwan's cause in UN (S)

headline: Compuserve Chief Steps Down After Troubled Year at Helm
abstract: Compuserve Inc chief executive Robert J Massey resigns; chairman Frank L Salizzoni will temporarily assume his duties; photo (M)

headline: Heating Oil and Crude Oil Climb as Cold Grips Europe
abstract: Futures Markets column; prices of heating oil and crude oil jump in shortened session on expectations that higher European prices, spurred by cold weather and shipping disruptions, could reduce supplies available to United States (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Greenwich Air Services turbine unit, Greenwich Turbine Inc, signs $50 million contract with Senegalese utility to build 50-megawatt gas turbine power station in Dakar, Senegal; Alcatel Alsthom SA telecommunications unit wins orders of approximately $42 million from three Chinese companies for equipment for mobile telephone networks; United Financial Group Inc files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: 1996 changed the way Americans think about stock funds.
abstract: Edward Wyatt (Market Place) column says 1996 certainly transformed how Americans think about mutual funds that invest in the stock market; cites Investment Company Institute figures showing mutual funds that invest in stocks received $223 billion in new cash from investors in 1996, surpassing by more than 70 percent both previous record for annual equity cash flows, set in 1993, at $129.6 billion, and 1995's net inflows of $128.1 billion; says most surprising was degree to which level of fund flows held up in second half of year, even after several bouts of short-term volatility caused net inflows to drop; graph (M)

headline: South Africa Rejects U.S. Warnings on Sale of Arms to Syria
abstract: Pres Nelson Mandela of South Africa rejects United States warning that selling arms to Syria might cause Washington to withdraw millions of dollars in aid; Mandela seems particularly enraged that State Department issued warning in public before talking it over with him; Nicholas Burns, State Department spokesman, says issue was raised privately in Pretoria and in Washington (M)

headline: BANKAMERICA TO BUY BACK $650 MILLION MORE IN STOCK
abstract: BankAmerica Corporation will buy back additional $650 million in common and preferred shares by end of 1998 (S)

headline: Stocks Rebound After Early Selloff in Technology Sector
abstract: Stock prices rose on New York Stock Exchange on February 11 despite early selloff in technology sector; Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 51.57 points to close at 6,858.11 (M)

headline: DRESSER TO SELL SUBMARINE ASSETS TO GLOBAL INDUSTRIES
abstract: Dresser Industries, drilling and energy-services concern based in Dallas, Tex, says its Sub Sea International subsidiary intends to sell some remote-control submarine assets to Global Industries Ltd for $110 million (S)

headline: S.E.C. Investigating Firms In Sale of Municipal Bonds
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co, Smith Barney Inc and Paine Webber Group Inc are being questioned by SEC about whether they overcharged municipalities in bond sales (S)

headline: Russia's New Court Sculptor: Only the Colossal
abstract: Artist Zurab Tsereteli creates monumental sculptures that are transforming landscape of Moscow, and not everyone is happy; his 15-story monument to Peter the Great has city abuzz; Moscow Mayor Yuri M Luzhkov backs monument as bold effort to recover Russia's past glory, but Alexsandr Solzhenitsyn speaks for growing chorus of critics when he derides Tsereteli's monuments as 'a case of Moscow being recklessly disfigured' (M)

headline: DIARY
abstract: Politicians are loathe to state the obvious, that Consumer Price Index, which dictates increases in retirees' checks, badly overstates inflation, costing Government hundreds of billions of dollars; Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman, did say publicly that index should be fixed; photo (S)

headline: REED ELSEVIER TO SELL BOOK UNIT TO RANDOM HOUSE
abstract: Reed Elsevier PLC says it agreed to sell division of its Reed Books publishing unit to Random House Inc (S)

headline: USA WASTE TO BUY CANADIAN UNIT OF WMX
abstract: USA Waste Services Inc agrees to buy most of Canadian solid waste business of Waste Management Inc, unit of WMX Technologies, for about $186 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Rule on Options and Warrants Could Alter Profit Perception
abstract: Financial Accounting Standards Board voted on March 3 to change the names and methods of computation of earnings per share; change is intended to make earnings calculations in US similar to those in most other countries, but the effect will be to make the first number higher for some countries; under the new rule, to take effect on Dec 15, companies will report 'basic' and 'diluted' earnings per share, rather than the current 'primary' and 'fully diluted' figures; difference is in the treatment of stock options, warrants and some convertible securities (L)

headline: A.M.D.'s 4th Quarter Exceeds Expectations
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices Inc, Sunnyvale, Calif, reports fourth-quarter loss of $21.2 million, narrower than expected, compared with earnings of $9.34 million in comparable quarter of 1995 (S)

headline: Palestinian, at U.N., Calls Israeli Plan 'Illegal'
abstract: Nasser al-Kidwa, Palestinian observer at United Nations, opens General Assembly debate on Israel's plan to build Jewish settlement in East Jerusalem by condemning plan as 'illegal' and deploring what he calls 'failure of the Security Council' to pass resolution opposing new construction (M)

headline: French Panel Cites Fraud at Credit Lyonnais
abstract: Finance Committee in France's Parliament says that past instances of fraud have cost Credit Lyonnais, state-controlled bank, as much as 5 billion French francs ($870 million) (S)

headline: Riding Wall St. on Autopilot: Indexed Funds Draw Investors
abstract: Many American investors are deciding that they no longer need expert to find best investments; they are investing in mutual funds whose sole purpose is to mimic performance of stock market; known as index funds, these funds simply hold shares in all companies that make up popular stock market index; these funds run on autopilot, giving up chance to do any better than market average but also guaranteeing that except for nominal cost of running fund, they will do no worse; people who sell index funds say that many investors appear to be full of misconceptions about relative safety of their investment; graphs (M)

headline: Two Marketers Shift Accounts
abstract: Great Western Financial Corp names Bozell Worldwide to handle advertising for Great Western Bank; account, with billings estimated at $15 million, had been at Dailey & Associates; Pathmark Stores Inc names DDB Needham Group to handle its account, which had been at Popofsky Advertising; billings are estimated at $10 million (S)

headline: NOVELL AND NETSCAPE FORM JOINT SOFTWARE VENTURE
abstract: Novell Inc and Netscape Communications Inc say they plan to form new privately held company called Novonyx to adapt, integrate and sell Netscape's Suite Spot server software modified to run on Novell's Intranetware network operating system; Novonyx will be based in Utah and initially employ 80 people (S)

headline: Great Western Accepts Rival Takeover Bid
abstract: Great Western Financial Corp, moving to thwart hostile takeover offer by H F Ahmanson & Co, agrees to be acquired by Washington Mutual for stock worth $6.6 billion in deal that would create country's largest savings and loan institution; combination would give Washington Mutual $87 billion in assets, with 1,193 banking and mortgage offices and 500 consumer finance offices; graph (L)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Bush Brothers & Co., Knoxville, Tenn., to W. B. Doner & Co., Baltimore, to handle the creative assignment for two brands, Bush's baked beans and Chili Magic, with billings estimated at $5 million. Those duties had been handled by Cole Henderson Drake, Atlanta, which resigned. The media duties remain at Media That Works, Cincinnati.

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The Commerce Department reports on personal income and spending for February.    TUESDAY  The National Association of Purchasing Management issues its purchasing managers' index for March.  The Conference Board releases the index of leading indicators for February.  The Commerce Department reports on construction spending for February.  The Federal Communications Commission holds an auction for digital audio radio licenses.    WEDNESDAY  The Commerce Department reports on factory orders for February.    THURSDAY  The Labor Department reports on weekly initial claims for unemployment insurance.    FRIDAY  The Labor Department reports the unemployment rate for March.

headline: MFS EMERGING GROWTH FUND BUYING NEW USA FUND
abstract: MFS Investment Management says its Emerging Growth Fund is acquiring assets of $200 million New USA Growth Fund, created by William O'Neil, founder of Investor's Business Daily; terms of transaction undisclosed (S)

headline: PATRIOT AMERICAN AGREES TO BUY WYNDHAM
abstract: Patriot American Hospitality Inc agrees to buy Wyndham Hotel Corp for estimated $640 million; transaction will allow Patriot American to rename its existing hotels as Wyndhams and eliminate franchise fees (S)

headline: Flat Christmas Sales Spur Fall in Toys 'R' Us Shares
abstract: Shares of Toys 'R' Us Inc fall 14.6 percent after company says its Christmas sales were flat, and that its fourth-quarter earnings will suffer; Michael Goldstein, company's chief executive, attributes weakness to lack of software titles for new video products and shortened selling season (M)

headline: Mastercard undertakes a review and Ammirati Puris, as it often does, says, 'No thanks.'
abstract: Mastercard International puts advertising account in review; Ammirati Puris Lintas, which handled creative part of account, declines to take part in review; Mastercard cites efforts to bolster brand position (M)

headline: Electronic Discovery Proves an Effective Legal Weapon
abstract: Electronic mail, draft documents and phone-mail messages that have been 'deleted' are often preserved in computer hard drives and on back-up tapes, waiting for discovery by lawyers seeking anything they can use to support their clients' claims and defenses or to discredit adversaries' witnesses; lawyers say that electronic discovery in legal cases has become a mini-industry, with the discovery process itself having increasing impact on outcome of litigation; simply the threat of enduring electronic discovery may prompt large company with hundreds of thousands, even millions, of documents to settle; this puts judges in bind, torn between wanting to give party access to relevant information and trying to minimize burden of discovery; photo (M)

headline: Christian Rebels Wage a War of Terror in Uganda
abstract: Lord's Resistance Army, Ugandan rebel group, has stepped up violent campaign to overthrow Pres Yoweri Museveni, who vowed year ago to wipe rebels out; rebels' war consists mainly of killing civilians, sowing terror in countryside and making it appear to Ugandans and outside world that central Government cannot control nation; rebels have killed at least 400 people in districts of Kitgum and Gulu since Jan; Western diplomats say rebels have little popular support and survive mostly on charity of Sudan, where their leader Joseph Kony holds court; map; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   9.00        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.31   5.37   5.53        3-MO. headline: In China's Far West, Tensions With Ethnic Muslims Boil Over in Riots and Bombings
abstract: Determined Muslim minority in western China has begun to reassert its demands for greater autonomy--even independence--from its Chinese rulers; recent bomb attacks in Urumuqi and rioting in Yining are only latest signs of rebellion against Beijing's campaign to keep country's 20 million Muslims under tight control; 5 people were killed and 60 wounded when terrorists bombed three buses in Xinjiang on Feb 26; map; photo (M)

headline: Boeing eliminates a program, and its investors are happy.
abstract: Decision by Boeing Co to scrap multibillion-dollar plan to develop two larger, longer-range versions of 747 jetliner discussed (Market Place) (M)

headline: Income Up at Morgan and Nationsbank
abstract: Several of the largest American banks, including J P Morgan & Co and Nationsbank Corp, say their earnings rose strongly in the fourth quarter; J P Morgan reports fourth-quarter net income of $419 million, from $366 million in last three months of 1995; Nationsbank says its net income for fourth quarter totaled $632 million, from $510 million in corresponding period last year; earnings charts (M)

headline: St. Joe Hires Executive From Disney
abstract: St Joe Corp's shares rise 16 percent after company hires Walt Disney Co executive, Peter Rummell, as chairman and chief executive to direct its switch to real estate company from paper producer (S)

headline: WORLD COLOR PRESS TO ACQUIRE RAND MCNALLY UNIT
abstract: World Color Press Inc to acquire Rand McNally Book Services Group, unit of Rand McNally & Co, for undisclosed terms (S)

headline: Pope's Easter Message Assails Hatred in World Trouble Spots
abstract: Pope John Paul II delivers annual Easter message from St Peter's Square in Rome; assails human discord in somber yet passionate homily; photo (M)

headline: In East Jerusalem, a Tale of 2 Neighborhoods
abstract: Umm Tuba, crowded Palestinian village in East Jerusalem, has lost part of its land for new Jewish neighborhood; contrast between village and new neighborhood of 6,500 apartments, Har Homa, which was recently approved for construction by Israeli Government, reflects wide gaps in development between Jerusalem's Arab and Jewish sections; map; photo (M)

headline: Egyptian Company to Buy Stake in Israeli Concern
abstract: Egypt's Kato Industries to purchase holding in Israel's Koor Industries (S)

headline: What Is a Grammy Worth?
abstract: Performing on the Grammy Awards show appears to do more for record sales than receiving an award does; graphs of winners' and performers' album sales in weeks following 1996 award show; photo (M)

headline: Mexican Data Suggest 30% Overstatement of Oil Reserves
abstract: Petroleos Mexicanos, Mexican state oil monopoly, releases data that suggest it has overstated its proven crude oil reserves by some 30 percent or more since late 1970's; Mexico apparently seeks to lay to rest long controversy over true size of its readily extractable petroleum wealth; independent experts, welcoming Mexico's new candor, say figures should have little immediate impact on Mexican oil prices or exports to United States (M)

headline: HOME DEPOT PLANS TO BUY MAINTENANCE WAREHOUSE
abstract: Home Depot Inc says it will buy Maintenance Warehouse/America Corp, direct-mail marketer of maintenance and repair supplies; terms of stock transaction are not disclosed (S)

headline: Heresy Brings Hint of Martyrdom to Sri Lanka Priest
abstract: Before Roman Catholic Church excommunicated Rev Tissa Balasuriya for heresy, few Catholics outside his native Sri Lanka had ever heard of him or his offending book, Mary and Human Liberation, which sold all of 600 copies; Balasuriya argues that Catholic dogma should adjust itself to social and cultural realities of Asia (M)

headline: Hebron Negotiations Are Still Deadlocked
abstract: Stalemate between Israel and Palestinians over deadlines for future Israeli withdrawals from West Bank persists, despite continued efforts by US to find compromise (S)

headline: A Top-10 List Not Too Many Care to Be On
abstract: California Public Employees Retirement System is set to release list of 10 target companies for 1997, firms in its indexed portfolio whose stocks have performed worst compared to industry peers over long term; will seek to press management and directors for change and sponsor shareholder resolutions and proxy contests if companies do not respond; list includes Apple Computer and Reebok International (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Comerica Inc., Detroit, to Fahlgren Inc., Columbus, Ohio, to handle its account, which had been handled by various local agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $3.5 million.

headline: Bull Market Worried Fed In December
abstract: Federal Reserve policy makers were unusually concerned about stock prices during their December 1996 meeting about two weeks after Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan questioned whether 'irrational exuberance' had inflated valuations; though members of Federal Open Market Committee voted unanimously on Dec 17 to keep interest rates steady, minutes of the December meeting showed that deliberations had been made more difficult by long boom in stock prices to levels they called 'extraordinary'; meeting took place 12 days after Greenspan's comments, which touched off sharp but fleeting skid in stock market on the fear they were a precursor to higher interest rates (L)

headline: German Unemployment Soars, Worsening Choices for Kohl
abstract: Number of jobless German workers soared by nearly half a million in January, to 4.66 million, an unexpectedly steep rise in what had already been Germany's highest unemployment since World War II; new figures startle economists and pose new problems for Chancellor Helmut Kohl, whose popularity has slumped to new lows in recent months and whose Cabinet ministers have engaged in open warfare with one another; overall unemployment rate in Germany climbed to 12.2 percent from 10.8 percent in December, and it is nearly 19 percent in formerly Communist eastern region (L)

headline: Y.& R. Promotes Two Executives
abstract: Young & Rubicam Advertising's New York office names Stephanie Kugelman vice chairwoman, managing director and executive committee co-chairwoman; names June Blocklin business development director (S)

headline: Peru Pledges to Reopen Talks With Rebels
abstract: Peruvian Pres Alberto K Fujimori, following meeting with Japanese Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto in Toronto, agrees to reopen formal talks with rebels to find peaceful solution to hostage crisis in Lima, but he rules out meeting demands for release of rebel prisoners; photo (M)

headline: WHAT HAPPENED: Latin America Grows
abstract: All major Latin American economies have embraced market reforms and growth is expected to improve. Trade increased throughout the region. Question marks include whether Brazil will allow its president, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, to run for a second term, and if Argentina will emerge from recession.

headline: U.S. Civil Jury Traces Ex-Mexico Aide's Millions to Drug Bribes
abstract: Jury in Houston decides that most of $9 million confiscated from Mario Ruiz Massieu, former coordinator of Mexico's drug program, came from traffickers' bribes; verdict endorses United States Government assertions that Mexico's cocaine cartels paid millions of dollars to Ruiz Massieu to allow drug shipments to move north to United States unimpeded; Ruiz Massieu has not been formally charged with drug crimes; but he is highest-ranking Mexican official ever publicly accused in court by US Government of narcotics-related activities; Ruiz Massieu's case was traced to December 1993, when he opened account in Houston bank and sent aide there 24 times in 15 months, carrying duffel bags stuffed with cash; funds were seized after Government ruled they were probably drug proceeds (M)

headline: Muslim Party Gets Huge Margin in Pakistan's Parliament
abstract: Muslim League, led by Nawaz Sharif, overwhelms party led by dismissed Prime Min Benazir Bhutto in Pakistan's general election, winning almost two-thirds majority in Parliament; new anti-corruption party that challenged two major parties fails to win any seats; Sharif, dismissed as Prime Min in 1993 on corruption and misrule charges, comments on victory; Bhutto charges election fraud, but says she will not lead mass protests because Pakistan needs stability, news conference; photo (M)

headline: Rising Dollar Has U.S. Executives a Bit Concerned
abstract: American companies are concerned about impact of dollar's rise against Japanese yen and German mark on their competitiveness, sales and profits; even forecasters who expect little change in dollar in 1997 see further rise toward end of century; graphs (M)

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: HI-LO AUTOMOTIVE INC., Houston, said the Hwang Family L.P., the holder of a 9.8 percent stake in Hi-Lo, had proposed forming a committee to search for a potential buyer of the company.    ALLTEL CORP., Little Rock, Ark., received a seven-year, $276 million contract from the Australian insurance company Colonial Ltd. to create and operate an information and telecommunications system.    BOSTON SCIENTIFIC CORP., Natick, Mass., a manufacturer of medical products, is closing its plant in Stenlose, Denmark, affecting about 240 employees.     HASBRO INC., Pawtucket, R.I., said its board declared a 3-for-2 stock split payable on March 21 to shareholders of record on March 7. It also increased its quarterly cash dividend by 20 percent.
