headline: Columbia/HCA Agrees to Buy Value Health for $1.3 Billion
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, nation's largest health care provider, adds to its expanding network of hospitals, clinics and managed-care operations by agreeing to buy Value Health Inc for $1.3 billion (L)

headline: Martin F. Jones, 84, Ex-Director Of Britain's Counterspy Agency
abstract: Sir Martin Furnival Jones, who headed British security apparatus when Western fears of Soviet penetration were at their obsessive cold war zenith, dies at age of 84 (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: ABC News Acts to Prepare A Successor to Arledge   ABC said that it was creating a new position for Roone Arledge, left, the longtime president of its news division, in a move to prepare a successor to him at that operation, which has faced legal and competitive challenges.    Mr. Arledge was named chairman of ABC News, while David Westin, who had been president of the ABC network, was named president of news. In an unusual reversal, Mr. Westin will now report to Mr. Arledge, who had reported to Mr. Westin.   $(Page D2.$)    ITT to Sell Stake in Garden   ITT said it had agreed to sell its half interest in Madison Square Garden, which includes the arena, the New York Knicks, the Rangers and the MSG network, to its partner, Cablevision Systems, for $650 million.   $(A1.$)

headline: British Company to Add Stake in a Mexican Bank
abstract: HSBC Holdings PLC signs agreement in principle to acquire 19.9 percent stake in Grupo Financiero Serfin of Mexico in deal likely to approach $300 million (S)

headline: ADT vs. Chase: Testing Limits Of Bank's Role In Takeovers
abstract: ADT Inc lawsuit against Chase Manhattan Bank contends that bank violated fiduciary and contractual obligations by allying itself with Western Resources in its $3.5 billion hostile bid for ADT; legal wrangling between ADT and Chase may well portend pitfalls that await those commercial banks that are aggressively moving into Wall Street's domain, providing investment banking services, merger advice and underwriting, as well as loans (M)

headline: Robert Lampman, 76, Economist Who Helped in War on Poverty
abstract: Robert J Lampman, leading researcher on poverty, dies at 76; photo (S)

headline: Outlook '97
abstract: The 90's so far have been marked by slow but steady economic growth and a strong stock market. Has the business market been tamed? How long can the bull market last? Business Day's annual survey of the economy, markets and industry, including year-end stock tables, begins on page C1.    The Home Section begind today on page C37 and The Arts on page B13. Television listings, page B24.

headline: Edwin Sutherland, 82, Soldier and Scholar, Is Dead
abstract: Brig Gen Edwin Van Valkenberg Sutherland, soldier and scholar who was one of first Americans to start fighting Germans in World War II and among the last to quit, dies on Jan 6 at age 82; photo (M)

headline: Treasury's List Of Auctions Limited to Bills
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.08 percent and on the six-month bill, 5.19 percent.

headline: AT&T Profit Rises but Bill Payments Lag
abstract: AT&T reports fourth-quarter income from continuing operations rose 14.2 percent, to $1.24 billion; reports fourth quarter net income was $1.62 billion, compared to loss of $2.68 billion a year earlier (M)

headline: 2 Brokerages In Insurance To Join Forces
abstract: Two giant New York insurance brokerages, Marsh & McLennan Companies and Johnson & Higgins, announce that they are merging; $1.8 billion deal will make combined company the world's largest insurance broker; merger will create a firm with more than $5.3 billion in annual revenue; Marsh & McLennan says it will pay one-third of $1.8 billion purchase price in cash and balance in stock; table (L)

headline: Agency Changes For 2 Marketers
abstract: Two consumer marketers are changing agencies: Budget Rent A Car names Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston to handle its account; Friendly Ice Cream Corp names Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners, New York, to create most important ad project for its Friendly's restaurant chain (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Data Service's Users Not Told Of Other Lines
abstract: America Online made little or no effort to inform subscribers unable to connect to service via clogged new phone lines in recent weeks that they could use older, lesser-used lines; must pay fee to outside carriers if subscribers use their lines instead of firm's own network; use of outside lines could also add to burden on AOL's computer system; David A Gang, AOL vice president, says it would not help customers to have list of access numbers on phone network run by Sprint Corp (M)

headline: Treasury Securities' Prices Rise
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities rise on bond markets on January 14; bellwether 30-year bond gains 31/32, to 96 19/31, yielding 6.77 percent; graph (M)

headline: EL PASO ENERGY TELLS OF $157 MILLION BUENOS AIRES DEAL
abstract: El Paso Energy Corp will acquire 29 percent stake in Capsa SA, Argentine energy concern, for $157 million (S)

headline: Israel to Yield 9% More of West Bank; a Victory for Netanyahu
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu meets with Cabinet into the night, and wins agreement to withdraw in varying degrees from further nine percent of West Bank, total is more than had been projected by some ministers; two percent of affected land would shift from exclusive Israeli control to Israeli-Palestinian control, and seven percent would go from joint to Palestinian control; lands under joint control are essentially closed to Israeli settlement (S)

headline: The Work-at-Home Executive
abstract: Letter by Elizabeth Bello on Jan 12 article on executives being able to work at home which featured Mike Zisman, former chief executive of Lotus Development Corp; says if Zisman were woman it is probable that few companies would create such work arrangement, even at such high level of management (S)

headline: Accidental Author: From Doily Maker to Literary Light
abstract: Article profiles 98-year-old Jessie Lee Brown Foveaux,' whose memoir, The Life Of Jesse Lee Brown From Birth Up To Age 80, has made her nation's latest literary sensation; publication rights were bought by Warner Books for more than $1 million following article on life story in Wall Street Journal; book describes quietly heroic struggles of woman to win independence while in bitter marriage to alcoholic; photos (M)

headline: Red Cross Suspends Aid To Hostages Held in Lima
abstract: Red Cross, for second time this week, suspends services to hostages being held in Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima after security forces crossed a boundary they had promised to respect (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Banc One Seen in Deal To Acquire First USA   Banc One is expected to announce today that it has reached an agreement to buy First USA, one of the fastest growing credit card issuers in the country, for about $7 billion, people familiar with the transaction said.    Banc One is offering about $52 a share for First USA, a premium of about 41 percent over its closing stock price on Friday. The deal would vault Banc One to rank third in the credit card market, after Citicorp and MBNA, with $33 billion in credit card loans. $(Page D2.$)    U.S. Wins Round in Dispute   The United States appears to have won an important skirmish with Canada over trade restrictions on cultural products like magazines. $(D8.$)    Energy Secretary's Valedictory   The price of energy is artificially depressed in the United States, Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary said on the eve of her departure from office, and Americans will not be serious about conservation until the price goes up. $(B6.$)    Mobile-Phone Use Surges in Japan   Japan has almost overnight become one of the world's fastest-growing markets for mobile telephones, with more than one million new subscribers signing up each month, or one every two seconds. $(D5.$)    End to Limits on P.X.'s Is Sought   The Pentagon may lift the last restrictions on what post exchanges can sell, arguing that small businesses near military bases, which those rules had been intended to protect, have mostly succumbed to large chains. $(A10.$)    High Technology's Rural Benefits   Some of the strongest Congressional advocates of communications technology come from places where the valleys are made not of silicon but of old-fashioned soil. They think that the information revolution may be the best hope for economic development in their rural districts. $(D5.$)    A Silicon Valley for Asia   Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, has visited Silicon Valley companies, asking them to join an ambitious, and similar, effort in his country. $(D4.$)    A TV Channel's Two Faces   By day, WBIS in New York dresses up with business-oriented programs from the domain of one owner, Dow Jones. By night, it loosens its tie to cover sports, the preserve of the other owner, ITT. $(D7.$)     Lights, Camera, Backhoe   After 40 years in which movie and television sound stages were torn down for real estate development, the Los Angeles area is at the beginning of a stage-building boom. $(D7.$)    Just Browsing? Sorry.   With programs called catchers, whackers, finders, savers and casters, a nascent industry is trying to create a new model for use of the Internet, replacing the browsers. Edward Rothstein: Technology. $(D5.$)    $1 Million Worth of Support?   If the three supporting stars of the NBC hit comedy ''Seinfeld'' get the $1 million per episode they are said to have asked for, the economics of the television industry could become more and more problematic. What, for instance, would Tim Allen, left, of ''Home Improvement,'' be worth? Bill Carter: Broadcasting. $(D7.$)    Bond Market Is Closed   The Treasury bond market and most American banks will be closed today in observance of the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. But the stock market and most commodity markets will be open.

headline: People
abstract: * Gregory Spector, executive vice president at GCI Group, San Francisco, a unit of Grey Advertising , was promoted to president, succeeding Joseph W. Jennings, who is leaving to start a venture capital partnership.

headline: In Pacific Race to Usher In Millennium, a Date-Line Jog
abstract: Tiny Pacific island nation of Kiribati decrees eastward bend in international date line so that it goes around Kiribati and makes it first place to see start of next century; other claimants from Tonga to New Zealand to Fiji, all hoping to welcome revelers, cry foul; rivals sit near line marking 180 degrees longitude, which date line zigs and zags around; map (S)

headline: As Value Falls, PBHG Funds Suffer a Wave of Redemptions
abstract: PBHG Funds, one of best-performing mutual fund companies of 1990's, has suffered wave of shareholder redemptions of more than 6 percent of company's assets in recent weeks as performance of its funds has dropped sharply (M)

headline: Swiss Envoy to U.S. Resigns After His Report on Holocaust Dispute Is Disclosed
abstract: Switzerland's Amb to US Carlo Jagmetti resigns after publication of diplomatic cable in which he advised his Government to make up its mind about how to deal with disclosures about its role as banker to Nazi Germany, and concluded with warning that this is war which Switzerland must win; Jagmetti photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Christian Science Monitor, published by the Christian Science Publishing Society, Boston, to Kelley/Dexter Advertising, Boston, to handle its account, which had been handled on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million.    * Emory University System of Health Care, Atlanta, to Ender Partners, Atlanta, to handle its account, which had been handled on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

headline: Jean-Dominique Bauby, 44; Wrote by Blinks
abstract: Jean-Dominique Bauby, French journalist who wrote book by blinking after he was almost completely paralyzed by a stroke, died on March 9, less than a week after book was published; he was 44 (S)

headline: Amre, Home Remodeling Concern, to File for Bankruptcy
abstract: Amre Inc, home improvement and remodeling company, will file for bankruptcy protection; HFS Inc moves to terminate licensing agreement for Amre's use of Century 21 name (S)

headline: Casting a Wider Net For Web Site Workers
abstract: Demand for people to manage corporate World Wide Web sites has far outstripped supply as number of Web sites has tripled, to 300,000, since last year; companies are recruiting computer-savvy workers right out of college, even high school in some cases; Web-related positions are paying over $46,000, compared to $36,400 salary for computer graphics artist and $42,600 for programmer (M)

headline: Dow Plunges 160.48 While Rates Jump
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average plummets 160.48 points, or 2.3 percent, to close at 6,878.89; drop in stock prices is widespread, with declining stocks beating advancers by almost 4 to 1 on New York Stock Exchange; Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks loses 14.70 points, or 1.8 percent, to 789.56, and Nasdaq composite is off 10.85 points, to 1,293.28; Nasdaq 100 index gains 1.93, to 840.50 (L)

headline: Tele-Communications Chief Gives Up President's Post
abstract: Board of Tele-Communications Inc appoints Leo J Hindery Jr president, title that was previously held by John C Malone, chairman and chief executive; in recent years, Malone has withdrawn from daily management, leaving that responsibility with Brendan Clouston, president of company's giant cable operations; photo of Malone (M)

headline: Times Co. Lifts Profit Forecast; Nominates 2 Executives to Board
abstract: The New York Times Co says it expects first-quarter earnings to be sharply higher from year earlier and well above analysts' estimates; cites higher advertising revenues at its print and broadcast operations and lower newsprint prices; company also announces that Russell T Lewis, president and chief operating officer, and Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr, publisher of The Times, have been nominated to run for election as directors at annual meeting; says three board members will not seek re-election: Louis V Gerstner Jr, Marian S Heiskell and Cyrus R Vance (M)

headline: Clear Channel Agrees to Buy Eller Media
abstract: In a side step out of its core radio business, Clear Channel Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Eller Media Corporation, a closely held outdoor advertising company, for $1.15 billion in cash and stock.     The transaction, which analysts said had been rumored for weeks, was announced after the stock market close. Earlier, shares of Clear Channel rose $2.25, or 5.4 percent, to $44.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: New Chief Named At Unit of Havas
abstract: Havas Advertising names Bob Schmetterer chairman and chief executive of its Euro RSCG Worldwide unit; he succeeds Alain Cayzac, named Havas vice chairman (S)

headline: Bonds Ease on New Talk Of an Interest-Rate Increase
abstract: Treasury securities prices fall; 30-year Treasury bond drops 5/32, to 95 29/32, to yield 6.95; graph (M)

headline: For Bedouin, Peace Has a Bitter Taste
abstract: Israel evicts Jahalin, Bedouin tribe, from Maaleh Adumin on West Bank to make way for expansion of sprawling Israeli settlement; explusion marks end of years-long legal dispute between tribe and Israeli authoritries over their right to remain on land they say has been home for more than 40 years; families have been resettled on rock-strewn hillside in Al Eizariya; map (M)

headline: U.S. Balloonist Trying a Circumnavigation Conquers the Atlantic
abstract: Steve Fossett, some 64 hours after launching his balloon from Busch Stadium in St Louis, reaches Portuguese coast after speedy crossing of Atlantic (M)

headline: Netcom's New Price Model Tailors Internet Services
abstract: Netcom On-Line Communication Services Inc, Internet access provider, offers range of new, higher-priced service packages aimed at business customers; has been phasing out flat-rate pricing model (M)

headline: Grey, surprised by Domino's, rejects the pizza chain's account rather than compete to regain it.
abstract: Advertising column discusses Grey Advertising's decision to resign from Domino's Pizza Inc account after Domino's unexpectedly announced that it would begin review on its national account; Grey's chairman, Edward H Meyer, notes Domino had its best sales and profits, and Grey received many awards for its Domino ads; says under those circumstances, there was no point in competing to retain account; Domino executives attribute Grey's departure to philosohical differences (M)

headline: Secretary of State Sells Foreign Policy at Home
abstract: Madeleine K Albright takes her first trip at Secretary of State, visiting Houston, Texas, where State Dept has offices; she visits a high school, where she tells students that foreign policy can not only be 'cool' but it can be 'awesome'; meets Mexico's Foreign Min, Jose Angel Gurria; she also visits Rice University, where an institute is named after one of her predecessors, James A Baker 3d; photo (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Centerior Energy  Oxford Inds    TUESDAY  NONE REPORTED    WEDNESDAY  US Life Income Fd    THURSDAY  Ford Mtr    FRIDAY  NONE REPORTED

headline: Deaths in the Workplace: Looking Beyond the Numbers
abstract: Letter by David Durbin and Richard J Butler on Dec 22 article examining deaths of 13 American workers in single day last fall (M)

headline: Bonds Retreat As Economy Shows Muscle
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities are battered again and remain near session lows; 30-year bond drops 11/32, to price of 97 14/32 to yield 6.83 percent, up from 6.80 percent on Feb 28, and highest yield level since Jan 30, when it was 6.86 percent; graph (L)

headline: British Payments Surplus In Last Quarter of '96
abstract: Britain posts current account balance of payments surplus of 873 million pounds ($1.4 billion) for 1996 fourth quarter, compared with revised deficit of 293 million pounds in third quarter (S)

headline: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES BUYS YORK WASTE DISPOSAL
abstract: Republic Industries Inc acquires York Waste Disposal Inc for $40 million in stock (S)

headline: BELLSOUTH TO ACQUIRE WIRELESS CABLE OF ATLANTA
abstract: BellSouth Corp agrees to buy Wireless Cable of Atlanta for $46.9 million in stock (S)

headline: America Online Reaches Big Marketing Deal With Tel-Save
abstract: America Online Inc. announced yesterday that it had reached a $100 million marketing deal with Tel-Save Holdings Inc., a reseller of long-distance telephone service.    The marketing pact, analysts say, is solid evidence of America Online's new business plan to rely more on on-line commerce and advertising revenues and less on subscriber fees.

headline: SAP Says Net Was Up 40% in 1996
abstract: SAP AG, maker of business management software, says that 1996 net profit rose 40%; pretax profit in fourth quarter soared to 457 million marks ($280 million) from 289 million marks, in part because companies bought SAP software to help cope with switch to European common currency in 1999; net profit in 1996 rose to 567 million marks ($348 million) (S)

headline: Head of Daimler Unit Resigns as Germany's Biggest Firm Regroups : Mercedes Chief Out in Power Struggle
abstract: FRANKFURT—  A months-long power struggle between the two most powerful men at Daimler-Benz AG, Germany's biggest industrial company, ended Thursday when Helmut Werner resigned as chairman of Mercedes-Benz AG, Daimler's profitable luxury-car and truck division.

headline: Doing the Right Thing in a Capital Gains Vacuum
abstract: Investors face difficulties in preparing for possible cut in capital gains tax rate in face of differences in plans favored by Clinton Administration and Congressional Republicans; are uncertain whether to sell at high current stock prices or risk waiting for tax cut that could itself have negative effect on prices; graph (M)

headline: A Black Joins Merrill Lynch's Top Ranks
abstract: E Stanley O'Neal is named executive vice president and co-head of Merrill Lynch's corporate and institutional client group, becoming one of most senior African-Americans on Wall Street; says he finds it 'bothersome' that people focus on his race; photo (M)

headline: Dow Up 100, But Late Rally Skips Nasdaq
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 100.46 points, to 6,905.25 on New York Stock Exchange trading volume of 452 million shares; table (M)

headline: Mexican Can Sue U.S.
abstract: Federal appeals court, San Francisco, rules Mexican physician, Humberto Alvarez Machain who was seized by bounty hunters and brought to trial in US for alleged participation in torture and killing of American drug agent Enrique Camarena in 1985, can sue Federal Government; Alvarez Machain was acquitted of all charges in 1992 (S)

headline: A Tale of 2 Economists: Sizing Up the Income Gap
abstract: Ernest J Oppenheimer letter on Louis Uchitelle's Feb 16 article on contrasting views of economists Paul Krugman and Lester Thurow, particularly their explanations for growth of income inequality in United States (S)

headline: The Summer Movie Magic Award
abstract: Description of challenges faced by visual effects artists, producers and technicians who worked on several movies up for Academy Awards this year; photos (M)

headline: CHICAGO REIT PAYING $227.5 MILLION FOR 12 PROPERTIES
abstract: Equity Residential Properties Trust acquires 12 apartment properties for total of $227.5 million (S)

headline: Pilots and Mechanics Reach Wage Deal at United
abstract: United Airlines reaches tentative settlement with its pilots and mechanics that gives owner-employees the largest salary and benefit increases permitted under arbitrator's ruling; wages will rise 5 percent this July and in July 1998, and company contributions to pension plans will be raised to 9 percent from 1 percent; pilots are represented by Airline Pilots Association and mechanics are represented by International Association of Machinists District 141 (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Home Resales Jump 9%, Exceeding Expectations  Home resales jumped 9 percent in February, to an annual rate of 4.26 million, the second-highest level on record, the National Association of Realtors said. Sales exceeded expectations and were bolstered by unusually mild weather and continued job creation.

headline: On Russian TV, Sincerest Form of Frivolity
abstract: Several new situation comedies have begun airing in Russia, representing radical shift in Russian broadcasting; Western-style shows are made in Russia for purely Russian audience, reflecting expanding advertising revenues, rising costs of imported programming and rapidly growing number of television stations; also reflect disaffection with West and growing nostalgia for Russian popular culture; photos (M)3

headline: U.S. Expands Search of Columbia/HCA in Texas
abstract: Federal investigators widen search of Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, seizing documents from doctors in El Paso area who are affiliated with its local hospitals; search warrants have been issued by Federal Bureau of Investigation, Internal Revenue Service and Dept of Health and Human Services; Defense Dept's Criminal Investigation Service has also reportedly joined inquiry; Government has not disclosed nature of probe, but agencies involved indicate that focus may be on Government health care payment programs such as Medicare, Medicaid and Champus, insurance program for military personnel; Columbia says it believes investigation is limited to El Paso, but law enforcement officials say privately that probe is proceeding in other cities where Columbia does business (M)

headline: Nicholas Hinton, Aid Official, 54; Worked in Bosnia And Sierra Leone
abstract: Nicholas Hinton, president of International Crisis Group, dies at age 54; photo (M)

headline: BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB CO. (BMY,N)
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co reports earnings of $716 million, or $1.43 a share, in fourth quarter, after net loss of $142 million, or 28 cents a share year earlier (S)

headline: Stocks End Day Mixed; Dow Up 4.24
abstract: Stocks close mixed despite broad selloff in technology sector; Dow Jones industrial average closes up 4.24 points, at 6,931.62; table (M)

headline: But Today's Dandies More Fake Than Real : Decadence Comes Back Into Style
abstract: PARIS—  Excess is its own reward, of course, and the more wretched the better. With the usual glossy fashion magazines full of vulnerable looking children — of both sexes — with come-hither poses and heroin-addict palor, with ads for big-name designers projecting debauchery, wanton luxury and perhaps worst of all stupidity, has fashion reached some kind of ultimate decadence?

headline: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES ADDS 2 DEALER GROUPS TO AUTO CHAIN
abstract: Republic Industries agrees to buy Chesrown Automotive Group and Bankston Enterprises for $104 million in stock, latest expansion of H Wayne Huizenga's chain of new-car dealerships (S)

headline: Applied Magnetics Begins $1.76 Billion Read-Rite Bid
abstract: Applied Magnetics Corp says it has offered to buy rival Read-Rite Corp for $1.76 billion in stock in effort to create one of leading computer disk head suppliers in country; says it started hostile offer after friendly talks with Read-Rite had ground to a halt (M)

headline: Going to Great Lengths To Get From Point A to B
abstract: There has already been a lot of booking and rebooking, as travel agents scramble to find creative solutions for getting clients from point A to point B in the event of a strike by pilots at American Airlines; table; photo (L)

headline: 3Com Plans To Acquire U.S. Robotics
abstract: 3Com Corp will acquire US Robotics Corp in $6.6 billion stock swap that would create second-largest computer networking company; acquisition would strengthen 3Com's hand against competitors, particularly Cisco Systems Inc, leader in computer networking, by broadening its product line (L)

headline: Crispin Porter Gets Time Assignment
abstract: Time magazine names Crispin Porter & Bogusky to handle television campaign to increase awareness of publication in Latin America; billings estimated at $1 million (S)

headline: Barnett Is Offering $570 Million To Acquire Oxford Resources
abstract: Barnett Banks Inc agrees to acquire Oxford Resources Corporation, largest automobile leasing company in US, for about $570 million in stock (S)

headline: Chapman Wins Six Caples Awards
abstract: Chapman Agency takes top honors, winning most awards, at annual presentation of John Caples International Awards for direct marketing (S)

headline: WHAT HAPPENED: Apple Fights for Survival
abstract: Apple Computer, long the daring of America's vibrant technology industry, had a painful year, losing more than $800 million as it struggled against the dominance of Microsoft's Windows. Apple outsed its chief executive and flirted with a merger. In the end, it went back to its roots, buying Next Software and bringing back Stephen P. Jobs, one of its charismatic founders.

headline: Times Mirror Gives Options to Workers
abstract: Times Mirror Inc to award options for 100 shares to eligible employees as reward for firm's fiscal 1996 performance (S)

headline: Russian Emigres Run Afoul of Stock Regulators
abstract: Law enforcement agencies and securities regulators are seeking to put out of business small but persistent group of Russian emigre stock brokers that Government charges is using strong-arm sales tactics and outlandish promises to sell shares in dubious enterprises to unwitting investors, many of them from Russia; regulators in Washington and around the country have brought enforcement cases against loosely linked community of Russian individuals and firms based in New York and California; in one case New York Attorney General has temporary restraining order served in San Diego on companies run by Vladislav Steven Zubkis, who state officials say owns unlicensed brokerage firm that pushes unregistered stock he controls; case follows shortly indictment in New York of Igor Shektman of Enciono, Calif, who helped more than dozen men get securities licenses by taking their exams for them; Shektman photo (L)

headline: Maidenform aims for soccer moms and just about everyone else.
abstract: Maidenform is engaging in ambitious marketing makeover for its line of women's brassieres, thongs, panties and other so-called intimate apparel; campaign carrying theme Maidenform unhooked, with budget of more than $5 million, is part of elaborate efforts to create less formal, more contemporary image of Maidenform brand; campaign is being developed by Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners; photo (L)

headline: Accused French Ex-Official Says Jews Aided Nazi Deportations
abstract: Maurice Papon, former French official facing trial on charges of crimes against humanity in World War II, accuses French Jews of helping to organize deportations to Nazi death camps (M)

headline: Uncovered Short Sales Rise 2.7% on Nasdaq
abstract: Nasdaq market reports number of open positions of short sales rose 2.7 percent in most recent month, to 1.307 billion shares from 1.265 billion in previous period; that represents 2.21 days of average daily volume, down from 2.57 days in January; figures reflect trades from Jan 16 through Feb 11 and settled as of Feb 14; tables (L)

headline: CBS to Acquire 22% of Sportsline USA
abstract: CBS announces that it will acquire 22 percent stake in Sportsline USA Inc, an Internet media company, in deal valued at more than $100 million; Sportsline will change name of its site on World Wide Web to CBS Sportsline (S)

headline: In H.M.O. Era, The House Call Is by Telephone
abstract: 'Telemedicine' is being tested as alternative to time-consuming process of having nurse or health aide visit homes of patients needing home health care; a miniature television camera and microphone allows nurse to see and hear patient, and other equipment measures vital signs, reminds patients to take their medicine and even takes electrocardiograms; results are transmitted to medical center over phone or cable television line; amount spent on home health care has soared in recent years, as insurers and managed care providers push to limit hospital stays, and Government has decided to pay lump sum for each Medicare patient's home care instead of paying for each nurse's visit; advocates of telemedicine claim reliable home-monitoring equipment is now inexpensive enough to justify approach; critics say it erodes quality of care; photo (M)

headline: Palestinian Killed in West Bank By an Undercover Israeli Patrol
abstract: Three undercover Israeli soldiers, evidently on a stakeout in this Palestinian village, shot and beat several residents today, killing one and wounding three, witnesses said.    The incident touched off a wave of rock-throwing in the village and contributed to tensions already mounting throughout the West Bank over an announcement that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is expected to make on Wednesday authorizing the construction of new housing for Jews in east Jerusalem.

headline: U.N. Opens Search for Rwanda Refugees Lost in Zaire's Jungles
abstract: United Nations begins an operation to find thousands of Rwandan refugees lost in jungles in eastern Zaire and discovers several hundred malnourished and ragged people in the ruins of a camp at Tingi Tingi, which was recently overrun by rebel army; rebel leader says he will open up safe corridors to allow refugees to march back to Rwanda (M)

headline: Guilty Plea by Ex-Executive of Archer Daniels
abstract: As part of an agreement to testify against fellow conspirators, a former executive with the Archer Daniels Midland Company pleaded guilty yesterday to one count of conspiring to steal more than $300,000 from the giant grain concern.    The plea, by Marty W. Allison, a former vice president with the bioproducts division of Archer Daniels, is the first public admission of criminal wrongdoing by an executive with the company since a series of scandals began to swirl around it in 1995.

headline: Literally Filling the Streets, Serbian Demonstrators Give New Meaning to Political Gridlock
abstract: Tens of thousands of anti-Government demonstrators defy police ban on street marches by paralyzing capital of Belgrade, Yugoslavia, with snaking parades of cars and throngs of gleeful supporters who crowded between vehicles (M)

headline: ITT HARTFORD GROUP (HIG, NY)
abstract: The company said it earned $205 million, or $1.75 a share, in the quarter, up 45 percent, from $141 million, or $1.20 a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

headline: Forbes Sells Newspapers
abstract: Forbes Inc sells its New Jersey newspapers for undisclosed amount to North Jersey Newspapers Co, a unit of Medianews Group; Forbes papers are The Bound Brook Chronicle, The Franklin Focus and The Journal of Green Brook; The Hills-Bedminster Press/Buyers Guide, The Somerset Messenger-Gazette, The Journal in Warren-Watchung, The Highland Park Herald and The Review in Metuchen-Edison (S)

headline: Stocks Up Again in Tokyo
abstract: Japan's Nikkei index of 225 issues is up 33.94 points, or almost one-fifth of 1 percent, at 18,722 on Friday, Feb 14 (S)

headline: 3 Companies to Jointly Develop a Powerful Computer Chip
abstract: Three companies will jointly develop computer memory chip capable of storing one billion bits of information; so-called one gigabit DRAM chip is not expected on market until after year 2000; companies are Mitsubishi Electric Co, Hitachi Ltd and Texas Instruments (M)

headline: U.S. Report Rebukes China Over Rights
abstract: Clinton Administration officials, describing conclusion they reached for US Government's annual report on human rights conditions, say by end of 1996, there were no active dissidents left in China who had not been jailed or exiled; report will be made public on Jan 30 (M)

headline: Mobil Consolidates Media Account
abstract: Mobil Corp consolidates media part of its domestic account, with billings estimated at $60 million, at Optimum Media, media services unit of DDB Needham Worldwide (S)

headline: U.S. Chain Buying Global Hotel Group
abstract: Doubletree Corp agrees to acquire Renaissance Hotel Group for $780 million in cash and stock; Doubletree's second deal in last two months would bring its lodging roster to 101,000 rooms in 382 hotels worldwide, putting it in same league as Hilton Hotels Corp and Marriott International Inc (M)

headline: Credit Card Default Rate Is Climbing
abstract: High default rate at Advanta Corp, fast-growing credit card issuer that says up to 7.5 percent of its loans outstanding have gone bad, reflects wider trend; 3.72 percent of credit card borrowers were behind on payments in 1996 fourth quarter, up from 3.48 percent in third quarter; problems are likely to worsen because credit card borrowing jumped sharply recently; card companies are preparing to get tougher with customers, imposing higher interest rates and more fees and providing fewer goodies (M)

headline: Secular Turks Alarmed by Resurgence of Religion
abstract: Many Turks fear Prime Min Necmettin Erbakan's Government seeks to undermine secular state as tensions rise between religious and secular Turks; Erbakan has backed away from most militant campaign promises, but is pressing ahead with series of moves that together with outbreaks of fundamentalism frighten secularists; map; photos (L)

headline: 'Closing the Circle,' Sharansky Visits Russia
abstract: Israeli Trade Min Natan Sharansky visits Russia, country from which he was expelled 11 years ago as convicted traitor; he signs economic cooperation agreement with Mayor Yuri Luzhkov to boost trade between Israel and Moscow (M)

headline: U.S. Aide Assails Colombia as New Drug Sanctions Are Studied
abstract: Asst State Sec Robert S Gelbard scores Colombia for 'cooperating' with drug traffickers, House subcommittee; stops just short of predicting Clinton Administration will impose economic sanctions (M)

headline: Bonds Higher On Hopeful Rate Outlook
abstract: Trading in US bond market turns positive after Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan indicates that Fed will not raise interest rates simply to snuff out growth, but only if imbalances appear in the economy; 30-year bond rate rises 16/32, to price of 97 16/32; yield falls to 6.82 percent, from 6.86 percent on March 4; graph (L)

headline: Gerber Sponsoring Service Campaign
abstract: Gerber Co will be first marketer to provide exposure for Federal public service campaign intended to prevent occurrence of sudden infant death syndrome, also known as SIDS; Gerber will carry information about campaign on boxes of its cereal products and send mailings to new parents (S)

headline: Chechnya's Mild but Steely New Chief
abstract: Aslan Maskhadov is overwhelmingly elected President of Chechnya in elections deemed fair and democratic by Russian and international observers; photo (M)

headline: Doubts About Your Lover?Send Out a Fidelity Decoy : AMERICAN TOPICS
abstract: For lovers with doubts, it's just the thing. A California company will place temptation in your mate's way, and then document just how sagely, or salaciously, he or she reacts.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators.    MONDAY  Existing-Home Sales Dec.    TUESDAY  Consumer Confidence Jan.    WEDNESDAY  Durable-Goods Orders Dec.    THURSDAY  Weekly Jobless Claims    FRIDAY  G.D.P. 4th Qtr.  New-Home Sales Dec.  Prices of New Homes Dec.

headline: ECUADOR'S CRISIS OVER PRESIDENCY ENDS PEACEFULLY
abstract: Political crisis in Ecuador ends peacefully as Vice President Rosalia Arteaga is named Interim President by Congress and will serve until Constitution is amended to provide clear mechanism to elect successor to Abdala Bucaram, who was voted out of office on February 6 on ground of mental incapacity; Arteaga will become nation's first female leader; photos (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Bausch & Lomb eyewear division, Rochester, to Bozell Worldwide, New York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, as agency of record for its worldwide Ray-Ban sunglasses account, with billings estimated at $40 million. The assignment had been expected since last month, when Bausch & Lomb and Bartle Bogle Hegarty, London, the Ray-Ban agency for six months, parted ways. Bozell also handles Bausch & Lomb skin-care brands like Curel.

headline: Raytheon Wins Arms Unit in Texas, Though At High Price
abstract: Raytheon Co wins bidding for Texas Instruments' military business; it will pay $2.95 billion in cash for a division that makes missiles, radar systems, night-vision equipment and electronic warfare gear; Washington has encouraged arms makers to combine in interest of efficiency, as military spending has shrunk; analysts think Raytheon paid too much, but Raytheon is determined to prevail amid brutal consolidation in industry; move signals its status as possible contender for Hughes Electronics military business, which General Motors hopes to sell for as much as $9 billion; Raytheon's chief financial officer, Peter D'Angelo, predicts that Raytheon and Texas Instruments operations would complement each other so well, with little overlap, that sales would grow with no staff cutbacks necessary (M)

headline: Treasury Bond Prices Move Up Amid Mixed Views on Jobs Data
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities surge despite release of February employment figures that are much stronger than expected; table shows key interest rates (S)

headline: Outsourcing Wins Over French Bank
abstract: PARIS—  While French corporations have been slower than their European counterparts to contract out, or outsource, all of their computer and network systems operations to high-tech service companies, such reluctance may be evaporating among French bankers.

headline: Just 26, but Thinking Far, Far Ahead About Money
abstract: Article in series Fresh Start, periodic look at crossroads of personal finance, focuses on financial strategy of 26-year-old Greg Smith, software design engineer for Microsoft Corp, who was paralyzed playing football in college; says Smith has a big portfolio, but the money will be needed for his future medical expenses; photo (L)

headline: HUGHES ELECTRONICS BUYS LANGUAGE TRAINING CONCERN
abstract: Hughes Electronics Corp acquires Door Training International to better serve international training clients and expand its Hughes Training Inc unit; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Barclays in Talks to Sell British Property Concern
abstract: Barclays PLC says it is in negotiations to sell Imry Holdings, a property company, to Dutch property investment fund Rodamco; Rodamco is discussing an offer of up to 450 million pounds ($729 million) (S)

headline: STATE REGULATORS SAID TO REJECT ENRON MERGER
abstract: Staff of Oregon Public Utility Commission will recommend against planned purchase of Portland General Corp by Enron Corp, on grounds that Enron's offering of $61 million in cost savings and rate reductions does not offer sufficient benefits to meet statutory burden needed to approve transaction (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Steve Madden Ltd., Long Island City, Queens, to Hampel/Stefanides, New York, to handle advertising for the footwear maker, which had been handled by Ryan Drossman & Partners, New York. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

headline: Offerings of Equity and Debt Expected to Be Made This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Aastrom Biosciences Inc., Ann Arbor, Mich., an initial public offering of 3.25 million shares. Cowen & Co.

headline: Mobutu Back in Zaire
abstract: President Mobutu returned but did not appear in public, causing speculation about his health. Washington is sending up to 250 troops to prepare for a possible American evacuation.     Articles, page 7.

headline: Bre-X Loses Fee For Gold Stake
abstract: Bre-X Minerals Ltd will not receive any payment for the 30 percent stake in the Busang gold deposit that it gave to its Indonesian partners; Bre-X discovered the deposit in 1994 and under its exploration contract with Indonesian Government, it expected to be given full title to develop the mine (S)

headline: Toyota Output Hurt By Fire at Supplier
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp's production will fall behind by 50,000 vehicles after fire at parts supplier forces closing of two plants (S)

headline: New Type of Leader; Same Army Friends
abstract: The man anointed to succeed Deng Xiaoping, Jiang Zemin, is a new kind of authority for China: a quiet intellectual who would be the first leader in the nation's history with a college degree. While not as imposing a figure as Mr. Deng, he appears to be a secure strongman.     In the eight years since his selection, he has tried to establish support in the military. But he has also tended to shift with the political winds, and has been more associated with caution than leadership.

headline: A Crime, They Say, to Shut Agatha Christie's Hotel
abstract: Standing like an aging but still proud matriarch, commanding one of the world's most spectacular vistas and guarding more than a century of secrets, the Pera Palace Hotel is a relic of Istanbul's most elegant era.    To enter its lobby from the bustling street outside is to pass into a vanished world once inhabited by kings, courtesans, aristocrats and spies. The lighting is muted, the tiled walls and marble columns imposing but restrained.

headline: Earnings Climb 17% At Columbia/HCA
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp reports earnings for fourth quarter 1996 rose to $414 million, compared with $354 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: At Radio's Tea Party, Nothing but Static for China
abstract: Interview with Albert Cheng, host of Hong Kong's most irreverent, and popular, radio talk show, Teacup in a Tempest; on program, Cheng harangues and teases, lectures, annoys and berates territory's leading political figures, its cultural icons and, perhaps most perilously, impending sovereign, China; glee with which he goes after his targets raises questions about his prospects under Chinese rule; photo of Cheng and his co-host, Peter Lam (M)

headline: Albanian Leader and Critics Urge Rebels to Stop Fighting
abstract: Albanian Pres Sali Berisha and opposition parties join to urge rebels in south to stop fighting and turn in weapons; photo; document promises that military will suspend operations for 48 hours; defiant residents of Vlore, now blockaded, vow not to comply; more than 20 people have died from gunfire since anarchy descended on town; protesters in Sarande seize weapons from deserted military post and set to sea in torpedo boats; string of small villages along coast are out of Government control following protests over loss of money to pyramid schemes (S)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/   As new issues go, Silgan has a lot of debt. But tentatively priced at just 7 times 1997 earnings, the stock is turning heads. By Reed Abelson.    INVESTING IT /Page 6/   When stocks zoom, you need to review how your assets are allocated. By Marcia Vickers.    MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 9/   Stay-at-home spouses and their employed mates can now put away much more money in their I.R.A.'s. By Leah Beth Ward.    EARNING IT /Page 10/   What to do if a history of alcoholism or substance abuse is hurting you in the workplace. By Laura Pedersen-Pietersen.

headline: General Mills Adds Duties to 2 Agencies
abstract: General Mills Inc expands relationships with two of its agencies to handle products company will acquire from Ralcorp Holdings Inc (S)

headline: Struggling Borland to Cut Work Force and Shift Product Focus
abstract: Borland International Inc, struggling software company, says it will lay off 300 people, or about 30 percent of its work force, as part of major restructuring; company will have 700 employees after the cuts (M)

headline: ACCUSTAFF ANNOUNCES THE PURCHASE OF CGS SERVICES
abstract: Accustaff Inc buys CGS Services Inc (S)

headline: Omnicom Unit Cuts Ties With AT&T
abstract: BBDO Worldwide and AT&T Corp agree to end ties, freeing BBDO to seek GTE Corp advertising account (S)

headline: MONSANTO OFFERS $218 MILLION FOR REST OF CALGENE
abstract: Monsanto Co, which owns 54.6 percent of Calgene Inc stock, offers $218 million for remaining shares (S)

headline: G.E. PICKS ALLIED SIGNAL TO SUPPLY AVIONICS EQUIPMENT
abstract: Allied Signal Inc says it received $100 million contract from General Electric Co to supply auxiliary power units and avionics for as many as 80 Airbus A320 aircraft that GE is purchasing; says GE Capital Aviation Services unit will lease aircraft to various airlines around the world (S)

headline: A General Motors Axle Supplier Is Also Facing a Strike Deadline
abstract: United Automobile Workers union's contract with American Axle and Manufacturing Inc, critical supplier of General Motors Corp, will expire at 12:01 AM on Feb 15; people close to talks say considerable progress is being made but will not rule out possibility of a strike (M)

headline: On the Tightrope? Index Options Can Be Your Net
abstract: With the Dow Jones industrial average up more than 60 percent during last two years, index 'put' options may be way for concerned investors looking for ways to cushion a fall; when investors buy put option on the S&P 500- and 100-stock indexes, that most closely matches their holdings, they are essentially insuring their portfolios against downturn in market; at same time, because they have not sold their stocks or mutual funds, they can still benefit from market climb large enough to offset option's cost; graph on 'put' index options (M)

headline: Correction
abstract: An article Dec. 27 described a reporter's efforts to find out how the magician David Copperfield performed his tricks in "Dreams and Nightmares," a Broadway show. The article included an interview with a man identifying himself as an audience "plant" who aided the magician. The man said he was disgruntled about being paid late for his work. He identified himself as Seth Greenspan, an employee of the show, but that identification was false. After the article was published in The New York Times, the show's producer visited The Times with the real Seth Greenspan, who produced full identification. A telephone number at which the impostor was initially reached has since been disconnected.

headline: GRANCARE TO EXPAND INTO ALABAMA WITH NORTHPORT DEAL
abstract: Grancare Inc will acquire Northport Health Services Inc for $84 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Stock Slide in Japan
abstract: Sharp decline in Japanese stock market noted

headline: On-Line City Guides Seek Print Partners As Competition Grows
abstract: Companies that provide on-line information guides in major cities are rushing to join forces with locally based print partners to gain access to their listings and articles; Citysearch's planned alliance with Time Out New York magazine cited (S)

headline: Heating Oil Prices Slip a Bit As Inventories Seem Sufficient
abstract: Prices of heating oil fall to one-month low, dragging crude oil prices lower, on mounting perceptions that inventories will be adequate this winter; in other markets, prices of soybeans and orange juice rise (M)

headline: A multimillion-dollar Super Bowl party will have familiar guests.
abstract: Advertising column describes commercials planned during Super Bowl XXXI; more than two dozen marketers are buying 58 30-second units of commercial time, paying record average of $1.2 million for each spot, or $40,000 a second; many advertisers hope to capture attention with famous faces and celebrity voices; photos (M)

headline: Salinas Speaks Out, About Plot, Brother and Regrets
abstract: Former Mexican Pres Carlos Salinas de Gortari breaks long silence, detailing his views on political mayhem and economic chaos that marked end of his six-year tenure in 1994; he describes conspiracy by senior politicians from his governing party in days after assassination of presidential contender Luis Donaldo Colosio to impose replacement candidate allied with their interests; he denies any connection to assassination; Salinas, who lives in Ireland, makes his remarks in interview with newspaper editor Ramon Alberto Garza; photo (M)

headline: The Incredible Shrinking Apple Computer
abstract: Recent annual Macworld computer conference, San Francisco, was aimed at reviving sorely tested beliefs of Apple Computer faithful; not much has gone right for Apple lately, from small things like problems during demonstration of new computer at conference, to Apple's faltering recovery campaign; one year after Gilbert F Amelio took over as chairman and chief executive, along with new management team, he has been unable to pull computer maker out of its spiral of decline; company's sales are falling, its losses are mounting and its stock price is deeply depressed; Amelio comments on future plans for Apple; financial graphs; photos (L)

headline: Easing Crisis, China Lets North Korea Defector Go
abstract: China defuses five-week diplomatic crisis by sending senior North Korean defector Hwang Jang Yop to Philippines by special plane, where he is expected to stay for decent diplomatic interval before traveling to South Korea; Hwang, ideological mentor to North Korean leader Kim Jong Il, is most senior member of his country's hard-line elite ever to defect; Hwang photo (M)

headline: Canada Issues an Apology To Mulroney in Libel Suit
abstract: Canadian Government and Royal Canadian Mounted Police issue formal public apologies to former Prime Min Brian Mulroney, who was falsely accused of soliciting kickbacks while in office; while top law enforcement officials acknowledge making unjustified allegations against Mulroney that hurt him and family, they insist that Government's investigation into supposed payoffs in purchase of 34 commercial jets in 1985 will continue; Mulroney claims complete vindication; Government will pay approximately $1 million in legal costs; Mulroney agrees to drop $37.5 million claim for damages; photos (M)

abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.19   5.39   5.20        3-MO. headline: Reuters Posts 17% Gain In Profit but Stock Falls
abstract: Reuters Holdings reports 1996 pretax profit of $1.15 billion, 17 percent gain over 1995 (S)

headline: U.N. Panel Proposes Expanding Security Council to 24 Members
abstract: Proposal to enlarge United Nations Security Council from its present 15 members to 24 is presented by Razali Ismail, General Assembly President who is chairman of panel that has been studying ways to reform Council (M)

headline: Nationalists Stoke Macedonia's Anxiety
abstract: Coexistence of ethnic groups in Macedonia is threatened by nationalist views of Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization, which is antagonistic to ethnic minorities and feeds on country's economic woes and governmental corruption; movement first arose in opposition to Ottoman rule in 19th century; map; ethnic Macedonians, Slavs and Orthodox Christians, are 70 percent of population, but prominent writer Meto Jovanovski recalls children speaking Turkish, Macedonian, and Spanish of Sephardic Jews when he was growing up in 1930's (S)

headline: Producer Data Help Initiate A Stock Rally
abstract: Stock prices rise to new highs, propelled largely by inflation report that caused short- and long-term interest rates to fall sharply; Dow Jones industrial average jumps 76.19 points, to 6,625.67, third closing high it has set this year; Standrd & Poor's index of 500 stocks rises 6.44 points, to 754.85; volume on New York Stock Exchange is heavy, at 555.37 million shares; analysts say catalyst for rally was Government report showing that producer prices remained largely in check during December(M)

headline: NORTHSTAR TO ACQUIRE MORRISON FOR $476 MILLION
abstract: Northstar Energy Corp agrees to acquire Morrison Petroleums Ltd for about $643 million (Canadian), equivalent of $476.4 million (US) (S)

headline: Over Here, Paper Chase for Nazi Gold
abstract: Documents in National Archives that were recently declassified by Federal Government are in demand by Government and private researchers looking for traces of gold and other treasures looted by Nazis during World War II; photo (M)

headline: Sharp Price Cut Lifts Market Share Of Tax Software
abstract: Kiplinger Tax Cut, published by unit of H & R Block Inc, raises its share of market for tax-preparation software to 28.2 percent after aggressive price-cutting; industry leader, Intuit Inc, sees its share of units sold at retail fall to 71.6 percent from 89.3 percent (S)

headline: EDISON INTERNATIONAL AND TEXACO TO SELL UNIT
abstract: Remington Energy Ltd, oil and gas company based in Calgary, Alberta, agrees to acquire B C Star Partners for $200 million (Canadian), or $146 million (US); B C Star is oil and gas producing partnership between Texaco Canada Petroleum Inc, unit of Texaco Inc, and Edison International, a utility based in Rosemead, Calif; Edison says it will receive $71 million for sale of its stake (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY   Consol Freight  Elcor

headline: Goldman, Sachs Profit Rose By 60% in Recent Quarter
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Company reports fiscal 1997 first-quarter pre-tax profit of $905 million, 60 percent increase over year-earlier period; profit reflects firm's second-best quarter in its 127-year history (S)

headline: Bankruptcy Judge Sets Back Perelman Bid to Keep Marvel
abstract: Ronald O Perelman, financier who is seeking to maintain control of Marvel Entertainment Group in bankruptcy, suffers setback when United States Bankruptcy Court Judge Helen S Balick rejects parts of borrowing agreement Marvel had negotiated with group of banks headed by Chase Manhattan (M)

headline: Opel Sales Rise, But Profit May Sag
abstract: Adam Opel, German unit of General Motors Co, says sales rose 9.3 percent in 1996, to 28.3 billion marks ($17.2 billion), from 25.9 billion marks in 1995; Opel estimates its 1996 profit at 250 million to 350 million marks, below earnings of 363 million marks in 1995 (S)

headline: The Return Of the Merchandiser
abstract: Re-release of George Lucas's Star Wars movie trilogy, enhanced with new special effects, is seen by experts as paradigm of marketing prowess and example of how movie industry has become art in service of huge commercial superstructure; Lucasfilm has distributed to hundreds of Star Wars licensees chart detailing, month by month, all merchandising and marketing events related to films through 1999; photos (M)

headline: Airbus Says '96 Orders Were Triple Those of '95
abstract: Airbus Industrie says it received orders for 326 aircraft worth $23.6 billion in 1996, more than triple the orders in 1995; company will increse production in 1997 and 1998 (S)

headline: TV Woos Viewers With News Of Business
abstract: Financial television grows rapidly in 1990's as programmers seek to attract the millions of Americans who now make more of their own financial decisions; many broadcasters on these newer channels are reluctant to say much about their ratings, and Nielsen Media, the television ratings company, keeps its numbers private; CNBC, one of few that reveals such information, says that it now reaches 61 million homes and that in the last quarter of 1996 an average of 2.3 million homes tuned in each week, up slightly from the prior year; race in December between CNBC and CNN to provide live ticker quotes running across the bottom of their screens highlights growing competition in the field; table; photo (L)

headline: Stocks Shake Midday Slide; Dow Up 26.16
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rallies late in the day, to close up 26.16 points, to 6,773.06, and Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks gained 1.87 points, to 780.125; Nasdaq composite index falls 2.04 points, to close at 1,346.40 (L)

headline: Papers for Homeless Offer Needy a Leg Up
abstract: There are more than 70 newspapers for the homeless in comunities of all sizes nationwide; papers are financed by combination of foundation grants, advertising from local businesses, circulation revenues and individual donations; their editors and supporters say these newspapers offer needy an alternative to panhandling and a first step to rejoining the work force; emergence of Real Change in Seattle is illustrative of how these street newspapers are started and spread; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Rebuffed in Global Proposal For Eavesdropping on the Internet
abstract: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development declines to endorse US proposal to allow computer eavesdropping by world's law enforcement agencies; setback for Clinton Administration demonstrates difficulty of setting global policies for Internet; US proposal, backed by Britian and France, is attempt to restrict private use of advanced data-scrambling technology that can protect privacy of electronic mail and other forms of computer communication; equipment can make it difficult for law enforcement officials to crack code when they suspect it is masking criminal or terrorist activities (M)

headline: 16.6% OF HERTZ TO BE OFFERED ON STOCK MARKET
abstract: Ford Motor Co will offer the public a 16.6 percent stake in its Hertz Corp car rental unit, selling 17.4 million shares in an initial public offering; shares will be offered at $21 to $24 (S)

headline: Motorola's Earnings Below Expectations
abstract: Motorola Inc reoprts earnings for fourth quarter that were lower than expected; company earned $238 million, down from $432 million in year-earlier quarter; most recent profits were weakened by more than $150 million in revamping costs and charges before taxes; revenue rose 5.2 percent, to $7.68 billion (M)

headline: WHAT HAPPENED: Dismemberment And Downsizing
abstract: AT&T began the year with an announcement last Jan. 2 that it would lay off as many as 40,000 workers as part of its plan to split itself into three companies. The move helped crystallize a nascent public backlash against corporate downsizing. AT&T split off Lucent Technologies in March and ended the year by spinning off NCR on Tuesday.

headline: An Extra Mortgage Cost May Last Far Too Long
abstract: Lenders require homeowners to buy mortgage insurance if their down payment is less than 20 percent of home's purchase price, on theory that the lower the down payment, the greater the chance of default; consumer advocates say many homeowners keep paying for insurance long after they have built up more than 20 percent equity in their homes because lenders do not tell the homeowner, and there is no law requiring such disclosure; photo (M)

headline: Move the Feast to Europe, Some Advise
abstract: Morningstar Inc says average mutual fund invested in European stocks outperformed the average American fund, 23.49 percent to 18.40 percent in 1996; given economic cycles, some managers think Europe will remain good place to be; graph (L)

headline: Netanyahu Calls for an End to 'Proxy War'
abstract: Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu calls on Syria to stop what he calls proxy war against Israel in southern Lebanon after bomb kills three Israeli soldiers there; map (M)

headline: Washington Hopes Mobutu Loses and Kabila Doesn't Win
abstract: The U.S. government wants the rebellion in Zaire to topple President Mobutu Sese Seko, but without an outright victory for the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, officials familiar with U.S. policy in the crisis say.

headline: Fallon McElligott drops McDonald's and Leap moves deeper into the Los Angeles market.
abstract: Advertising column discusses Fallon McElligott's decision to resign its McDonald's account and pursue Domino's Pizza Inc account; Pat Fallon says agency was unhappy at not having exclusive assignment for promoting Arch Deluxe (M)

headline: CANADIAN 88 WITHDRAWS BID FOR MORRISON PETROLEUMS
abstract: Canadian 88 Energy Corp drops bid for Morrison Petroleums Ltd (S)

headline: Foster's Brewing Posts 2% Gain in Net Income
abstract: Foster's Brewing Group Ltd reports net income rose 2 percent in six months ended Dec 31 to $169.4 million (Australian) (US$129 million) (S)

headline: Medical Savings Accounts: Not the Perfect Answer
abstract: Prof Felicia Ackerman letter on Feb 16 article on medical savings plans (S)

headline: If Deal Occurs, the Garden Faces Still Another Round
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp bid for ITT Corp, half owner of Madison Square Garden, could give Garden yet another new parent; Hilton might seek to sell stake; possible buyers include Fox Sports unit of News Corp (M)

headline: Viacom Scales Back Plans For New Blockbuster Stores
abstract: Viacom Inc says that it has reduced number of Blockbuster video stores it plans to open this year to 600 from 800; says it has cut back on store construction to reduce its debt, which amounts to about $9.5 billion (S)

headline: Two Top AT&T Executives in Europe Quit
abstract: AT&T announces resignations of Mario Bonzano, its president for Europe, Middle East and Africa, and Sergio Giacoletto, president of international multimedia on-line services business in Geneva (S)

headline: NINE WEST TO CLOSE 3 PLANTS AND DISMISS 1,000 WORKERS
abstract: Nine West Group Inc, largest manufacturer of women's shoes in US, will close three plants and dismiss 1,000 workers, or more than half of US work force; will shift shoe production abroad (S)

headline: Microsoft Notified Of Texas Inquiry
abstract: Microsoft Corp, which has fought series of Federal antitrust investigations, faces inquiry by Texas state officials into its Internet products; antitrust lawyers say state investigations could ratchet up pressure on Justice Department to take action in its investigation; both investigations involve questions over whether company is using its dominance of market for personal computer operating systems to gain unfair advantage in competition for Internet browsers or other software and on-line products (S)

headline: HANSON TO BUY CONCRETE PIPE AND PRODUCTS OF RICHMOND
abstract: Hanson PLC says its Cornerstone Construction and Materials Inc unit will acquire Concrete Pipe and Products Co for about $125 million, including assumption of undisclosed amount of debt (S)

headline: Two Companies Name New Ad Agencies
abstract: NEC Technologies Inc selects Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston, Mass, to handle its advertising account, with billings estimated at $15 million; account has been handled by Hampel/Stefanides; Weather Channel, cable network owned by Landmark Communications, names TBWA Chiat/Day unit of Omnicom to handle its advertising account, with billings estimated at $7 million; account had most recently been handled by Bozell Worldwide (S)

headline: PLASTECH ENGINEERED PRODUCTS IN DEAL FOR UNITED SCREW
abstract: United Screw and Bolt Corp says it agreed to be acquired by Plastech Engineered Products Inc for $128 million in cash (S)

headline: Stanislav Shatalin, 62, Russian Who Tried to Open the Economy
abstract: Stanislav S Shatalin, Soviet economist who during perestroika era was instrumental in promoting an economic plan to dismantle Communism, dies at age 62; photo (M)

headline: Treasury Auctions This Week Include Inflation-Indexed Note
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week comprises sales of bills and notes, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. On Wednesday, the Treasury will auction a new 10-year inflation-indexed note.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.01 percent and on the six-month bill, 5.11 percent. In when-issued trading, the new 10-year inflation index note was offered at a price to yield 3.49 percent.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: NCR CORP., Dayton, Ohio, a maker of automated teller machines and cash registers, acquired a 14.5 percent stake in Turbon International A.G., Hattingen, Germany, a manufacturer of various printer products, for about $14.5 million.

headline: Latin Markets Again Run With the Bulls
abstract: Latin American stock and bond funds have both gained handsomely in recent years, exceeding 40 percent in some cases; recently, bonds have been replaced by stocks as winning investment in region; continued political changes and resurgent local economies created two-year bull market for bonds and set stage for current stock rally; charts (M)

headline: Earnings at Bear Stearns Exceed Projections
abstract: Bear Stearns Companies reports earnings of $176.5 million for its fiscal second quarter, increase of 68 percent from comparable year earlier period (S)

headline: Hunger Strike by Humble Sweepers: Mood in Mexico Is Angry
abstract: Hunger strike by striking street sweepers draws wide attention in Mexico, propelling otherwise local labor dispute to forefront of national concern; two hunger strikers are forcibly hospitalized after riot police break up strikers' campside near human rights commission; strike fits pattern of increasingly radical protests in capital as prolonged recession takes toll and governing party's traditional patronage system breaks down (S)

headline: CHAIN TO SHUT FALTERING RED LOBSTER OUTLETS
abstract: Darden Restaurants Inc will close 36 Red Lobster and Olive Garden restaurants, expense that is expected to lower fourth-quarter profits by $230 million (S)

headline: Banco Popular of Spain Says Profit Rose 6.1%
abstract: Banco Popular SA reports 1996 net rose 6.1 percent, to $459 million (US) (S)

headline: January Car Sales Up 2.3%; Foreign Makers Have Surge
abstract: Foreign auto makers show biggest sales gains in American auto market in January, as strong dollar continues to help them offer generous lease deals and low prices; foreign auto makers reporting results saw their combined sales rise 10.9 percent, while combined sales of two American auto makers reporting results dropped tenth of 1 percent; Chrysler Corp reports sales up 1.5 percent in January, while General Motors Corp sales dropped nine-tenths of 1 percent, compared with year earlier month; among foreign auto makers, Honda Motor Co reports sales up 21.1 percent and Subaru reports increase of 24.5 percent; Nissan's sales were up 10.7 percent, Mitsubishi Motors sales were down 4.2 percent and Isuzu Motors Ltd were down 28.5 percent; Toyota Motor Corp and Ford Motor Co are expected to report their January results on Feb 4 (M)

headline: French Show An Eagerness To Mend Ties With the U.S.
abstract: Aides to French Pres Jacques Chirac hint he is eager to meet with Pres Clinton in next few weeks to defuse recent tensions over NATO, UN and Middle East; Foreign Min Herve de Charette tells journalists he wants to meet with Madeleine Albright as soon as she is confirmed as Secretary of State (S)
