headline: 73 Israeli Troops Die As 2 Copters Collide
abstract: Two Israeli helicopters ferrying soldiers to south Lebanon collided in midair yesterday over the northern Galilee, killing all 73 men on board. It was the the worst military air disaster in Israeli history and the accident stunned the nation.

headline: ARAFAT IN HEBRON, OFFERING ISRAELIS AN OLIVE BRANCH
abstract: Yasir Arafat is engulfed by thousands of cheering Palestinians as he visits West Bank city of Hebron for first time in more than 30 years, where he proclaims city liberated and holds out olive branch to Israel and to 450 dejected Jewish settlers; visit caps breakthrough in dealings with Israeli Government, which concluded arrangements for withdrawal of troops from four-fifths of city and transfer of all major Palestinian population centers to Palestinian control; Arafat sends messsage of moderation and conciliation to Israelis; speaks of moving with Israel toward just and comprehensive peace; thanks Pres Clinton, Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak and King Hussein of Jordan; photos; maps (M)

headline: RJR Nabisco Holdings Posts Gain in 4th-Quarter Earnings
abstract: RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp posts fourth-quarter net income for $215 million, up from $44 million in 1995 period; Carl C Icahn says he remains committed to proxy fight despite gains (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Business Digest for January 14; stories include record net investment of $223 billion last year for mutual funds that buy stocks

headline: Harried Shoppers Turned to Gift Certificates
abstract: Sales of gift certificates were up at least 5 percent in 1996 among dozens of retailers, and the trend is likely to continue; gift certificates sold in record numbers during Christmas shopping season (L)

headline: FTP Software Narrows Review to 3 Agencies
abstract: FTP Software Inc narrows review on its advertising account to three finalists; account had been handled by Matzell, Richard & Watts Inc (S)

headline: HARVEST TO SELL ASSETS TO GROUP INCLUDING KROGER
abstract: Harvest Foods Inc says it agreed to sell most of its assets to group including Kroger Company supermarket chain for about $50 million (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Strike Over Labor Pact Idles G.M. Plant in Ohio  Close to 4,100 workers went on strike against General Motors at a huge plant in Moraine, Ohio, where sport utility vehicles are assembled. The International Union of Electronics Workers ordered the strike after workers voted against ratification of a new labor agreement.

headline: Equity Offerings for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:   American Communications Services Inc., Annapolis Junction, Md., 8 million shares. Alex. Brown & Sons.

headline: AMERICAN AIR SEEKS ARBITRATION IN PILOTS' DISPUTE
abstract: American Airlines agrees to binding arbitration in effort to settle contract dispute with Allied Pilots Association (S)ï

headline: Condominiums Planned For the Mayfair Hotel
abstract: Colony Capital real-estate group, which bought Mayfair Hotel on Park Avenue and 65th Street for $15 million, decides to hire Donald J Trump to develop 60 to 70 high-priced condominiums at hotel (M)

headline: Deng's Legacy: Finishing Long March to Capitalism
abstract: Deng Xiaoping, architect of China's policy of economic openness, seemed to possess magic touch with China's economy in its rocky transition from Communism to capitalism; but Deng has left his successors facing even tougher challenges; Jiang Zemin, Deng's designated successor, has far less political legitimacy and influence than Deng; question is whether Deng's death will derail pace of China's progress on economic restructuring; graphs (M)

headline: Deutsche Bank Sets Fund for Irregularities
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG reports setting aside $710 million in 1996 to reimburse customers and pay potential fines arising from previously disclosed irregularities by fund manager at its Morgan Grenfell Asset Management unit (S)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt     BankAmerica Capital III, San Francisco, is selling $400 million of capital securities due in 2027 through Merrill Lynch & Co. and BA Securities. The securities are priced to yield 57 basis points above the three-month London interbank rate offered, and interest is paid quarterly. The issue is rated A1 by Moody's and A- by S.& P.

headline: Cracking Paris:The Inside Loop of Hip Professionals Out on the Town
abstract: PARIS—  The hot fashion restaurant Anahi has tripled its order of Perrier. The Hotel Montalembert has been fully booked for this week for over three months. At the designer boutique Maria Louisa expect tears: The waiting list there for a Galliano floral sprigged dress peaks at 10, and there are only six dresses.

headline: MERCK SETS $5 BILLION STOCK REPURCHASE
abstract: Merck & Company said yesterday that it would buy back as much as $5 billion of its stock on the open market. Merck, a leading drug maker, said it was completing a $3 billion buyback program announced in November 1995. Through Dec. 31, Merck spent $2.1 billion to buy 33 million shares under that program. The latest program was announced as Merck shares traded near their record of $99.875, reached on Feb. 13. The shares closed yesterday at $97.75, down 62.5 cents. Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., said it was also raising its quarterly dividend to 42 cents a share from 40 cents.

headline: Sudanese Rebels Claim a Major Advance in Their Offensive
abstract: Sudanese rebel army reportedly advances close to Damazin, Blue Nile city whose dam and hydroelectric station provide Khartoum with most of its power; map; Government sends reinforcements, and high-level emissary to seek support from other Arab capitals (S)

headline: Bonds Extend Losses to 4th Day on Fear of Rate Increase
abstract: US bonds extend their losing streak to four consecutive days; 30-year bond falls 10/32, to price of 97 25/32, pushing yield up to 6.80 percent, from 6.77 percent on Feb 26; graph (L)

headline: Bond Prices Rise on Release of Jobs Data
abstract: Investors return to bond market after Labor Department releases employment figures that indicate that growth in wages was slow; 30-year Treasury bond gains; tables (M)

headline: Donation Of Organs Is Unusual In China
abstract: Confucian faithful in China are shocked by announcement that Deng Xiaoping's family wanted to respect his wishes that his corneas be donated to eye bank and body parts offered for medical research; Deng, known for his bold strokes in life, sought to combine cremation and organ donation as double attack on old way of doing things; in Chinese society, idea of voluntarily donating one's body to be used by person one will never know is anathema; photo (M)

headline: Press, Politics and Consensus in New Old South
abstract: John D Johnson is out as executive editor of Clarion-Ledger of Jackson, Miss, state's biggest and only statewide newspaper, reportedly because paper's aggressive coverage of Gov Kirk Fordice's mysterious automobile crash displeased Duane K McAllister, publisher, who had directed Johnson to pay more attention to 'the positive aspects of the Republican revolution'; newspaper is owned by Gannett Co; Hodding Carter 3d, whose family owns the crusading, liberal Democrat-Times of Greenville, sees a shift back to traditional conservatism in newspapers across the South; photo (M)

headline: Westinghouse To Buy Units From Gaylord For $1.5 Billion
abstract: Westinghouse Electric Corp to buy Nashville Network and Country Music Television's United States and Canadian operations from Gaylord Entertainment Co for $1.55 billion in stock; Gaylord reports fourth-quarter net income rose 23 percent, to $27.4 million; table (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Business Digest for Jan 18

headline: Since Dawn of Armani, Italian Tailoring a Touchstone for Quality
abstract: MILAN—  Tailoring, always Italy's strongest fashion suit, played well on the Milan runways earlier this month, particularly in the collections of Gucci, Dolce & Gabbana and Giorgio Armani. In the case of Armani, his numerous accomplishments as a tailor have been lionized to the point of mythology, but by far the most important of these efforts is the fact that the designer revolutionized the way men and women dressed in the 1980s.

headline: Dutch Government Assists in Fokker Talks
abstract: Dutch Government confirms that it is involved in talks on rescue plan for Fokker NV, collapsed aircraft builder (S)

headline: AVIS EUROPE TO BUY BACK INTEREST HELD BY HFS
abstract: Avis Europe said yesterday that it had agreed to buy back the 8.7 percent of its stock held by HFS Inc., which owns the Avis name in the United States. Financial terms were not disclosed. As part of the agreement, Avis Europe will license the Avis name for use in the car rental business in Asia and Africa and will pay annual royalties to HFS, which is based in Parsippany, N.J. HFS also franchises hotels and real estate offices. The transaction is contingent on Avis Europe's completing its public offering and listing on the London Stock Exchange, which is expected by the end of March. Avis Europe is 77 percent owned by the Belgian car importer and distributor D'Ieteren S.A.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: $1.76 Billion is Offered For Computer Part Maker  In a hostile bid that would combine two suppliers of computer disk heads, Applied Magnetics offered to buy Read-Rite for about $1.76 billion in stock.    Applied Magnetics said friendly talks with Read-Rite had ground to a halt. Analysts said the move to consolidate was spurred by increasing competition, as I.B.M. enters the business and Seagate expands production. $(Page D10.$)    U.S. Buyers for British Utility  Another British utility is being bought by American companies eager to expand into a rapidly deregulating market. American Electric Power and the Public Service Company of Colorado agreed to acquire Yorkshire Electricity for $2.43 billion. $(D4.$)

headline: Q&A/ Strobe Talbott: NATO Expansion Is Not Intended to 'Move the Iron Curtain Eastward'
abstract: Staying on as a principal foreign policymaker in the second Clinton administration, Strobe Talbott, the deputy secretary of state, will continue to be an architect of U.S. policy toward Russia. Prior to consultations in Europe this week with allied governments, he talked to Joseph Fitchett of the International Herald Tribune about NATO's expansion, potentially a crucial issue for future relations with Moscow.

headline: A Tale of 2 Economists: Sizing Up the Income Gap
abstract: Jack Scarangella letter on Louis Uchitelle's Feb 16 article on contrasting views of economists Paul Krugman and Lester Thurow, particularly their explanations for growth of income inequality in United States (S)

headline: Gore Tries His Wings, Such as They Are (Even Flights of Chinese Verse)
abstract: Reporter's Notebook behind-the-scenes vignettes of Vice Pres Gore during visit to Beijing; photo (M)

headline: How a Popular Product Can Fray Relations With Small Merchants
abstract: Ty Inc struggles to meet demand for Beanie Babies, hottest toy on market; some of small specialty retailers that sell stuffed animals say they are the ones smarting from company's growing pains; while store owners seethe over unfilled orders, for instance, McDonald's Corp recently announced that Ty would supply its restaurants with millions of teeny Beanie Babies to be given away in Happy Meal promotion starting on April 11; situation discussed; photos (M)

headline: MAPCO SELLS NATURAL GAS RESERVES IN TEXAS TO MESA
abstract: Mapco Inc sells its natural gas liquids reserves in West Panhandle fields in Texas to Mesa Inc for $66 million; Mapco says it will buy back from Mesa all natural gas produced at the fields (S)

headline: Koreans Divided on Leader's Apology
abstract: South Korean Pres Kim Young Sam appears to have won sympathy from public by apologizing for scandal that has engulfed his administration, but political experts say he has still not fully put affair behind him (M)

headline: Even if German TV Doesn't Blush, You Might
abstract: More German cable television planners are demanding greater freedom to show programs displaying uncensored sexual organs and acts; seek change in 1968 pornography law; sexually explicit programs are already carried on late-night shows; photo (M)

headline: MELLON BANK AGREES TO BUY GANZ CAPITAL MANAGEMENT
abstract: Mellon Bank Corp says it has agreed to acquire Ganz Capital Management Inc; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: China Hints at Accords on Rights
abstract: China says it is 'positively considering' signing two covenants on human rights that would oblige Beijing to report on protection of civil liberties on mainland and in Hong Kong after it reverts to China on July 1 (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * National Association of Home Builders, Washington, to Eisner & Associates, Baltimore and Washington, as its first agency. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million.    * SBC Advertising, Columbus, Ohio, received two accounts with combined billings estimated at $2.5 million: Central Benefits Mutual Insurance Co., Columbus, as the first agency to handle advertising and public relations, and GOJO Industries Inc., Akron, Ohio, to handle promotions and other projects for the skin care products marketer.

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY    The Commerce Department reports on personal income and spending for January. In December they rose 0.8 percent and 0.5 percent, respectively.  The National Association of Purchasing Management releases its February index. In January it stood at 52.0.

headline: For Many From Hong Kong, Vancouver Is a Way Station
abstract: Second article in series Waiting For China: Straddling Two Worlds notes that 110,000 Hong Kong Chinese have come to Vancouver, British Columbia, over last decade to escape uncertainty in Hong Kong; many are rich men who are referred to as 'astronauts' because they rocket back and forth to Hong Kong, where they still run businesses; even though they are rarely in Vancouver, most 'astronauts' and their wives have managed to become Canadian citizens; their passports are prized insurance policies that allow them to straddle both worlds; they can return to Hong Kong in waning days of British rule, but can get out again if need be after China takes over on July 1; graph; photo (M)

headline: Can the television networks afford supporting actors making $20 million a year?
abstract: All three networks are concerned about delicate negotiations NBC is conducting to bring Seinfeld, television's most successful comedy, back for one more season; at issue is demand from its three supporting actors, Jason Alexander, Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Michael Richards, for $1 million an episode, or $22 million each; fear is that once a standard is set on one show, stars of other shows will demand same or more money; photos (M)

headline: Sanofi of France Says Income Rose 11% in '96
abstract: Sanofi S.A., France's second-biggest drug company, said yesterday that its income rose 11 percent in 1996. The company, known for its blood-clot drug Ticlid and Yves Saint Laurent perfumes, posted a profit of 1.74 billion French francs ($307.61 million) in 1996, compared with 1.57 billion francs in 1995.

headline: Salvador's Ex-Rebels Expect Gains in Vote Today
abstract: Voters in El Salvador prepare to go to polls for second election since civil war ended five years ago, and guerrillas-turned-politicians are expected to make gains in midterm congressional and municipal vote that they failed to achieve in more than 12 years of fighting; series of polls put former rebels in virtual dead heat with, or ahead of, their former enemies of right-wing governing party; these results have energized left and elated architects of effort to transform armed insurgency into a conventional political party; photo; map (M)

headline: CAMCO EXPANDS OILFIELD SERVICES WITH ACQUISITION
abstract: Camco International Inc will buy Production Operators Corp for $575 million in stock (S)

headline: Porsche will make a splashy debut for its new Boxster sports car during Super Bowl XXXI.
abstract: Porsche Cars North America Inc will debut its racy topless two-seater, named the Boxster, during Super Bowl XXXI on Jan 26; company plans to spend about $20 million in initial year of promoting the car; Goodby, Silverstein & Partners developed ad campaign (L)

headline: RAYTHEON CONSORTIUM GETS $262 MILLION CONTRACT
abstract: Consortium led by Raytheon Co wins $262 million contract to plan and build iron-production plant, Guayana City, Venezuela; consortium also includes Pohang Iron & Steel Co's Posco Engineering & Construction unit and Hyundai Corp (S)

headline: A Japanese Retailer Is Selling 16 Outlets
abstract: Yaohan Japan Corp, continuing to announce revamping plans, said it will sell 16 retail outlets in Japan to Daiei Inc for 33 billion yen ($264 million) (S)

headline: The Dow Falls 33.87 Points As I.B.M. Shares Tumble 6%
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 33.87 points to close at 6,850.03; volume is 587.3 million shares; graph (M)

headline: A Warning Investors Have Ignored Before
abstract: Analysis of Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan's Senate testimony questioning rationality of current stock prices; says when Greenspan speaks of overvalued stocks, investors usually do not listen; or at least they do not do so for long; says that is the history of the very few examples when the Fed has chosen to go public with concerns over the stock market; says on Wall Street, reaction to Greenspan's remarks was swift but brief; notes Dow Jones industrial average plunged on first word of Greenspan's comments, falling nearly 100 points; but by end of the day, it had made up a large part of that loss; says reaction was reminiscent of reaction in December, when Greenspan first stunned traders by using words 'irrational exuberance' in discussing the market (L)

headline: RPM BUYS TREMCO FOR $230 MILLION FROM B. F. GOODRICH
abstract: RPM Inc says it acquired Tremco Inc from B F Goodrich Co for $230 million in cash (S)

headline: For Long-Haul Performance, Consider All the Best Families
abstract: Over the long term, large publicly held family companies substantially outperformed their peers; study by Prof Robert Kleiman of Oakland University, Rochester, Mich, finds that from April 1976 to March 1996, stocks of 209 largest family businessses earned an average annual return of 16.6 a year for companies in Standard & Poor's 500; top five companies during the 20 years were: Berkshire Hathaway, Manor Care Health Services, Comcast, Mirage Resorts and Tyson Foods; photo (M)

headline: As More Catholics Turn Against I.R.A., the Number of Police Informers Rises
abstract: Overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Irish Republican Army acknowledges increasing numbers of Catholics in Belfast have begun to inform on organization's planned violent attacks, and warns it will punish such informers; British officials confirm that number of Catholic informers is rising; say they can tell informers live in Catholic neighborhoods from nature of their information on IRA guerrillas already known to authorities; say information has helped thwart several bomb attacks in Ulster (M)

headline: In 2004, Will the Glory Be Greece's, or Rome's?
abstract: Athens and Rome, ancient rivals, are in modern-day competition to host Summer Olympics in 2004; International Olympic Committee will announce five finalists and select winner in September; neither Athens nor Rome are dwelling on glorious past as they talk up high-tech, cleaned-up environment, with new subway lines and high-speed roadways; Athens committee director Costas Liaskas and Raffaele Ranucci of Rome committee comment; photo (S)

headline: MAGELLAN HEALTH TO SELL PSYCHIATRIC HOSPITALS ABROAD
abstract: Magellan Health Services Inc will sell two psychiatric hospitals in London and Nyon, Switzerland, for total of $76 million to Priory Hospitals Group (S)

headline: Dow Rises 78.50, to 7,079.39; Technology Issues Rebound
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 78.50 points to close at record 7,079.39; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 8.68, to 813.65; technology-heavy Nasdaq 100 gains 13.81, or 1.64 percent, to close at 854.84 (L)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Dana  Green Mtn Pwr  Total Sys Svcs

headline: Qantas Sells Stake In Air New Zealand
abstract: Qantas Airways Ltd sells its 19.4 percent stake in Air New Zealand Ltd for about $295 million to ANZ Securities Ltd (S)

headline: DOW JONES TO SELL DEMOGRAPHICS UNIT TO COWLES MEDIA
abstract: Dow Jones & Co to sell its American Demographics Inc unit to Cowles Media Co (S)

headline: Health Care Costs Edging Up And a Bigger Surge Is Feared
abstract: Medical costs, which have risen less than inflation for last three years, are inching upward and may be poised for sharper rise, especially for small businesses; employers project 4 percent rise this year as managed care companies strive to make up for thin profits they tolerated while pushing for new members; other factors also remain, such as aging population and costly medical technology; alliances and mergers have also put doctors and hospitals in stronger position to demand higher fees; combined annual premiiums paid by employers and employees averaged $3,915 per employee in 1996; Labor Department reports consumer medical costs rose 3 percent, compared with 3.3 percent rise in overall consumer price index in 1996 (M)

headline: ARDEN REALTY ACQUIRES FIVE PROPERTIES AND CREDIT LINE
abstract: Arden Realty Group Inc says it acquired five suburban office properties totaling 1.3 million rentable square feet for $82.1 million (S)

headline: NETSCAPE COMMUNICATIONS CORP. (NSCP, NNM)
abstract: Netscape Communications Corp reports fourth-quarter net income rose to $8.76 million from $511,000 in 1995 period; table (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Orders for Durables Jump, A Sign of Stronger Growth  Showing unexpected strength, orders for durable goods jumped sharply again in February, suggesting that the economy was gaining momentum as it began its seventh year of expansion.    The increase, 1.5 percent, after January's 4.1 percent surge, lent after-the-fact support to the Federal Reserve's decision on Tuesday to raise short-term interest rates by one-quarter percentage point, to 5.5 percent, to try to avert inflationary pressures. $(Page D3.$)

headline: Agencies Make Three Acquisitions
abstract: Three acquisitions involving agencies have been announced: Arnell Group, New York, acquires majority ownership in Paul Sports, Events and Entertainment Marketing; Gavin Anderson & Co acquires McDonough & Associates, NY; Zuckerman Fernandes MacDaniels Sproul, San Francisco, acquires and absorbs Foley & Magill Inc, Corte Madera, Calif (Advertising column) (S)

headline: MEDPARTNERS PLANS $416.7 MILLION ACQUISITION
abstract: Medpartners Inc will acquire Inphynet Medical Management Inc for stock valued at $416.7 million (S)

headline: McDonald's To Cut Prices To Stem Slide In U.S. Market
abstract: McDonald's Corp, frustrated by steady market share gains by its leading rivals in US, plans to strike back with some of its steepest discounts ever, raising possibility of fast-food price war; initially, Big Mac burger that now sells for about $2 would be cut to about 55 cents when purchased along with fries and a drink; after a while, the Big Mac's price would rise and McDonald's would cut prices to 55 cents on another sandwich; investors fear wave of price cutting in fast-food industry would lower profits; on Wall Street, shares of McDonald's, Wendy's and Pepsico, which owns Pizza Hut and Taco Bell, fall in active trading; table (L)

headline: Milwaukee Bank in Bid to Acquire Rival
abstract: Marshall & Ilsley Corp to buy Security Capital Corp for $945 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: In Trying to Get Into Cuba, CNN Hits Snags at Home
abstract: CNN's effort to open first United States news bureau in Havana is being stalled by Clinton Administration; at issue is whether to allow American news organizations to establish permanent foothold in Cuba, the object of American economic embargo for 34 years; Administration officials say that rival news organizations worry that CNN will gain competitive advantage and that Fidel Castro would have right to grant or withhold access to Cuba to American news organizations; Miami Herald, for example, has been denied access because Cuban officials object to substance and tone of newspaper's coverage; more than half of all Cuban-Americans live in South Florida, and coverage of Cuban affairs is major part of Herald's news coverage; Cuban exile groups are especially critical of CNN's coverage of Cuba, in part because of friendship between Ted Turner, network's founder, and Castro; photos (M)

headline: As Deng Joins the Immortals, Jiang Vows to Keep the Faith
abstract: As the center of this city came to a brief halt today, President Jiang Zemin delivered a final eulogy to Deng Xiaoping before 10,000 Communist Party faithful in the Great Hall of the People on Tiananmen Square. He promised to continue Mr. Deng's policies and invoked his own links to the legacy of Mr. Deng and Mao.    Across the nation of 1.2 billion Chinese, whistles at factories and on trains and ships blew at 10 A.M. for three minutes in tribute to Mr. Deng.

headline: JUDGE TRIPLES DAMAGES IN MEINEKE MUFFLER LAWSUIT
abstract: Franchisees of Meineke Muffler, unit of GKN PLC of Britain, win damages of as much as $591 million in ruling against the company by Federal District Judge Robert Potter; Potter triples damages that were awarded in December after jury found that Meineke defrauded 2,500 franchisees by skimming commissions from advertising money franchisees had invested; plaintiffs contended that Meinke's in-house advertising agency, New Horizon Advertising, broke agreement in way it handled advertising funds (S)

headline: K.G.B. Agent Plays Down Atomic Role Of Rosenbergs
abstract: Aleksandr Feklisov, retired KGB colonel and the conduit between Moscow and Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, says Julius Rosenberg did not provide Russia with any useful material about atomic bomb, although he did give away military secrets; says execution of Ethel Rosenberg was particularly unfair because she did not actively spy herself; Feklisov is latest retired KGB official to confirm that Rosenbergs were spies but did not provide any useful atomic secrets (M)

headline: In Fine Print, Customers Lose Ability to Sue
abstract: Americans are signing away their right to sue, often without even knowing it, by consenting to have disputes with banks, doctors, retailers and others settled through arbitration in which a private referee or panel renders a binding, nonappealable decision; consumer advocates and some scholars fear that wider use of arbitration is sharply limiting the kind of compensation that individuals can receive and warn that system of private justice fostered by the trend conceals wrongdoing from the public; supporters say alternatives to litigation free up courts and provide benefits to companies and customers alike by reducing time and expense of resolving disputes, but even supporters are disturbed by how arbitration clauses are slipped into contracts in ways that escape all but the most conscientious consumer; photo (L)

headline: A Browsers' Bookshop, but There's No Espresso
abstract: Interview with Chen Yunzhen, 80-year-old proprietor of One Heart Bookstore--center of intellectual life in Chengdu, China, where romance novels have replaced teahouse gossip; map; photo (M)

headline: SHAREHOLDERS REJECT PLANNED FOREST PRODUCTS MERGER
abstract: Avenor Inc shareholders reject company's proposed acquisition of Repap Enterprises Inc (S)

headline: A Dining Room Built for 3
abstract: Article by James Tackash, single person and teacher at Roger Williams University, Rhode Island, says recent census data suggest that people who design products and provide services for four-person family may be out of step with American patterns of living; notes 1990 census showed that about 26 percent of American households consisted of married couple and their children, down from 31 percent in 1980 and 40 percent in 1970; also says 1990 census showed 23 million Americans lived alone; says part of the problem is that society expects everyone to be happily coupled and, as result, many products are desiged to accommodate units of four (M)

headline: A Beloved Lady of Spain, Hostage in a Tug-of-War
abstract: Elche, Spain, is angry over government commission's refusal to let it borrow 2,500-year-old Iberian stone bust for celebration marking 100th anniversary of bust's discovery at archeological site near city and 2,000th anniversary of city's foundation; panel holds bust is too fragile for 250-mile trip from National Museum of Archeology, Madrid; dispute is part of growing effort by Spain's regions to reassert their historical and cultural identity and reclaim cultural treasures; map; photos (M)

headline: Orders Down For Durables In December
abstract: Commerce Department reports factory orders for durable goods unexpectedly fell 1.7 percent, Dec, from revised drop of 1.7 percent in Nov; orders rose 5.5 percent in all of 1996, compared with 7.2 percent 1995 gain; graph (S)ï

headline: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES RAISES QUARTERLY DIVIDEND 13%
abstract: United Technologies Corp says it raised its dividend 13 percent, to 31 cents quarterly; company says its chairman, Robert F Daniell, will retire on April 29; post will be assumed by president and chief executive George David (S)

headline: Supermarket Chain To Pay $81 Million To Settle a Bias Suit
abstract: Publix Supermarkets Inc, one of nation's largest supermarket chains, agreees to pay $81.5 million to settle accusations that it systematically denied promotions, raises and preferred assignments to women; settlement may be largest workplace discrimination case in terms of number of people it covers; class-action lawsuit covers more than 100,000 women who worked since 1991 at Publix supermarkets in Florida, Georgia, South Carolina and Alabama; Publix also agrees to $3.5 million settlement with Equal Employment Opportunity Commission over accusations that company had similarly denied job opportunities to blacks; company admits to no wrongdoing in either case, saying it is in full compliance with all fair-employment laws (M)

headline: Zaire Rebel Leader's Big Test: Saving the Economy
abstract: Rebellion sweeping eastern Zaire is fueled by fury at Pres Mobutu Sese Seko for driving vast, resource-rich land into abject poverty, so that big test for rebel leader Laurent Kabila will be how he administers government and economy; Kabila appears to be serious about overhauling civil service, stamping out corruption and inviting foreign investment; administration in Goma has restored roads and electricity, lowered import and export duties and deposited money in treasury so that banks are opened for first time since 1991; some foreign-owned businesses have also returned; photo; map; finance minister Mwana Mawampanga, former economist at University of Kentucky, outlines plans to cut public workforce, begin paying employees and stopping runaway inflation (M)

headline: A Political Survivor Who Travels Light Finally Wins the Trust of the Untrusting
abstract: Man in the News profile of Dennis B Ross, State Department official who brokered deal on Israeli withdrawal from West Bank, winning trust of two people who did not trust each other, Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat; photo (M)

headline: Ideal Economy, but Fed Has Its Guard Up
abstract: Federal Reserve policy makers say economy is finely balanced between healthy growth and inflation, and they do not expect to change interest rates when they meet to consider monetary policy for first time in 1997; four Federal Reserve governors and several regional Federal Reserve Bank presidents suggest they would move swiftly to raise rates if they see any acceleration in wages or prices later in year, despite current ideal combination of steady growth, low unemployment and low inflation; on Wall Street, emerging consensus is that Fed is growing increasingly wary of rising wages, and will raise rates, as early as March, in pre-emptive strike against inflation; comments from Federal Reserve officials Alice M Rivlin, Susan M Phillips, Edward W Kelley Jr and Laurence H Meyer (M)

headline: China Eastern looks good on the surface, but look deeper.
abstract: Market Place column discusses possible risks of buying stock in most profitable and best managed airline in China, China Eastern Airlines, which will list its American depository shares on New York Stock Exchange; says most important question is whether company can manage its finances efficiently (M)

headline: Stocks Lower in Japan
abstract: Japanese stocks close lower on Jan 23, the Nikkei index down 104.42 points, to 17,909.46 (S)

headline: Dow Finishes Up 5.39 After Strong Start
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 5.39 to record 6,709.18, on volume of 445.4 million shares; chart (M)

headline: The Link Grows Cloudy Between Jobs and Prices
abstract: Economists are scrambling to explain why inflation remains low despite drop in unemployment rate below 6 percent; some forecasters hold thesis that low unemployment pushes up wages and prices remains valid and that prices will rise in 1997 (M)ï

headline: All Workers Deserve A Flexible-Hours Law
abstract: Mark Wilson article backs proposal in Congress to enable private-sector workers to save their overtime and use it later as paid time off; lauds Sen John Ashcroft bill, which would also allow employers to offer workers flexible work schedules; drawing (M)ÿ

headline: What Dean Witter's Clients May Be Worth
abstract: Investing column discusses how brokerage firms have edge over individual investors in terms of buying, selling and getting best price on trades; graph on how brokers can often profit more by trading equities on exchanges other than New York Stock Exchange (M)

headline: ADT SPURNS SWEETENED OFFER FROM WESTERN RESOURCES
abstract: ADT Ltd rejects sweetened offer from Western Resources Inc, saying it remained too low; Western raised cash portion and lowered the amount of stock in $3.5 billion hostile bid; new offer is for $12.50 in Western stock and $10 in cash for each ADT share, instead of $15 in stock and $7.50 in cash (S)

headline: The new campaign for 3 Musketeers adds diversity to portray contemporary America.
abstract: New advertising campaign for 3 Musketeers, candy brand sold since 1932 by M&M/Mars division of Mars Inc, will feature black Musketeer in effort to portray diversity in contemporary America phoot; (Advertising column) (M)

headline: New Push for a U.S. Chemical-Arms-Pact Vote
abstract: Pres Clinton renews drive to win Senate ratification of treaty banning chemical weapons, saying failure to act before April will harm both nation's national security and its economic interests; issues statement on fourth anniversary of chemical weapons convention, which prohibits development, production, stockpiling or use of such arms, and calls for destruction of existing stocks and factories that produce them (M)

headline: Lone Rangers Of Charity Are Losing Their Masks
abstract: Charles F Feeney is latest anonymous large philanthropist to have his identity revealed; anonymous giving accounts for only 1 or 2 percent of all contributions over $1 million, but donors are being pressured to reveal themselves by institutions to which they give; institutions like publicity that attends gifts with name attached, and they know that public gifts often spark competitive instinct among other givers; photos; charts (M)

headline: New-Home Sales Jumped 8.6% in January
abstract: Figures released jointly by Commerce and Housing and Urban Development Departments show sales of new homes rose 8.6 percent in January, but private analysts react with caution, suggesting that several factors might have skewed the figures; Conference Board says its index of leading indicators, designed to predict turns in the economy, climbed three-tenths of 1 percent in January, its biggest advance since May 1996; graph; table (L)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: APPLE COMPUTER INC., Cupertino, Calif., named David Manovich executive vice president for worldwide sales and service.

headline: National Education Agrees to Be Acquired for $750 Million
abstract: Sylvan Learning Systems Inc agrees to acquire once-troubled National Education Corp for about $750 million in stock; it is biggest combination to date in fast-growing for-profit education services market; transaction would create biggest provider of tutoring, testing and other education services, with revenue of more than $445 million (L)

headline: New Models Of Growth On a Hot, Hot Stock Index
abstract: Market Place column on growth stocks focuses on new index, the Montgomery Securities Growth Stock Index, which is based on 500 stocks for which Wall Street expects greatest profit growth in coming five years or so; says index is down 11.7 percent since end of January, a period in which Standard & Poor's 500 index is up 2 percent and Russell 2000 is down 1.5 percent; search for growth stocks discussed; graph (L)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.06   5.40   5.13        3-MO.
