headline: Takeover Bid for Barney's Is Reportedly Turned Down
abstract: Creditors committee for Barney's Inc decides that bid offered by Dickson Concepts (International) Inc is unacceptable and begins scramble for other options; Dickson Poon, chairman of Dickson Concepts, says he is prepared to offer $240 million in cash for Barney's and adds that he would also offer minority stake in retailer's licensing business outside United States to either executives of Barney's or retailer's creditors (M)

headline: Sony to Offer Digital TV Studio Equipment
abstract: Sony Corp plans to introduce new line of professional television studio equipment that can produce digital, high-definition programming--the first major product introduction for cameras, monitors and related equipment since Federal Government set industrywide standard for digital broadcasts in late December; other equipment manufacturers are certain to make similar announcements in coming months, to take advantage of marketing bonanza that transition to digital television will provide (L)

headline: In Junk Bond Funds, Risk Often Paid Off
abstract: Junk bonds proved to be among stellar performers of 1996; best of the fund crop was newcomer, the Strong High-Yield Bond fund; fund is managed by Jeffrey A Koch; graph; photo (L)

headline: Producer Prices Fall and Industrial Output Is Flat
abstract: Largely reflecting a big drop in the cost of food, the prices charged by American producers fell in January, the first monthly decline in more than two years, the Labor Department said today.    Separately, the Federal Reserve reported that industrial production was flat in January, providing evidence that the economy was slowing.

headline: Dollar Gets Powerful Help From a Surge in U.S. Stocks
abstract: Rally in US stock market lifts US dollar, as currency traders bet that Asian and European investors will continue to buy American securities and the dollars needed to buy them (M)

headline: BT OFFICE PRODUCTS PAID $42 MILLION FOR SWEDISH OUTFIT
abstract: BT Office Products International Inc says it paid about $42 million for J F Bjorsell AB, Sweden's largest office-products distributor (S)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             Jan. 31   Jan. 24   Feb. 2          1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   7.3   7.4   7.2       Distillate production, daily   3.2   3.1   2.9       Gasoline stocks   204.2   201.3   211.6       Distillate stocks   115.5   119.6   115.2       Crude imports, daily   7.1   7.8   6.9       Product imports, daily   1.5   2.3   2.2       Crude stocks   295.8   289.8   305.4       Crude production, daily   6.5   6.5   6.5       Refinery utilization (%)   90.3   89.1   89.6          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: White House Picks a Slow Path To World Ban on Land Mines
abstract: Clinton Administration announces that it will seek to negotiate worldwide ban on antipersonnel mines, but choses to take slower of two diplomatic tracks; US will push for ban at Conference on Disarmament, which could take years, rather than join Canada on faster track in negotiating ban; US also commits itself to capping and eventually eliminating military's inventory of seven million land mines (M)

headline: NOVELL INC. (NOVL, NNM)
abstract: Novell Inc says its earnings fell 20 percent in first fiscal quarter ended on Jan 31; net income fell to $51 million from $64 million a year earlier; sales fell 14 percent, to $375 million from $438 million; table (S)

headline: THERMO FIBERTEK TO BUY BLACK CLAWSON FOR $110 MILLION
abstract: Thermo Fibertek Inc says it intends to buy Black Clawson Co's paper stock-preparation business for $110 million in cash and assumed debt (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table shows key interest rates

headline: Cable Sports Viewers Face Changes
abstract: Cablevision chmn Charles F Dolan is planning to overhaul way local cable television subscribers pay for and choose Yankees, Mets, Rangers, Knicks, Nets, Islanders and Devils games, raising concerns about how much it will cost viewers; says that now that his company is taking control of Madison Square Garden, he wants to consolidate current system, offering more choices to consumers; but based on way most cable subscribers in metropolitan area pay to watch either MSG Network or Sportschannel, two former market foes now completely under Dolan's control, it appears that many will pay more to fulfill his vision of future (M)

headline: Bell Atlantic Takes Control of Iusacell
abstract: Bell Atlantic Corp and Grupo Iusa say they completed transfer of management control of Grupo Iusacell to Bell Atlantic (S)

headline: One African Takes Fangs Over Fido As a Sentry
abstract: Ben Vermeulen has just founded a company, Respec, for reptile security in Harare, Zimbabwe; Harare is an ideal venue for watchsnakes; Zimbabwe has low rate of violent crime but large number of burglaries (L)

headline: Zaire Rebels Begin Attack On Key City of Kisangani
abstract: Zairian rebels attack Kisangani after three-week siege, setting off panic among Government troops and civilians; photo; map; rumors fly about capital of Kinshasa concerning future of Pres Mobutu's Government (S)

headline: Grumbling on the Job: A Worker's Right or a Wrong?
abstract: Federal appeals court rules that employees can be dismissed for muttering to one another within earshot of customers; National Labor Relations Board ruled in favor of four nurses dismissed by an opthalmology center in Maine for complaining to one another in front of patients, but court found such grousing inherently bad conduct and cause for dismissal (M)

headline: The French And Germans Hear Refrain: Tighten Belts
abstract: Leaders of France and Germany, sounding remarkably alike in televised New Year's addresses, urge their restive voters to keep making sacrifices so their countries can meet increasingly tough global economic competition against Europe's welfare-state economies; excerpts from remarks by Pres Jacques Chirac and Chancellor Helmut Kohl (M)

headline: Dear Mother England, Don't Cut the Apron Strings
abstract: Notion of breaking away from Mother England toward independence, as suggested in recent policy statement from British Foreign Office, has distressed many citizens of Caribbean island of Anguilla, who fear island's small size and limited economic options would not make it viable state; map; photo (M)

headline: Trouble on the Waiting List For Heart Transplants
abstract: Article by John Bray, who has written extensively on science and medicine, discusses problems associated with receiving heart transplant, which he says have been exacerbated by increased use of mechanical devices that can keep people alive for months while they await donated organs; says new devices have increased demand organ donations relative to supply; notes Medicare, which covers costs of some devices, has specified surgeons should make 'every reasonable effort to transplant patients on such devices as soon as practicable' (M)

headline: Celebrity Cruises Narrows Search to 5
abstract: Celebrity Cruises Inc names five finalists to compete for its advertising account, with billings estimated at $15 million (S)

headline: West Bank Town Hails Freed Prisoner
abstract: Stream of visitors to her Ramallah, West Bank, home hail Abir al-Wehaidi, one of 30 Palestinian women freed from Israeli jails under accord with Palestine Liberation Organization; Wehaidi, jailed since 1992 for membership in armed group that killed Jewish settler, has become national heroine to Palestinians; she comments, interview (M)

headline: Tomkins Profit Up 34%, Aided by Denver Deal
abstract: Tomkins PLC reports unexpectedly large 34 percent rise in first-half profit, reflecting its $1.16 billion acquisition of the Gates Rubber Co, Denver; pretax profit of Tomkins rose to 168.8 million pounds ($285 million US) in six months ended Nov 2, from 126 million pounds in previous year (S)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 7/   Thailand tries calming investors as its economy sputters and stocks tumble. By Seth Mydans.    MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 8/   Why four celebrated managers came up short in 1996. By Lisa Reilly Cullen.    SPENDING IT /Page 10/   Through 1999, people over 59 1/2 can take big bucks from a retirement account free of excise tax. But it may be wiser to leave the money in for tax-free compounding. By Jan M. Rosen.    EARNING IT /Page 16/   Thanks to cloning and questions on medical ethics, philosophy majors can finally earn a living. By Barbara Whitaker.

headline: New Software Expected to Cut Web Delays
abstract: Study published by group, based at World Wide Web Consortium in Cambridge, Mass, an industry-sponsored group that sets standards, shows that significant part of delay on World Wide Web has been created by design of software underlying the Web; also shows that redesign of that software would improve basic performance on the Web (L)

headline: Equity Listings For This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Caribiner International Inc., New York, 1.9 million shares. Alex. Brown & Son.    Check Point Software Technologies Ltd., Ramat-Gan, Israel, 5.5 million shares, 4.4 million in the U.S. and Canada. Goldman, Sachs & Co.    Deltek Systems Inc., McLean, Va., an initial public offering of 2.9 million shares. Montgomery Securities.    Edge Petroleum Corp., Houston, an initial public offering of 2 million shares. Raymond James & Associates.    Esprit Telecom Group P.L.C., Reading, England, an initial public offering of 5.4 million American depository shares, each representing seven ordinary shares. Lehman Brothers.    First Aviation Services Inc., Stamford, Conn., an initial public offering of 3.9 million shares. Smith Barney.    General Cigar Holdings Inc., New York, an initial public offering of 6 million class A shares. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.    Group Long Distance Inc., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 1.25 million shares. LT Lawrence & Co.    Iona Technologies Ltd., Dublin, 7.6 million American depository shares, each representing one ordinary share, 6.1 million in the U.S. and Canada. Lehman Brothers.    Nact Telecommunications Inc., Orem, Utah, an initial public offering of 3 million shares. Hambrecht & Quist.    Nordic Equity Partners Corp., New York, an initial public offering of 875,000 shares and 1.75 million warrants. Mason Hill.    Panaco Inc., Kansas City, Mo., 8.4 million shares. Nolan Securities.    Phycor Inc., Nashville, 6.4 million shares. Alex. Brown & Sons.    Riviera Tool Co., Grand Rapids, Mich., an initial public offering of 1.1 million shares. National Securities.    Special Metals Corp., New Hartford, N.Y., an initial public offering of 3.7 million shares. Morgan Stanley & Co.    Sterling Commerce Inc., Dallas, 12.5 million shares. Alex. Brown & Sons.    Trinet Corporate Realty Trust Inc., San Francisco, 6 million shares. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.    Tyco International Ltd., Exeter, N.H., 8.5 million shares, 6.8 million in the U.S. and Canada. Merrill Lynch & Co.    Vistana Inc., Orlando, Fla., an initial public offering of 5.6 million shares. Montgomery Securities.    Westpoint Stevens Inc., West Point, Ga., 1.8 million shares. Merrill Lynch & Co.    Source: MCM Corporatewatch.

headline: Arabs May 'Punish America' for Extradition, Hamas Says
abstract: Hamas spokesman Mahmoud Zahar says that extradition of one of its top leaders, Mousa Mohammed Abu Marzook, to Israel by US could provoke efforts to 'try to punish America'; photo (M)

headline: VIACOM TO TAKE $100 MILLION CHARGE
abstract: Viacom Inc to take fourth-quarter pretax charge of $100 million to close some Blockbuster Music stores and relocate its Blockbuster Entertainment unit's headquarters (S)

headline: After the Talk or the Touching Gets Too Personal, Where to Turn?
abstract: Advice for workers on handling sexual harassment complaints against senior managers; Trisha Brinkman, expert in field, notes companies tend to settle quickly in cases involving supervisors who seek sexual favors in return for job benefits; complaints of hostile job environment are more common and harder to prove; graphs; photo (L)

headline: Egypt Rebuffs Israeli Leader on Spying Case
abstract: Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak, despite appeal from Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, says he will not intervene in case of Azam Azam, Israeli accused of spying against Egypt (M)

headline: PATRIOT AMERICAN HOSPITALITY AGREES TO BUY 5 HOTELS
abstract: Patriot American Hospitality Inc agrees to acquire five hotels for $104.5 milion; hotels, which have total of 1,593 rooms, are Sheraton Park Place Hotel and Hotel Luxeford Suites, both in Minneapolis; Hyatt Regency in Tampa, Fla, and Holiday Inn and Ramada Inn in San Francisco; Doubletree Corp will co-invest 10 percent of purchase prices of Minneapolis hotels and will manage those properties (S)

headline: Europeans Question the French Over Disagreements With U.S. : What's With Paris?
abstract: PARIS—  A string of French diplomatic fumbles that led to headbutting with Washington on issues as diverse as Zaire, Iraq, trade, United Nations leadership and NATO reform has also sown doubts among its European neighbors about France's methods and manners in seeking a stronger Europe, Western policymakers say.

headline: Veteran Executive Is 'Tough And Direct'
abstract: Article on 'tough and direct' management style of John J Mack, who has been named president and chief operating officer of combined Morgan Stanley Group Inc-Dean Witter, Discover & Co companies; Mack is president of Morgan Stanley and has been named to succeed Richard B Fisher as chief executive in June; photo (L)

headline: Summit Bancorp Buying Collective Bancorp
abstract: Summit Bancorp says agrees to buy Collective Bancorp for $867 million in stock, cementing its position as largest bank based in New Jersey (S)

headline: Long Bond Unchanged in Mixed Trading
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities are mixed, as end-of-month buying partly offsets investors' concern that Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates to keep economy from overheating (M)

headline: The Lawyers Get Their Turn
abstract: Lawyers have found niche in debt collection business; while most collection agencies can only threaten to sue delinquents, lawyers actually do; applying mass-production techniques, law firms will often receive thousands of cases a month from credit card issuers and other national lenders and pass them on to lawyers licensed in each state (S)

headline: Heads, I Win. Tails, We Change The Rules.
abstract: Floyd Norris (Market Watch) column questions decision of some companies to slash price their executives have to pay to exercise stock options during times when company's stock price is in period of decline; says corporate rationale for such action is that drop in stock price frustrates purpose of executive option; says by taking such action directors send message that their managements will not suffer if stock price declines; notes this is not true for shareholders who paid for their shares; notes some companies that have reduced price of executive options; graph (M)

headline: In Russia, Teaching Tiny Capitalists to Compete
abstract: Growing number of elementary school teachers in Russia are teaching children about capitalism; chief tool is new textbook Economics for Little Ones, or How Misha Became a Businessman, which tells story of simple but industrious bear who opens a store in the forest and become a tycoon; photo (L)

headline: America Online Cutting Off Inactive Users
abstract: America Online Inc begins monitoring individual subscribers and disconnecting those who do not appear to be using the service; move comes as America Online grappled with increased use after introduction of flat monthly fee (M)

headline: Earnings Rise 9% At British Cement Maker
abstract: Blue Circle Industries PLC reports 1996 pretax profit rose to 297.6 million pounds ($476 million), up 9 percent from 272.8 million pounds in 1995 (S)

headline: The Perks for Parents
abstract: Letter by Claire Lapiska on Dec 1 article which discussed supposed workplace advantages given to parents, as opposed to the childless (S)

headline: In the Land of the Small It Isn't Easy Being Tall
abstract: A quick glance around is enough to tell the arriving visitor here that Ghana is a country designed for the abbreviated of stature.     Visit most homes and the doorways are low. Lie down on any bed outside of the major international hotels and discover how short a mattress can be. And if you are over 6 feet tall, don't even think about buying clothes off store racks here; they won't fit.

headline: CAMPBELL SOUP TO BUY BACK 2% OF ITS SHARES EACH YEAR
abstract: Campbell Soup Co sets long-term goal of buying 2 percent of its shares outstanding each year, following up on buyback program company announced last year (S)

headline: A big brouhaha erupts when Advertising Age takes a few shots at a Miller Lite campaign.
abstract: Miller Lite commercials produced by Fallon McElligott are praised by some for their off-center humor, but critics, led by columnists at Advertising Age, say they are sophomoric and irrelevant to selling beer (M)

headline: A Sudden Sage on Soft Money
abstract: Article by Richard J Mahoney, retired corporate chief executive, on his opposition to soft money, unlimited contributions to political parties often used to circumvent limits on giving to individuals (M)

headline: Miladin Zivotic, 66, Serb Foe of Nationalism
abstract: Miladin Zivotic, leading dissident during Communist era in Yugoslavia and one of most prominent domestic critics of Serbian involvement in Balkan wars, died on Feb 26 at age 66; photo (L)

headline: How an Agency Was Left Behind on the Road Ahead
abstract: Current $4 billion computer modernization fiasco at Internal Revenue Service is traced to Congress's decision in mid-1970's to weaken IRS by not providing funds for new computer systems and master plan for coping with explosive growth in tax return volume; experts say IRS, with its culture of secrecy, misplaced faith in its own expertise and inability to sharply define its mission, bears biggest share of blame; photos; tables (L)

headline: Cigna to Buy Healthsource, Vaulting Ahead in H.M.O.'s
abstract: Cigna Corp agrees to buy Healthsource Inc, troubled managed health-care company, for $1.45 billion in cash and assumption of $250 million of debt; with deal, Cigna, based in Philadelphia, will become one of nation's three largest health insurers, with 12.3 million customers spread over 29 states; graph (M)

headline: Mexico, Harried Over Drugs, Presses Own Peeve: U.S. Guns
abstract: Senior Mexican officials, parrying almost daily attacks from Washington belittling their record on drugs, are complaining to Clinton Administration and Congress that US needs to do more to stem deluge of illegal weapons crossing US border into Mexico (M)

headline: Stocks Sell Off in Japan, And Worst May Not Be Over
abstract: Market Place column on Japan's troubled markets; latest market drop suggests that slide may be far from over; benchmark Nikkei 225 index, which fell all week, closed on Jan 10 at 17,303.65, its lowest level in more than year; frenzied selling surprises even stock market bears and fuels jitters that policy makers are not taking effective measures to turn around nation's faint economy; analysts cite several reasons, but main one is accumulating evidence that Japanese economy is likely to remain too weak to expand out of the troubles that have weighed down banks and other financial institutions; Government recently forecast that economy would grow 1.9 percent in 1997, its lowest forecast since end of World War II (M)

headline: THERMO INSTRUMENT READIES BID FOR LIFE SCIENCES
abstract: Thermo Instrument Systems Inc will make $395 million cash offer for Life Sciences International PLC (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Vail Resorts Inc., Vail, Colo., to Kelley/Dexter Advertising, Boston and Denver, to handle its Breckenridge and Keystone ski resorts, with combined billings estimated at $7 million to $10 million. Those resorts had been handled by an in-house team and fielded out on a project basis. Kelley/Dexter also handles the company's Vail and Beaver Creek ski resorts.

headline: Downsized, but Not Out: A Mill Town's Tale
abstract: Biddeford Textile Co workers battle to save jobs and Biddeford, Me, mill, which Albert J Dunlap, chairman of parent Sunbeam Corp, plans to close or sell in drive to slash Sunbeam's overall work force; Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees seeks to negotiate employee buyout of mill with help of former mill president Rene Boisvert, who resigned in Dec rather than oversee firm's destruction, and investor Michael Liberty; graphs; table; photos (L)

headline: Christopher and U.N. Chief Discuss Differing Agendas for Change
abstract: Outgoing US Sec of State Warren Christopher meets with new UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan; tells him Clinton Administration is confident US can renew close relationship with world body (M)

headline: The Betrayed Maori Are Calling for a Reckoning
abstract: Maori efforts to reclaim lands confiscated by white settlers in New Zealand and raise their status discussed in light of attack on America's Cup by Maori protester; poverty, worsened by severe cuts in Government services, has generated rootless and alienated urban Maori underclass; photo (M)

headline: SNYDER PLANS TO ADD AMERICAN LIST AND BRANN
abstract: Snyder Communications Inc will acquire American List Corporation for $125 million in stock and Brann Holdings Ltd for about $77.5 million in stock and debt (S)

headline: T. EATON RETAIL CHAIN SEEKS BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
abstract: T Eaton Company Ltd, owner of Canada's best-known chain of department stores, declares equivalent of Chapter 11 bankruptcy (S)

headline: For the Clintons' Kitchen: A Three-Leg Cooking Pot
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton visits Cape Town, South Africa, as part of two-week Africa tour; meets with Abp Desmond Tutu, who heads commission probing apartheid-era political crimes; photo (M)

headline: Three States Settle With Prudential On Sales Practices for Life Policies
abstract: Prudential Insurance Co of America agrees to pay $19.4 million to Florida, Texas and Massachusetts that opposed huge class action settlement the company reached with millions of customers who had been sold life insurance policies they did not need; agrees to payment to three states to win their support for $410 million settlement that goes before Federal judge for approval on Feb 24; California is only state still opposing the settlement (L)

headline: Thwarting Irrational Pessimism
abstract: Prof Edward Renshaw letter offers history lesson to prove that Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, should be more concerned about 'irrational pessimism' in stock market than he is about 'irrational exuberance'; chart (M)

headline: Russian Wives Learn What Money Can't Buy
abstract: Many wives of successful Russian businessmen are finding that money and privilege are shadowed by isolation, anxiety and boredom; phenomenon is new in post-Soviet society; such women represent less than 1 percent of population; vast majority of Russian women have little choice but to work; millions are locked in dead-end jobs and have not been paid in months; there is little sympathy for laments of ladies of leisure; Russia remains highly sexist society where women, regardless of marital or professional status, are rarely allowed prominent public role; stay-at-home wife has become important status symbol for new rich, but prestige falls on husbands far more than wives; Elvira Averyanova, who is married to successful CD manufacturer, comments; photos (M)

headline: The Check Is In the Mail? The Wolf Is At the Door
abstract: Elayne Robertson Demby article debunks some myths about pleasures of being able to work at home; says as freelance writer, one major problem is in getting paid; says freelancers do not receive regular paychecks, which makes paying bills on time difficult; says reason she does not go back to her regular job is because she is better off financially by freelancing, given costs of full-time day care, commuting and business wardrobe (M)

headline: A Showdown Forced by the Power of a Union
abstract: Pilot's dispute at American Airlines represents rare instance in which union holds extraordinary power over both employer and much of nation; airline prosperity and resultant increase in pilots' job security has tipped balance of power in pilots' favor (L)

headline: Apple Reports a Loss of $120 Million for First Quarter
abstract: Apple Computer Inc posts loss of $120 million for its first quarter, compared with loss of $69 million in comparable period year ago, and says it does not expect to return to profitability as quickly as it had predicted; Sun Microsystems Inc reports record revenues and earnings for its second quarter, exceeding analyst estimates; Sun had earnings of $178.3 million, up 41 percent from $126 million in period a year earlier; sales were $2.08 billion, up nearly 19 percent; charts (L)

headline: Enron Utility Merger Approved In Move to Expand Nationwide
abstract: Federal Energy Regulatory Commission approves Enron Corp's $3.2 billion purchase of Portland General Corp, using for the first time a procedure intended to speed up pace of adjudicating utility mergers; it is also first approval of a merger between a natural gas company and an electrical utility, a step that could intensify interest in such mergers that began in 1996 (M)

headline: True North Communications and Publicis find a way to end a European joint venture amicably.
abstract: Advertising column describes peaceful end to most fractious dispute in advertising--dissolution of global business alliance between two big agency companies, True North Communications and Publicis SA; venture, called Publicis FCB Europe, covers 31 countries and handles accounts worth an estimated $3.3 billion in billings; it is being renamed Publicis Europe (M)

headline: Otto John, 88, Bonn Official At Center of Counterspy Mystery
abstract: Otto John, high West German official who was at center of counterspy mystery during cold war, dies at age 88 (M)

headline: Ad Review Council Names New Chief
abstract: National Advertising Review Council says that Eric D Haueter, executive director of its National Advertising Review Board, has been promoted to chairman; he succeeds Kenneth A Cox, who is retiring (S)

headline: Tyson Set to Join Ameritech Board
abstract: Former White House economic adviser, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, plans to join board of Ameritech Corp (S)

headline: Weyerhaeuser Plans Account Review
abstract: Weyerhaeuser Corp has begun review of its corporate account, which has long been handled by Seattle office of Cole & Weber, a unit of WPP Group (S)

headline: 401(k) Investments From the Company Store
abstract: Gregory Judd letter on Mar 16 article on perils of companies offering own stock in 401 (k) pension plans (S)

headline: 30 Brokers Fined In Test Fraud
abstract: Thirty of 53 brokers charged in the biggest case ever of brokerage licensing-test fraud were fined as much as $20,000 each yesterday after pleading guilty to felony charges of attempted forgery.    The 30 brokers, who were accused of paying two impostors to take the six-hour licensing exam for them, were also barred for life from the securities industry, said Wayne Brison, spokesman for the Manhattan District Attorney.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Imported Cars Show Gains, But Domestic Models Ebb  Foreign auto makers showed the biggest sales gains in the American market last month as the strong dollar continued to help them offer generous leasing deals and low prices.    Seven foreign auto makers saw their combined sales rise 11 percent, while those of General Motors and Chrysler dropped by a tenth of one percent. $(Page D4.$)    Reports Indicate Slowing of Growth  The Commerce Department said construction spending fell seven-tenths of a percent in December, holding the year's gain to 4 percent, in one of several reports that suggested a moderation of economic growth. A survey of corporate purchasing managers found that manufacturing slowed in January. And personal income outpaced consumer spending in December. $(D4.$)

headline: Where Euro-Parliament Meets, Ideals of Egalite Collide With Immigrant Realites
abstract: Strasbourg, symbol of French-German reconciliation and home of European Parliament, also has high unemployment, ring of slums and tensions over Muslim immigrants; thousands of demonstrators from all over France are expected when National Front holds convention in city; map; Socialist mayor, Catherine Trautmann, gave permission for convention, and will lead demonstrators against front (S)

headline: Reservations Most Definitely Required
abstract: Photo of armed guard outside World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland; only those at pinnacle of business or politics were allowed to attend

headline: Women and minorities are courted by auto makers, which now recognize their buying power.
abstract: Auto makers, nation's biggest advertisers, are stepping up marketing efforts aimed at women and minorities, who account for rising share of car buyers (L)

headline: Mexico Fails to Solve Mystery of Dug-Up Body
abstract: Mexican authorities say they cannot identify remains of body discovered in October, 1996, on farm belonging to Raul Salinas de Gortari, brother of former Pres Carlos Salinas de Gortari; acknowledgment is embarrassing in light of government's earlier hints that remains were those of Manuel Munoz Rocha, a Congressman missing since 1994, and would show that Raul Salinas ordered assassination of Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu (M)

headline: West Bengal Finds It Creates Child Beggars for Export
abstract: Recruiters in West Bengal, India, prowl local villages looking for children to work as beggars; at least 120 children from Berhampur have been exported to Saudi Arabia to beg; Indian officials say scheme began about 15 years ago, but they did not learn about it until 1996, when Saudis put children in detention centers and then on flights home; map; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: EA ENGINEERING, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY INC., Hunt Valley, Md., an environmental consulting company, will lay off about 124 employees as part of a plan to reduce annual costs by more than $9 million.    STEWART ENTERPRISES INC., Metairie, La., which owns funeral homes and cemeteries, acquired Sentinel Cremation Societies Inc. for an undisclosed price.

headline: Reports of Mild Economic Advances Raise Inflation Jitters
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities drop for third day in a row; price of 30-year bond plunges 31/32, to 99 23/32, and yield rises to 6.65 percent, from 6.57 percent on Feb 19; graph (L)

headline: Thailand's Struggling Lenders Put Investors on Edge
abstract: Woes of Thailand's banks and finance companies discussed; regulators suspended trading in shares of debt-ridden banks and finance companies, which account for third of stock market's capitalization, for day; have ordered 10 finance companies to act urgently to raise capital levels; moves, designed to restore public confidence, have driven down stock market and currency and set off run on banks (M)

headline: Code Set Up to Shield Privacy Of Cellular Calls Is Breached
abstract: Team of well-known computer security experts has cracked key part of electronic code meant to protect privacy of calls made with new, digital generation of cellular telephones; will warn public that digital phones may in practice be little more secure from eavesdropping than analog phones; David Wagner, who cracked code along with Bruce Schneier and John Kelsey, blames industry design process (M)

headline: What jurors in Houston may have seen in the landmark Dow Jones libel case.
abstract: Media column examines record $222.7 million libel award against Dow Jones & Co for article in its Wall Street Journal about MMAR Group Inc; says poll of jury found members took to heart judge's instructions about nature of punitive damages, without having idea of how big or small a dollar figure constitutes punishment for company like Dow Jones; notes award left experts in field with feeling that libel award system seems to be going out of control (M)

headline: New Software to the Allocation Rescue
abstract: New software now available to help mutual fund investors review their portfolios at start of new year discussed (M)

headline: In Surprise, Chief at Electrolux Is Named to Head Volvo
abstract: Volvo AB says chief executive Soeren Gyll will leave in Apr, year earlier than planned, and remain director; names Leif Johansson, Electrolux AB chief executive, to succeed Gyll; Electrolux names Michael Treschow, Atlas Copco managing director, to succeed Johansson (M)

headline: Looking Abroad? It Still Pays to Diversify
abstract: Carole Gould Funds Watch column; comments on some international stock funds that have performed well; comments on Berger 100 fund, whose manager, Rodney Linafelter, has left; fund has stumbled since 1993; photo of Linafelter (M)

headline: French Doctor With AIDS Reportedly Infected Patient in Surgery
abstract: Dr Patrick Cohen, surgeon suffering from AIDS, has almost certainly infected patient during operation at hospital near Paris, French Health Ministry says (M)

headline: FRANKLIN QUEST TO ADD SELLER OF TRAINING PRODUCTS
abstract: Franklin Quest Company agrees to pay $160 million in stock for Covey Leadership Center (S)

headline: S.E.C. Adopts Derivatives-Disclosure Rules
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission adopts rules to force most American firms to disclose more data about derivative securities they own and risks derivatives entail; gives firms more discretion in how they make disclosures than proposed earlier; SEC Chmn Arthur Levitt Jr estimates compliance will cost American business $40 million, interview (M)

headline: Conditions Are Right for a Takeover Frenzy
abstract: Corporations are expected to continue looking to mergers as source of growth in 1997, following year in which merger deals soared to over $647 billion; see acquisitions as way to increase profit margins, expand unit growth and control costs; major obstacle to merger wave is number of big targets that have already been bought; graphs; table (M)

headline: Canadian Gold Stock Investors Strike It Poor
abstract: Bre-X Minerals Ltd's stock loses more than 80 percent of its value; trading on Calgary, Alberta, company had been suspended since March 25 because of reports, later partly confirmed by Bre-X and its prospective American partner in developing Indonesian gold site, Freeport-McMoran Copper & Gold, that Indonesian gold strike is probably not nearly as lucrative as Bre-X had said it was; Indonesian Government, which retains 10 percent share of gold site, in Busang area of Borneo, announces that it is suspending the project by withholding mining rights and work contracts that are necessary for mining to begin; death of geologist Michael T De Guzman has added to mystery surrounding Bre-X's gold find; photo (L)

headline: Who Will Pay for a Generation of Expensive Plants?
abstract: Debate about nuclear power's future in United States heats up again, amid fears that nuclear power plants could become financial albatrosses when deregulation allows businesses and residential consumers choices about where they buy power; at issue: how will investors, taxpayers and consumers share in paying for $70 billion in debts piled up to build the plants and the billions more that will eventually be needed to retire them; most nuclear utilities want transition to free markets over 10 years, in which time they can recoup their investment in nuclear plants from rate payers; even those who switch to lower-cost competitors would be dunned with so-called exit fees or surcharges; consumer groups and some nonnuclear utilities are pushing for much quicker transition, saying that forcing consumers to continue paying for plants they are not using will give electricity users choices but no real savings; chart; diagram (L)

headline: BRITISH PAPER COMPANY TO BUY UNIT OF AMERICAN FILTRONA
abstract: Bunzl PLC agrees to buy bonded fiber businesses of American Filtrona Corp for $72.5 million; Bunzl is buying the unit from WBT Holdings LLC, which agreed to buy American Filtrona for about $172 million on Feb 10 (S)

headline: Businesses Urge Turkey To Broaden Democracy
abstract: Leading Turkish business federation calls for faster progress toward full democracy by curbing power of political party leaders and allowing education of Kurds in their own language; also recommends abolishing National Security Council, through which military influences Government policy, and repealing laws limiting public debate on sensitive topics; political and military leaders strongly reject suggestions (S)

headline: NORFOLK SOUTHERN BEGINS TENDER OFFER FOR CONRAIL
abstract: Norfolk Southern Corp begins tender offer for 90.1 percent of shares of Conrail Inc that it does not already own (S)

headline: Nation May Buy Big Copper Mine
abstract: Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea, Julius Chan, confirms that his Government will try to buy abandoned Bougainville copper mine from CRA Ltd, Australian arm of world's largest mining company, RTZ-CRA; CRA owns 53.6 percent of Bougainville Copper Ltd; Government owns 19 percent (S)

headline: FUNDS WATCH
abstract: Scudder, Stevens & Clark starts investment advisory program for people who invest at least $100,000 (S)

headline: Mexico Says Critical Report On Drugs Would Hurt Ties
abstract: Mexico warned today that any move by the United States to downgrade this country's standing as a partner in the effort to fight narcotics smuggling would jeopardize Mexico's future cooperation in the drug war.    Faced with a growing clamor in Washington about the corrupting influence of Mexican drug lords, Foreign Minister Angel Gurria issued a strongly worded appeal to President Clinton today, asking him to renew Mexico's certification as a cooperative ally in the fight against drugs when he files an annual progress report to Congress this week.

headline: Swiss Bank Guard: A 'Document Hero'
abstract: Last Thursday, Christoph Meili, a guard at Union Bank in Zurich, was startled to find two bins filled with papers ready for shredding: old ledgers, lists of mortgaged buildings in Germany in the 1930's and 40's -- the years of Nazi rule.

headline: Texaco to Let U.S. Monitor Bias-Law Compliance
abstract: Texaco Inc, avoiding discrimination lawsuit by the Government, agrees to settlement under which Equal Employment Opportunity Commission will directly monitor company's compliance with employment laws; settlement gives EEOC the power to scrutinize every detail of Texaco's hiring and promotion practices for next five years to insure there is no discrimination against minority employees (L)

headline: Two Koreas and the U.S. Talk About Talks on Declaring Peace
abstract: Delegation from North Korea meets with US and South Korean officials in New York City to discuss possibility of negotiating formal end to Korean War (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * West Coast Entertainment Corp., Philadelphia, to Media That Works, Cincinnati, to handle media planning and buying for the account, with billings estimated at $6 million, of its stores operating under the West Coast Video, Videosmith and Palmer Video names. Those duties had been handled by Harmelin & Associates, Philadelphia. SFGT Advertising, Philadelphia, handles creative duties.    * Houston Image Group to Bates Southwest, Houston, as the first agency to handle advertising and public relations for the civic association. Billings were estimated at $1.5 million.

headline: Bomb Hoaxes in Belfast Disrupt the Nervous City
abstract: False reports of bombs in Belfast follow by a day the IRA's formal declaration that it will continue its campaign of violence to end British sovereignty in Northern Ireland (S)

headline: Compaq Reduces Prices on Some Models
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp cuts prices as much as 27 percent on desktop computers for corporate customers, portable computers, file servers and work stations (S)

headline: South Koreans Limit Strike To One Day Of Each Week
abstract: South Korea's labor leaders limit their strike to one day a week in effort to reduce its paralyzing effect on the economy, but they warn of wider strikes after Feb 18 if Government does not agree to its demand to repeal new labor law; Stephen Cardinal Kim Sou Hwan appears to be trying to mediate, but the prospects for compromise are uncertain (M)

headline: George W. DeFranceaux, 83; Encouraged Investment in Housing
abstract: George W DeFranceaux 2d, retired mortgage banker and developer who helped establish corporation that encouraged private investment in housing for people with low and moderate incomes, dies at age 83 (M)

headline: Consumer Confidence Index Shows a March Dip
abstract: Conference Board reports Americans' confidence in economy slipped in March 1997, and that expectations for coming months dimmed as well; index of consumer confidence fell to 118.5 in March, from revised 118.9 in February, which was highest reading in eight years (S) y

headline: China Reported Ready to End Some Barriers
abstract: China quietly tells US it is willing to abandon many of largest trade barriers, including some of laws that protect state-run and military-run industries from foreign competition, in return for membership in World Trade Organization; offer, conveyed also to European and Japanese officials, marks first time China has discussed eliminating specific laws that have long been subject of complaints by foreign investors; despite new offer, Government has yet to indicate any willingness to tackle most politically explosive problem in opening its markets, namely, ending big subsidies to state-run industries, which employ significant portion of country's workers (M)

headline: The Tale of a Tree, in Which Science Meets Soul
abstract: Bruce Macdonald, director of Botanical Garden at University of British Columbia, offers to transplant two rare golden Sitka spruce trees to Haida Indian land in Queen Charlotte Islands, to replace 300-year-old parent tree that was felled by vandal; photo; map; two young trees were grown from cuttings of giant old tree, which was sacred to Haida (Vancouver Journal) (S)

headline: Gunfire in Residence Raises Tensions in Peru Hostage Crisis
abstract: Tensions remain high at Japanese Ambassador's residence, Lima, Peru, after guerrillas holding 73 hostages fire shots into aid during night, presumably to scare off policemen conducting maneuvers outside compound; gunfire raises fear that Government will raid residence or that maneuvers could spur rebels to kill some hostages (M)

headline: Saudi Group Tied to Other Attacks
abstract: Saudi opposition group Saudi Hazbollah, which Canada says bombed US barracks in 1996, is said to number few hundred people, and has not been implicated in attacks involving high explosives; Canadian report blames group for four other 'terrorist operations,' three separate attacks on Saudi diplomats overseas and 1987 sabotage of gas plant in Saudi Arabia; truck bombing of Dhahran barracks was far more sophisticated attack, which could indicate link to main Hezbollah organization; Hani Abd Rahim al-Sayegh, who allegedly drove lookout car, spent years in Iran and could be link between Saudi Shiite militants and Hazbollah (S)

headline: Heinz and Campbell Settle
abstract: H J Heinz Co and Campbell Soup Co settle legal dispute over Heinz's attempt to hire a Campbell executive; two companies have been feuding since last month, when Heinz said that it had hired Daniel O'Neill, who headed Campbell's domestic soup business, to run Heinz pet food and tuna businesses; Campbell contended that O'Neill had signed noncompetitive agreement that precluded his working for Heinz for 18 months; O'Neill has agreed not to take up any duties at Heinz until Sept 15; until then he will be permitted no business business contacts with Heinz employees, but may see them socially (M)

headline: Dollar's Slide Hurts Prices Of Treasuries
abstract: Treasury market turns down in response to slide in the dollar and continued concern that the economy may be growing at fast enough pace to accelerate inflation and drive interest rates higher; 30-year Treasury declines 5/32, to 96 12/32, to yield 6.78 percent, up from 6.77 percent on Monday (Credit Markets column) (M)

headline: A General in Mexico's Drug War Is Dismissed on Narcotics Charges
abstract: Defense Min Enrique Cervantes Aguirre dismisses Gen Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo, named two months ago to head Mexico's national drug agency, from armed forces, charging he and personnel under his command aid drug baron Amado Carrillo Fuentes; says Gutierrez faces arrest; holds he pursued some drug cartels while serving Carrillo's cartel; dismissal throws Mexico's anti-drug drive into turmoil days before Pres Clinton must certify whether Mexico cooperates in fighting drug traffickers (M)

headline: CNN Is Planning to Provide Live Video as Part of Its Web Service
abstract: Cable News Network plans to join growing number of networks that are moving to offer live video over the Internet; CNN's financial news Web site will offer full video coverage of two programs from CNN's business news channel beginning on Mar 24; company also plans to post video financial news updates from cable channel on Web site twice an hour during business day (M)

headline: HARBINGER ACQUIRING SUPPLYTECH FOR $49.2 MILLION
abstract: Harbinger Corp says it agreed to buy Supplytech Inc for $49.2 million in stock and take first-quarter charge of $7.5 million to $10 million as a result (S)

headline: CB COMMERCIAL AGREES TO BUY KOLL REAL ESTATE SERVICES
abstract: CB Commercial Real Estate Services Group agrees to acquire Koll Real Estate Services for $145 million in stock (S)

headline: Coffee Rises to 5-Month High And Gold Tumbles Further
abstract: Coffee prices jump to five-month high on Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York; gold drops to its lowest price since Sept 1993; soybeans fall (S)

headline: Report Foreign Guests? French Tempers Flare
abstract: Immigration reform bill pending in French Parliament outrages intelligentsia because of requirement that citizens inform authorities of movements of visiting foreigners who are on special guest visas and stay in French homes; would exempt some foreigners, including those from Japan and US, but targets those from long list of countries, especially Africa and Middle East; is seen as reaction to allegations by extreme-right position of National Front Party, which blames country's high unemployment to influx of immigrants (M)

headline: Balloonist, Fuel Short, Unlikely to Circle Globe
abstract: Steve Fossett's balloon crosses Red Sea into Saudi Arabia, but it is doubtful if he has enough fuel to complete a nonstop trip around the world (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.69   5.57   5.29        3-MO. headline: Europe's Wine Industry Is Facing Serious Challenges
abstract: Europe's wine industry faces serious challenges; drinking habits of Europeans in their 20's are changing, with many of them preferring milk, soft drinks, mineral water and beer to wine; while Europe remains heart of global wine production, declining interest in wine drinking among Europeans has contributed to lower overall consumption; meanwhile, countries outside Europe have increased exports, eroding market share of Europe's makers; with too much wine chasing too few drinkers, prices for rieslings and Riojas, Chiantis and cabernets are often well below what it costs to produce them; this spells long-term trouble for Europe's wine industry, with only bright spots being upsacle wine and some cheaper ones; photos; charts (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: INTERIM SERVICES INC., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., acquired Aimexecutive Holdings Inc., an employment services company, for $32.9 million. Interim said that it paid part of the purchase price in cash and that the rest would be made in payments based on future performance.

headline: DIARY
abstract: Diary of business events of week ended Mar 16; graph; photos; drawing (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Chart on key United States interest rates

headline: FLORIDA POWER TO BUY TIGER BAY POWER PLANT
abstract: Destec Energy Inc says Tiger Bay LP agreed to sell a 220-megawatt power plant in Fort Meade, Fla, to Florida Power Corp for $445 million; Destec holds 50 percent stake in Tiger Bay (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Loses 92.75 Points, Falling Below 7,000   Stocks tumbled in what some analysts saw as a natural retreat for an increasingly expensive market. The Dow industrials fell 92.75 points, to 6,927.38, after being down by 114 points at one point late in the session.

headline: Lehman Brothers Earnings Climb by 38.5% in Quarter
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc reports earning $144 million in fiscal first quarter ended Feb 28, up 38.5 percent from $104 million a year earlier; table (M)

headline: G.M. Data Solve Mystery On Auto Parts
abstract: General Motors Corp provides separate financial information on its sprawling auto parts operations; data show what analysts had long suspected: that profits from auto parts division, Delphi Automotive Systems, were propping up otherwise weak results in car-building business; last year, Delphi earned $526 million on sales of $26 billion, for profit margin of 2 percent; by contrast, GM's North American Operations division earned $730 million on sales of $93.38 billion, for profit margin of just eight-tenths of 1 percent (M)

headline: Conagra Set to Settle Criminal Charges It Increased Weight and Value of Grain
abstract: Conagra Inc will pay $8.3 million to resolve criminal charges that its Peavey Grain unit illegally sprayed water on stored grain to increase its weight and value and also bribed Federal inspectors (S)

headline: Studying Bosnia's U.S. 'Prisoners of Peace'
abstract: US Army, in major psychological study of peacekeeping mission in Bosnia, finds that combat readiness, morale and effectiveness of troops appears to plummet after six months of police duty; study, conducted at US staging base in Kaposvar, Hungary, has serious implication for future peacekeeping operations; results worry officers, who note that peacekeeping is not primary function of military; Dr Roger G Gano comments; responses of several soldiers and officers quoted; photo; map (M)

headline: Serb Protests Take On a Holiday Mood
abstract: Anti-Government protesters in Belgrade welcome New Year with thousands of whistles and a display of fireworks, expressing hope for beginnings of democracy in Serbia and for end of one-man rule by Slobodan Milosevic; photo (M)

headline: Even if Times Get Tough, the Technology Industry Is Expected to Shine
abstract: United States high-technology industry is expected to prosper, boosted by rising demand and increasing exports, largely independent of overall economy (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   9.00        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.31   5.05   5.56        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.02   5.03   4.97        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.08   5.08   4.90        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.35   3.39   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.58   6.61   5.69        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.86   6.90   6.11        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.90   7.93   7.27        MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.86   5.87   5.62          *Estimated daily average, Telrate  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: NANTUCKET SUES LEVI STRAUSS OVER LICENSING AGREEMENT
abstract: Nantucket Industries sues Levi Strauss & Co for $37 million in connection with licensing agreement between the two companies; suit contends that Nantucket was defrauded into entering new licensing agreement with Levi's Brittania Sportswear Ltd line three weeks before Levi announced it would sell the unit; Nantucket says Kmart Corp, its biggest customer, is re-evaluating its plan to sell Brittania line because of Levi's announcement (S)

headline: Hilton International wants its frequent guests to have the latest technology for staying in touch.
abstract: Hilton International will invest more than $35 million in three-year program to develop advanced telecommunications technologies for guests, including toll-free telephone number that will follow them around world when they stay at Hilton chain; Swissair will commemmorate 50th anniversary of its trans-Atlantic service by offering aviation buffs trip between Switzerland and New York aboard vintage, 40-seat DC-4; Eurostar, which operates high-speed rail service between major European capitals, has new executive lounge at Waterloo International Terminal in London (Business Travel) (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The emergency board named by President Clinton releases its recommendations for ending the dispute between American Airlines and its pilots.  Earnings reports are expected from Hills Stores and Rexall Sundown.    TUESDAY  Tyco Toys holds a shareholders meeting to consider Mattel's acquisition offer.  The Commerce Department reports on housing starts for February. In January, they rose 2 percent.    WEDNESDAY  The New York State Public Service Commission rules on Bell Atlantic's planned acquisition of Nynex.  The Labor Department releases the Consumer Price Index for February. In January, prices rose one-tenth of 1 percent.    THURSDAY  The Commerce Department reports on the trade deficit for January. In December, it was $10.3 billion.    FRIDAY  The Treasury Department reports its February budget statement.

headline: Jacor Buys EFM Media, Limbaugh's Distributor
abstract: Jacor Communications Inc will acquire EFM Media Management, the New York-based radio syndication company, for undisclosed sum (S)

headline: Popularity Contests for Contrarians
abstract: Roundup of mutual fund news; Morningstar Inc update of earlier study finds strategy of buying least-popular fund categories at beginning of each year, and selling most popular ones, continues to improve investors' odds; fewer taxable money market funds are waiving expenses to bolster yields, with 57.9 percent doing so in 1996 4th quarter, down from 61.2% in 1995 period; graph (M)

headline: El Paso Energy Drops 329 More Workers
abstract: El Paso Energy Corp dismisses additional 329 employees, ending round of job cuts following acquisition of natural gas operations from Tenneco Energy (S)

headline: IMO HIRES INVESTMENT BANKER TO STUDY SALE
abstract: IMO Industries hires Credit Suisse First Boston to study options, including possible sale of company, to increase value of its stock and reduce debt (S)

headline: Islamic Militancy vs. Money-Making in Iran
abstract: Iran is locked in fierce and bitter struggle over how hospitable it should be to non-Muslim world; nation, in need of hard currency that tourism can provide, has begun to lure tourists; but with Islamic strictures banning alcohol, forbidding any display of affection among nonmarried couples and requiring women to cover their heads with scarves and wear clothing that covers their bodies, it is not all that easy being tourist in Iran (L)

headline: Cuba Measure Strikes Back At the U.S.
abstract: Cuban Government approves law penalizing Americans who seeks restitution of their expropriated properties under American legislation that allows American citizens or corporations to seek damages in American courts for their expropriated properties; law also allows Cuban citizens to sue US for damages; does formally recognize that American companies and individuals who were US citizens when Castro came to power in 1959 have right to seek compensation for their losses, though only when US and Cuba are able to negotiate an agreement to that effect (M)

headline: Japan's Economy Expanded At 3.9% Rate in 4th Quarter
abstract: Japan's economy expanded at annual rate of 3.9 percent in fourth quarter; economists caution that growth is likely to slow again this year as tax increases, to take effect in April, dampen consumption; gross domestic product, adjusted for inflation and seasonal factors, grew 1 percent in fourth quarter from prior three months; in all of 1996, economic output rose inflation-adjusted 3.6 percent; about 40 percent of fourth quarter's growth came from increase in net exports, raising prospect that as in the past Japan is exporting its way out of a recession; over all, exports rose 4.3 percent in fourth quarter (L)

headline: Drop in Paper Demand Hurts Finnish Producer
abstract: Metsa-Serla Oy pretax profit fell 83 percent in 1996 to 315 million markkaa ($67 million) from 1.914 billion markkaa in 1995 (S)

headline: S.E.C. May Ease Regulation On Mutual Fund Disclosure
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission aide Barry Barbash says SEC weighs dropping requirement that mutual funds disclose to shareholders all securities in their portfolios, mutual fund industry conference, Palm Desert, Calif; says possible change is part of planned overhaul of semi-annual reports mutual funds must send to shareholders; weighs letting funds substitute list of top 25 to 50 holdings, along with graphic presentation of concentration in different industries or geographic areas, and send complete list of holdings only to shareholders who seek it (M)

headline: Russian Politician Sues U.S. Magazine for Libel
abstract: Boris A Berezovsky, wealthy Russian businessman and politician, sues Forbes magazine, London, charging magazine defamed him by linking him to shady business deals and murder of journalist Vladislav Listiyev; Aeroflot airline aide Nikolai Glushkov joins him in suit; Forbes defends article (S)

headline: Albania Struggles to Contain Dissent Over Lost Investments
abstract: Angry demonstrators swarm through port city of Vlore, Albania, as Government tries to contain crisis brought on by collapse of nationwide phony investment schemes; two reported killed and several dozen hurt; Prime Min Alexander Meksi urges Albanians not to join in unrest that could push country into economic collapse; map (M)

headline: Absence of Foreign Guests Shows Beijing's Attitude
abstract: When the Great Hall of the People filled with 10,000 people today for the memorial service for Deng Xiaoping, there were no foreign faces in the crowd.    No foreign heads of state, special envoys or even resident ambassadors were invited. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright was in town and could easily have represented the United States, but she was told politely that it was best if she left Beijing before the ceremony began.

headline: Jeans Maker To Streamline Operations
abstract: VF Corp, manufacturer of Lee and Wrangler jeans, will combine 17 businesses into 5 as part of streamlining expected to cut costs by $150 million annually; will increase spending on marketing and research by 25 percent, to $1.25 billion (S)

headline: Severe Winter Hurts Sales of Existing Homes
abstract: National Association of Realtors reports home resales fell 3.5 percent in Dec to annual rate of 3.87 million units, down from revised Nov gain of 1.8 percent; cites severe winter weather; reports 1996 sales rose to record 4.086 million homes (M)

headline: The Merger: Reshaping Wall St. or a Step Back?
abstract: Analysis: while some on Wall Street are hailing merger of Morgan Stanley Group and Dean Witter, Discover & Co as shape of things to come, it may turn out to be more of a step back into securities industry's past; traditionally, securities firms that dealt with general public have existed mainly to 'push product,' to sell customers the stocks, bonds and mutual funds that their firms created; Dean Witter is not generally regarded as being in forefront of changes in brokerage business, which include using electronic communications like the Internet, giving customers a full range of investment choices, and letting them pay for advice and performance instead of being charged for every trade (L)

headline: Norway's Rieber & Son Bids for Danish Concern
abstract: Rieber & Son ASA, a Norwegian food, packaging and asphalt company, bids about 747 million Danish kroner ($123 million) for Phoenix Contractors A/S, a Danish maker of roofing and building materials (S)

headline: MEDPARTNERS TO BUY AETNA PHYSICIAN-MANAGEMENT UNIT
abstract: Medpartners Inc agrees to buy Aetna US Healthcare's physician-management business, adding to nation's largest manager of doctors' offices; terms of acquisition of unit of Aetna Inc, the Aetna Professional Management Corp, are not disclosed (S)

headline: Municipal Elections Again Postponed in Bosnia
abstract: Municipal elections in Bosnia, considered cornerstone of rebuilding country, are postponed again in order to better organize teams of international monitors and raise money for balloting; Defense Sec William Cohen, visiting peacekeeping troops, sharply criticizes decision as reflecting lack of commitment by civilian authorities (S)

headline: That Reasonable Standard
abstract: Marshall H Tanick letter on Herbert Barchoff's Jan 26 article on vagueness of sexual harassment laws (S)

headline: Hotels Look For 5th Year Of Growing Profitability
abstract: Hotel industry executives see outlook for 1997 favorable after fourth straight year of record profits; industry's vulnerability to business cycle swings discussed; graph (M)û

headline: CASTLE HARLAN FUND ACQUIRES 60% OF U.S. SYNTHETIC
abstract: Castle Harlan Inc acquires 60 percent stake in US Synthetic Corp for about $60 million (S)

headline: For Some Star Managers, a Bull-Market Year to Forget
abstract: Mutual funds managed by investment stars Richard S Strong, Mario Gabelli, James E Crabbe and Robert J Sanborn failed to match big 1996 gain in Standard & Poor's 500 index and averages of similar funds; managers and analysts comment; tables; photos (L)ÿ

headline: N.T.& T. Aims to Provide 3-Continent Phone Links
abstract: Nippon Telegraph and Telephone to provide communications links between Asia, Europe and United States (S)

headline: Stocks Rise in Japan
abstract: Japan's Nikkei index of 225 issues is up 28.65 points, or 15-hundredths of 1 percent, at 18,750.65 on Monday, Feb 17 (S)

headline: Correction: Fretting Over the Market
abstract: Corrected version of chart that appeared last Sunday about performance of different types of mutual funds during bear markets (S)

headline: Tokyo Stocks Post Gain
abstract: Japanese stocks post small gain in trading on Mar 21; Nikkei index of 225 issues climbs 139.45 points, to close at 18,633.16 (S)

headline: South Korean Strikes Expand as President Delivers Appeal to Labor Unions
abstract: South Korean Pres Kim Young Sam appeals for understanding from striking workers as country's labor strike continues to widen; refuses to make concessions to workers in first extensive remarks on strike that has paralyzed some of country's biggest factories since December 26; workers are protesting labor legislation they fear will make it easier for companies to dismiss workers; photo (M)

headline: Nasdaq Posts 6.5% Increase In Uncovered Short Sales
abstract: Short-selling rose 6.5 percent between mid-February and mid-March 1997 as Nasdaq stock market declined sharply (S)

headline: Failure of AT&T Satellite Will Alter Deal With Loral
abstract: Loral's $712.5-million deal to purchase AT&T's Skynet Satellite Services will be repriced now that AT&T has failed to re-establish communications with Telstar 401; photo; satellite carried signals for big customers, including ABC, Fox and PBS, as well as telephone and computer data; AT&T has moved some customers to Telstar 402R (S)

headline: Irate Agency Quits Delta Account Battle
abstract: Closely watched contest to determine who will create worldwide advertising campaigns for Delta Air Lines Inc--which spends $100 million a year--has taken extraordinary turn at the 11th hour; incumbent agency, BBDO Worldwide, withdraws, charging the review had been rigged by Delta executives to end with BBDO's dismissal; contretemps is emblematic of tumult that has been roiling advertising industry since early 1996, particularly as pace at which huge accounts are going into review--and changing agencies--has accelerated; BBDO withdrawal also doubles as resignation of Delta account, abruptly ending relationship between BBDO, nation's second-largest agency, and Delta, nation's third-largest airline, dating back to 1945; it has become far more common for incumbents to decide against participating in review when clients undertake reviews unexpectedly (L)

headline: North Korea's Leader Says 'Cowards' Are Welcome to Leave
abstract: North Korean leader Kim Jong Il gives new sign that nation might accept defection of Hwang Jang Yop, saying 'cowards' are welcome to leave, radio broadcast; South Korea says North Korea has agreed to attend briefing by United States and South Korea on proposed peace talks aimed at formally ending Korean War; doubts are emerging that shooting of prominent defector Lee Han Young was carried out by North Korean agents in retaliation for Hwang's defection (M)

headline: Israel Begins Jerusalem Housing Project Without Confrontation
abstract: Israeli bulldozers clear ground in Jerusalem for construction of new Jewish neighborhood at focus of latest crisis in Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu's stormy dealings with Palestinians; map (M)

headline: Investors See a Correction, Sometime
abstract: Surfeit of good news is making number of leading stock market pessimists turn bullish despite recent market jitters (M)

headline: Japanese Stocks Lower
abstract: Japanese stocks trade lower on Mar 10; Nikkei index of 225 issues closes down 84.85 points, at 18,113.89 (S)

headline: Secrecy at Scholastic May Have Been in Vain
abstract: Market Place column describes movement in Scholastic Inc stock immediately before and after company announced poor sales figures; says company executives sought to keep news secret before making formal announcement, but action in options market in two days before announcement makes it appear that some traders either knew bad news was coming, or got very lucky; spokesman for Chicago Board Options Exchange refuses to say if exchange has begun investigation, but there is little doubt that probes are under way, and that those who bought put options will be asked to explain how they came to make such timely investments (M)

headline: Pilots Union Faults United On Contract Negotiations
abstract: Leaders of pilots union at United Airlines say they will no longer cooperate in trying to foster collegial culture at employee-owned company; Michael H Glawe, chairman of United Airlines division of Air Line Pilots Assn, who is also on United Airlines board of directors, scores company's approach during recent contract negotiations with pilots; Glawe contends that pilots deserve greater raise than tentative contract allows, because they contributed to unexpected success of company in recent years (M)

headline: China Turns the Tables, Faulting U.S. on Rights
abstract: China issues report on human-rights violations in US; report criticizes US for its racism, inequality of sexes and for its arrogance in trying to tell world how to behave; State Dept recently issued its report on status of human rights in China (M)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt     * Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., known as Freddie Mac, is selling $300 million of debentures due in 2007 through Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch & Co. and Goldman, Sachs & Co. The debentures are callable in one year, carry an interest rate of 7.41 percent and are priced at par.

headline: Continued Rise In the Dollar May Compel Officials to Act
abstract: Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin and members of Group of Seven industrial nations, in move to stem surge of dollar, may have inadvertently given currency traders reason to push it even higher; their statement affirms view that exchange rates should reflect economic fundamentals; dollar gains on currency markets on February 12 (M)

headline: Roche to Buy Flavor Maker for $1.1 Billion
abstract: Roche Holding AG agrees to buy Tastemaker, a flavors company, in transaction that two sellers, Hercules Inc and Mallinckrodt Inc, value at total of about $1.1 billion, including debt assumption (M)

headline: AT&T TO DISMISS 709 LONG-DISTANCE WORKERS
abstract: AT&T Corp will lay off 709 long-distance operators, clerks and customer-service employees at eight offices across US (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Social Security Panel Seeks Investment in Stock Market  A Federal advisory panel suggested that the nation consider investing part of its Social Security revenue in the stock market to insure the solvency of the retirement program, which now invests solely in Government securities. But panel members disagreed on exactly how to do that. $(Page A1.$)    Funneling billions into the market through Social Security could prove to be a boon to Wall Street and would conceivably help to send stock prices to new heights. But the shift could raise interest rates. $(A14.$)    A Better Year for Auto Makers  The auto industry ended the year with a 4 percent drop in sales, but even with the slowdown, auto makers sold 15.1 million vehicles, slightly better than 1995. $(D4.$)    Monsanto Agrees to $1 Billion Deal  Monsanto agreed to buy Holden's Foundation Seeds, a major producer of corn seed, and two Holden seed distributors, for $1.02 billion to capitalize on what it sees as a revolution in agricultural biotechnology. Some analysts viewed the deal as expensive, and Monsanto's stock slipped. Market Place. $(D8.$)    A Bag of Coal for Toys 'R' Us  Shares of Toys ''R'' Us tumbled 14.6 percent in active trading, after the big toy retailer said its Christmas sales were flat and that its fourth-quarter earnings would suffer. Sales of popular items like Nintendo 64 and Tickle Me Elmo dolls were insufficient to offset a lack of software titles and a shortened holiday selling season. $(D2.$)    Apple's Shares Fall Sharply  Apple Computer's shares fell nearly 18 percent after the company announced on Friday that it would report a loss in what is typically its strongest quarter. $(D2.$)    The Dow Staggers to Record  The stock market lurched to a new high, but a broad follow-through to Friday's rally faltered as the bond market continued to sputter. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 23.09 points, to 6,567.18. $(D8.$)    Prices of Treasury securities sagged, dragged down by a weaker dollar and the higher cost of energy. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.77 percent. $(D15.$)    Texaco Names Ad Agency  Texaco named the BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group as its lead corporate agency, to handle a new assignment centered on burnishing Texaco's tarnished brand image. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. $(D7.$)    Heinz and Campbell in Feud  The rivalry between H. J. Heinz and Campbell Soup landed in a courthouse when Heinz hired away a top Campbell executive and Campbell accused the executive of violating a noncompete clause in his contract. $(D4.$)    Prudential Insurance Is Fined  A Federal judge fined Prudential Insurance $1 million after several incidents of document destruction in the company's long-running legal dispute concerning deceptive sales practices. $(D3.$)    Economic Adviser Suits Mainstream  Four years ago, many top economists criticized President Clinton's choice of Laura D'Andrea Tyson to lead the Council of Economic Advisers. But when he selected Janet Yellen as the council's latest head, the move made barely a ripple among economists, and the shift says a lot about their new attitude toward the Administration. $(D3.$)    German Developer Is Charged  Prosecutors in Germany announced fraud charges against Jurgen Schneider, the real estate developer whose empire collapsed nearly three years ago. $(D18.$)

headline: Apple to Take Big Write-Off On Acquisition
abstract: Apple Computer, in moves underscoring extent of its planned corporate overhaul, says it will take $322 million write-off this quarter to reflect cost of acquiring Next Software Inc and that Heidi Roizen, executive in charge of courting outside software allies, has resigned; says it will pay about $30 million more than $400 million previously estimated for Next; Roizen comments, interview (M)

headline: Sporting Goods Concerns Agree to Combat Sale of Soccer Balls Made by Children
abstract: Coalition of major sporting Goods manufacturers and child-advocacy groups, in plan intended to fight child labor, has pledged to combat sale of soccer balls stitched by thousands of children in Pakistan (M)

headline: How to Keep Your Privacy: Battle Lines Get Clearer
abstract: Privacy and anonymity are rarely guaranteed on Internet; there are encryption programs available on Internet, but Clinton Administration and FBI are wary of programs that make E-mail and files impossible to read; sampling of encyrption program sites (M)

headline: Mexico's Telecommunications Giant Reaches Out, and North
abstract: Telefonos de Mexico plans to offer its own long-distance, cellular, paging and other services in American markets where Spanish-speaking customers are concentrated; company will formally file for authorization from Federal Communications Commisssion in coming weeks; its project is most ambitious by a foreign telecommunications operation to take piece of rapidly growing Hispanic market in United States, where Mexicans and first-generation Mexican-Americans alone number 14 million; American companies currently charge considerably more for phone calls from US into Mexico than Telmex and others in Mexico charge for calls going the other way; Telmex will be competing for long-distance business in Mexico against AT&T and MCI Communications through companies they formed with Mexican partners (M)

headline: Florida Brokerage Is Sued by S.E.C.
abstract: Meyers Pollock Robbins Inc, brokerage firm in Boca Raton, Fla, has been accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of fraudulently selling millions of dollars of worthless bonds to investors; SEC lawsuit contends that firm falsely told customers that $13.9 million in corporate bonds were fully insured and risk free (S)

headline: South African Rugby Coach Quits Over Slur
abstract: South African Rugby Football Union accepts resignation of Andre Markgraaff, coach of national team, who was accused of using racial slur to describe national sports officials (S)

headline: Strong U.S. Export Sales Push High Soybean Prices Higher
abstract: Price of soybeans surges on Chicago Board of Trade as unexpectedly strong United States export sales show that highest prices in eight years have not slowed international demand; wheat prices also rise (M)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: STATEWIDE FINANCIAL CORP., Jersey City, named Michael J. Griffin president and chief operating officer of its Statewide Savings Bank unit, succeeding Clifford Adams, who resigned.

headline: Northrop, Losing Bid, Still Hopes To Contend
abstract: Northrop Grumman's unsuccessful effort to acquire Hughes Electronics raises questions about Northrop's ability to compete against three titans that will soon dominate aerospace industry; industry analysts say there are few attractive merger prospects for Northrop that could catapult it into same league as Lockheed Martin Corp, proposed Boeing Co-McDonnell Douglas Corp combination, and now, Raytheon-Hughes; chart (M)

headline: Allied Domecq to Sell Restaurants to Morland
abstract: Allied Domecq PLC says it will sell its Exchange Bar restaurants to Morland PLC for $52.3 million so it can focus more on expanding brands (S)

headline: Netscape Takes On Rivals in KPMG Deal
abstract: Netscape Communications Corp is expected to announce that accounting firm of KPMG Peat Marwick LLP has selected newest version of Netscape's business communications software as standard for 17,000 workers in its 120 offices in United States; deal is important endorsement for Netscape, which seeks to challenge both Microsoft Corp and Lotus Development unit of IBM as leading supplier of messaging software to businesses and institutions; terms of deal are not disclosed; software package, called Communicator, combines Web browser with work-group collaboration and electronic mail; it is still in test version and will not be generally available for several months; KPMG's adoption of Communicator will broaden Netscape's sales effort because deal also calls for accounting firm to become prime reseller of the software to clients of KPMG's information technology consulting business (M)

headline: In Battle Over Strikes, South Korean Police Search Union Offices
abstract: South Korean authorities step up pressure on striking workers; police search union offices and issue subpoenas to leaders of two-week work stoppage that has crippled major industries (S)

headline: Bill Sale Is Treasury's Only Auction This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.01 percent and on the six-month bill was 5.10 percent.

headline: Internet Bookstore Files To Sell Stock to Public
abstract: Amazon.com, popular Internet bookstore, files with securities regulators to sell 2.5 million shares to public in initial offering (S)

headline: Ownership of Newspaper In Chattanooga Is Transferred
abstract: Ownership of The Chattanooga Times is being transferred from four grandchildren of Adolph S Ochs, who bought the paper in 1878 and remained its publisher until 1935, to his 13 great-grandchildren; four grandchildren are also trustees of four trusts that own controlling stake in The New York Times Co; Chattanooga Times remains separate from Times Co (S)

headline: Marion Epley, 89, Former Texaco Chairman
abstract: Marion J Epley Jr, former president and chairman of Texaco Inc, dies at age 89 (S)

headline: A Tale of 2 Economists: Sizing Up the Income Gap
abstract: Richard Albert Seid letter on Louis Uchitelle's Feb 16 article on contrasting views of economists Paul Krugman and Lester Thurow, particularly their explanations for growth of income inequality in United States (S)

headline: 26 Arrested in Mexico; Major Drug Tie Suspected
abstract: At least 26 people, many police officers, are arrested at ranch in western state of Sinaloa during wedding party for sister of Amado Carrillo Fuentes, reputed to be nation's top drug trafficker (S)

headline: Honoring Deng by Making Money, and Laughing
abstract: Calm reaction in Xiangyang, China, to death of Deng Xiaoping points to way that Beijing's authority has receded from ordinary life all over country; map; photo (M)

headline: Immigrants a Strain on Schools : Can Hong Kong Cope With Influx?
abstract: HONG KONG—  Two years ago, 15-year-old Lam Cheong Hung immigrated to Hong Kong from Kwongling, a small town in the southern Chinese province of Guangdong. Upon arrival, he immediately began applying to schools.
