headline: Ion Cioaba, 62, of Romania, Self-Styled King of All Gypsies
abstract: Ion Cioaba, Romanian who proclaimed himself King of All Gypsies, dies at age 62; photo (M)

headline: Silicon Graphics Profit Lower than Expected
abstract: Silicon Graphics Inc reports profit from operations for its second quarter, which ended Dec 31, fell to $2 million from $52.4 million year earlier; cites production delays; says sales rose 23 percent, to $825.3 million; company had loss of $13 million, including $14 million pretax charge related to merger with Cray Research (S)

headline: GENERAL INSTRUMENT RECEIVES $240 MILLION IN CONTRACTS
abstract: General Instrument Corp says it received $240 million in contracts to provide digital wireless systems to People's Choice TV Corp and CS Wireless Systems Inc; says two companies are committed to ordering 600,000 set-top boxes and associated equipment over three years (S)

headline: HealthSouth May Acquire Horizon/CMS
abstract: HealthSouth Corp, nation's largest operator of rehabilitation and outpatient surgery centers, reportedly discusses buying Horizon/CMS Healthcare Corp, which operates hospitals and clinics, for about $1 billion in stock and assumption of $700 million in debt; graphs; table (M)

headline: Mobutu Offers to Share Rule; Some See Ploy to Keep It
abstract: Spokesman for Pres Mobutu Sese Seko says he is willing to negotiate end to Zaire's civil war and share power with rebels, televised statement; says he has formed negotiating team and asked Parliament to name Prime Minister and form transitional government; analysts see Mobutu maneuvering to retain power longer; advancing rebel alliance rejects offer; opposition leaders, angered by rebel leader Laurent Kabila's plan to exclude all existing parties from transitional government, fear he may become another dictator; map; photo (M)

headline: STOCK OF ACCESS HEALTH FALLS ON NEWS OF EARNINGS DROP
abstract: Shares of Access Health Inc plunge more than 31 percent, a day after company says its earnings for current fiscal year will be below expectations; shares fall $7.125, or 31.7 percent, to $15.375 (S)

headline: Andrei Sinyavsky, 71, Dies; Writer Was Sent to Gulag
abstract: Andrei Sinyavsky, a Russian dissident and writer whose imprisonment in the 1960's marked the end of the more liberal period after Stalin's death, died today at his home in the Paris suburb of Fontenay-aux-Roses. He was 71 and emigrated to France in 1973.     The cause was cancer, his son, Iegor, said.     Mr. Sinyavsky's name first became known in the West in 1965 when he was arrested and tried alongside Yuli M. Daniel, another writer, for publishing ''anti-Soviet'' works. He spent six years in a Soviet prison camp near the small town of Potma, 300 miles east of Moscow.

headline: Dispute Ends Donna Karan Jeans License
abstract: Donna Karan International Inc and Designer Holdings Ltd, which was to make a jeans line for the fashion house, end their six-month relationship over disagreements about production schedules and about what and how much clothing Designer Holdings was to make; news is latest in series of disappointments from Donna Karan since it went public in June; Donna Karan says it will return all money involved in the deal, including $6 million initial payment and a $1.26 million advance royalty payment; as a result, Donna Karan plans to restate its third-quarter earnings for 1996, reversing $6 million gain; for the fourth quarter, Donna Karan plans to write down about $3 million in expenses associated with pattern making, marketing and other development costs for DKNY jeans business, which will now return to in-house production (L)

headline: Times Co. in On-Line Pact
abstract: New York Times announces agreement with America Online Inc to expand on-line provider's exclusive use of news features from Times, including original material developed by newspaper (S)

headline: BAIN CAPITAL TO ACQUIRE STAKE IN WALCO INTERNATIONAL
abstract: Bain Capital agrees to acquire majority stake in Walco International Inc, largest US distributor of animal health care products, for $100 million in cash (S)

headline: U.S. Rebuffed By Syrians Over Bombing
abstract: United States says it has failed to win Syria's cooperation in probe of June 1996 terrorist bombing that killed 19 Americans at military residence, Saudi Arabia; says US sought information about Jaafar Chueikhat, Saudi suspected in bombing, who died in Syrian jail in Sept, just before Saudi team arrived to question him; bid for data offers early sign that State Sec Madeleine K Albright may take tougher attitude toward Syria than her predecessor, Warren Christopher, who avoided confronting Syrians about bombing (M)

headline: Rock Singer's Raucous Role: Serbia's Jeer Leader
abstract: Rock musician Bora Djordjevic has emerged as Bob Dylan of protest movement that has swept Serbia since Government's annulment of election victories by opposition in 14 of country's 18 largest cities; photo (M)

headline: Smith Barney and Lehman Bros. Told to Refund $5.6 Million
abstract: Several thousand people who were overcharged when they sold mutual funds held in accounts at Smith Barney and Lehman Brothers will receive $5.6 million; National Association of Securities Dealers has censured and fined Smith Barney and Lehman Brothers $250,000 each and ordered them to pay the refunds, which include interest; in response to agency's findings, Smith Barney has already refunded $2.7 million and Lehman will make refunds of $2.9 million in next 180 days (M)

headline: Terse Congressman Questions Greenspan's Market Motives
abstract: Many people on Wall Street have been asking in last few days why Alan Greenspan thought it was his place to judge that stock prices might be too high, and Rep Jim Bunning, a Republican member of House Budget Committee, puts that question to him, directly and somewhat testily, suggesting that Greenspan should quit meddling when it comes to financial markets (M)

headline: Enclave Reflects Aborigines' Plight
abstract: Redfern enclave in Sydney, Australia is a haven for its 400 to 500 residents, a place of history and community for native people; it is first land Aborigines got to own in Australia in 1973, and is now the last stronghold of Aboriginal land and law in inner Sydney; many Aborigines still come to crime- and drug-infested enclave to find relatives and old friends; residents are fighting redevelopment project as further attempt to assimilate Aborigines and bury their culture; map; photo (L)

headline: Germany May Seek Leeway On Single-Currency Criteria
abstract: Germany, traditionally fortress of fiscal rectitude in Europe, may miss requirement for participating in Euro, single European currency to be introduced in 1999 as leading feature of European monetary union; German Finance Minister Theo Waigel tells meeting of European Union in Brussels that exceptional circumstances, such as 12.2 percent unemployment, will force country to miss requirement, that nation's total debt cannot exceed 60 percent of its gross domestic product in 1997; Germany's debt is estimated at 61 percent by European Union calculations (M)

headline: Syed Amjad Ali, 89, of Pakistan, Envoy to Washington and U.N.
abstract: Syed Amjad Ali, who served as Pakistani Ambassador to US and as his country's representative to United Nations, dies at age 89 (M)

headline: Moderate Weather Forecasts Send Oil and Gas Lower
abstract: Heating oil prices fall, New York Mercantile Exchange, as result of revised forecasts for warmer-than-usual temperatures in the coming week; February heating oil declines to 72.49 cents a gallon, down 1.15 cents; activity in other futures markets also discussed (M)

headline: A Tale of 2 Economists: Sizing Up the Income Gap
abstract: Louis Cohen letter on Louis Uchitelle's Feb 16 article on contrasting views of economists Paul Krugman and Lester Thurow, particularly their explanations for growth of income inequality in United States (S)â

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Home Sales Report Shows Big Gain but Raises Doubt  The Government said that sales of new homes had risen 8.6 percent in January, but private analysts reacted with caution, suggesting that several factors, including the negative effect of the blizzard in the Northeast a year earlier, might have skewed the figures.    In a second report, the Conference Board said that its Index of Leading Indicators climbed three-tenths of 1 percent in January, its biggest advance since May. $(Page D4.$)    The economic reports raised fears of inflation in the bond market. The yield on the 30-year bond climbed to 6.86 percent from 6.83. $(D17.$)    A strong dollar kept Treasury prices from falling further. In a broad rally, the dollar touched a three-year high of 1.7152 German marks before settling at 1.7146. $(D21.$)    Fed Chief Defends Words on Stocks  Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, denied that he intended to talk the markets down by warning last week that investors might be unduly optimistic. He was responding to questions about his comments on stock valuations by a Republican member of the House Budget Committee. $(D10.$)    Mr. Greenspan urged the House Banking Committee to appoint a commission to provide a better estimate of increases in the cost of living than the Consumer Price Index, which most economists believe overstates inflation. The Clinton Administration and Congress have been dancing around the issue of whether to reduce cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security payments. $(A17.$)    Job Cuts at Renault  A plan for job cuts at Renault of France -- of which Belgium will bear the brunt -- shows how the European push toward unity, with its demands for fiscal discipline and greater competitiveness, and the tradition of the social safety net can collide. $(D4.$)    Ford, Too, Says Sales Are Down  Ford Motor said that its domestic vehicle sales fell 3.2 percent in February from a record pace a year earlier, rounding out a down month for the Big Three auto makers. $(D22.$)    Two Retailers Report Earnings  Two retailers, Dayton Hudson and Federated Department Stores, reported higher operating earnings, though Dayton Hudson said its earnings fell after special charges. $(D4.$)    Earnings Calculations to Change  The Financial Accounting Standards Board has voted to change the way earnings per share will be calculated, making it more important to pay attention to the diluted number, the second one in most reports. $(D5.$)    Offer for Barney's Is Rejected  As expected, the creditors committee of Barney's has rejected a $240 million bid for the retailer from Dickson Concepts. $(D4.$)    2 Views on Big Steel  Analysts generally like the stocks of scrap recyclers who provide the raw material for steel minimills, as well as those of service companies that turn steel into parts for the eventual user. But on old-line manufacturers like USX, Wall Street cannot seem to reach a consensus. Market Place. $(D10.$)    Watch Out for Paper Cuts!  Because most product liability cases filed these days include an allegation that a manufacturer failed to warn of potential dangers, companies have reacted -- many experts say overreacted -- by pasting warnings on every imaginable product. $(A1.$)    Pass Go and Collect Cheap Burgers  McDonald's no longer has anything like a monopoly on the fast-food market. In fact, sales have been flagging in the face of tough price competition, and the company is responding with a burger sale of its own. But first, it is turning to another promotion with Monopoly, the game. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. $(D9.$)    Digital TV Gear From Sony  Sony plans to introduce a line of TV studio equipment that can produce digital, high-definition programming. $(D8.$)

headline: Racial Killing Bursts a British Press Taboo
abstract: Daily Mail, British tabloid, audaciously defies country's official secrecy and libel laws by publishing photographs of five white men, alleged white supremacists, who it identifies as murderers of Stephen Lawrence, 18-year-old black, in London in 1993; acts after defendants refused to testify before reconvened coronor's jury, which found them guilty of unlawful killing but refused to publicly identify them; case has provoked outcry over police competence and sensitivity in racial crimes, rights of defendants to be presumed innocent and responsibilities of press; number of judges have denounced newspaper's action, and Attorney General may press formal contempt charges; photos (M)

headline: Petro Vietnam Rejects Bid by Foreign Partners
abstract: Petro Vietnam, state-run oil company, rejects offer from group of companies to help build refinery in center of country; says it will build facility without outside help (S)

headline: Look at That! TV's a Window on Japan's Silly Side
abstract: Increasing number of Japanese voice dissatisfaction with their television programs, as battle for Japan's airwaves heats up in anticipation of more cable channels and satellite TV programs; anyone who turns on television at night in Japan finds succession of variety shows that are crazy, zany and absolutely inane; photo (M)

headline: Vienna Philharmonic Lets Women Join in Harmony
abstract: Vienna Philharmonic, proud bastion of male musicians since its founding 155 years ago, agrees to admit women as full members; members of orchestra, facing protests during upcoming overseas tour and after being held up to ridicule even in socially conservative Austria, agree to admit Anna Lelkes as harpist; they also vote to welcome women to their annual auditions in June; Lelkes photo (M)

headline: New Commercial Service Will Provide Real-Time S.E.C. Corporate Filings
abstract: Internet Financial Network plans news service that will provided brief, headlined excerpts from complex corporate filings with Securities and Exchange Commission; service uses proprietary computer program, rather than people, to sift filings (S)

headline: $2 Billion Deal Expected For Utility
abstract: Western Resources Inc is expected to announce within a few days the acquisition of Kansas City Power and Light Co for $2 billion in stock, bringing to an end a bitter nine-month battle for control; Western Resources would establish itself as Midwest powerhouse by combining Kansas City Power's 430,000 customers in Missouri with its 1.2 million gas and electric customers in Kansas and Oklahoma (L)

headline: France and Germany to Discuss Joint Nuclear Deterrent
abstract: france and germany agree to open discussions on adding a common nuclear dimension to European defense policy, according to secret paper signed by leaders of two countries last month and published by Le Monde; document shows that Chanceller Helmut Schmidt of Germany and Pres Jacques Chirac of France agreed that their security interests have become 'inseparable,' and that two Governments would open 'a dialogue on the role of nuclear deterrence in the context of a European defense policy'; American diplomats in Paris are reassured that joint policy would evolve within, not outside, modernized NATO alliance that Clinton Administration wants to emerge from summit meeting in Madrid in July (M)

headline: Real Estate Company In Japan to Close
abstract: All Corp, real estate financing company in Tokyo, says it will cease operations and set up company to collect its outstanding loans; company says bad loans amount to 85 percent of all its lending and that its total debt is $2.93 billion (S)

headline: Meet Some Buyers of the New Inflation Bonds
abstract: Government's new inflation-indexed bond receives warm reception in its debut; investors demand $37 billion of bonds, more than five times as much as $7 billion offered; most investors were institutions, not individuals; opinions differ on size of individual interest in bonds; as with other Treasuries, new bonds will be auctioned quarterly, with next offering in April; photo (M)

headline: Ecuadorean Is Again Elected Interim President, Five Days Later
abstract: Ecuadorean Congress elects its president, Fabian Alarcon, interim national president; Rosalia Arteaga, interim president, resigns to resume vice presidency after being barred from addressing Congress; blames political 'machismo' for her fate and calls for election; Abdala Bucaram, ousted as president for mental incompetence, leaves for Panama (M)

headline: PEST-CONTROL CONCERN TO JOIN SEARS SERVICES DIVISION
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co says it agreed to acquire All America Termite and Pest Control as part of its plan to expand its services division; terms of transaction not disclosed (S)

headline: WISCONSIN CENTRAL BUYS UNION PACIFIC TRACK
abstract: Wisconsin Central Transportation Co's Sault Ste Marie Bridge Co unit buys 220 miles of track in northern Wisconsin and Michigan from Union Pacific Corp for about $85 million (S)

headline: U.S. May Drop Mexico as Ally Fighting Drugs
abstract: Gen Barry R McCaffrey, head of White House anti-drug office, says that Mexico could for first time lose its status as country that fully cooperates in war against drugs; he presides over interagency meeting on Feb 24 in which senior officials consider downgrading Mexico's rating as ally in drug fight; says recent disclosures about ties between Mexican officials and drug traffickers have reopened discussion about Mexico that had been all but concluded several weeks ago; Mexican officials disclose that corruption of its anti-drug program is more widespread than previously acknowledged (M)

headline: The Trauma of the 90's: Adding New Area Codes
abstract: Telephone area codes are running out of numbers all over country, leading to creation of new area codes; nostalgia for old area codes has led to some bitter squabbles over new ones; resistance is particularly acute in Manhattan, where people blanch at prospect of giving up their 212's; roots of area code lie deep in early years of telephony; photo (M)

headline: COOPERS & LYBRAND TO ADD KWASHA LIPTON CONSULTANCY
abstract: Coopers & Lybrand LLP to merge benefits consulting company Kwasha Lipton into its human resource advisory business; terms of deal are not disclosed (S)

headline: Nasdaq Revises Its Plan to Cut Share Minimum
abstract: Nasdaq Stock Market responds to Securities and Exchange Commission request, and scales back its proposal to reduce minimum number of shares that can be traded under commission's new order-handling rules (M)

headline: Growth Rate In 4th Quarter Cut to 3.9%
abstract: Commerce Dept reports that economy grew at annual rate of 3.9 percent in fourth quarter, slower than 4.8 percent estimated originally; attributes downward revision in growth of gross domestic product to unexpected liquidation of inventories at retailers and other businesses (M)

headline: VALERO SEES POSSIBLE MERGER ACCORD BY FEBRUARY
abstract: Valero Energy Corp says it received number of proposals since it announced plans to spin off its refining and marketing business and sell off its remaining natural gas assets (S)

headline: Boston Beer Acquisition
abstract: Boston Beer Co, brewer of Samuel Adams beers and ales, acquires Hudepohl-Schoenling brewery in Cincinnati from Hudepohl-Schoenling Co; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Chrysler hopes a corporate-image campaign helps shake the memories of K-cars and bailouts.
abstract: Chrysler Corp will unveil new television ads on January 16, continuing first corporate advertising campaign in four years; three 30-second spots, created by Bozell Worldwide, described (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Dr. Ian A. H. Munro, 73, Editor Of The Lancet Medical Journal
abstract: Dr Ian A H Munro, crusading editor of British medical journal The Lancet for 12 years, dies at age 73 (S)

headline: Zaire's Rebels Win New Converts
abstract: Rebel leaders who control 900-mile swath of eastern Zaire have been winning more and more converts among local population; Zairian Government's counteroffensives and mercenary-led attacks have made little headway against rebel alliance; even bombing of Bukavu by Pres Mobuto Sese Seko's mercenary pilots, which took six lives, has not diminished support for rebels; rather, many Goma residents see bombing as act of desperation, sign that Government is losing the war; map (M)

headline: Fujimori Softens Tone Before Talks in Canada
abstract: Peruvian Pres Alberto Fujimori flies to Toronto to confer with Japanese Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto on hostage siege at Japanese diplomatic compound in Lima; 72 hostages are still being held by Tupac Amaru guerrillas who invaded residence December 17; Japan is concerned about aggressive police tactics at scene; Fujimori reportedly will assure Hashimoto that Peru will not use force to end crisis as long as hostages do not die (S)

headline: Ameritech Exceeds Earnings Expectations
abstract: Ameritech Corp reports better-than-expected 38 percent rise in fourth-quarter, with earnings of $570 million, compared with $413 million in same period in 1995; earnings chart (M)

headline: Fresh from London, Saatchi & Saatchi's new chief executive in the U.S. is off to a fast start.
abstract: Interview with Jennifer Laing, newly appointed chief executive of North American operations of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide (Advertising column); photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Accord Is Seen to Fuel Textile Trade With China   China and the United States reached a broad agreement on textile trade, which American officials said was likely to increase Pacific region commerce that is already worth billions of dollars.

headline: Corporate Spinoffs Are Getting a New Spin
abstract: Corporate spinoffs are booming, with diversified firms spinning off to shareholders far larger chunks of their business than in past; much of pressure for spinoffs is coming from institutional investors (M)x

headline: USAir Earnings Tumble by 55% As Costs Continue to Increase
abstract: USAir Group Inc says that earnings fell 55 percent in fourth quarter to $27.2 million; reports net income for year rose to $263.4 million from $119.3 million a year earlier (S)

headline: There's a new scheme afoot for getting, and then using, hotel guests' credit card numbers.
abstract: Business travel news roundup; Denver area Days Inns are warning guests against revealing their credit card numbers to people who call their room posing as front desk staff; HFC's Days Inns to open first Days Business Place, Houston; plans to open 20 more such hotels for business travelers within few weeks; Swissair tests in-flight gambling system developed by Interactive Flight Technologies; Hilton Hotels and Ladbroke Group's Hilton International team up to offer guests frequent-flier miles for multiple hotel stays at business rates; American Poetry and Literacy Project plans to give away books of love poems for Valentine's Day to airline, train and subway passengers and hotel guests; some 5,000 couples will renew wedding vows aboard Princess Cruise Lines ships around world on Valentine's Day (M)

headline: Netanyahu to Visit Egypt but Mubarak Won't Reciprocate
abstract: Prime Minister Bejamin Netanyahu of Israel will visit Egypt to discuss quest for wider peace in Middle East; Pres Hosni Mubarak says time is still not right for him to make return visit to Israel; says under current circumstances Egyptian public would not approve even of visit to second-tier Israeli town; says he has little faith that such gesture would have any effect on quest for peace (M)

headline: Treasury Offerings Set for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.     By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.02 percent and a six-month bill was 5.11 percent.

headline: On Capitol Hill, Praise for U.N. Leader but No Firm Word on Aid
abstract: Kofi Annan, new Sec Gen of United Nations, completes second day of lobbying on Capitol Hill, winning praise and pledges of cooperation from Republicans who control House, including Speaker Newt Gingrich; ends his visit to Washington with no concrete commitment that United States will soon repay the more than $1 billion in dues it has withheld for more than three years (S)

headline: Times Site On the Web Wins Awards
abstract: New York Times on the Web, the World Wide Web service of The New York Times, won 2 of 10 prizes awarded by Editor and Publisher magazine last week, one for best overall on-line newspaper service and one for best editorial content by an on-line newspaper service; other winners noted (S)

headline: Russia Atom Aides Buy I.B.M. Supercomputer Despite U.S. Curbs
abstract: Russia's nuclear weapons establishment says in effort to circumvent US export controls, it has obtained powerful International Business Machines supercomputer through unidentified European middleman; Russian officials say computers are needed to maintain reliability of their nuclear stockpile now that Moscow has agreed to ban on nuclear tests (M)

headline: Vero Wynne-Edwards, 90, Evolution Theorist
abstract: Vero C Wynne-Edwards, British ethnologist who theorized that natural selection acts on groups as well as individuals, dies at age 90; photo (S)

headline: VISHAY OFFERS TO ACQUIRE GENERAL INSTRUMENT DIVISION
abstract: Vishay Intertechnology Inc. said yesterday that it had made a bid for the semiconductor division of the General Instrument Corporation, becoming the second company to seek the division. Neither General Instrument nor Vishay, an electrical component maker in Malvern, Pa., would disclose the bid price. The division has sales of about $360 million. General Instrument is also talking to Taiwan's Liton Group about selling the semiconductor division.

headline: Finally, a Social Security plan that may achieve a consensus.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column says corporate-sponsored Committee for Economic Development has come up with Social Security plan that may achieve a consensus; notes that it would gradually reduce benefits guaranteed to future retirees, gradually increase retirement age to 70, and increase years of lifetime employment needed to be eligible for maximum benefits to 40 years, from current 35 years; says 'grandfathering' privileges of current elderly would neutralize senior citizens' potent lobby; drawing (M)

headline: U.S. Jury Links Mexican's Cash To Drug Bribes
abstract: Federal jury in Houston, Tex, rules that most of $9 million confiscated by US Government from Mario Ruiz Massieu, former coordinator of Mexico's anti-drug program, came from drug traffickers; decides to return $1.1 million of total it believes he obtained legally (S)

headline: MVSI SHELVES BID FOR NICHE COMMUNICATIONS COMPANY
abstract: MVSI Inc shelves its $60 million plan to buy E-Net Inc, citing decline in its own stock since its primary underwriter, Stratton Oakmont Inc, was banned from securities business (S)

headline: VEBA SELLS 20 PERCENT STAKE IN PENN VIRGINIA
abstract: Veba AG sells 20% stake in Penn Virginia Corp for $36 million to various buyers, including Penn Virginia board members and senior managers (S)

headline: CKS Group Buys McKinney & Silver
abstract: CKS Group says it acquired McKinney & Silver for $24 million in stock; McKinney & Silver will operate s autonomous unit of CKS (S) y

headline: Royal Navy Shipyard Sold
abstract: Halliburton Co's Devonport Management Ltd venture agrees to acquire Devonport Royal Dockyard Ltd in Plymouth, Eng, for $66.1 million (S)

headline: Intel Doubled Its Earnings In 4th Quarter
abstract: Intel Corporation reports fourth-quarter '96 net of $1.91 billion, compared with $867 million in year-earlier period, exceeding expectations of Wall Street analysts; attributes hefty gains to record sales of Pentium and Pentium Pro microprocessors and to high profit margins; will pay special $1,000 bonus to each of 48,500 employees; board of directors authorize 2-for-1 stock split; shares closed at record $147.125 in Nasdaq trading on January 14; president and chief executive Andrew S Grove comments (M)

headline: LESLIE FAY DELAYS HEARING ON PLAN TO EXIT BANKRUPTCY
abstract: Leslie Fay Companies postpones until February 13 hearing on plan to exit bankruptcy; has not completed financing and other details of reorganization (S)

headline: Too Much Fun At the Kremlin: Aides Lose Jobs
abstract: Dimitri Sokolov, Pres Boris N Yeltsin's personal photographer, and several senior members of presidential security service are dismissed after party in Kremlin gets drunkenly out of hand; informed sources note that revelers were all cronies of Aleksandr V Korzhakov, who was recently ousted as Yeltsin aide (S)

headline: Correction
abstract: A report in the Business Diary column last Sunday about the fourth-quarter results for Philip Morris misstated the period in which the company sold 891 billion cigarettes. It was all of 1996, not the final quarter.

headline: People
abstract: Kevin McKenna was named president of Harte-Hanks Direct, New York, a unit of Harte-Hanks Communications, succeeding Jan Steinert, who left. Mr. McKenna had been president of the data technology group and new business development director at Draft Direct Worldwide, Chicago, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos.

headline: An office supplier takes a page from Lombardi's playbook.
abstract: Advertising column describes advertising campaign for Ikon Office Solutions, giant office equipment and technology company, that will urge consumers to 'work to win'; theme was created by W B Doner & Co; Ikon is new name for what is now known as Alco Standard Corp; photo (M)

headline: Ingalls Moranville Preparing Sun Ads
abstract: Ingalls Moranville Advertising, finalist in review for account of Sun Microsystems Inc, is creating campaign that marks company's first national television advertising (S)

headline: Chevron's Bet On Kazak Oil, A Long Shot, Is Paying Off
abstract: Chevron Corp's $700 million investment in Tengiz oilfields of former Soviet republic of Kazakstan, derided as foolish by other major producers, is finally paying off and is forcing many skeptics to swallow words and competitors to follow lead into former Soviet lands; company is expected to report profit of $80 million from Tengiz oilfields in 1996, up from $1 million in 1995; map; chart (Market Place) (M)

headline: Voice of Britain, First Thing Each Day
abstract: BBC's Today program is thought by many to be indispensable to British life; it sets agenda for public discussion more than any other news program, in a country with particular appetite and talent for debate; major figures in public life clamor for chance to appear on program, even though it means bracing encounter with aggressive interrogators; program has made its content increasingly serious in recent years, and manages to be contentious without descending to 'Crossfire'-type slugging matches; politicians from Britain's two biggest parties have smarted from sharper-edged questions; it is said that former Prime Min Margaret Thatcher judged mettle of her ministers by how well they held their own against combative Today hosts; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Dana Perfumes, Stamford, Conn., a division of Renaissance Cosmetics Inc., to Lotas Minard Patton McIver, New York, to handle advertising for the Navy and Navy for Men line of fragrances. Lotas Minard also handled the account under the line's previous owner, the Procter & Gamble Co. Billings were estimated at $4 million to $5 million.

headline: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES AGREES TO BUY WALLACE AUTOMOTIVE
abstract: Republic Industries agrees to buy Wallace Automotive Group for $55 million in stock (S)

headline: Swiss Producer Prices Fell 2.2% Last Year
abstract: Swiss producer and import prices fell 2.2 percent in 1996, lowest yearly rate since 1986; Swiss interest rates are expected to stay at their lowest levels in 18 years (S)

headline: Consultants Setting Up On the Web
abstract: Many management consultants have sites on World Wide Web, but finding management consulting information is not as easy as it would seem; photo (M)

headline: India Rehabilitates Wartime Leader Who Fought for Japan
abstract: India officially rehabilitates independence leader Subhas Chandra Bose with elaborate ceremonies marking 100th anniversary of his birth; Bose was leader of Indian army that fought alongside Japanese forces in World War II; he reportedly died in 1945 (M)

headline: Love Among the Cubicles
abstract: The New York Times is looking for stories on office romances and their effects on office productivity; drawing

headline: U.S. Factory Orders Rise 2.5%, and Joblessness Gauge Falls
abstract: Commerce Department reports orders placed with American factories rose 2.5 percent in January, while Labor Department report shows more strength than expected in labor market; rise in factory orders brings them to record $323.2 billion and is first increase in three months; December's decline is revised to 1.5 percent, from 1.3 percent; Labor Department reports number of workers applying for first time for state unemployment benefits fell unexpectedly last week by 6,000, to seasonally adjusted 310,000; graph (L)

headline: NETSCAPE SHARES DROP AFTER ANALYST CUTS RATING
abstract: Shares of Netscape Communications Corp decline 19 percent after Wall Street analyst cuts his rating on the stock on the ground that the software maker's revenue growth may stall (S)

headline: Media Madness Down Under
abstract: Television networks in Australia owned at least in part by billionaires Rupert Murdoch and Kerry Packer regularly tangle over news coverage; competition involves open checkbooks and even bare knuckles; networks regularly raid one another's talent and use dirty tricks to disable their rivals' news-gathering abilities; networks were so eager to get exclusive on recent survival-at-sea story that they hired bodyguards to keep others at bay; Australian viewers see humor in the situation; photo (M)

headline: Agency Puts Off A Stock Offering
abstract: Frankel & Company, marketing and promotion agency in Chicago, will postpone initial public offering of shares, citing unfavorable market conditions (S)

headline: HEALTH COMPANIES DROP MERGER IN FAVOR OF STOCK PLAN
abstract: Health Risk Management Inc and Healthplan Services Corp call off their planned $80 million merger because of delays caused by Securities and Exchange Commission; Healthplan agrees to buy 200,000 unregistered Health Risk shares, representing about 4.5 percent of company's stock (S)

headline: 'Like the Bad Old Days' as Fright Revisits Ulster
abstract: Residents of Markets, predominantly Roman Catholic working-class neighborhood of Belfast, Northern Ireland, fear Protestant paramilitaries may be preparing to end self-imposed cease-fire in response to recent increase in campaign of violence by overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Irish Republican Army; map; photo (M)

headline: Peru Rebels Fire Guns From Residence, but No One Is Hurt
abstract: Leftist Tupac Amaru guerrillas fire guns from residence of Japanese Ambassador in Lima, Peru, where 74 hostages are being held, day after plans for renewing direct talks between them and Government fell apart; guerrilla leader Nestor Cerpa Cartolini says shots were intended to ward off police, who had breached 110-yard security zone (M)

headline: Republic Industries to Buy National Car Rental
abstract: Republic Industries to buy National Car Rental System for $600 million in stock and assumption of $1.7 billion in debt; Republic bought Alamo Rent-a-Car Inc just two months ago; National, which caters to business travelers, would complement Alamo's concentration on leisure market; two have average combined fleet of 265,000 vehicles, which would also provide steady inventory for Republic's used-car supermarket chain, Auto Nation USA; analysts say H Wayne Huizenga, head of Republic Industries, seeks to become major force in auto industry; his strategy has been to cobble together array of automobile-related operations that can in turn benefit each other; graphs (M)

headline: COX IN $160 MILLION DEAL FOR SEATTLE TV STATION
abstract: Gaylord Entertainment Co says it has agreed to sell its KSTW-TV station in Seattle to Cox Broadcasting Inc for $160 million; if and when transaction wins approval from Federal Communications Commission, parent company Cox Enterprises will own or operate 12 television stations (S)

headline: Home Is Where the Work Is
abstract: Mary Schumacher article on growing number of home-based businesses in Seattle, Wash, where she lives; says small businesses are taking advantage of new ways to mine small markets, and computer allows them to be served more efficiently by home-based operators; describes how she and her husband ended up running home-based company; drawing (M)

headline: House Votes To Punish Mexico Over Drugs
abstract: US House votes, 251-175, to impose sanctions on Mexico after ninety days unless Pres Clinton reports substantial progress by Mexican Government on various aspects of drug war, from extraditions to concrete measures to root out corruption; vote falls short of two-thirds needed to override almost certain veto by Pres Clinton; five Senators offer alternative, nonbinding, resolution that expreses concern about insufficient Mexican progress on halting production and shipment of narcotics (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CAMERON ASHLEY BUILDING PRODUCTS INC., Dallas, a building products distributor, agreed to buy Bois Daigle, a Canadian distributor of building materials with revenues of $47 million last year, from Simard-Beaudry Inc., Quebec, for undisclosed terms.

headline: MAJOR CITY'S FALL POSES DIRE THREAT TO ZAIRE'S RULERS
abstract: Kisangani, largest and last Government-held city in eastern Zaire, falls to rebel forces, posing most serious threat yet to 31-year rule of Pres Mobutu Sese Seko; even more worrisome for Government than fall of Kisangani is reported switch of elite Government forces to rebel side; fall of Kisangani represents final unraveling of war strategy of Government, which relied on Serbian mercenaries and battle-hardened Hutu fighters from former Rwandan Army to shore up its own inadequate forces; photo; map (M)

headline: INTUIT STOCK FALLS WITH PROJECTED REVENUE SLOWDOWN
abstract: Shares of Intuit Inc fall to 52-week low of $22.625 after company says revenue in coming quarters will be crimped by slowing growth in market for personal-finance software; company expects revenue of $600 million to $620 million in current fiscal year, just shy of analysts' forecasts of about $640 million (S)

headline: G.M. May Sell Up to 20% Of Merged Parts Business
abstract: General Motors Corp is in process of adding its Delco Electronics Corp to its Delphi Automotive Systems unit to form world's largest auto suplier, with 210,000 employees and revenue of about $32 billion; John F Smith Jr, GM's chairman and chief executive, says company is considering selling up to 20 percent of merged unit; Delco is subsidiary of GM's Hughes Electronics Corp; GM acknowledges that it is cooperating with Justice Dept, which is investigating whether employees of GM or Volkswagen accepted kickbacks to steer contracts to auto suppliers (M)

headline: Dividends Rise, but Not as Fast as Stocks
abstract: Data released by Standard & Poor's show that 2,171 American companies increased their dividend payouts in 1996, up 13.8 percent from prior year and the most for any year since 1980; at same time, dividend payout on stocks in Standard & Poor's 500 stock index rose 8 percent, nowhere near the 20.3 percent price rise shown by S&P 500 during 1996; as result, dividend yield on index fell to record low of 1.97 percent in November, and 2.02 percent at end of 1996; graph (M)

headline: Serbia's Socialist Rulers Face A Growing Split Over Protests
abstract: Battle for control of Serbia's key cities, which opposition coalition appeared to win in November '96 elections but lost when Government annulled results, has opened serious rifts within ruling Socialist Party; faction that emerges triumphant from power struggle will either propel Serbia toward democracy, and toward compromise, or plunge country into authoritarian rule that gives up any pretense of democracy; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: Promotions in advertising field noted (S)

headline: Seeing Hints of Suharto in His Old Friend's Business Deals
abstract: Profile of Mohamad Hasan, ethnic Chinese magnate in Indonesia who is longtime trusted friend of Pres Suharto, and peacemaker among Suharto's six powerful children; Hasan owns forests, paper and plywood mills, airlines and banks, and recently won stake in hotly contested Busang gold mine in East Kalimantan; he has also become head of country's biggest carmaker, Astra International, to help settle feud among two Suharto sons (S)

headline: How U.N. Chief Discovered U.S., and Earmuffs
abstract: Interview with new UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan; photo (M)

headline: Sale of Gucci Lifts Investcorp Earnings
abstract: Investcorp reports earning record $90.4 million, 1996, up 29 percent from 70.3 million in 1995; says it is poised for acquisitions in Europe and United States (S)

headline: CLEAR CHANNEL TO BUY 2 MILWAUKEE RADIO STATIONS
abstract: Clear Channel Communications Inc will aquire two Milwaukee radio stations, WMIL-FM and WOKY-AM, from Chancellor Broadcasting Co for $40 million (S)

headline: U.S. TRANSPORTATION TO ACQUIRE PRECEPT INVESTORS
abstract: US Transportation Systems Inc agrees to buy Precept Investors Inc for stock valued at about $135 million (S)

headline: Daimler-Benz Rebounds With $1.7 Billion Profit
abstract: Daimler-Benz AG rebounds from record $3.4 billion loss in 1995 to higher-than-expected profit of $1.7 billion in 1996 (S)

headline: Buffett, Who Deems Stocks High, Will Still Keep McDonald's
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway chairman, Warren E Buffett, says most stocks are overvalued, letter to shareholders; excludes shares of own company, which has acquired 4.3 percent stake in McDonald's Corp (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Apple Chief Presses Plans But Offers No New Details  Gilbert F. Amelio gave the best speech of his one-year tenure as chief executive of Apple Computer, persuading frustrated shareholders to give him more time to turn around the troubled company.    But he offered no new initiatives to reverse Apple's decline and instead criticized its corporate culture, drawing big applause at the shareholders' meeting when he said that in the past Apple's marketing efforts had been too soft and that in the future the company would ''attack'' the competition. $(Page D4.$)    Fed Leaves Rates Unchanged  The Federal Reserve's policy committee voted to leave interest rates unchanged, betting that a surge in economic growth would moderate and leave inflation under control. The decision continues a yearlong pattern in which the Fed has kept monetary policy steady. $(D2.$)

headline: G.M. Increases Payout and Sets Stock Buyback
abstract: General Motors Corp raises quarterly dividend to 50 cents a share from 40 cents and sets $2.5 billion stock buyback; plans to buy back some 5 percent of shares outstanding over next 12 months (M)

headline: $9.5 Billion Merger In Weapons Industry
abstract: Raytheon has agreed to acquire General Motors' military businesses for $9.5 billion in stock and new debt in what could be the last big takeover in the weapons industry.     The deal for the Hughes Electronics businesses will make Raytheon the third largest military contractor -- after Boeing and Lockheed Martin -- and it will leave Northrop Grumman, the losing bidder for Hughes, facing an uncertain future.

headline: Job Search Lures Mexicans to Far Corners of U.S.
abstract: Millions of Mexicans, who over decades have headed from Gaudalajara and vast agricultural region around it to work as migrant laborers at traditional sites north of border, are finding new frontiers, responding to demand for cheap labor in parts of US far from its southwestern border; dispersion into virtually all 50 states has increased since 1986, when Immigration Reform and Control Act legalized status of more than two million Mexicans who had been working in US without documents; trend has accelerated since peso crisis of 1994, when many middle-class Mexicans began traveling north in search of work; Urban Institute reports 6.7 million Mexicans, excluding migrant workers, living in US in 1996; map; photo (M)

headline: Morgan Stanley Executive Is Set to Lead Van Kampen
abstract: Philip N Duff, chief financial officer of Morgan Stanley, has reportedly been named chief executive and president of Van Kampen American Capital, company acquired by Morgan Stanley last fall; at Van Kampen, Duff will work with Don G Powell, current president and chief executive of Van Kampen, who is expected to stay on as chairman (M)

headline: South Korea Is Upset and Its Leader Imperiled by Tycoon's Way With Forbidden Fruit
abstract: South Korean Government of Pres Kim Young Sam, who took office four years ago vowing to wipe out collusive relationship between Government and business that has existed for decades, is imperiled by scandal surrounding business tycoon Chung Tae Soo, who is accused by prosecutors of paying large bribes to politicians in exchange for favors, notably helping arrange bank loans to his Hanbo Steel Corp, which collapsed in January under nearly $6 billion in debt (M)

headline: Ingalls Wins Citizens Telecom
abstract: Citizens Telecom unit of Citizens Utilities names Ingalls Advertising to handle account, with billings estimated at $12 million to $17 millioin (Advertising) (S)ï

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: Chart on United States Petroleum data on Jan 3, 1997, Dec 27, 1996 and Jan 5, 1996

headline: Broderbund Shares Plunge on Profit Outlook
abstract: Shares of Broderbund Software Inc plummet following company's announcement on March 4 that its second-quarter earnings will fall below analysts' estimates; Broderbund says price cuts prompted by competitive market eroded its profit margins; shares decline $7.375, to $23.125 (M)

headline: Peruvians Back Fujimori In Facing Hostage Crisis
abstract: First opinion survey in Peru since Dec 17 takeover of Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima finds that 59 percent of Peruvians approve the way Pres Alberto K Fujimori is handling the hostage siege; 30 percent disapprove, and 11 percent have no opinion (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: Another Shortcut At the Gas Pump
abstract: Just as drivers are becoming used to paying by credit card at the pump, the Mobil Corporation has come up with an even faster way to buy gasoline -- a chore that most customers do not savor.    During a six-month trial at 55 Mobil stations in St. Louis, about 10,000 customers have been able to simply wave a miniature electronic device attached to their key chains in front of certain pumps.

headline: Hong Kong Celebrates a Money Man's Audacity
abstract: Many executives in Hong Kong fear that China's rule will mean corruption of efficient and open business practices that have allowed Hong Kong to profit so handsomely off China's economic boom in last decade; they are shocked and fascinated at recent deal in which Larry C K Yung, chairman of mainland-backed Citic Pacific Ltd, personally bought $1.24 billion of company's stock at sharply discounted price; they wonder how Yung's superiors at Citic, parent company in Beijing, ever agreed to deal which gives Yung a total of 18 percent of the company; deal illustrates how high-stakes risk and opportunity abound in Hong Kong, with a mainland Chinese twist (M)

headline: Internet Advertising Growing Slowly
abstract: Growth of advertising on World Wide Web is not keeping pace with use; $200 million or more was spent in advertising in 1996, up from from $55 million in 1995, but more than half of that was accounted for by Web- or computer-related companies, and it remains an insignificant portion of the estimated $173 billion spent on advertising in US that year; advertisers say they would be more active if there were more sophisticated ways to measure Web advertising's effectiveness as a marketing tool; chart (M)

headline: Analysts Debating Valuation of Stocks
abstract: Several leading stock analysts hold old rules no longer apply when judging whether stock prices have soared beoynd reason; see stock prices only modestly high at worst when adjusted for new era defined by low inflation and public's keen attraction to stock mutual funds; New Era analysts meet skeptical resistance from traditionalists sobered by experiences of past downturns, who fear grossly excessive stock prices could fall sharply; analysts of both schools broadly agree that investors should temper enthusiasm for market; New Era theorist Abby Joseph Cohen and traditionalist Byron R Wien comment; graphs; photo (L)

headline: People
abstract: * Gerry Millet, chairman, chief executive and chief creative officer at Lehman Millet, Boston, was named president of LM International, a new unit; he continues as chairman and chief creative officer of all Lehman Millet units. Bruce Lehman, president at Lehman Millet, becomes chief executive.

headline: Siemens to Buy 2 Units From Daimler-Benz
abstract: Daimler-Benz AG, Germany, to sell its AEG Electrocom GMBH and AEG Electrocom International Inc units to Siemens AG for undisclosed terms (S)

headline: In Hebron Accord, the Future Begins to Take Shape
abstract: Palestinian political entity on West Bank and Gaza Strip begins to emerge with Israeli troop withdrawal from city of Hebron; it still resembles nothing more than islands in an Israeli sea, with every area under some form of Palestinian control separated by channels policed by Israeli authorities, but some territorial contiguity appears likely with the transfers of land to which Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has committed Israel over next 18 months; map shows who control various parts of Gaza Strip and West Bank; photo of Palestinian celebration in Hebron (M)

headline: OXFORD HEALTH PLANS INC. (OXHP, NNM)
abstract: Oxford Health Plans reports fourth-quarter 1996 net inncome of $32 million, compared with $15.6 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: Investing Manager Is Part of S.E.C.'s 'Soft Dollar' Inquiry
abstract: SEC is investigating Dawson-Samberg Capital Management, investment management firm in Southport, Conn, as part of wider inquiry into financing arrangements between investment managers and their brokers (S)

headline: Top Officials of 3 Railroads to Meet on Conrail Takeover Dispute
abstract: CSX Corp and Conrail, in what may be breakthrough in costly three-month-long battle for Conrail, agree to meeting with Norfolk Southern Corporation to discuss reshaping rail freight industry in East; Norfolk Southern, which has offered $10.5 billion in hostile bid to take over Conrail, has stymied friendly merger between CSX and Conrail (M)

headline: DOUBLETREE RAISES BID FOR RENAISSANCE BY MORE THAN 5%
abstract: Doubletree Corp says it increased amount of stock it plans to pay for Renaissance Hotel Group, raising acquisition price more than 5 percent, to $890 million in cash, stock and assumed debt; purchase price also includes assumption of $70 million of Renaissance debt (S)

headline: 3 NATIONS AGREE ON FREEZING GOLD LOOTED BY NAZIS
abstract: US, Britain and France agree to freeze distribution of $68 million in gold bars looted by Nazis from European central banks; Clinton Administration officials say gold could form core of fund to compensate Holocaust victims; gold has stored at Federal Reserve Bank in New York and Bank of England since Switzerland, Sweden and other nations turned them over to Allied powers at end of World War II; most of estimated 337 metric tons collected from secret accounts was returned to central banks after systematic looting by Nazi troops as they moved across Europe; Tripartite Commission, scheduled to distribute remainder to central banks early in '97, was blocked by Jewish groups led by World Jewish Congress, which claimed some part of gold came from private citizens in Europe, especially Jews, whose assets were seized as they were sent to death camps (M)

headline: Y.& R. to Link 2 Operating Units
abstract: Young & Rubicam Inc forms new operating entity, Young & Rubicam/Wunderman Partnership to formally link, but not merge, its Young & Rubicam Advertising and Wunderman Cato Johnson units; names Edward H Vick chairman and chief executive of new unit and Mitch Kurz president and chief operating officer; also names Kurz president and chief operating officer of Y & R Advertising; names Barbara Jack to succeed Kurz as worldwide chief executive of Wunderman Cato Johnson (S)

headline: South Korean Labor Leaders Falter in Effort to Broaden Strike
abstract: Three weeks of labor strife in South Korea may be winding down; Government officials threaten to arrest strike leaders soon; two labor union umbrella groups had called for strikes to intensify, but many workers decide at last minute not to strike (M)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: Buying a Better Bottom Line      Companies flush with cash but unable to increase revenues made 1996 a record year for mergers and acquisitions. Are there any good targets left? Page C3.    Yes, the Euro      No longer a joke, the European Union's common currency is set to become reality, even as many of the Continent's real problems go unaddressed. Page C9.    Follow the Buyer      With growth slowing at home, many American consumer goods makers are seeking customers abroad. But that may be harder to do than it sounds. Page C10.    Opening Markets, Closing Doors      Challenging Disney, the BBC and the Internet, China made it clear that it will welcome foreign investment but not freedom of ideas. Will the West go along? Page C12.    Phone Free-for-All      With deregulation the law and mergers reshaping the telecommunications landscape, expect a lot of lawsuits and surprises. Page C14.    Bulls Run and Run (Nervously)      Stocks rose to record heights. But the ifs have started to mount about earnings, savings and Alan Greenspan. Page C21. Year-end stock tables begin on page C25.

headline: 'Unlimited' On-Line Access Does Have Its (Time) Limits
abstract: Some Internet access companies are having second thoughts about so-called unlimited $19.95-a-month service plans that became industry's de facto standard in 1996; many smaller access providers who were forced by competition to go along with flat-rate plan are now complaining that price plan that encourages people to log on and linger is simply not profitable; even big access providers typically will disconnet user's Internet session after 15 minutes if absence of keystroke or mouse click indicates subscriber may have logged on and then wandered away (M)

headline: Talks Resume Between Peru And Guerrillas
abstract: Peru resumes talks with Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement guerrillas holding 74 hostages at Japanese Ambassador's residence, Lima; makes first public show of communicating with rebels after cloaking earlier talks in secrecy; photo (M)y

headline: Catera Ad Pulled By Cadillac
abstract: General Motors Corp pulls TV commercial for its small cadillac catera because of concerns that it might offend women; ad, by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, showed model wearing dominatrix outfit (S)

headline: Panel Resumes Talks With Rebels Holding 72 Hostages in Peru
abstract: Members of Peruvian Government-designated commission resume contact with Tupac Amaru rebels holding 72 hostages in Japanese Ambassador's residence, seeking framework to resolve standoff (M)

headline: Unit of HSBC Buying British Train Company
abstract: Forward Trust, leasing and finance unit of HSBC Holdings PLC, says it agreed to buy British train leasing company Eversholt Holdings Ltd for $666.13 million in cash and additional $68.9 million in loan notes (S)

headline: New Video-Conferencing Unit Aims for the Middle Market
abstract: Sony Corp and handful of other companies are trying to fill gap in United States for mid-range video-conferencing equipment; Sony will introduce Trinicom Mini 1000, priced at $6,995, to take its place alongside Sony's $21,600 'roll about' system and its $1,995 desktop system; Trinicom Mini 1000 is compact and incorporates video camera and 20-inch screen (M)

headline: In wake of brief American Airlines strike, some second thoughts about consolidators' tickets.
abstract: THE short-lived American Airlines strike caused plenty of confusion but relatively little disruption among travelers, yet it is already generating some second thoughts among the growing number of business travelers.    Those are the travelers who have been using tickets sold by consolidators -- companies that buy deeply discounted seats from airlines on flights that are not expected to fill up, then sell them at bargain prices (in most cases) to individuals or to travel agents who add a commission and pass along the remainder of the savings to the customer.

headline: Web Transforms World of Personnel
abstract: World Wide Web offers many resources for corporate human resources departments, making possible instant information, recruiting and networking; chart listing sites (M)

headline: Spike/DDB Comes Out Swinging
abstract: SET Pay Per View division of Showtime Networks and Don King Productions name Spike/DDB to handle advertising and promotion for boxing rematch between Evander Holyfield and Mike Tyson, set for May 3; assignment is first for firm, joint venture between Spike Lee and DDB Needham Worldwide; AIM Management Group Inc names Deutsch Inc to handle its account, which had been at Rives Carlberg; El Al Airlines names Goldberg Fossa Seid to handle American advertising, which had been handled by Goldsmith/Jeffrey (S)

headline: Enron, seeking to be a household name, plans to start its campaign on Super Bowl Sunday.
abstract: Allen R Myerson (Advertising) column discusses plans by Enron Corp, nation's largest independent natural gas company, to transform itself from natural gas and electricity trader, into competitive electricity retailer as well, with brand name as familiar at AT&T or Sprint; says Enron will announce its first major ad campaign starting with televised spots before and after Super Bowl XXXI, as well as multimedia print campaign; says ads, developed by Conquest, unit of WPP Group, will explain how company helped citizens in Peterborough, NH, and elsewhere to cut their electricity bills (M)

headline: Web Publishers Start to Feel Lack of Advertising
abstract: Shakeout of World Wide Web publishers has been gathering momentum for at least year as Internet advertising has failed to grow quickly enough and users continue to balk at paying for much on-line material; battle seems to be evolving into war of attrition, with those with least resolve or resources dropping out first; some media giants, including Time Warner Inc, continue to lose heavily on Web ventures while awaiting medium's success (M)

headline: Peru Rules Out a Rebel 'Suggestion' in the Hostage Crisis
abstract: Peruvian Government rejects proposal by Nestor Cerpa Cartolini, leader of Tupac Amaru rebels holding 74 hostages at Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima, that Guatemalan official be included on commission that is being formed to end standoff (M)

headline: TELEPORT IN STOCK SWAP FOR INTERNET SERVICE PROVIDER
abstract: Teleport Communications Group to buy Internet company Cerfnet Services Inc from General Atomics for $68.3 million in stock (S)

headline: RYERSON TULL AGREES TO ACQUIRE THYPIN STEEL
abstract: Ryerson Tull Inc says it agreed to acquire Thypin Steel Co for $140 million in cash and assumed debt (S)

headline: Murdoch Again Tries His Luck on Line
abstract: Rupert Murdoch's News Corp, which has had many false starts on Internet, is trying again; Murdoch's son, James, will guide company's latest Internet venture, the TV Guide Entertainment Network; new site will include contents of TV Guide magazine as well as original articles on movies, television, pop music and sports; photo (M)

headline: Spain Accuses Basques In Fatal Bombing Attack
abstract: Car bombing in Bilbao, Spain, kills Spanish policeman; Government blames Basque separatists (S)

headline: The Lawyer Leading the Charge Against the F.C.C.'s Regulations
abstract: Former Atty Gen William P Barr, now general counsel at GTE Corp, is leading landmark legal assault on how Government plans to carry out Telecommunications Act of 1996; Barr has argued in Federal court that Federal Communications Commission has no business ordering GTE or other local phone companies to open their networks to new competitors like long-distance providers or cable system operators; Barr has become standard bearer for those who believe Government is shackling GTE and the Bells in its zeal to unshackle rest of industry; some experts expect court to overturn new rules entirely; FCC officials say Congress directed them to open up local telephone market; FCC fear is that if GTE prevails in court, competition promised by telecommunications act will be strangled by countless other legal challenges; photo (M)

headline: Killings Erode Cairo's Claim to 'Control' Militants
abstract: Series of attacks that have left 23 civilians dead undermine Egyptian Government's claim to victory in war against Islamic militants; many of those massacred were Coptic Christians, who are about ten percent of population and have long suffered persecution; Islamic militants have waged violent campaign against Governnment for five years; graph showing numbers killed in attacks and Government countermeasures; map (S)

headline: Tradition triumphs: an obvious choice is the clear favorite in planning where to be on Dec. 31, 1999.
abstract: Annual survey by YP&B/Yankelovich Partners shows 45.8 percent of respondents plan a special trip to New York City on New Year's Eve 1999 to welcome in year 2000 in Times Square; other destinations noted; airline seats and hotel rooms for travelers to Hong Kong are still scarce to nonexistent for days leading up to July 1, when colony reverts from British to Chinese rule; but plenty of seats and rooms are available in most of weeks and months after change of government; Roswell, NM's permanent population of about 50,000 is expected to double over three-day Fourth of July weekend--the 50th anniversary of what many believe was crash of UFO on nearby ranch; more and more New York hotels are installing automated currency conversion machines in their lobbies; machine in Ramada Milford Plaza, a Broadway hotel, dispenses money in various currencies (L)

headline: In Crowded Market, Retailers and Brand Names Struggle to Keep Ahead in Asia
abstract: HONG KONG—  Designer-label fashion is still in big demand in Asia, but retailers are finding that the good old days, when simply bringing these products to a hungry market was enough, are long gone. Today, with an abundance of famous brands available, everyone has to fight hard for market share.

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: SHERIDAN HEALTHCARE CORP., Hollywood, Fla., said it would sell 11 office-based physician practices in Florida, resulting in a fourth-quarter pretax charge of about $17 million. Terms were not disclosed.     CENTRAL HUDSON GAS AND ELECTRIC CORP., Poughkeepsie, N.Y., said it would repurchase 2.5 million of its shares, or 14 percent of its common stock outstanding, over three years.     RAYTHEON CO., Lexington, Mass., the military electronics and aerospace company, received a $240 million contract to manage United States Navy bases in Florida and the Bahamas.

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS : 10-4, Good Buddy:CB Radios Enjoy a Roadway Renaissance
abstract: A generation after citizens-band radios had millions of people, especially truckers and other drivers, chattering over the airwaves in colorful jargon ("I tried to warn him about that Smokey, but he had peanut butter in his ears"), a revival is under way.

headline: Netanyahu and Arafat Say Peace Talks Are on Track
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat meet at Erez checkpoint between Israel and Palestinian-controlled Gaza Strip to discuss further steps in carrying out peace accords; describe meeting as constructive; meeting is aimed at fulfilling various apects of agreement reached in January '97 on Israeli troop withdrawal from most of Hebron; map (M)

headline: Albright Picks 2 Diplomats For Top Posts
abstract: Madeleine K Albright, confirmed as Secretary of State by Senate, 99-0, names Thomas R Pickering Under Secretary for Political Affairs, replacing Peter Tarnoff; names Stuart E Eizenstat Under Secretary for Economic Affairs, succeeding Joan E Spero; choices seen signaling she intends State Department to play leading foreign-policy role on issues with strong economic components; Strobe Talbott will remain for now as Deputy Secretary (M)

headline: Construction Companies To Merge in Netherlands
abstract: Royal Volker Strevin NV is in talks to buy Kondor Wessels Groep NV for about 500 million guilders ($262 million), creating Netherlands' second-largest construction company (S)

headline: Skyy vodka is staking a claim to the color blue in a campaign that takes on a popular rival.
abstract: Skyy Spirits Inc in San Francisco, Calif, is bringing out advertising campaign bathed in blue for Skyy vodka, which has enjoyed robust growth since its introduction in 1993; blue-mood print advertisements, with budget of $2.5 million to $3 million, are first from Hal Riney & Partners since that shop was awarded Skyy account in November 1996 from Monte Sandy & Needham in San Francisco; photo (L)

headline: Unlikely Meeting of Minds: Lebed Meets The Donald
abstract: Aleksandr I Lebed, in New York City to court investors and apparently to further bid to succeed ailing Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin, meets with developer Donald Trump; Trump says he hopes to build 'something major' in Moscow; photo (M)

headline: Barney's-Isetan Dispute to Require a Trial
abstract: Barney's Inc loses round in its effort to have court find that Isetan Company is an equity partner of Barney's rather than its landlord; Barney's bankruptcy case reviewed (S)ï

headline: U.S. Remains Odd Man Out In Global Push For Phone Deal
abstract: Negotiators meeting at World Trade Organization in Geneva, Switzerland, say that most countries in organization appear ready to sign agreement to open up $600 billion worldwide market for telecommunications services; US is still threatening to walk away from any pact unless it obtains more concessions from Canada, Mexico and Japan; US is pushing for an end to legal barriers that protect state-controlled telephone monopolies in many countries from all competition (L)

headline: Prices of Crude Oil Increase On Yeltsin Health Rumors
abstract: Crude oil futures soar on New York Mercantile Exchange amid speculation by traders that health of Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin is worsening, raising fears of political upheaval in oil producing country (M)

headline: SERBIAN PRESIDENT ACCEPTS VICTORIES BY HIS OPPONENTS
abstract: Serbian Pres Slobodan Milosevic, abandoned by key supporters, unable to force police or army to crush daily street protests and under intense diplomatic pressure, says he will restore opposition victories in local elections, letter to Parliament; opposition leaders, wary because of his history of feigning compromise while retaining power, say they will continue protests until he eases grip on news media; call for democratic reforms (M)

headline: Bonds Improve on Outlook for Inflation
abstract: Bond market participants bracing for the worst are surprised with better-than-expected producer price report that temporarily supplants notion that rate increase is a given at Federal Reserve's coming policy meeting; 30-year bond rises; tables (M)

headline: G.M. Expects a 7% to 8% Sales Drop in February
abstract: General Motors Corp, hurt by slow introductions of number of redesigned models, estimates that its sales dropped 7 percent to 8 percent in February compared with corresponding period year ago (S)

headline: Ex-Centennial Head Is Arrested by F.B.I.
abstract: The former chairman of Centennial Technologies Inc., Emanuel Pinez, was arrested today on charges of securities fraud by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.    Mr. Pinez, 58, who was dismissed on Monday, was accused of trying to profit from a decline in Centennial's stock by buying put options and selling call options on the stock, according to the F.B.I.

headline: Hearst to Buy Argyle TV In a Rare Public Venture
abstract: Hearst Corp will buy Argyle Television Inc, owner of six stations, for $320 million and create public company, Hearst-Argyle Television Inc (M)

headline: Albright: View From a Czech Town
abstract: Letohrad, Czech Republic, Mayor Petr Silar on Feb 25, 1994 wrote to Madeleine K Albright, then US representative at United Nations, to tell her that her Jewish father hailed from town and that her grandparents and other close relatives had died in Nazi camps; letter and accompanying article summarized events in Albright's family history that she described as 'major surprise' after they were reported in Washington Post recently; Albright, who was raised Catholic, has said she knew nothing of her Jewish past; map; photo (M)

headline: Britain Names Panel For Ulster Parades
abstract: British Government says it will appoint commission in Northern Ireland to try to control religious-patriotic parades that have led to violence (S)

headline: To Get More Defensive, Try Cost-Cutting Companies
abstract: Michael Brush observes that judicious stock picking may soon gain on broad market bets as an investment strategy, with market looking so pricey these days; some analysts say that stocks in cost-cutting, and downsizing, companies can be particularly good bets in a market decline; table (M)

headline: A doctor has devised a knot for securing a new flexible thread to bones during surgery.
abstract: Dr Chaim Rogozinski receives patent for devising knot for securing new flexible thread to bones during surgery; Louis Kuhn receives patent for new garment that can improve posture through placement of side pockets that force wearer's shoulders back when hands are inserted; William McKewen receives patent for transparent sketch plate to help artists; Mei-Hui Chang, Wang-Jung Chih and Shih-Yi Chang get patent for pacifier that can also take baby's temperature; Joseph Manico and Cynthia Bell of Eastman Kodak get patent for talking photo album--boxlike picture viewer with built-in recording and playback device (M)

headline: Dow Roars to Early Gains But Finishes the Day Lower
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 4.61 points, to 6,656.08; table (M)

headline: VF Plans to Bolster Position By Acquiring Maidenform
abstract: VF Corporation will acquire Maidenform Worldwide Inc for undisclosed amount, shoring up its position as leading manufacturer of women's intimate apparel (S)

headline: Equity and Convertible Issues Expected This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Agco Corp., Duluth, Ga., 4.7 million shares. Merrill Lynch & Co.

headline: Cowboy at U.N.: A Smile and a Lasso
abstract: William Blaine Richardson begins work as United States delegate to United Nations; pledges Clinton Administration support for UN, while pressing drive to cut US dues and UN budget and bureaucracy; stuns diplomats and bureaucrats by working cafeteria like politician; photo (M)

headline: In Wales, Doubts on Foreign Investment
abstract: CARDIFF, Wales—  Prime Minister John Major will sink a silver-plated spade into the thin Welsh soil near here Wednesday, officially breaking ground for what is said to be the largest foreign investment Europe has ever seen — the new $2.75 billion manufacturing base for LG Group of South Korea.

headline: Campbell Battles Heinz in Court Concerning Move by Executive
abstract: H J Heinz Co announces that it has hired Daniel O'Neill, president of Campbell Soup Co's domestic soup business; Campbell claims O'Neill signed noncompetition agreement with company that precludes working for Heinz; Heinz has filed lawsuit seeking to invalidate O'Neill's noncompetition agreement; O'Neill was passed over recently at Campbell for promotion (M)

headline: Swedish Company to Sell Air Brake Shares
abstract: Incentive, a Swedish company, will sell its 10 million shares in Westinghouse Air Brake Co for $110 million; Westinghouse Air says investment group led by Vestar Capital Partners and including Harvard Private Capital Group, American Industrial Partners and certain members of company's management will acquire about 6 million shares at $11 a share, and Westinghouse Air will acquire rest at same price (S)

headline: Arms Cache in Nicaragua Casts a Long Shadow
abstract: Police discovery of huge arms cache in ranch outside Managua, Nicaragua, leads to bitter falling out among left-wing parties that were close allies during revolutionary effervescence of 1980's and suggests ties to recent terrorism from Mexico to Peru; cache was found in storeroom at ranch belonging to retired Sandinista Army officer; Nicaraguan and Salvadoran authorities say that arms cache, like an even larger one found in Mangagua in 1993, belongs to Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, Salvadoran guerrilla group that used Sandinista-ruled Nicaragua as base throughout 1980's; leaders of Front deny any connection and dismiss accusation as plot to discredit them (M)

headline: Dow Up 101.60, But Ends Week Little Changed
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average is up by 101.60 points, at 6,544.09, on New York Stock Exchange volume of 453 million shares; graph (L)

headline: Treasury Sets Bill Offering
abstract: The Treasury's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills will be postponed until Tuesday because of Washington's Birthday.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.95 percent and a six-month bill was also 4.95 percent.

headline: Fidelity Forms An Alliance With Salomon
abstract: Fidelity Investments and Salomon Brothers announce unique alliance that is to give Fidelity better access to stock offerings and sophisticated research, and give Salomon an instant retail brokerage; Fidelity will, for three years, distribute offerings lead-managed by Salomon, in return for guaranteed access to Salomon's equity offerings and research; alliance is direct challenge to big brokerage firms that have dominated retail market; deal should also allow Fidelity Brokerage Services to break into ranks of Wall Street firms (M)

headline: REGIONS FINANCIAL TO BUY NEW IBERIA BANCORP
abstract: The Regions Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy New Iberia Bancorp Inc. for $65 million in stock. Regions Financial, of Birmingham, Ala., has assets of $20 billion, including pending acquisitions. New Iberia, based in New Iberia, La., is a banking company with assets of $299 million. Under the agreement, Regions will swap 1.1 million of its shares for all of the shares outstanding of New Iberia, at a ratio of 0.36 Regions share for each New Iberia share. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, Regions Financial stock climbed 25 cents, to $57.75. On the American Stock Exchange, New Iberia Bancorp stock was unchanged at $21.

headline: The Stray Cats of Australia: 9 Lives Seen as 9 Too Many
abstract: Conservationists say stray cats are driving some indigenous birds and other species to extinction in Australia; say 12 million wild cats have been killing small creatures whose evolution has not taught them that cats are their enemy; Richard Evans, member of Parliament, is calling for eradication of cats in Australia by year 2020; he has drawn wide support with his proposal to kill all cats by neutering and spreading fatal feline diseases in wild; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: * Diana Pearson was named public affairs director at Time magazine, New York, published by Time Warner Inc., succeeding Robert A. Pondiscio, now a managing director at the Hill & Knowlton unit of WPP Group, New York. Ms. Pearson had been communications director at Newsweek magazine, New York, owned by the Washington Post Co.    * Peter Erzberger was named chief executive at J. Walter Thompson Germany, Frankfurt, a unit of WPP Group, effective in July, succeeding Michael Madel, who recently became president of J. Walter Thompson Europe, Middle East and Africa. Mr. Erzberger had been general manager for marketing and head of the network services unit at Scholz & Friends, Hamburg, owned by Cordiant P.L.C.    * Kate Lynch, media research director for the European and London operations of the Leo Burnett Co., was named director for media research at Leo Burnett USA, Chicago, succeeding Jayne Z. Spittler, who continues as worldwide director for media research at Burnett.    * Scott Franks, executive vice president and chief operating officer at Tierney & Partners, Philadelphia, owned by True North Communications, was named to an additional post, head of a new office in Cherry Hill, N.J.

headline: Heinz and Campbell Agree to Mediation
abstract: H J Heinz Co and Campbell Soup Co agree in Federal court to work out their differences with a mediator; at issue is Heinz's hiring of Daniel O'Neill, former Campbell Soup executive; Campbell claims O'Neill signed noncompetition agreement that precludes his working for Heinz for 19 months (S)

headline: Despite Setbacks, Democracy Gains in Africa
abstract: Two sharply divergent groups of countries are emerging in Africa: those in which spirit of democracy is fast taking root and those in which the power of incumbents faces minimal risks behind a facade of democracy (M)

headline: Centennial Technologies Soars Though Delisting Is Next Week
abstract: Looking for a bullish story? How about this one: a company's chief executive is in jail, charged with falsifying its books. The stock is scheduled to be kicked off the New York Stock Exchange next Monday. And in two days, on phenomenal volume, the share price rises to $14.75 from $2.50.    That is what has happened this week to the stock of Centennial Technologies, the onetime high flier whose share price collapsed earlier this year with the arrest of its founder and chief executive, Emanuel Pinez, who is accused of reporting phony sales even while he was making money by buying options that would rise in value if the stock price declined.

headline: Inaugural, From Pomp To Socks
abstract: Many World Wide Web sites will offer information on inaugural activities and related information; inaugural committee's Web site will offer live feed through day's events (M)

headline: A Voice for Jews Shows Range and Resonance
abstract: Article examines circumstances surrounding success by World Jewish Congress in winning acknowledgment by Swiss banking officials of existence of dormant accounts of victims and survivors of Holocaust and setting up special fund, with initial worth of $70 million, to reimburse victims; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Wins A Round Against Cartel
abstract: Haarmann & Reimer Corp, Bayer AG unit, pleads guilty to role in highly organized international conspiracy to fix price of citric acid, additive used in food and household products, and agrees to pay $50 million fine, Federal court; is sixth firm to admit participating in pricing schemes involving Archer Daniels Midland Co (M):

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  NONE REPORTED    TUESDAY  Insteel Inds

headline: Ex-Japanese Bureaucrat Admits Accepting Bribes
