abstract: Former senior bureaucrat Nobuharu Okamitsu pleads guilty to accepting about $500,000 in bribes in case that has focused attention on corruption in Japan's Government (S)

headline: Merrill Lynch Growth Fund
abstract: Interview with Stephen C Johnes, head of Merrill Lynch Growth Fund, which currently has $6.02 billion in assets; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.38   5.36   5.21        3-MO. headline: Hearing Begins on Restraint Of Trade in Toy Industry
abstract: Federal Judge James P Timony begins hearing arguments on whether Toys 'R' Us Inc illegally colluded with manufacturers to keep prices of Barbie, GI Joe and Elmo artificially high; Federal Trade Commission has accused Toys 'R' Us, world's largest toy retailer, of using its marketing muscle to keep popular toys off the shelves of deep-discounting warehouse clubs like Price/Costco and Sam's Club (L)

headline: NEW VENTURE TO CHALLENGE PHONE COMPANIES
abstract: Central and South West Corp forms joint venture with ICG Communications Inc and BellSouth Corp, enabling it to be one of first electric utilities to challenge Baby Bells for telephone customers (S)

headline: Expanding, but Keeping an Eye on Value
abstract: Profile of Legg Mason, Baltimore-based mutual fund company, in light of its plans for adding series of funds that will aim at the growing 401(k) market; Raymond A Mason, chairman and chief executive, William H Miller 3d, manager or co-manager of three of its stock funds, and Edward A Tabor 3d, senior executive vice president, comment; photo; graph (M)

headline: Krupp Agrees to Pay Initial Merger Costs
abstract: Fried Krupp AG plans to pay 800 million marks ($474 million) to 1.3 billion marks ($778 million) in revamping costs resulting from merger of its steel operations with Thyssen AG (S)

headline: Ameritech to Review Ad Assignments
abstract: Ameritech Corp unexpectedly beings a review of advertising agencies that handle its consumer, brand and business accounts, with billings estimated at more than $100 million; agencies under review are Leo Burnett Co in Chicago, Fallon McElligott in Chicago and Minneapolis, and DDB Needham Chicago unit of Omnicom Group (S)

headline: HIGHLANDS INSURANCE CUTS OFFER FOR VIK BROTHERS
abstract: Highlands Insurance Group Inc. cut its offer for Vik Brothers Insurance Inc. again yesterday, this time to $97 million. Highlands first slashed its offer for Vik Brothers in January from $164 million to $110 million, when Vik reported a loss for the 1996 fiscal year. This time, Highlands said it was modifying its offer for technical reasons and because of the unspecified involvement of a third party. Under the new deal, Highlands would issue 1.7 million shares and $21 million worth of preferred stock to the owners of Vik Brothers, as well as assume $40 million of Vik Brothers' debt. Highlands specializes in commercial property and casualty insurance.

headline: Dialing Into Gridlock
abstract: Dr Stefan P Kruszewski letter on Eric Firdman's Feb 9 article calling for usage-based pricing to make Internet more accessible (S)~

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: I.B.M. Drags Down Dow, But Nasdaq Hits Record  I.B.M. stock fell sharply, dragging down the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell 33.87 points to close at 6,850.03.    But the Nasdaq reached another closing high as Microsoft and Intel rose. I.B.M., Intel and Microsoft have all reported strong fourth-quarter earnings, and all have warned investors that their rates of growth may slow. But investors see a brighter future for Intel and Microsoft than for I.B.M. $(Page D10.$)    Compaq Earnings Up, Lifting Stock  Compaq's earnings exceeded Wall Street estimates, and the company's stock rose sharply. Compaq attributed the earnings gain to greater sales in the more profitable parts of the company's product line and to internal changes that have resulted in lower costs and increased profit margins. $(D3.$)    Jury Decides Against ABC  A jury ruled against ABC and two employees, awarding the Food Lion supermarket chain more than $5.5 million in punitive damages in a case that focused on the propriety of gathering TV news with hidden cameras and undercover reporting. $(A1.$)    A Strong Quarter for Bear Stearns  Quarterly earnings at Bear Stearns rose 68 percent, surpassing analysts' forecasts, as they have at other investment banks. Dean Witter reported strong profits, too. $(D3.$)    USAir Profit Down 55%  USAir said that earnings fell 55 percent in the fourth quarter as it continued to struggle with rising costs. $(D3.$)    Perelman: Ruling Is No Problem  Ronald O. Perelman, who is seeking to maintain control of Marvel Entertainment, suffered a setback when a judge rejected parts of a borrowing agreement that Marvel had negotiated. But a spokesman for Mr. Perelman said the ruling was not a problem because the judge had indicated that she would approve alternate language in the agreement that would amount to the same thing. $(D2.$)    Pharmacia Stock: A Bargain?  Most securities analysts were unhappy with Pharmacia & Upjohn even before the surprise resignation this week of John L. Zabriskie, the chief executive. But a few contrarians saw a brighter side. The share price was already one of the cheapest in the pharmaceutical sector, and after Mr. Zabriskie quit it got even cheaper. Market Place. $(D10.$)    Bank Employees Release President  Employees protesting a Government plan to cut jobs at Credit Foncier de France released the bank's president and other executives after six days. But labor organizers pledged to continue occupying the Paris headquarters until the Government scrapped plans to eliminate the jobs. $(D8.$)    Consumer Accounts in Shifts  Account activity has been accelerating in the last week in consumer product advertising. One big change involved a division of Johnson & Johnson, which moved the account of the Nicotrol anti-smoking patch, with billings estimated at $41 million, to the Health Care Connection unit of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York from DDB Needham New York. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. $(D7.$)    Pizzeria Uno has acknowledged that ads for ''low-fat'' pizzas were misleading and has promised the F.T.C. not to make such claims again. $(A21.$)    New York City Job Growth Gains  Last year, for the first time since 1980, New York City created more jobs than its suburbs, breaking one of the trends of recent economic development in America. $(B8.$)    A Big Donor's Anonymous Giving  Charles F. Feeney, the founder of the DFS Group chain of duty-free shops, which was recently sold to LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, has secretly donated more than $600 million to hospitals, universities and other beneficiaries over the last 15 years. $(A1.$)

headline: Alcatel Profits Return, And More Are Forecast
abstract: Alcatel Alsthom SA says it returned to profitability in 1996, posting higher-than-expected net profit of $473 million (S)

headline: RUSSIA THWARTING U.S. BID TO REMOVE A NUCLEAR CACHE
abstract: United States is making quiet effort to have cache of enriched uranium moved out of Georgian Republic; effort, part of broader program to stem theft by terrorists or aspiring nuclear powers of bomb ingredients from Russia and its neighbors, has thus far been thwarted by months of diplomatic impasse between Russia and US; map; photo (M)

headline: Good Results Reported In Tokyo Land Auction
abstract: JNR Settlement Corp, company entrusted with disposing of debts of Japan's former national railway company, raises greater-than-expected $3.05 billion auctioning parcels of land in Tokyo (S)

headline: Burst of Pride for a Staccato Executioner: AK-47
abstract: Russian military is celebrating 50th anniversary of Mikhail T Kalashnikov's assault rifle, AK-47, which has become one of most important and widespread weapons in world; photo (M)

headline: 2 Hurt at Arabic Paper as Bombs Are Mailed to London and U.N.
abstract: Two mail clerks are injured in London in explosion of one of four letter bombs mailed to Arab-language newspaper, Al Hayat; four other bombs, also addressed to newspaper, are found and disarmed at UN; investigators report no suspects or motives in widening campaign of terror against tabloid, which is owned by Saudi Prince Khalid bin Sultan; photo (M)

headline: ACCORD ON HEBRON GETS ENDORSEMENT OF ISRAELI CABINET
abstract: Pres Benjamin Netanyahu's coalition Cabinet endorses Hebron agreement by vote of 11 to 7 after fierce, 12-hour dispute; Cabinet vote, while not required, fulfills pledge made by Netanyahu that he would not carry out any agreement that his Government did not endorse; Science Min Benny Begin, most ideologically conservative member of Government, resigns in protest; agreement must now go before Israeli Parliament, where Labor Party support makes its passage all but assured; Palestinian leadership in Gaza City gives their leader, Yasir Arafat, endorsement of agreement; Israeli military officials say actual redeployment from 80 percent of Hebron could be concluded within 24 hours, since most preparations have been concluded for weeks; 400 Palestinian police officers to be deployed in Hebron are standing by; photo (M)

headline: NGC SHARES PLUNGE ON PROFIT REDUCTION
abstract: Stock of NGC Corp drops 20 percent after company says costs associated with its natural gas business will drive its first-quarter profits far below expectations; shares of NGC fall $4, to $15.375 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: VW to Pay $100 Million To G.M. to Settle Lawsuit  Volkswagen agreed to pay $100 million to General Motors to settle a lawsuit contending that a former top VW executive, Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, stole trade secrets when he left G.M. The settlement brings to an end a four-year feud between two of the world's largest car companies.    In the agreement, one of the biggest in a corporate espionage case, Volkswagen also agreed to buy at least $1 billion worth of auto parts from the American company over the next seven years. While not admitting any wrongdoing, VW also said that it ''acknowledges the possibility that illegal activities'' by Mr. Lopezmight have occurred. $(Page A1.$)    Hughes Bids May Top $10 Billion   The two bids for the military businesses of Hughes Electronics are likely to come to perhaps $10 billion, but will hinge less on their face value than tax considerations and estimates of the future value of the stock of the winning company. The bidders, Raytheon and Northrop Grumman, have both submitted packages that come to 500 pages each. $(D2.$)    Producer Prices Rise   Producer prices rose more than expected during December, but when the cost of energy and food was excluded, the increase was below forecasts. Prices were up half a percent over all, but they rose only one-tenth of a percent without the two volatile categories. $(D2.$)     Liggett Seeks Broader Settlement   The Liggett Group, which shocked the rest of the tobacco industry last March by breaking ranks and agreeing to settle several major lawsuits, is now trying to reach an even broader settlement, according to lawyers familiar with the talks. $(A16.$)     F.A.A. Found More Valujet Flaws   The F.A.A. found problems with Valujet's system for assuring the safety of its planes as recently as December, six months after one of its jets crashed in the Everglades. $(A12.$)    Labor Votes at United Airlines   Mechanics for United Airlines rejected a wage increase proposal, but other workers accepted the plan. $(D2.$)    Norfolk Southern Loses Court Bid   Norfolk Southern lost a bid to have a court strike down an agreement that prevents Conrail from discussing a merger with anyone other than the CSX Corporation. $(A16.$)    Telmex Aims for American Market   Telefonos de Mexico plans to seek authorization with the F.C.C. to offer its own phone services in United States markets that are heavily Spanish-speaking. $(D3.$)     The Agony of Finishing Second   Ikon Office Solutions, a giant office equipment and technology company with a new name, is urging those who consider business a battle to ''Work to win.'' The company hopes the theme of its $50 million campaign will cut through the technological clutter of office supply advertising. And it will do that with humorous views of the downside of not finishing first. One ad shows a dinosaur skeleton, declaring, ''Second place, evolution.'' Another ad shows a statue of Lenin being pulled from its pedestal; the headline is ''Second place, cold war.''  Stuart Elliott: Advertising. $(D15.$)    Nasdaq Shifts on New Rules   Nasdaq said that it had it scaled back its proposal to reduce the minimum number of shares that can be traded under the S.E.C.'s new order-handling rules. $(D2.$)

headline: Mikel Cardinal Koliqi of Albania Dies at 94
abstract: Mikel Cardinal Koliqi of Albania, who spent 38 years in jails and labor camps, dies at age 94; photo (M)

headline: Shell Consolidates European Accounts
abstract: Shell Oil Co names J Walter Thompson Co to handle creative and strategic assignments for all brand advertising in Europe (S)

headline: Rental Car Insurance: Staying Out of Financial Potholes
abstract: Minding Your Business column answers question about ways to beat high cost of insurance on car rentals; drawing (M)

headline: Ties to Indonesian Rulers Secure Mother Lode of Gold Deals
abstract: Freeport-McMoran Copper & Gold, with long history in Indonesia and ties to nation's political and business leaders, beats out several corporate rivals to become sole operator of Busang gold mine, Borneo; agrees to invest up to $1.6 billion in exchange for 15 percent of joint-venture firm co-owned by Bre-X Minerals (with 45 percent), two Indonesian firms and Indonesian state; graph; map (M)

headline: A Price of Success: An Unbalanced Portfolio
abstract: As investors perform January rite of reviewing their portfolios for new year, market's 1996 outstanding performance makes job more difficult; process of allocating assets among basic classes of investment--along with regular reviewing of allocation--is crucial to portfolio's success, accounting for more than 90 percent of differences in investors' returns; asset allocation strategy of Dr Bruce Bieber of Bayside, NYC, cited; his photo (M)

headline: HEWLETT-PACKARD TO SEEK ENCRYPTION-EXPORT APPROVAL
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co will seek approval from Commerce Department to export stronger encryption technology following announcement by three companies of plans for such exports (S)

headline: Nile-in-Miniature Tests Parent's Bounty
abstract: Egypt debates grand scheme to pump nearly six billion gallons of Nile water a day from Lake Nasser into canal extending northwest across desert, to create lush region called New Valley that could sustain soaring population; Pres Hosni Mubarak makes announcement in Toshka, designated headwaters; map; financing for staggeringly expensive project is unclear; about 90 percent of Egypt's 62 million people now live crammed on just 4 percent of land, narrow swath irrigated by Nile for thousands of years (S)

headline: Omnicom Promotes 3 Top Executives
abstract: DDB Needham Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group promotes three executives (S)

headline: German Coal Miners Protest Subsidy Cuts
abstract: German coal miners demonstrate in Bonn against proposed cuts in coal industry subsidies (S)

headline: U.S. Said to Step Up Criticism of Germany's Scientology Curbs
abstract: United States reportedly will step up its criticism of Germany's curbs on Church of Scientology in annual survey of human rights conditions around world; State Department notes US has criticized Germany's treatment of Scientology as cult, rather than religion, since 1992 (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ford Said to Be in Deal To Sell Budget Rent A Car  Team Rental is expected to announce today that it is acquiring Budget Rent A Car for more than $350 million from Ford, as the big Detroit auto makers continue to flee the car rental industry, which they once dominated.

headline: Coffee Prices in Sharp Rise On Forecasts of Tight Supply
abstract: Coffee prices surge after United States inventory report and Brazilian crop estimate heighten concern that supplies could grow scarce late this year; in other markets, wheat and soybeans fall (M)

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: CIRCUIT CITY STORES INC.,  Richmond, the electronics retailer, said its shareholders had approved a plan to create two series of common stock that would separately track the performance of its Circuit City consumer electronics and appliance business and its Carmax auto retailing business.     HILTON HOTELS CORP.,  Beverly Hills, Calif., and ITT Corp. said they had bought Circus Circus Enterprises Inc.'s share in their joint venture that operates a casino in Windsor, Ontario. Terms were not disclosed.     LTV CORP.,  Cleveland, the steel company, said it planned to buy back shares of its stock valued at up to $75 million. The company has about 108.4 million shares outstanding.

headline: Barney's Committee Spurns Dickson Bid
abstract: Barney's Inc creditors committee rejects initial bid by Dickson Concepts (International) Ltd to buy Barney's for $240 million, with lawyers saying that 'the value of the company is substantially in excess of the proposal' (S)

headline: Wall Street's Search for the Perfect Blend
abstract: Even as directors of Morgan Stanley Group met to approve $10.2 billion merger with Dean Witter, Discover & Co that would shake Wall Street, investment bankers were bombarded with telephone calls asking about their rumored takeover of Paine Webber; Paine Webber Group, like Lehman Brothers and Salomon Brothers, is the kind of second-tier competitor that Wall Street now believes must find a partner if it wants to stay in the game with full-service giants that are coming to dominate a swiftly changing financial services industry; Paine Webber heads most analysts' lists as next most likely target of a takeover, followed by Equitable Companies's Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette unit; prospects of investment banks or commercial banks assuming brokerage firms discussed; diagram (L)

headline: Turning Direct Deposits Into Direct Withdrawals
abstract: About half of all workers in private sector are paid by direct deposit, but questions about safety of direct deposit system have been raised by employees who have found money removed electronically from their bank accounts by their employer; such access to individual's private accounts is unsettling; employers can reverse a deposit to an employee's account, but only under specific circumstances and only during limited time; photo (M)

headline: REPUBLIC ENGINEERED STEEL TO CUT 12% OF ITS WORK FORCE
abstract: Republic Engineered Steel Inc to cut 500 jobs, 12 percent of work force; reports second-quarter loss widened to $11.6 million from $5.4 million a year earlier (S)ï

headline: AMERISOURCE HEALTH TO ACQUIRE WALKER DRUG
abstract: Amerisource Health Corp to buy Walker Drug Co (S)

headline: Chief Strategy Officer Quits McCann-Erickson
abstract: McCann-Erickson Worldwide says that Peter Kim, vice chairman and chief strategic officer, has left agency, effective immediately; he will be replaced by Eric Einhorn (S)

headline: A shift in leadership as ABC News faces challenges in a new age.
abstract: Roone Arledge, who was branded a radical when he took over ABC's news division 20 years ago, now finds himself in uncharacteristic position of insisting that ABC has not fallen behind its newly aggressive rival, NBC News; industry executives say Arledge faces steepest challenge in his 30-year career at ABC, which is battling legal judgments against several of its programs; its evening newscast has relinquished its ratings lead to NBC; and Arledge's image as leader in network news seems almost quaint in era of proliferating cable news channels and ever-softer news coverage; drawing (M)

headline: SFX BROADCASTING TO PURCHASE 7 RADIO STATIONS
abstract: SFX Broadcasting to buy seven radio stations from Secret Communications LP for $225 million; four are in Pittsburgh, three in Indianapolis; omitted from earlier agreement are WLTF and WTAM-AM in Cleveland (S)

headline: East Germany's Spy Chief On Trial in the West Again
abstract: Trial of former East German spy chief Markus Wolf begins in Dusseldorf, Germany; represents second effort to prosecute Wolf, who outfoxed West for three decades, after Supreme Court ruling in 1995 that overturned six-year jail term for treason; photo (M)

headline: Kohlberg Kravis Set to Offer $1.2 Billion for Cable Maker
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co announces agreement to buy control of Amphenol Corp, leading maker of electronic cables and connectors, for $1.2 billion in cash; Kohlberg Kravis intends to buy 90 percent of Amphenol's common stock, then shift ownership structure so that Kohlberg Kravis and its affiliates would own about 75 percent of company; management will own about 8.5 percent of company; Martin H Loeffler will continue as chief executive and assume position of chairman (M)

headline: New tourism ads try to show the French are fun after all.
abstract: THE French are coming.     And not a moment too soon. After all, the French Government's new youth-oriented advertising and marketing campaign, scheduled to begin next month, is intended not only to increase tourism but also to solve a problem that has become formidable.

headline: Royal Ahold in Deal With Royal Dutch/Shell
abstract: Royal Ahold NV and Royal Dutch/Shell Group agree to put supermarket outlets in Shell service stations throughout the Netherlands; companies say that Albert Heijn food stores, unit of Royal Ahold, will be opened under franchise in most of Shell's 750 Dutch stations (S)

headline: Good Year for Manhattan Or Perhaps Not So Good
abstract: Two of New York City's largest real estate companies, Corcoran Group and Halstead Property Co, issue year-end reports that come to differing conclusions on overall health of residential market; Halstead report finds prices for broad market of Manhattan rose 8.1% on average, while Corcoran finds prices down (M)

headline: Bundesbank Chief Says No Rate Rise Is in Sight
abstract: Bundesbank president Hans Tietmeyer says German central bank does not see upturn in German interest rates in near future (S)

headline: LORAL COMPLETES BUYING AT&T'S SKYNET SATELLITE
abstract: Loral Space and Communications Ltd says it completed acquisition of AT&T Corporation's Skynet Satellite Services for $478.1 million (S)

headline: Swimming in Smaller Pools
abstract: John Rekenthaler, publisher of Morningstar Mutual Funds, finds that investors in big-company funds are bucking odds if they refuse to index, while for investors in small stocks, reverse may be true; chart (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Ronald C. Ognar, Strong Growth Fund
abstract: IF you like the leaders of the pack, you will feel right at home with the Strong Growth fund.    Its manager, Ronald C. Ognar, invests in rapidly growing companies that lead their industries and has built a record that truly stands out.

headline: U.S. Builds Case Against Salinas Brother
abstract: US Government is reportedly prepared to argue that Raul Salinas de Gortari used his power as brother of former President of Mexico, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, to protect drug shipments and traffickers; case will be made at trial in Houston in March in which Government will seek to confiscate $9 million in reputed narcotics profits from Mario Ruiz Massieu, former Mexican Deputy Attorney General, who is now under house arrest in Newark (M)

headline: Little Progress in Talks, Yet Albright Is Hopeful on China Ties
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright, after visit to Beijing filled with symbols of warmth but little progress on contentious issues, says that she is encouraged about possibility of more congenial relationship with China; US officials say they expected no dramatic concessions on day in which Chinese cremated Deng Xiaoping (M)

headline: Romania, Braving the Odds, Knocks on NATO's Door
abstract: Romania's leaders, in quest that Western officials view as quixotic, have been campaigning for their country to be included when NATO expands its ranks this year; Romanian officials stirring public enthusiasm for NATO membership acknowledge they are taking chance that could backfire against democratic leaders; France, Italy and Spain support Romanian entry, but US, Germany and Britain are noncommital (S)

headline: Samsung Loses Chance To Take Over Fokker
abstract: Samsung loses chance to revive its failed bid to take over bankrupt Dutch aircraft maker Fokker NV when other Korean airplane makers reject its offer to form consortium (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Buffett Likes McDonald's But Worries About Market  Warren E. Buffett, the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, says most stocks are overvalued. But he excludes the shares of his own company, and he has been loading up on shares of McDonald's.    Berkshire's newly released annual report shows that as of the end of last year, the company owned 30.2 million shares of McDonald's, or a 4.3 percent stake. $(Page D3.$)

headline: Nasdaq must wait a little longer for its new market-maker rules.
abstract: Floyd Norris (Market Place) column notes long-awaited new rules for Nasdaq stock market have been delayed for week, largely because Securities and Exchange Commission has not yet decided on some important details; says trading in 50 stocks under new rules will now begin on January 20; says new rules are aimed at giving investors better prices when they buy and sell; notes that if changes work, fundamental nature of Nasdaq market will be changed and for market makers--brokers who have always been at heart of Nasdaq market--an eventual result will probably be lower profits (M)

headline: COR THERAPEUTICS SAGS AFTER PANEL VOTES AGAINST DRUG
abstract: Shares of Cor Therapeutics Inc drop nearly 24 percent after company's experimental heart drug Integrilin failed to win backing of Food and Drug Administration advisory panel on Feb 28; shares fall $2.9375, to $9.375 (S)

headline: KOREAN SHOOTING IS CASTING CLOUD ON SIGNS OF THAW
abstract: South Korea goes on terrorism alert as police and soldiers seek two men who shot Lee Han Young, a prominent North Korean defector, on Feb 15; brazen assassination attempt, the work of suspected North Korea agents, and the earlier defection in Beijing of Hwang Jang Yop, a senior North Korean official, dramatically intensify cold war animosity on Korean Peninsula and could derail recent steps toward easing tensions; Hwang's defection and widespread food shortages in the North dampen celebration in Pyongyang of Kim Jong Il's birthday, a national holiday; photos (M)

headline: U.S. WON'T OFFER TRADE TESTIMONY ON CUBA EMBARGO
abstract: United States refuses to take part in World Trade Organization's (WTO) legal proceedings involving European challenge to Washington's embargo of Cuba; US position is that WTO 'has no competence to proceed' in issue of American national security; American action follows six months of negotiations with Europe over Helms-Burton Act, which is intended to punish companies that trade with Cuba; central issue is Europe's claim that US has violated international law by imposing penalties on foreign companies that conduct business in Cuba using properties or assets that once belonged to American companies; these properties were expropriated by Havana four decades ago; penalties are intended to force foreign governments to support American effort to isolate Fidel Castro; some of Pres Clinton's advisers oppose Helms-Burton Act, and Pres Clinton has twice suspended crucial element of law, which would allow Americans to sue foreign companies in American courts for use of expropriated American property in Cuba (M)

headline: Chechen Voters' Key Concerns: Order and Stability
abstract: There are 16 presidential candidates in Chechen election that will be held on Jan 27, and they all support independence from Russia; five leading candidates say they favor establishment of Islamic society; Aslan Maskhadov and Shamil Basayev are front-runners; photo (M)

headline: Success in Cloning Hardly Insures Profit
abstract: Shares in PPL Therapeutics PLC soar on London Stock Exchange following news that scientists in the tiny Scottish biotechnology company successfully cloned a sheep, in collaboration with researchers at Roslin Institute in Edinburgh; despite investors' enthusiasm, there is often vast gulf between scientific breakthrough and marketable product; analysts note that biotechnology industry's short history is littered with remains of companies that shined in laboratory, but came up short on route to sales success; analysts warn that investment in PPL is subject to technology risk, because use of genetically altered animals may not be best way to make drugs (M)

headline: George Wins Readers, but Little Respect
abstract: John F Kennedy Jr's magazine George fails to win praise in elite publishing and political circles but does achieve circulation of 400,000 in just 18 months, making it largest political magazine in nation; Kennedy stresses goal is commercially viable consumer-oriented magazine about politics that attracts broad general audience, interview; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Carmichael Lynch Drops National Car
abstract: Carmichael Lynch Inc unexpectedly resigns from National Car Rental System advertising account (S)

headline: Y'all Hear? African English With a Dixie Drawl
abstract: Side-by-side use of standard English and pidgin vernacular that echoes both antebellum Southern speech and speech of American inner-city blacks is unremarkable fact of life in Liberia; cartoons (M)

headline: BIOGEN NAMES ITS PRESIDENT TO BE CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: Biogen Inc. said yesterday that James R. Tobin, its president and chief operating officer, had been named chief executive. Mr. Tobin, who is 52, succeeds James L. Vincent, 57, who will continue as chairman. Mr. Tobin joined Biogen three years ago, after 22 years with Baxter International Inc. Mr. Tobin joined with the understanding that he would succeed Mr. Vincent if Biogen met its goal of becoming a fully integrated pharmaceutical company. Biogen, based in Cambridge, Mass., was one of the first biotechnology companies but had until recently derived all of its income from royalties.

headline: WHAT HAPPENED: A Boom in Mergers
abstract: Boeing's $14 billion acquisition of McDonnell Douglas capped a record year for mergers as companies turned their attention from cost-cutting to growth. The rising stock market helped finance the deals. Pushed by the Pentagon, few industries consolidated more quickly than military contracting, which has carried out more than $40 billion mergers the last four years.

headline: Patching the Cracks in the Rock
abstract: Prudential Insurance Co of America, nation's largest insurer, has been bombarded by calamities in recent years and reported loss in 1994 of more than $900 million; Arthur F Ryan, who was recruited two years ago, has put company back in the black through cost-cutting and profitable sales of securities and other assets; earnings for 1996 are estimated at roughly $1 billion, up from $478 million in 1995; question now is whether Ryan can improve operating performance and restore prosperity to company; photos; charts; graphs (L)

headline: Recent Changes at WMX Satisfy Dissident, for Now
abstract: WMX Technologies, beleaguered waste hauler, reaches detente with Soros Fund Management, dissident holder of 5.2 percent of WMX's stock; Stanley Druckenmiller, chief investment strategist of Soros, says that he is satisfied with WMX's efforts to find two outside board members, as well as the 'best chief executive officer available' to replace Phillip Rooney, who resigned (S)

headline: Swedish Manufacturer Reports Increase in Profit
abstract: Atlas Copco AB, Swedish maker of industrial machinery, reports that it had 6.6 percent increase in pretax profit in fourth quarter of 1996 compared with the quarter a year earlier; profit rose to 838 million kronor ($114 million) from 786 million kronor ($106 million) (S)

headline: Yes, This Is the Nile, but Don't Go Near the Water
abstract: Polluted Nile River, which is source of water for Egypt's most abundant agricultural lands in Nile Delta region, is also source of virulent water-borne parasite that causes bilharzia and affects 1 in 12 Egyptians; disease, known as schistosomiasis, is carried by parasites to liver, where they lay eggs in blood vessels in bladder or intestine, causing irritations and disorders that can result in death; situation in Batania, one of many Nile Delta villlages where officials are trying to cope with disease, discussed; photo; map (M)

headline: TOY BIZ IS PLANNING TO ACQUIRE COLORFORMS
abstract: Toy Biz Inc to acquire Colorforms Inc (S)

headline: Mobutu, Emerging, Vows to Unite Zaire but Doesn't Say How
abstract: Ailing Zaire Pres Mobutu Sese Seko makes first public appearance in capital of Kinshasa since returning from France on March 21; vows to unite shattered country, reeling from effects of civil war; meets with South African Deputy Pres Thabo Mbeki, and with members of Cabinet and other officials of Government (M)

headline: REYNOLDS & REYNOLDS COMPLETES PURCHASE OF VANIER
abstract: Reynolds & Reynolds Co completes its purchase of Vanier Graphics Corp for $47 million in cash from American Business Products Inc (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Steve St. Clair was named creative director at the New York office of Earle Palmer Brown, succeeding Michael Drazen, now the agency's chief creative officer. Mr. St. Clair had been associate creative director at W. B. Doner & Co., Baltimore.    * Steven V. Dubin was named to the new position of marketing services director at Dickinson Direct, Braintree, Mass. He had been president at Dubin & Farrell Advertising/Public Relations, Weymouth, Mass., which merged with Dickinson.

headline: On Both Sides, Dissatisfaction With the Accord Feeds Tension and Anxiety
abstract: Israeli settlers and Palestinians in Hebron express dissatisfaction with new agreement that calls for Israeli soldiers to cede most of city to Palestinian police (M)

headline: 46-Month Sentence in Internet Stock Fraud
abstract: Charles O Huttoe, former chmn of Systems of Excellence Inc, is sentenced to 46 months in prison for his role in multimillion-dollar stock fraud that used Internet to promote his company's shares (M)

headline: MERRILL LYNCH & CO. (MER, N)
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co reports fourth-quarter net income rose 47 percent, to $445 million, up from $303 million in 1995 period; says 1996 profit rose to record $1.62 billion, up 46 percent from $1.11 billion in 1995; table (S)

headline: VERITAS SIGNS $400 MILLION DEAL FOR OPENVISION
abstract: Veritas Software Corp signs definitive agreement to merge with Openvision Technologies in stock swap. Veritas, Santa Clara, Calif, to acquire Openvision in deal valued at $400 million (S)

headline: Rudderless Russia: Melancholy Mingles With Bravado
abstract: News analysis reports that Russia, rousing itself from long Christmas holiday, faces new year without the leader who just last week promised to be finally back in charge; Pres Boris Yeltsin is back in hospital, this time with pneumonia, tax collection is so anemic that Government cannot pay many employees or soldiers and new round of preening is expected among those who would replace Yeltsin, notably Aleksandr Lebed (S)

headline: The Beat of Different Drummers
abstract: Offices usually have an ethos to which most workers conform. But what of the employees who stand out from the group? Do they try desperately to fit in, or do they celebrate their differnces? Have you ever stood alone? Did it create any distressing or humorous situations? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: NEWPORT PETROLEUM TO ACQUIRE CIMARRON
abstract: Newport Petroleum Corp agrees to acquire Cimarron Petroleum Ltd for stock valued at $369 million (Canadian), or $273 million (US); acquisition would enable Newport Petroleum to expand its oil and gas operations in western Canada (S)

headline: Rise in Defaults Roils Credit Card Issuers
abstract: For issuers of credit cards, the good news is that millions of people have taken up offers for cards and borrowed more than ever before. The bad news is that a growing number cannot pay their bills.     The problem was illustrated yesterday by an announcement by the Advanta Corporation, one of the fastest-growing credit card issuers. The company said that it would lose money in the first quarter because as much as 7.5 percent of its loans outstanding had gone bad. Advanta also hired an investment banker to consider, among other options, selling the company outright.

headline: Warning: Maybe Too Much of a Good Thing
abstract: Labels with increasingly elaborate and sometimes embarrassingly obvious warnings are becoming more common as product makers try to avoid costly personal-injury lawsuits; labels are response to fact that now that many dangerous products are no longer on market, plaintiffs' lawyers are increasingly building their cases around idea that manufacturers have not sufficiently warned customers of risk of using their products; some experts say product makers have reacted by pasting warnings on every imaginable product; photos (M)

headline: Time Warner Planning to Sell Stake in Legal Publisher
abstract: Time Warner says it will sell its stake in American Lawyer Media, parent of American Lawyer trade paper, but will keep its interest in Court TV; Steven Brill will leave paper and cable channel he founded; Time Warner and Brill together own American Lawyer Media, which in turn has option to buy 20 percent of Court TV from Time Warner; Court TV is owned equally by Time Warner, NBC and Liberty Media; Brill sought to put together group, including NBC, to buy Time Warner's stake in Court TV and American Lawyer Media and combine two operations; that plan was reportedly thwarted by Ted Turner, who oversees Time Warner cable programming, and is said to be concerned about NBC's increased ownership of rival cable service to Time Warner's Cable Network News (M)

headline: Goldman, Sachs Names 2 Vice Chairmen
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Co names two new vice chairmen, Roy J Zuckerberg and Robert J Hurst, to replace Henry M Paulson Jr; Paulson will become president of firm, newly created position, while retaining title of chief operating officer; photos (M)

headline: France Offering Shares Of Computer Company
abstract: French Government has decided to enter third stage of privatization of Companie des Machines Bull, France's largest computer company, by offering 19 million shares to institutional and individual investors in Europe (S)

headline: Applauded, An Investor Steps Onto A New Stage
abstract: Profile of Randall Eley, head of Edgar Lomax Co, and his successful Profit Lomax Value fund, which opened in November; Tony Chapellle, editor of Securities Pro, monthly newsltetter that reports on African-Americans on Wall Street, calls Eley an 'outstanding investor'; Eley photo; chart on funds top 10 holdings (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Sherwin-Williams diversified brands division, Cleveland, to Wyse Advertising, Cleveland, to handle the account of its Krylon paints, which had been inactive. Billings were estimated at $6 million.

headline: Albania Fights to Regain 2 Angry Towns
abstract: Albanian Government forces are fighting to regain control of Vlore and Sarande, towns that have become camps for heavily armed citizens enraged at Government for failing to warn them about fraudulent investment schemes that left thousands penniless; map; photo (M)

headline: Krupp to Drop Bid if Thyssen Cooperates on Steel
abstract: Krupp-Hoesch, German steelmaker, says it will drop unsolicited takeover bid for Thyssen AG if companies can reach agreement to combine their steel operations (S)

headline: ITT Sells Cablevision Control Over Madison Square Garden
abstract: Cablevision Systems will acquire half of Madison Square Garden from its partner, ITT; $650-million deal will give giant Long Island cable operator near-total control of professional sports televising in New York, Cablevision will get New York Knicks and Rangers and MSG Network, nation's second-largest regional sports network; company will be able to combine MSG's rights to show Yankees, Rangers and Knicks games with rights for Mets, Nets, Devils and Islanders games on Sportschannel, which Cablevision also owns; chairman Charles F Dolan hopes to market teams in multiple cable channels; Richard Kessel is among consumer advocates voicing concern; ITT gets 81 percent gain on $360-million investment in August 1994, at time when it is fending off hostile takeover bid by Hilton Hotels (M)

headline: Limited to Close 200 of Its Stores
abstract: Limited Inc says it will close 200 underperforming women's apparel stores this year; also says Michael Weiss, company vice chairman, will return to posts of president and chief executive at Express, largest unit of Limited; Limited also names Barry Erdos chief financal offical at Express, replacing John Kyees, who resigned (S)

headline: Nestle Unit Shuffles Accounts
abstract: Perrier Group of America, unit of Nestle SA, reassigns accounts of several brands of bottled water (S)

headline: Bleak Debate in Berlin on a Holocaust Memorial
abstract: German historians, artists, public figures, architects and politicians gather in Berlin to debate projected Holocaust memorial near Brandenberg Gate, but no consensus emerges (M)

headline: MERCURY FINANCE SETS SALE OF INSURANCE UNIT
abstract: Mercury Finance Co, troubled auto loan company, says it reached agreement to sell its Lyndon Insurance Group unit to Frontier Insurance Group Inc for $92 million in cash (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Supermarket Chain to Pay $81.5 Million in Bias Suit  Florida's largest supermarket chain agreed to pay $81.5 million to settle accusations that it systematically denied promotions, raises and preferred assignments to its women employees. The settlement, by Publix Supermarkets, may be the largest workplace discrimination case in terms of the number of people it covers.    The class-action lawsuit covers more than 100,000 women who have worked since 1991 at Publix stores in Florida and other Southern states. $(Page 1.$)     White House Coffee for Bankers  The Democratic National Committee organized a meeting at the White House last May in which some of the nation's most prominent bankers met to discuss banking regulation with President Clinton, a senior bank regulator, the Treasury Secretary and the top fund-raiser for the party, Administration officials said. The meeting was one of 103 at the White House arranged by the Democratic Party that were attended by the President and other top officials. $(1.$)    Abortion Pill Is Closer to Market  Three years ago, it seemed inevitable that the French abortion pill would soon be sold on the American market. But a dispute between the American group that was given the patent rights to the pill, RU-486, and the businessman the group had chosen to raise money and arrange for the pill's manufacture and distribution kept the pill off the market. Now there is hope that the stalemate is ending. $(7.$)    Bond Prices Fall Sharply  Prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply, as investors sold on concern that coming reports on the economy and wages would show faster growth and greater inflationary pressures. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 10/32, to 955/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.88 percent from 6.86 percent on Thursday. $(38.$)    Dollar Rises, Then Slips  The dollar vaulted over the 120-yen barrier for the first time in nearly four years then dropped, hurt by fear that Japan's central bank was selling dollars to defend the yen. The dollar fell against other major currencies on profit taking from the dollar's sharp rise over the last week and on news of higher inflation in Germany. $(36.$)     Big Bankruptcy in South Korea  The Hanbo Steel Corporation, South Korea's second-largest steel producer and the flagship of one of the country's big industrial conglomerates, is seeking court protection from its creditors, dealing a new blow to an economy already reeling from labor strife and prompting an injection of money into the financial system by the central bank. Hanbo's collapse, one of the biggest in Korean corporate history, was caused largely by a plant expansion that the company could not afford. $(38.$)    More Funds for Food Inspections  President Clinton's 1998 budget will propose spending $43 million for a program to detect outbreaks of food-borne illnesses and to improve food safety. $(1.$)     Fresh Moves for British Telecom  Fresh from striking Britain's largest corporate acquisition, in which British Telecommunications will buy MCI Communications of the United States for $20 billion, the chief executive of British Telecom is charting additional steps toward turning this once-mundane utility into the world's fourth-largest telecommunications enterprise. Sir Peter Bonfield said his personal experience working in the United States would help BT shift from being just a telephone company into a multiservice, multimedia telecommunications phenomenon. $(38.$)     Coffee Prices Fall As Strike Ends  Coffee prices tumbled after dock workers in Colombia ended a 10-day strike, allowing thousands of bags of coffee to flow into the world market. The strike at the key Colombian port of Buenaventura ended after union leaders and management reached a wage agreement, port officials said. $(36.$)

headline: Marriott Aims Overseas With Acquisition
abstract: Marriott International will acquire Renaissance Hotel Group for about $1 billion, expanding presence in hotel business overseas; acquisition will more than double number of hotels run by Marriott outside US; will help it cement relationships with international travelers and make it more competitive abroad with upscale properties of ITT Sheraton and Hilton Hotels Corp (M)

headline: Payoff Still Elusive In Internet Gold Rush
abstract: Few entrepreneurs have yet succeeded in making money on Internet; big winners so far are data networking firms and Web site designers, who reap investment others must make to join on-line marketplace; photo (M)

headline: Spending Rises For On-Line Ads
abstract: Survey by Internet Advertising Bureau finds spending for on-line advertising grew steadily throughout 1996 (S)

headline: Roche in Pact to Sell H.I.V. Drug in Europe
abstract: Roche Holding AG says it signed agreement with Agouron Pharmaceuticals Inc that would give it exclusive rights to sell American drug maker's Viracept HIV treatment in Europe (S)

headline: Max Factor Duties Expand for Burnett
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co names Leo Burnett Co, Chicago, to handle its consolidated worldwide Max Factor cosmetics account; account had been divided between Burnett internationally and Lotas Minard Patton McIver in NY for the United States (Advertising column) (S)

headline: For Business Air Fares, the Sky's the Limit
abstract: Airlines are steadily raising ticket prices for travelers who fly during work week on short notice, to point where business travelers often pay four times as much for same seat on same flight as passengers booking in advance; charts; prices are particularly hard on small companies that lack clout to negotiate discounts; leisure fares are also up since 1992 fare war, but not as much, although seats are limited for lowest fares, and must be purchased days or weeks in advance; Richard A Hill of Blach Industries in New Jersey tells of $800 fare to North Carolina; airlines are keeping tight control on number of seats they sell, even as demand increases; industry as result showed record profit of $3.2 billion last year (M)

headline: Christopher Sees Threat Of Isolation Via U.S. Cuts
abstract: Secretary of State Warren Christopher warns of 'new isolationism' emerging in Congress; says State Department could not sustain more budget cuts without seriously undercutting American foeign policy around world; Christopher, who steps down next week, claims steady decline in foreign-affairs spending has already forced United States to close consulates and even embassies and to shortchange efforts in some parts of world in order to address immediate crises in others (M)

headline: U.S. Voices Its Concern on Civil War in Zaire
abstract: US is growing increasingly concerned that civil war in Zaire is intensifying, drawing in guerrilla forces from neighboring countries, displacing thousands of refugees and threatening to further destabilize country; State Dept spokesman Nicholas Burns comments; map (M)

headline: Colombia Cited For a 2d Year For Drug Trade
abstract: Decision in Washington to decertify Colombia's efforts to fight drug trafficking for second year in row--but without imposing economic sanctions--comes as bitter reproach, but also a relief to Colombians who had lobbied hard for country's approval; decision appears to signal that as long as Pres Ernesto Samper remains in office, Colombia wll remain on United States list of pariah nations (S)

headline: Home in South Africa, Vintner With a Mission
abstract: Jabulani Ntshangase developed passion for wine when he worked for New York City wine shop; he is South Africa's most knowledgeable black expert on wine; his mission is to get more blacks into business (M)

headline: WHITETREE ACCEPTS $72 MILLION BID FROM ASCEND
abstract: Ascend Communications Inc will acquire Whitetree Inc for about $72 million in stock (S)

headline: Rebels Holding Hostages in Peru Don't Rule Out Cuba Asylum
abstract: Nestor Cerpa Cartolini, leader of guerrillas who are holding 72 hostages inside Japanese diplomatic residence in Lima, Peru, says he has not ruled out possibility of accepting asylum in Cuba (M)

headline: U.S. Wants Public Interest Rules For New Digital TV Channels
abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore says Clinton Administration will try to impose new public interest programming requirements on broadcasters as a condition of awarding them extra channels for use in digital television; Federal Communications Commission is expected to award new digital licenses to existing broadcasters by April; those licenses would enable television stations to begin using digital signals as early as next year to deliver crystal-clear pictures and CD-quality sound; Gore says broadcasters should agree to carry some form of public interest programming on new channels in return for the licenses (L)

headline: As Law Takes Effect, Irish Embrace Divorce at Arm's Length
abstract: Ireland's first law permitting divorce goes into effect on Feb 27 (M)

headline: TCF FINANCIAL TO BUY COMPUTER LEASING COMPANY
abstract: The TCF Financial Corporation agreed to acquire the Winthrop Resources Corporation for $326 million in stock. Winthrop leases computers, telecommunications systems and other equipment. TCF is a savings bank with $7.1 billion in assets. It offered stock worth $36.50 a share based on its closing price on Thursday. TCF will pay 6.9 million shares, exchanging one share for 1.2877 Winthrop shares. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, TCF shares fell 62.5 cents, to $46.50. In Nasdaq trading, Winthrop stock gained 37.5 cents, to $34.375.

headline: ALLIES WELCOMING U.S. HINT AT PAUSE IN DOLLAR'S SURGE
abstract: Finance ministers and central bankers from world's seven largest capitalist countries, partly shell-shocked and partly delighted by dollar's extraordinary surge in value in recent months, voice relief after signals from US that pause was in order; quickly nod in assent, day after Treas Sec Robert E Rubin issued broad hint that US has abandoned two-year effort to boost currency's value (M)

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: KIDS MART INC.,  City of Industry, Calif., an operator of children's retail apparel stores, filed for Chapter 11 protection in Federal Bankruptcy Court and said it was looking for a buyer.    UNILEVER N.V.,  the Netherlands, said its Diversey Lever unit wouldclose its Mississauga, Ontario, manufacturing plant to reduce excess chemical manufacturing capacity in the North American market.    FOUR SEASONS HOTELS INC.,  Toronto, which manages luxury urban and resort hotel properties, said it had filed a prospectus with Canadian and U.S. securities regulators to enable it to offer additional limited voting shares.

headline: New in Cambodia: Justice Without Torture
abstract: Cambodia, with help of international organizations, is developing small corps of lawyers and judges to train police officers in proper procedures and to revive rudiments of working legal system, which was destroyed by radical Khmer Rouge between 1975 to 1979; justice system is just beginning to recover from mass killings of hundreds of thousands, including lawyers, doctors, teachers, monks and other educated people, and destruction of Government institutions; photos; map (M)

headline: Like Oil and Water: A Tale of Two Economists
abstract: Profiles of Drs Paul Krugman and Lester Thurow, professors of economics at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), who have vastly different opinions on phenomenon bedeviling not only the experts, but everyone else too: why has the resulting income gap become so glaring in last two decades while affluent minority has so visibly prospered; Krugman maintains that technology, not global competition, is principal cause of American income inequality; Thurow maintains that global economy, offering huge supply of low-wage foreign workers is main cause of income inequality in US; two men have become high-profile combatants in espousing their views, never face-to-face; both men are well paid for speaking on issue, with Krugman making $15,000 a speech and Thurow $30,000 a speech; photos of both men; outline of their positions and where they agree (L)

headline: Banca di Roma to Sell Assets to Padua Bank
abstract: Banca di Roma SpA says it will sell 55 branches and controlling stake in Interbanca SpA for about 724 billion lire ($453 million) to Banca Antoniana Popolare Veneta SpA (S)

headline: Former King of Romania Is Welcomed Home Again
abstract: Former King Michael of Romania, dethroned by Communists at gunpoint 50 years ago, makes emotional homecoming, where he is truly welcomed by Govt and people alike; new centrist Govt has embraced him as gallant soldier of World War II and a real citizen, unlike former Communists, who barely tolerated former King's presence five yers ago and banned all further visits; now 75, Michael appears visibly moved and teary as he arrives from exile in Switzerland; photo (M)

headline: Bonds Rise On Jobs and Factory Data
abstract: Treasury securities traded higher yesterday for the third consecutive session after reports suggested the economy might be slowing enough to keep inflation benign and the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates.    The price of the 30-year bond rose 15/32, to 95 13/32. The yield was 6.86 percent, down from 6.90 percent on Wednesday.

headline: A Summit That Blurs Strength and Weakness
abstract: Russian and US officials in Helsinki are waging public relations war before summit meeting between Pres Boris Yeltsin and Pres Clinton begins in earnest on March 21; photo (M)

headline: EMS CHEMIE TO JOIN H.B. FULLER IN CHEMICALS VENTURE
abstract: Ems Chemie Holding A.G., a chemical and engineering company based in Zurich, will combine its auto parts specialty chemicals business with that of the H. B. Fuller Company, based in St. Paul. Terms were not disclosed. Ems will contribute its Ems-Togo unit, and Fuller will bring its H. B. Fuller Automotive Company into the venture, to be called Eftec. It will supply adhesives, coatings and sealants to the automotive industry and will post 1997 sales of about $250 million, Fuller said. Fuller will own 70 percent of Eftec's American operations, and Ems will hold 70 percent of Eftec's European operations.

headline: Brokerage Chief Arrested On Charge of Taking Bribe
abstract: Philip John Milligan, head of J P Milligan stock brokerage firm, is arrested by Federal officials and charged with accepting $100,000 bribe to sell worthless stock in Pilot Transport to his customers; Milligan is also accused of threatening to beat and shoot employees of his firm if they did not lie to investigators for Securities and Exchange Commission (M)

headline: The Empire That Henry Luce Built Now Works at Bolstering the Bottom Line
abstract: Time Inc has undergone transformation under leadership of Don Logan, president and chief executive, and Norman Pearlstine, editor in chief; Pearlstine and Logan's common interest in financial details has gone a long way toward alleviating historically distant relationship between editors and publishers throughout company; company's priority is profits, and publishers know they have to make their numbers; emphasis on performance is reinforced by Pearlstine, who is described as first editor in chief at Time Inc to take active interest in financial as well as editoral side of magazines; Logan's strategy has been to extend the brand and develop new products, while solidifying the base; result has been five years of 13 percent compound annual growth; photos (L)

headline: Likely Impact: Less Disruption Than Last Time
abstract: Federal Reserve's move raising short-term interest rates is likely to have much smaller effect on stock and bond markets than did similar 1994 move; causes little immediate market reaction, in part because it was widely expected; reaction could change should Federal Reserve continue to raise rates or if Japan joins in raising rates (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Joblessness Slips to 5.3%; Little Inflation Risk Seen  The job market grew at an unexpectedly brisk pace in February as the unemployment rate slipped a tenth of a point, to 5.3 percent, the Labor Department reported.

headline: Daiwa Bond Trader Puts His Spin on Scandal
abstract: Toshihide Iguchi, former star bond trader for Daiwa Bank in New York, has writen book, The Confession, about losing $1.1 billion in bond trades; book describes ease with which he hid his illicit trading; Iguchi wrote book while serving term in American jail; reaction to book in Japan is muted; Japan's leading daily newspapers virtually ignored book, but widespread print advertising campaign has prompted publisher to increase first printing, expecting sizable order; photo (M)

headline: Compaq Takes a Gamble With Its New PC
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp will announce its entrance into market for personal computers priced less than $1,000, with machine based on new chip produced by Cyrix Corp; Cyrix's Media GX chip is not a Pentium-equivalent chip, but company contends it offers similar performance to comparable-speed Pentiums; Compaq is taking gamble in using chip other than Intel Corp's Pentium; industry analyst notes that consumers may be less willing to buy machine without Pentium-based or Pentium-equivalent chip (M)

headline: In Mainly Muslim Country, Mob Outbreaks Are Taking On an Ethnic or Religious Edge : Intolerance in Indonesia
abstract: MANADO, Indonesia — In a country where official statistics show Muslims forming 85 percent of the 200 million population, a striking feature of the buildings lining both sides of the road on the one-hour drive between Manado and Bitung, the two main towns of North Sulawesi Province, is the prevalence of churches and chapels.

headline: Baby Bells Rely on Specialty Services for Solid Earnings
abstract: Four regional Bell telephone companies report generally healthy fourth-quarter 1996 earnings, bolstered by profits from specialty services; Pacific Telesis reports net for quarter of $191 million, compared with $231 in 1995 period; SBC Communications earned $542 million, compared with $505.2 million in 1995 quarter; Nynex Corp earned $379.7 million, up from $235.6 million in 1995; Bell Atlantic earned $345.6 million in quarter, compared with $391.1 million in 1995 period (M)

headline: Iran's Central Bank Chief HailsCooperation From 'Partners,'Citing Failure of U.S. Sanctions : Europe and Japan Are Guaranteeing $5 Billion in Loans Tehran Reports
abstract: DAVOS, Switzerland—  Despite U.S. anti-terrorism sanctions, Iran has managed to obtain offers of more than $5 billion in government-backed loan guarantees from Europe and Japan over the last 18 months, according to the governor of Tehran's central bank

headline: Albright Flies Toward Vexing Issues
abstract: Foreign policy challenges facing new Sec of State Madeleine Albright in first official visit abroad, to nine countries in Europe and Asia, discussed; map (M)

headline: Peru Crisis Takes Toll on Hostages' Health
abstract: Physical and psychological health of 72 hostages held by guerrillas at Japanese Embassy residence in Lima deteriorate, spurring renewed calls for Peru and guerrillas to speed up talks on resolving crisis; Red Cross has stepped up medical activities inside compound; photo (M)

headline: Authorities Can Track Fugitive Financiers, but They Can't Bring Them In
abstract: US has had little success in persuading even friendly nations to tighten laws that provide safe harbors for financial fugitives; and often there are serious questions about how hard anyone tries to find these international scofflaws; efforts to track down Dario Garces-Velez, Miguel Gonzalo Recarey Jr, Marc David Rich, Giancarlo Parretti and Ghaith R Pharaon detailed; map; photos (L)

headline: Record for Chicago Board
abstract: Chicago Board of Trade reports membership to trade financial contracts sold for record $512,500 (S)

headline: Top Turkish General Visits Greeks, Bearing Good Will
abstract: Gen Ismail Hakki Karadayi, commander of Turkish general staff, pays unprecedented visit to Greek independence day reception at Greek Embassy in Ankara, first time in memory that such a high-level Turkish official has appeared; Karadayi astonishes gathering even more by asking to deliver toast to ending 'deep mistrust' between two countries; Greek Amb Demitrios Nezeritis welcomes general, in what may be slight thaw in frigid relations between two NATO allies (S)

headline: Big Swedish Banks End Merger Talks
abstract: Sweden's third-and fourth-largest banks, Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken AB and Nordbanken AB, say they ended talks about merging their operations, which would have created one of Scandinavia's top two banks (S)

headline: Blowing the Whistle, and Now Facing the Music
abstract: Interviews with Richard A Lundwall, dismissed Texaco Inc aide who made public tapes of Texaco executives belittling minorities and plotting destruction of documents sought in discrimination suit; Lundwall, indicted for role in destroying documents, discusses negative impact of disclosure on his life and his reasons for recording, keeping and belatedly disclosing tapes; photos (L)

headline: Thousands Join Leaders In Bidding Deng Farewell
abstract: China's leaders bid last farewell to Deng Xiaoping in traditional ceremony; tens of thousands of people line Beijing's main thoroughfare to watch funeral procession; photo (M)

headline: MEREDITH TO BUY 4 TV STATIONS FROM FIRST MEDIA
abstract: Meredith Corp agrees to acquire four television stations from First Media Television LP for $435 million; Meredith would gain CBS affiliate in Orlando, Fla, and affiliates of Fox network in Portland and Bend, Ore, and Greenville, SC (S)ü

headline: The Work-at-Home Executive
abstract: Letter by Andi Gray on decision by Mike Zisman, to give up his role as chief executive of Lotus Development to work at home and spend more time raising his children (S)

headline: Global One In Negotiations On Expansion
abstract: France Telecom says talks were under way for Cable and Wireless PLC to become British arm of Global One, French company's joint venture with Sprint Communications Corporation and Deutsche Telekom AG; Sprint and France Telecom deny report that Cable and Wireless is considering takeover bid for Sprint (S)

headline: Pamela Harriman Is Dead at 76; An Ardent Political Personality
abstract: Pamela Harriman, US Ambassador to France and leading figure in Democratic Party, dies in Paris from complications of cerebral hemorrhage; she was 76; Pres Clinton calls her 'extraordinary US ambassador' and source of inspiration to him; photos of Harriman with her three husbands, Randolph Churchill, Leland Hayward and W Averell Harriman (M)

headline: Gehe of Germany Raises Bid for Lloyds Chemists
abstract: Gehe AG raises its bid for Lloyds Chemists PLC by 5 percent, to 684.1 million pounds ($1.16 billion); competes with bid by Unichem (S)

headline: EMI Reports Drop In 9-Month Profit
abstract: The EMI Group, the British music company, said yesterday that the strong pound and weak holiday sales reduced nine-month pretax profit by 6.1 percent, though a promising fourth-quarter release schedule might bolster full-year earnings. Pretax profit before a one-time gain from asset sales declined to $:293.3 million ($478.6 million) in the nine months ended Dec. 31 from $:312.4 million a year earlier.

headline: Soybean Prices Keep Climbing On Signs of Strong Demand
abstract: Futures Markets column; soybean prices continue to climb on Chicago Board of Trade on signs that strong domestic demand would erode lean inventories in United States even more than expected (S)

headline: Ousted Yeltsin Bodyguard Wins Parliament Seat, Threateningly
abstract: Aleksandr V Korzhakov, shadowy former bodyguard of Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin, wins election to represent Tula, ailing industrial area 120 miles south of Moscow; boasts inside knowledge of Kremlin secrets and threatens to release them to embarass Yeltsin aides, and perhaps even Yeltsin himself (M)

headline: Paper Makers Plan a $1.7 Billion Merger
abstract: Abitibi-Price Inc and Stone-Consolidated Corp say that they will merge in transaction valued at about $1.7 billion (US), creating world's largest maker of newsprint; control of new company, to be called Abitibi-Consolidated Inc, would be almost evenly split between Abitibi and Stone-Consolidated (M)

headline: Stocks Lower in Japan
abstract: Stocks trade sharply lower in Tokyo on Jan 27; Nikkei index of 225 issues is down 354.46 points, at 17,334.90 (S)

headline: Lebanon Seizes Japanese Radicals Sought in Terror Attacks
abstract: Lebanon detains up to six suspected members of Japanese Red Army guerrilla group, which has maintained bases in Bekaa region since late 1970's with tacit Lebanese and Syrian approval; one of guerrillas, Kozo Okamoto, took part in May 1972 attack at Lod Airport, Israel, in which 24 people died; roundup may be sign that Syria seeks to improve its image (M)

headline: ABC Sets Review Of Majority of Account
abstract: ABC television network opens review on majority of its advertising account, which has been handled by Grey Entertainment unit of Grey Advertising (S)

headline: Clinton Says Mexico's Firmness Is Bright Side of Drug Scandal
abstract: Pres Clinton says arrest of Mexico's chief anti-narcotics officer on charges of collaborating with drug traffickers is 'deeply troubling' but also encouraging because it shows commitment by Mexican Government to combat corruption; says arrest would cut both ways as he considers whether to certify to Congress that Mexico is making progress in fighting drugs; certification is needed to continue certain aid to Mexico; officials at Justice and State Departments echo Clinton's bad news-good news analysis of situation in Mexico (M)

headline: Prelude To a Perfunctory Kiss
abstract: Comment by Susan Fishman Orlins about greeting colleagues and clients in the workplace with hugs and kisses; discusses her social-kissing anxiety, which she says hits a peak during Christmas holiday season; drawing (L)

headline: British Insurers In Merger Deal
abstract: Lowndes Lambert Group Holdings PLC says it has agreed to acquire Fenchurch PLC in stock deal worth $46 million; businesses will be combined to form Lambert Fenchurch Group (S)

headline: Small Software Company Nears Pact With Motorola
abstract: In the Macintosh computer community, Plan B just won't go away.    In December, when Apple Computer's chief executive, Gilbert Amelio, decided to buy Next Software Inc. to provide the company's new software operating system for the Apple Macintosh, he joked he was choosing ''Plan A over Plan B.''

headline: Pilots May Strike 4 Air Canada Units
abstract: Canadian Air Line Pilots Assn warns that pilots for four Air Canada units would strike if there is no new labor agreement by Jan 10; talks between pilots and management broke down on Dec 4; strike could halt more than 700 flights a day to 70 destinations in Canada and United States (S)

headline: Flexibility for Workers
abstract: Letter from Acting Labor Secretary Cynthia A Metzler, commening on Mar 9 article on flexible-hours law; says question is how to do it, not whether it is good idea (S)

headline: Germ War, a Current World Threat, Is a Remembered Nightmare in China
abstract: Germ warfare, current world threat, remains nightmare in China more than 50 years after secret units of Japanese invasion force that occupied much of country from 1931 to 1945 launched biological warfare attack against Congshan, tiny southeastern hamlet, killing hundreds of its 1,200 villagers; after half-century of recriminations both countries have agreed to take first steps toward cleaning up remains of chemical and biological warfare arsenals abandoned in China at end of World War II; Japan will propose plan to build environmentally safe factories in China to destroy chemical weapons, bombs and related equipment used by Imperial Army; some surviving residents of Congshan recall Japanese attack and subsequent outbreak of bubonic plague; map; photo (M)

headline: G.M. Never Wavered in Its 4-Year Fight Over Executive Who Defected to VW
abstract: General Motors Corp's victory in long legal battle with Volkswagen over Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, who allegedly stole thousands of documents when he left GM for Volkswagen, reflects fierce determination of some GM aides, GM's own detective work and its collaboration with German and American law enforcement authorities; biggest turning point in case was GM's decision to sue VW in Detroit and detail thousands of pages of documents taken by Lopez or his friends; graphs; photos (M)

headline: How a Deal Crowned A New King Of Wall St.
abstract: Historic $10.2 billion merger of Morgan Stanley Group and Dean Witter, Discover Co was almost derailed on Jan 20 when Banc One Corp announced that it was buying First USA Inc, a credit card company, for $7.3 billion in stock; hefty price sent First USA's stock soaring $8.875 in a day; most stocks in the sector moved up, too; Dean Witter's climbed 7 percent in next few days; Morgan Stanley's did not; and some people familiar with talks advised Dean Witter's chief executive Philip J Purcell to lower his bid; Purcell knew that Morgan's brass--Richard B Fisher, chairman and chief executive, and John J Mack, president--wouild hear nothing of it; Purcell stood pat; photo (L)

headline: Lloyds Buying Assets Of Brazil Joint Venture
abstract: Lloyds TSB Group PLC confirms that it intends to buy some assets from its Brazilian joint venture, Banco Multiplic SA; Lloyds says talks involve buying assets from Multiplic Empreendimentos, which owns the other half of Banco Multiplic, and ending companies' 19-year partnership (S)

headline: COLLINS & AIKMAN SELLS FLOOR-COVERINGS UNIT
abstract: Collins & Aikman Corp sells its floor-coverings business for more than $195 million to Quad-C Inc, a merchant-banking concern in Virginia, and US private equity unit of Groupe Paribas of France; sale is estimated at $170 million (S)

headline: A chain loses executives yet still maintains its reputation.
abstract: Market Place column queries whether decision by Luby's Cafeterias Inc board of directors to proceed with business as usual, following recent suicide of newly-appointed chief executive John Edward Curtis Jr and resignation of chairman Ralph Erben, was in best interests of investors (M)

headline: Labor Rifts Return to Employee-Owned United Airlines
abstract: United Airlines pilots vote to reject new wage contract, putting managers of employee-owned United in roughly same position as their counterparts at conventionally managed airlines such as American, whose pilots also voted down contract; in both cases, unions appear to be ignoring management's warning that letting labor costs creep too high will undo hard-won gains and damage carriers' standing on Wall Street; for United, it appears to be another experiment in employee ownership that is falling short of creating new formula for running a business; pilots' resentments are fueled by contrary perceptions about reasons for United's fast rebound; pilots attribute record profits mostly to hard work of employees, and managers give more weight to macroeconomic factors; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Swiss Bank Cannot Identify Papers in Cache It Shredded
abstract: Investigators say a historian working for Union Bank of Switzerland ordered the destruction of hundreds of pounds of archives compiled by a subsidiary that had extensive dealings with Nazi Germany; historian kept no inventory of what was destroyed, which will make it difficult to determine whether bank broke month-old Swiss law that prohibits companies from destroying material that may shed light on Switzerland's role as banker to Hitler's Germany; new details surrounding destruction of documents come as Swiss Government seeks to mend its strained ties with Jewish groups worldwide; Minister of Economics, Jean-Pascale Delamuraz, apologizes for his comment last month that Jewish groups engaged in 'blackmail' when they demanded that Swiss set up fund for Holocaust survivors (M)

headline: Airline travel is due to become a bit more frustrating when revalidation stickers are barred.
abstract: Airlines Reporting Corp, clearinghouse owned by major United States airlines that processes tickets issued by travel agents, will bar use of re-validation stickers used by agents and clients to make last-minute changes on airline tickets; Inter-Continental Hotels, owned by Saison Group of Japan, will introduce own version of guest rooms designed expressly for business travelers at nine North American properties; Israel and Jordan plan to open Peace International Airport at Red Sea port of Aqaba, Jordan, by mid-1998 (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Peru and Rebels Open Talks to End the Siege
abstract: Peruvian Government negotiator Domingo Palermo, Tupac Amaru guerrilla aide Rolly Rojas and international commission of guarantors open preliminary talks to end hostage siege at Japanese Ambassador's residence, Lima; agree on structure of future talks; Pres Alberto K Fujimori, in London, is hopeful for peaceful end to crisis; says he will not free jailed rebels (M)

headline: Polygram Starts TV Unit
abstract: Polygram NV starts television production division in Los Angeles, Calif, expanding its foray into movies and television; Polygram Television will expand Polygram's ability to produce a range of TV shows for broadcast networks, cable television and international syndication (S)

headline: London's BMP DDB Retools Media Unit
abstract: BMP DDB, British unit of DDB Needham Worldwide, reorganizes media services department under separate name of BMP Optimum (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * The Street.com, New York, to Ryan Drossman & Partners, New York, as the first agency for the Internet financial publication. Billings were estimated at $6 million.

headline: Sunbeam to Sell Maine Textile Factory
abstract: The Sunbeam Corporation has agreed to sell its textile factory in Biddeford, Me., to an investment group that includes the labor union representing factory workers. The terms of the agreement were not disclosed.    The investment group also includes American Capital Strategies, an investment banking firm, and an investment group led by Michael Liberty, a Maine executive.

headline: Reading The Mind Of Alan Greenspan
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan's testimony to Congress and its impact on stock market; cites quandry he faces about pushing up interest rates should economy weaken somewhat while stock prices continue to soar (M)

headline: How Web Smut Is Regulated May Depend on Tools to Filter It
abstract: Supreme Court hears oral arguments on constitutionality of Communications Decency Act, Federal law to regulate Internet pornography; Deputy Solicitor General Seth P Waxman, arguing in defense of law, says it is not enough that screening, or filtering, software, exists; says there are too many Web sites for such software to cover, making it impossible for parents to keep their children away from digital smut; Bruce J Ennis, lawyer challenging law, disagrees, saying parents can use software controls to prevent their children from having access to any indecent speech (M)

headline: MURPHY OIL PULLS OUT OF THREE-WAY CONSOLIDATION PLAN
abstract: Murphy Oil Corp decides not to merge its Murco Petroleum Ltd unit's British refining and marketing business with those of Elf Oil and Gulf Oil; Elf Oil is unit of Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine of France and Gulf Oil is part of Chevron Corp (S)

headline: Trade Gap Modestly Wider; Industrial Production Surges
abstract: US exports rose to record $72 billion in November 1996, led by sales of farm products; trade deficit widened, to $8.4 billion less than expected; graphs; trade deficit for 1996 is now certain to eclipse $105.1 billion recorded in 1995; November gap with China was $3 billion, down from $4.9 billion; gap with Japan shrank to $4.3 billion from $5 billion (S)

headline: Chapter 11 Filed After Fraud Case
abstract: Systems of Excellence Inc files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, just weeks after its former chmn, Charles O Huttoe, was sentenced to 46 months in prison after pleading guilty to charges of securities fraud and money laundering (S)

headline: Nazi Gold and Portugal's Murky Role
abstract: Portugal follows Switzerland in confronting history of financial dealings with Nazi Germany; regime, which was officially neutral but had strong Nazi sympathies, sold tungsten and other goods to Germany, profiting handsomely as Nazis paid with gold bullion taken from occupied countries and Holocaust victims; Portugal secretly sold off some of gold after war through its colony, Macao; embarrassed establishment and central bank, which still has some gold bars stamped with swastikas, decline public comment amid pressure to open archives; Allies tried to get Portugal to surrender 44 tons of gold after war, giving up and accepting four tons in 1953; historian Antonio Louca documents dealings with Nazis (M)

headline: Canada's Ex-Leader Accepts Apology in Libel Suit
