abstract: Former Canadian Prime Min Brian Mulroney reaches out-of-court settlement on eve of unprecedented trial on libel charges against Government; $36.5 million suit charged his reputation had been permanently damaged by disclosures that he was being investigated for taking kickbacks in 1988 in Air Canada's $1.8 billion purchase of 34 airliners from Airbus Industries, European consortium; Government will issue public apology, and will pay $730,000 in Mulroney's legal fees; Mulroney has repeatedly denied wrongdoing (M)

headline: Fleet to Sell 18 Branches
abstract: Fleet Financial Group Inc agrees to sell 18 bank branch offices in upstate New York; will sell 12 branches to Community Bank System and 6 branches to Glens Falls National Bank and Trust Co (S)

headline: The Surging Dollar? In U.S., Most Companies Shrug It Off
abstract: Number of Amercan companies expressing alarm over surging dollar has been surprisingly small, compared with 12 years ago when many manufacturers warned that businesses would be severely injured by influx of cheap imports; many have been insulated from effects by expanded production overseas, decade of aggressive cost-cutting and active hedging of currencies; officials at Boeing Co, General Electric and Intel Corp have dismissed worries about dollar; even Caterpillar Tractor, which led complaints in mid-1980's, has been quiet, as have machine-tool makers which were nearly driven out of business by low-priced Japanese imports; currency continues surge, despite statement by Treas Sec Robert E Rubin that it has corrected itself after hitting record low against yen nearly two years ago; graph (M)

headline: LASALLE RE HOLDINGS TO REPURCHASE SHARES
abstract: LaSalle Re Holdings Ltd say it will buy back 3.7 million of its common shares for $27 to $30 a share, or a total of about $100 million (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.75   5.61   5.31        3-MO. headline: Brussels Meeting Dims Turkey's Bid to Join European Union
abstract: Group of powerful European leaders deals blow to Turkey's hopes for admission into European Union; leaders of some of Continent's most important center-right parties, at meeting in Brussels, say they do not consider Turkey to be serious applicant (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   5.50   5.33        3-MO. headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes noted (S)

headline: S.E.C. Asks Judge to Soften Stand on Fraud
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission urges Federal Judge Fern M Smith to reconsider decision making it tougher for investor lawsuits against companies to go forward under year-old law; argues she misinterpreted Congress's intent in passing Private Litigation Reform Act of 1995 and deviated from other courts on issue (M)

headline: Campus Mood Is Unlike '89, But Lid Is Kept On Anyway
abstract: Passing of Deng Xiaoping provokes little reaction from students at Beijing University, former hotbed of radical politics; China's new leaders are so concerned that any spontaneous political expression could set off unrest that they are taking extensive measures to prevent it; officials mount photo exhibit to commemorate Deng; one of photos shows Deng swimming at beach one month after ordering brutal suppression that resulted in killing of hundreds of unarmed civilians near Tiananmen Square (M)

headline: PROGRESSIVE FOOD INVESTS IN HARRY'S FARMERS MARKET
abstract: Harry's Farmers Markets Inc says it received $23 million in new capital from Progressive Food Concepts Inc, affiliate of Boston Chicken Inc; Progressive could get up to 43% stake in Harry's as result of investment (S)

headline: Challenging the Boss and Living to Tell About It
abstract: Advice for workers on handling complaints of wrongdoing against boss; drawing (M)e

headline: Chance of Hebron Deal Fades As Israelis and Arabs Dig In
abstract: Prospects for Israeli pullback from Hebron seem to dim in face of Palestinian demands for detailed agenda for further Israeli withdrawals elsewhere in West Bank; Yasir Arafat holds tense meeting with US mediator Dennis Ross and says there are 'more burning issues' than signing Hebron agreement; photo; Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu reportedly tells Ross he will commit only to first redeployment, and not to Palestinian demand for joint patrols at Cave of Patriarchs; he faces mounting opposition within his broad and fractious Cabinet; Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak is urging Arafat to insist on additional concessions (S)

headline: Publicis/Bloom Promotes 2 in Dallas
abstract: Publicis/Bloom unit of Publicis SA names Steve Price president and chief operating officer of Dallas office for last three years, and Seth Werner, vice chairman and executive creative director for last decade, to head Dallas office as co-chairmen and co-chief executives; they assume responsibilities from Paul MacMahon, who will retire (S)

headline: Heinz Cutting 2,500 Jobs In Revamping
abstract: H J Heinz Company, in what it calls largest revamping in its history, announces that it will sell or close at least 25 plants around world and dismiss 2,500 employees, or 5.8 percent of its work force of 43,300; company will take $650 million charge in current quarter to pay for cutbacks; also says it will sell most of its Ore-Ida Foods Inc frozen-foods business for $500 million to McCain Foods Ltd of Canada; company's unprofitable Weight Watchers business in United States will be revamped, at cost of $55 million to be included in reorganization charge (M)

headline: Stocks Advance in Late-Afternoon Rally
abstract: Stocks prices rose on New York Stock Exchange on February 4; Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 27.32 points, closing at 6,833.48; Standard & Poor's 500 Index gained 2.53 points, closing at record 789.26 (M)

headline: Dutch Food Concern Buys Illinois Baker
abstract: CSM NV of Netherlands says it bought Karp's Inc for undisclosed sum (S)

headline: Orange Juice Prices Tumble; Crop Estimate Is Raised Again
abstract: Orange juice prices fall on New York Cotton Exchange after Agriculture Department increases its estimate for record Florida orange crop, promising ample supplies in the coming year (M)y

headline: For Albright in Moscow, a Chorus of NATO Nyets
abstract: American officials seek to lower expectations about any quick Russian acquiescence to NATO expansion as Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright arrives in Moscow for first round of talks with Russian leaders; Albright will offer package of proposals designed to convince Moscow that expanded NATO would not be an aggressive alliance, and could lead to a Europe armed with fewer weapons than Russians face now; but Russian officials make unremittingly negative public statements about issue; photo (M)

headline: Stocks Up a Bit in Tokyo
abstract: Stock prices rose on Tokyo Stock Exchange on March 20; Nikkei average gained 48.51 points, to close at 18,493.71 (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes noted (S)

headline: Recycling Advocates Don't Take Less News Coverage Lightly
abstract: Steel Recycling Institute is abandoning righteous indignation and attempts to play to journalists' social conscience that advocacy groups usually use to drum up friendly coverage; mounts public relations campaign with enough gimmicks, celebrity endorsements and other bells and whistles to sell the most crass consumer product; reporters and editors offer numerous reasons for sporadic interest in a topic that once routinely hit page one (L)

headline: Informant in Archer Daniels Price-Fixing Case Is Indicted
abstract: Mark E Whitacre, former executive with Archer Daniels Midland Co who worked as Government informant in sweeping price-fixing investigation, is indicted on charges that he defrauded the company of more than $9 million; 45-count indictment charges that Whitacre conspired with other executives to steal money in complex scheme involving fraudulent invoices, front companies, forged records and Swiss bank accounts; Archer Daniels accused Whitacre of stealing the money in 1995, and Whitacre has previously acknowledged obtaining it; but he has maintained for more than a year that he received it through illegal, corporate-wide compensation system for its top executives (L)

headline: Zaire Rebels Try to Find Way to People's Hearts
abstract: Zaire rebels, having won military battle for Kisangani, are trying to win hearts and minds of people there, holding meetings with political officials and promising elections to choose local government; map (M)

headline: U.N. Backs Sending Troops To Restore Order in Albania
abstract: UN Security Council authorizes multinational force of thousands of soldiers to oversee relief efforts in Albania and encourage return to order; Pres Sali Berisha again calls for aid (S)

headline: A Deft Ski Maker Works a Slippery Slope
abstract: Profile of K2 Inc, Los Angeles, which despite dormant state of ski business, has seen sales rise dramatically with introduction of its K2 skis; all told, sales have risen from $435 million in 1994 to an estimated $600 million last year; while several of K2's more expensive skis have become hard to find, its shares have, in line with many other small-capitalization stocks, performed poorly over last year; photo; graphs on number of visits to ski areas each season and on K2's stock price (M)

headline: A molecular biologist receives protection for discoveries that could be millions of years old.
abstract: Dr Raul J Cano, molecular biologist who published evidence that he had brought back to life a microorganism that had been preserved in amber over millions of years, receives patent for process, along with his associate, Dr Monica K Borucki; William F Wood receives patent for synthetic version of compounds with antibiotic properties that are secreted from special glands on feet of black-tailed deer; Joel Baumwoll receives patent for device meant to deter thieves from breaking into cars to steal valuables (M)

headline: Debate Over Taxes in '97 Is Likely to Stress 'Relief'
abstract: Focus in Washington in 1997 is on tax breaks, not on reforming tax system; Clinton Administration and Congressional Republicans are divided over whether to tie tax breaks to specific conduct or to make across-the-board rate cuts; proposed cuts reviewed; photo (M)ï

headline: Longer Tenure for Top Fed Bank Executives
abstract: Top Federal Reserve Bank officials can now stay in their jobs longer; in policy change, Federal Reserve System board of governors says it approved changes in rules for tenure of highest officials at 12 regional banks, by adding optional exception to rules that govern their retirement; under new policy, if appointed after age of 55, a Fed bank pres or first vice pres would be allowed to stay in job for 10 years, or until age of 70 (S)

headline: Rich, 82, and Starting Over
abstract: Interview with 82-year-old John Werner Kluge, head of Metromedia International Group, who is busy constructing wireless cable television and cellular communications networks throughout Russia, Baltic states, Eastern Europe and China; table; graphs; photos (L)

headline: In a Tough Hint to Rebels, Peru Fills Hostages' Jobs
abstract: Peruvian Pres Alberto Fujimori replaces president of Peru's Supreme Court and six police generals who are among hostages still being held by leftist guerrillas; diplomat sees 'brutal' message that hostages are expendable; 74 remain in Japanese ambassador's residence; Fujimori, in second address since crisis began in December, again brands guerrillas 'terrorists'; photo (S)

headline: Former Archer Daniels Executive Is Indicted
abstract: Reinhard Richter, former executive at Archer Daniels Midland Co, is indicated on Federal charges that he used bogus invoices to steal more than $180,000 from the company; Richter, a native of Germany, was vice president of the bioproducts division and president of Archer Daniel's Mexican subsidiary; Justice Department says it is seeking Richter's extradition from Mexico to face charges (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY   Urban Shopping Ctrs    TUESDAY   Century Tel Entrpr  Kellwood    WEDNESDAY   Amcast Indl  Ametek  PP&L Res    THURSDAY   Belden    FRIDAY   Aetna  Harris  Meridian Indl Tr  Piedmont Nat Gas

headline: Cordiant Announces Management Shifts
abstract: Nadeen Peterson resigns as Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising vice chairwoman and creative director to open consulting firm; Cliff, Freeman & Partners names Jonathan Brody to new post of senior vice president and group director on Ameritech Corp account (S)

headline: Torn by War, Sri Lanka Faces Deepening Despair
abstract: Business district of Colombo, Sri Lanka, still bears scar of truck bombing that devastated it a year ago, a symbol of impasse that has settled over the country after nearly 15 years of bitter civil war; both Government and Tamil rebels seem to have hunkered down for further conflict; Pres Chandrika Bandaranaike Kumaratunga is credited with political courage in offering constitutional concessions to Tamils, but she is faulted for tuning the war with rebels and the political battle with Sinhalese opponents in Colombo into a personal crusade; photo; map (M)

headline: Shares of Polygram Rise As It Meets Expectations
abstract: Shares of Polygram NV rise on Amsterdam's stock exchange after company reports 1996 earnings matched expectations (S)

headline: Saatchi Absorbs Sibling Agency
abstract: London office of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, unit of Cordiant PLC, has absorbed a sibling, K Advertising in London; Saatchi & Saatchi will retain 34 of 39 employees; Hamish Pringle, chairman of K Advertising, becomes vice chairman and marketing director at Saatchi & Saatchi; he assumes some duties from Jo Smith, Saatchi & Saatchi new business director, who left (S)

headline: H & R Block's spots suggest that a taxpayer's best friend is the one who does the taxes.
abstract: H & R Block's new national advertising campaign presents stories that depict how people really feel about filing taxes; this is Young & Rubicam's first campaign for H & R Block since it was awarded contract last spring (M)

headline: 'Be flexible' is the advice as a holiday weekend and a strike deadline at American Airlines near.
abstract: Possible effects of strike by Allied Pilots Assn against American Airlines discussed; strike would not only shut down carrier, but would also severely inconvenience tens of thousands of passengers throughout nation's already crowded air transportation system on Washington's Birthday weekend (Business Travel) (M)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization               Dec. 27   Dec. 20   Dec. 29          1996   1996   1995       Gasoline production, daily   7.8   7.6   7.7       Distillate production, daily   3.5   3.6   3.3       Gasoline stocks   191.7   192.0   201.5       Distillate stocks   123.8   121.3   129.2       Crude imports, daily   7.6   7.2   7.3       Product imports, daily   1.9   1.7   1.6       Crude stocks   295.6   292.9   303.3       Crude production, daily   6.5   6.5   6.4       Refinery utilization (%)   92.3   93.3   92.2      (Source: American Petroleum Institute)

headline: Moving From the Card Catalogue to the Internet
abstract: Field of library science has changed drastically, as technology has made more data available than can be bound in books or catalogued by Dewey decimal system; field now requires great deal more technical expertise with electronic information and computer networks; these new demands have opened raft of new career opportunities, attracting more people to the profession over last decade; in response, many universities have converted their schools of library science into schools of information and library science; librarians are now being referred to as information specialists, cybrarians, data base managers or knowledge navigators; photo; graph (M)

headline: Peru Resumes Contacts With Rebels Holding 74
abstract: Peruvian officials resume talks with guerrillas holding 74 hostages in Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima (S)

headline: AFFINITY GROUP TO ACQUIRE A RETAILER AND A PUBLISHER
abstract: Affinity Group agrees to acquire Camping World Inc, retailer of recreational vehicle merchandise, and Ehlert Publishing Inc, publisher of sports and recreation magazines, for total of about $139 million (S)

headline: Retailers' Sales Gained at High And Low Ends In February
abstract: Retail same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least one year, were strong in February, particularly among two sectors of the industry: extremely expensive and rock-bottom priced; Goldman, Sachs & Co same-store sales index shows retail sales in February were up 3.8 percent compared with figures from year earlier; in February 1996, they had risen 4.9 percent; table (L)

headline: It's a Fund! Bringing Up Baby Mutuals
abstract: MORE than any other factor, performance sells mutual funds. That puts start-up funds, with no performance record, at a disadvantage in the battle for investors' dollars.    To give the start-ups a booster shot, a growing number of fund companies are following an old strategy that allows a new fund to build a performance record even before it starts to solicit money from the public.

headline: $2.5 BILLION PRICE PUT ON MOBIL-SAUDI CHEMICAL PROJECT
abstract: Mobil Corp and Saudi Basic Industries Corp say they will spend $2.5 billion to double capacity of their petrochemicals ethylene project on Red Sea (S)

headline: Despite Scandal, U.S. Plans To Certify Mexico Drug Fight
abstract: Clinton Administration plans to certify Mexico as ally in drug war, despite shock over arrest of top anti-drug official on charges of colluding with traffickers; Gen Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo, new appointee welcomed in Washington only few weeks ago, allegedly collaborated with Amado Carrillo Fuentes, whose syndicate has smuggled tons of cocaine, heroin and marijuana across US border; some US officials want review of certification, but others in Administration say Gutierrez arrest shows Pres Ernesto Zedillo's commitment to drug war; Colombia is likely to be decertified for second year (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PMT SERVICES INC., Nashville, which markets and services credit card authorization and payment systems, signed a definitive agreement to buy Bancard Systems Inc. of Irvine, Calif., an independent credit-card processor, for about $45 million in common stock.

headline: Clinton Concedes China Policy Hasn't Helped Much on Rights
abstract: Pres Clinton concedes that his doctrine of 'constructive engagement' with China has failed to engender progress on human rights; says he still believes that Administration's policy is correct one (M)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/   It's time to dust off those bearer bonds to see whether they've come due. By Sharon R. King.    SPENDING IT /Page 7/   The luxury tax on cars has been rolled back, but not eradicated. Buy a sport utility, and you won't have to worry. By James Schembari.    SPENDING IT /Page 7/   A new biography of Mayer Rothschild offers a fresh take on the history of entrepreneurship, and tells how he came to invent mail-order catalogues along the way. By Deborah Stead.    EARNING IT /Page 8/   The nation's briefcases carry an odd assortment of items, from Twix bars to human arteries to nothing at all. By Lawrence Van Gelder.

headline: France to Lose Jobs In Renault Cost-Cutting
abstract: Renault SA says it is preparing job cuts in France in acceleration of cost-cutting program begun last week when car maker announced that it will close its Belgian factory; plan is expected to involve cutting 3,000 jobs at Renault's four plants in France; that just about matches 3,100 job cuts planned in Belgium, where Renault will close its plant in Vilvoorde (S)

headline: As Life Gets Even Harder, Albania Grows More Fractured
abstract: New Albanian coalition Government is struggling to unify country, riven by several rebellions in north and south over failure of pyramid schemes; three weeks after country was consumed by armed insurgencies in south and in counter-rebellions in capital of Tirana and in north, picking up pieces is proving very hard; southern port towns of Sarande and Vlore remain in hands of rebels, who are insisting on resignation of Pres Sali Berisha before any consideration is given to surrendering arms seized from army depots (M)

headline: $400 MILLION AGREEMENT FOR MAGELLAN HEALTH
abstract: Magellan Health Services Inc says it will divest its 95 psychiatric-hospital operations in sale-lease-back agreement to Crescent Real Estate Equities Inc for about $400 million in cash (S)

headline: Hostage Crisis Imperils the Growth of Peru's Economy
abstract: Peru's hard-won image as a country safe for tourism and investment is beginning to be eroded by hostage crisis; as the standoff between Government and leftist guerrillas continues into its third week, with 74 hostages still held at the residence of the Japanese Ambassador, officials warn that their assertions that Peru's economy will not suffer any long-term effects is based on a rapid, decisive solution that ends with no deaths among the hostages; so far, economic damage has been limited, with some tourists canceling trips and a few investors shelving projects out of fear that political violence has returned (M)

headline: Mutual Fund Concern Feels Impact of Lender's Default
abstract: Strong Capital Management has repurchased millions of dollars of short-term commercial paper issued by Mercury Finance Co from three of its popular money market funds to keep funds from losing money on the notes; each of funds had up to 5 percent of assets invested in notes issued by Mercury Finance; Mercury's notes were rated 'first tier' by two agencies and 'second tier' by two others at time of purchase by three funds (M)

headline: BTR Agrees to Buy French Meter Group
abstract: British industrial conglomerate BTR PLC agrees to buy Pollux Meter Group of France for 163 million pounds ($267.4 million) (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Converse Inc says US Bankruptcy court has approved liquidation of Apex One subsidiary (S)

headline: BERGEN BRUNSWIG TERMINATES MERGER DEAL WITH IVAX
abstract: Bergen Brunswig Corp says it has terminated its agreement to acquire Ivax Corp and that it will sue Ivax for breaking terms of agreement; Ivax claims Bergen Brunswig unilaterally terminated pact 'without good cause' (S)

headline: A Democrat in China: Like an Egg Against a Rock
abstract: Tong Yi, who played brief role in Chinese democracy movement, now lives in internal exile in Wuhan; she served over two years in labor camp, from which she emerged in Oct 1996 to find China harsher place and herself in continuing state of persecution; map; photo (M)

headline: Shareholders Pressure Cablevision
abstract: Charles F Dolan, chairman of Cablevision Systems Corp, is under mounting pressure to focus more intently on reducing debt and increasing earnings; some shareholders are angry at Dolan's announcement that company is entering cellular telephone business at time when its stock is under so much pressure (M)

headline: Hong Kong Stock Issue Thwarted And a Beijing Role Is Suspected
abstract: World of Hong Kong business--which has boasted of immunity from territory's political tremors as China prepares to resume sovereignty in four months--is jolted out of its reverie; leading investment banking concern abruptly withdraws as underwriter for local magazine and newspaper company that was on verge of issuing shares for first time on Hong Kong Stock Exchange; company, Next Media Group Ltd, publishes some of harshest criticism of China, and decision to drop stock sale is seen as result of political pressure from Beijing; Next Media is owned by Jimmy Lai, retail clothing entrepreneur and vociferous critic of China; Next Media had chosen Sun Hung Kai International Ltd as underwriter for deal (M)

headline: PREMISYS STOCK FALLS, WITH QUARTERLY LOSS EXPECTED
abstract: Premisys Communications shares drop sharply for second straight day as company says it expects to report loss for its third quarter (S)

headline: Political Books Become Less Sober, More Pop-Oriented
abstract: Political books have become less sober and more pop-oriented; politics is following rest of American culture, and going pop; so is political literature; implications for classic Washington, DC, book are starting to worry some people in book industry; twenty years ago, Washington politics generated wave of sobersided, brisk-selling reportage; political books that sell today are by comedians, scandalmongers and celebrities; list of 1996's top five political works on The New York Times Best Seller List and top five all-time best sellers; photos (L)

headline: Taco Bell joins the industry shake-up with a review, and there's nothing ordinary about it.
abstract: Advertising column describes recent changes in volatile realm of fast-food advertising; in latest development, Taco Bell disclosed review on creative part of its account with billings estimated at $200 million; review will include incumbent shop, Bozell Worldwide; Fallon McElligott recently resigned from McDonald's agency roster to take part in review for Domino's Pizza account; photo (M)

headline: Palestinian Held in U.S. May Halt Fight On Extradition
abstract: State Dept says Mousa Mohammed Abu Marzook, leader of militant Palestinian faction called Hamas, intends to drop his challenge to Federal court decision to extradite him to Israel to face terrorism charges; he has been in Manhattan jail since July 1995, when he was arrested upon his return to New York from trip abroad (M)

headline: MAFCO HOLDINGS TO BUY MAFCO CONSOLIDATED SHARES
abstract: Mafco Holdings will buy 15 percent of Mafco Consolidated Group that is held by public and take full control of cigar maker; Mafco Holdings will pay $33.50 a share, or $114 million, for Mafco Consolidated (S)

headline: Change of Marketers At Miller Brewing
abstract: The Miller Brewing Company in Milwaukee is unexpectedly changing its vice president for marketing by hiring Jack Rooney, a longtime agency executive, to replace Neil Harrison, who had held that post since March 1993.    Mr. Rooney, 39, will join Miller on Feb. 1 from the San Francisco office of the British agency Leagas Delaney, where he had been managing director. Mr. Harrison, 43, is leaving Miller, the company said yesterday, ''to pursue other general management opportunities.''

headline: One Journalist Takes a Chance and Others Just Follow
abstract: Freedom of press gains new meaning in Peru when group of 20 cameramen and photographers, who were allowed to cross police lines to film front of Japanese Ambassador's residence, sneak into compound and enter house, where Tupac Amaru guerrillas hold impromptu news conference; Government has tried to tightly control rebels' access to news media ever since they took hostages (M)

headline: A Chinese City Is a Model of Good Behavior
abstract: Zhangjiagang, thriving port on Yangtze River, represents future of China as Beijing's leaders would like to see it: prosperous and law-abiding, clean and orderly, fully modern and yet firmly in control of Communist authorities; map; photo (M)

headline: Nigerian Nobel Winner Faces Treason Charges
abstract: Nigeria's military Government charges Nobel laurete, Wole Soyinka and 11 other dissidents with treason in connection with series of bombings of army installations; Soyinka, playwright, has lived in exile since he fled Nigeria in Nov 1994 (M)

headline: New Captains, Steady Ships
abstract: Carole Gould (Funds Watch) column says Fidelity Investments, well aware of investor frustration with manager turnover at fund, says it will create new class of its shares--preferred stock with yields above market average--to 'attract, retain, compensate and motivate qualified employees'; says Jack Bowers, who edits Fidelity Monitor, independent newsletter, Rocklin, Calif, examined number of Fidelity's domestic stock funds and grouped them by number of managers they had had over last five years; says he then calculated average five-year return for those with one, two, three, four, or five managers and found no significant correlation between how well fund performed and how often its manager changed; chart (M)

headline: Tajik Rebels Said to Kill U.N. Aide in Hostage Deal Gone Awry
abstract: Russian news organizations report that Tajik rebels have killed United Nations observer they have been holding hostage in campaign to secure release of fellow insurgents (M)

headline: HOME DEPOT TO PAY $245.4 MILLION FOR DIRECT MARKETER
abstract: Home Depot Inc to pay $245.4 million in stock for Maintenance Warehouse America Corp (S)

headline: Tracing Your Family Tree to Cheddar Man's Mum
abstract: Interview with Adrian Targett, resident of Cheddar, England, who DNA tests reveal is descendant of Cheddar Man, 9,000-year-old skeleton at Natural History Museum in London that was found in local cave in 1903; photo; maps (M)

headline: Behind a Chief Executive's Death
abstract: Day-to-day pressure of running a company is blamed for suicide of John Edward Curtis Jr, new chief executive of Luby's Cafeterias Inc; Luby's chairman, Ralph Erben, who groomed Curtis as his successor, comments; death sets off search for serious problems at firm; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.13   5.24   5.40        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.01   5.01   4.96        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.11   5.11   4.85        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.61   6.58   5.52        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.88   6.86   5.97        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.90   7.87   7.17        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   5.87   5.84   5.56          *Estimated daily average, source Telerate  **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Trump Hotels Approves Buyback of Stock
abstract: Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts Inc says its board approved repurchase of as many as 1.25 million common shares, or about 5 percent of shares not held by company's chairman, Donald J Trump; stock of company has languished as efforts fail to sell up to half of one holding, Trump Castle (S)

headline: Russia's Staff of Life Is Now a Bone of Contention
abstract: Moscow's chief food inspector announces that quarter of the bread made in city each day is 'unsuitable for use as food,' and Muscovites react with anger and dismay; Mayor Yuri M Luzkhov promises to shut any bakery whose products fail to please him; this reflects important role of plain, chewy black bread in life of Russia and its people; photo (M)

headline: Chineses Wonder if TV Documentary Means Deng Is Slipping
abstract: China's central television station is devoting hour in prime time during week to broadcast documentary on life of 92-year-old Deng Xiaoping, nation's paramount leader for past 20 years; move is seen as additional sign that Deng's days are near end (M)

headline: Can England Save Its Hedgerows? Whipping Is Out
abstract: Developers and agribusiness interests are razing British land, ridding it of its most singular visual characteristic: brambly hedgerows that articulate rolling land; Penelope Farquhar-Oliver is on front lines in fight to save the hedgerows; she and legions of other celebrators of English countryside are lobbying Government to adopt promised regulations to 1995 environmental law; photo; map (M)

headline: Beach Clubs and Ski Slopes Would Lose Money, Too
abstract: Travel agents are besieged by worried clients at destinations where American Airlines, threatened with walkout by pilots on February 15, dominates air-travel market; officials at several popular vacation spots heavily served by carrier say economies of regions could be hit hard by strike (M)

headline: Helping the S Corporations
abstract: National Association of Manufacturers aide James P Carty letter on Jan 26 article on assisstance S corporations received in Small Business Job Protection Act of 1996 (S)ï

headline: In War-Battered Zaire, Two Leaders, Two Welcomes
abstract: Pres Mobutu Sese Seko, Zaire's ailing President, returns to Kinshasa after several weeks in France, but does not appear in public, fueling rumors of his failing health; Laurent Kabila, rebel leader, is greeted by tens of thousands of cheering and dancing supporters when he arrives triumphantly in fallen provincial capital of Kisangani; photos; map (M)

headline: JAMES RIVER WILL SELL TIMBERLANDS TO JOHN HANCOCK UNIT
abstract: James River Corp agrees to sell 95,000 acres of timberlands in Alabama and Mississippi to investment unit of John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Co of Boston for $110 million; James River also signs long-term wood supply agreement with John Hancock unit, Hancock Timber Resource Group, under which James River will have cutting rights on the lands (S)

headline: Clinton Aides Say That Income Gap Narrows
abstract: Pres Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, in annual report on economy, says gap between rich and poor in America seems to have stopped widening and may have reversed; finds poorest 20 percent of households had biggest income gains, 1993-95, averaging nearly 3.5 percent a year; says it is too soon to tell whether long-term trend toward greater income inequality has ended (M)

headline: After 4,000 Years, It's Time for Urban Renewal
abstract: Plans by Egyptian Government to relocate 8,000 residents of Qurna to new village being built nearby have caused tensions with villagers, many of whom have vowed to remain; Egyptian officials say long-overdue action is aimed only at providing archeologists and tourists with full access to hundreds of tombs, dating to 2200 BC, that include fine examples of Egyptian relief, painting and sculpture; unsuccessful efforts to relocate villagers since shortly after World War II noted; map; photo (M)

headline: New U.S. Bond Promises To Match Cost of Living
abstract: Treasury to auction $7 billion in new 10-year inflation-indexed bonds, expected to yield holders some 3.5 percent above inflation rate; such bonds, if available earlier, would have outperformed most financial investments in 1970's, but would have provided relatively poor returns in recent years; graphs; drawings (M)

headline: Intel Chief Named Chairman as Well
abstract: Andrew C Grove, co-founder of Intel Corp, is named chairman and Craig R Barrett is promoted to president; Grove will remain chief executive and succeed Gordon E Moore as chairman; Moore will become chairman emeritus (S)

headline: Fiscal Fandango Damages an Emerging Uzbek Market
abstract: Uzbekistan was seen as potential gold mine by foreign investors; but despite progress in curbing inflation and narrowing current account deficit, economy remains stagnant and recent decisions by Government of Pres Islam Karimov have hurt country's credibility with outsiders; International Monetary Fund, disappointed with Uzbekistan's runaway monetary growth, has suspended republic's $180 million loan program; many executives from small- and medium-size Western businesses say they are freezing their investments or simply pulling out; maps; graphs; photos (L)

headline: U.S. Expands Protection For Contract Farm Labor
abstract: Labor Department officials announce new rules to increase protection for hundreds of thousands of farm workers by making it harder for farmers to avoid liability for violations of laws on wages and sanitation committed by contractors who supervise farmers' employees; Government adopts rules, which are opposed by growers, after farm workers groups complained that contractors who hire and manage workers for thousands of farms are often shadowy operators who fail to pay minimum wages or provide clean drinking water (L)

headline: Intel Seen Facing Fight On Chips
abstract: Intel Corp may finally face stiff competition when Advanced Micro Devices Inc releases powerful K6 chip in April 1997; some industry experts say chip is better bargain than Intel's competing Pentium II (S)

headline: Special Winter Games Warm Hearts in Toronto
abstract: Sixth Special Olympics World Winter games are held in Toronto, Canada, involving handicapped athletes from 75 countries (M)

headline: Heinz U.S.A. Picks DDB Chicago Unit
abstract: Heinz USA division of H J Heinz Co names DDB Needham unit of Omnicom Group as lead agency for advertising (Addenda)

headline: Mild-Mannered Comics Lover or Businessman of Steel?
abstract: Steve Geppi, owner of Diamond Comic Distributor Inc, has become leading figure in world of comics by consolidating lucrative distribution end of the industry; Diamond is already largest distributor of English-language comics; if it proceeds with talks with bankrupt Marvel Entertainment, it could become only major distributor in this country; photo (M)

headline: 3 Sides of 'Dirty War' Laid Bare In One Day in Spain's Top Court
abstract: Spain's Supreme Court weighs bid by families of suspected Basque terrorists killed by state-sponsored death squads to declassify secret intelligence data on squads; another court panel jails two more top Herri Batasuna party leaders for refusing to testify about party's campaign videotape that prosecutors hold shows party actively collaborates with Basque separatists; court mourns Judge Rafael Martinez Emperador, whose Madrid murder Government is linked to Basques (M)

headline: 2 Years After Kobe's Quake, Lives Are Still in Ruins
abstract: KOBE, Japan—  Her face remained calm, but 64-year-old Hisako Kohashi became animated as she described the life she has led since an earthquake engulfed her home in fire and she was forced to move into a tiny room that she shares with her older brother.

headline: Firm Dollar And Rate Bet Lift Bonds
abstract: US Treasury bond prices close higher on February 4 for sixth consecutive session as investors remain optimistic that Federal Reserve will leave interest rates unchanged; benchmark 30-year bond rose 14/32, to 97 14/32; graph (M)

headline: NETANYAHU AND ARAFAT AGREE ON ISRAELI PULLOUT IN HEBRON
abstract: US mediator Dennis Ross announces that Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat have reached agreement on partial Israeli withdrawal from Hebron; says agreement detailing Israel's withdrawal from 80 percent of Hebron is 'fair and balanced approach' to dealing with concerns each side has; Pres Clinton says accord brings us another step closer to lasting peace in Middle East; praises Netanyahu and Arafat, and says King Hussein of Jordan deserves 'special recognition and gratitude for his work for peace'; photo (M)

headline: CENTENNIAL SHARES PLUNGE AFTER TRADING RESUMES
abstract: Shares of Centennial Technologies plunge 76 percent after trading of the stock, which had been halted since Feb 25, resumes; company says it falsely reported earnings of $12.1 million in last three and a half years while actually losing money; shares fall $11.25, to $3.50, on trading of about 11.2 million shares (S)

headline: Ayer Names Media Director
abstract: N W Ayer & Partners, New York, names William P Tucker to head its media services department as senior vice president and media director (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Harder Life for Lebanon Palestinians
abstract: Palestinians who fled to Lebanon after Israel was established in 1948 see little hope that they will be allowed to return and are more concerned about deteriorating conditions and lack of civil rights at refugee camps; United Nations officials say conditions at camps have worsened drastically in recent years, as Palestinian Authority has cut off most of financial support it once provided and Lebanon has imposed strict travel curbs discouraging Palestinians from working abroad; rising tempers and increasing violence are among new portents of trouble at camps; map; photo (M)

headline: WHAT'S AHEAD: Hong Kong's New Owner
abstract: Its residents are nervous, but Hong Kong's economy seems unperturbed by China's impending takeover. The stock and property markets continue to climb and the economy is healthy. But many fear that China will bring its worst habits to Hong Kong, including corruption, restrictions on free speech and the media and laws that are applied selectively.

headline: Ammirati Puris Lintas Announces Revamping
abstract: Ammirati Puris Lintas reorganizes worldwide management by promoting several executives to new posts and eliminating title of zone chairman (S)

headline: Dow Jones Family Feud Grows More Intricate
abstract: Complex drama involving family control of Dow Jones & Co grows more byzantine as Elisabeth Goth, young dissident member of Bancroft family which controls 70 percent of shareholder votes, accuses other family members of misrepresenting her views regarding management of company in letter to Fortune magazine; recent article in Fortune reported Goth was unhappy with management of Dow Jones and had hired lawyers and investment bankers for advice on how to increase company's lagging stock price (M)

headline: Did Arafat Abet Violence? A Complex Tale
abstract: Analysis of Israeli Government charges that Yasir Arafat has allowed Islamic militants to renew terror attacks; diplomats, Palestinians and Israelis familiar with Palestinian affairs see many of his moves that Israel depicts as encouraging militants as efforts to co-opt opponents in areas he controls and to split them off from outside radicals; photo (M)

headline: Anarchy of Thugs Menaces Albania
abstract: Armed revolt in Vlore, Albania, which began as outgrowth of peaceful protests, is showing signs of going sour; people say they want to see end of Pres Sali Berisha, whose Government sat back as pyramid investment schemes left hundreds of thousands of Albanians penniless; they are proud that their uprising has set stage for string of popular uprisings against Government in 10 major towns; they are also terrified by gangsters and thugs who are currently ruling streets with automatic weapons; map; photo (M)

headline: Icahn Names His Advisers In RJR Battle
abstract: Carl C Icahn names Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette as his investment adviser for proxy assault on RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp; Icahn reiterates his intent to seek immediate spinoff of company's food business, even after RJR Nabisco reported improved fourth-quarter results (M)

headline: Pearson's New Chief Discloses Big Plans for Financial Times
abstract: Pearson PLC chief executive Marjorie M Scardino says firm plans to invest $160 million over next five years in Financial Times, to bolster its circulation and brand name in United States and Asia; says she has put in place new management team at Pearson and new focus on performance; Pearson reports operating earnings rose 8 percent in 1996, before 100 million pound charge for improper accounting practices at Penguin unit, to 281 million pounds ($447 million); after charge, operating profit fell 30 percent (S)

headline: No Need To Raise Rates Again
abstract: Economist Edward Yardeni article, opposing further rise in interest rates, holds Federal Reserve is too concerned about inflation threat; defends current prosperity (M)›

headline: Court Supports Transmission Of Sports Data
abstract: Federal appeals court rules, 3-to-0, that National Basketball Assn may not stop Motorola Inc and sports statistics-gathering company from transmitting continuously updated scores of NBA games on hand-held pager that Motorola sells; decision reverses ruling by lower court judge who had concluded that NBA's commercial property was being misappropriated by Motorola and Sports Team Analysis and Tracking Systems, known as Stats Inc; defendants' winning argument was that pager-like gadget, called Sportstrax, was merely relaying factual information already in the public domain; court's ruling has broader implications: because Stats Inc also has America Online site where users can view same game information, ruling could also protect news information transmitted via on-line services; because of First Amendment implications of case, news organizations had filed friend-of-the-court briefs supporting the defendants (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: After Demotion, Executive Resigns From Apple  The revolving door in Apple Computer's executive suites continues to turn. Marco Landi, left, Apple's chief operating officer until the company shuffled its management this month, has resigned, the company said.    The chairman, Gilbert F. Amelio, said Apple intended to cut costs by $400 million a year, and it is expected to announce layoffs. Apple stock rose more than 9 percent yesterday, up $1.5625, to close at $17.875. $(Page D4.$)    WMX Chief Quits Amid Pressure  WMX, the sprawling waste management company with shrinking profits, said that Phillip B. Rooney, its chief executive, had resigned. Soros Fund Management, a big shareholder in WMX, had been seeking the ouster of Mr. Rooney, who has been retreating from a diversification strategy he once pushed for the company. $(D2.$)

headline: Albania Chief's Associates Flee; Gunfire Halts Evacuation by U.S.
abstract: Collapse of authority in Albania worsens; Pres Sali Berisha's associates flee, Government fails in attempt to take back weapons from roving bands of thugs and mobs of desperate Albanians try to push themselves onto Italian boat; photos; map; US suspends evacuation of Americans after gunmen fire at two helicopter gunships waiting to pick up families near diplomatic compound; only 408 of estimated 2,000 Americans have gotten out so far; police and military officers are not heeding appeals by new coalition Government to return to posts; NATO turns down Berisha's call for troops; anarchy spreads to eastern region near Macedonia, where new $10-million cigarette plant is burned and looted; Government buildings and medieval streets are set afire in Shkoder; new Government forces resignation of Bashkim Gazidede, unpopular head of secret police; defiant Berisha refuses to resign, but sends grown son and daughter to Italy (M)

headline: Finding Common Ground For Global Markets
abstract: Lehman Brothers aide Thomas A Russo article calls for voluntary guidelines to promote financial market stability worldwide; drawing (M)

headline: Swiss to Share Control of Holocaust Fund With Jewish Groups
abstract: Swiss Government, after 18 months of tortuous and sometimes secret negotiations, agrees to share control of Holocaust memorial fund with leading Jewish groups (M)

headline: Chubb and Reliastar Deals Continue Merger Trend
abstract: Life insurance companies are merging to cut costs and compete with mutual funds by offering their customers more options for investing in stock market; in latest merger news, Chubb Corp says it agreed to sell its life insurance business to Jefferson-Pilot Corp for $875 million, and Reliastar Financial Corp says it will buy Security-Connecticut Corp for $413 million in transaction that would create 11th-largest publicly held life insurer in nation (M)

headline: Firm Awarded $222.7 Million In a Libel Suit Vs. Dow Jones
abstract: Federal jury in Houston, Tex, awards $222.7 million to local bond brokerage firm, MMAR Group Inc, in libel suit over 1993 article in The Wall Street Journal; Dow Jones & Co, publisher of Journal, says it will appeal; MMAR claimed article made false statements that drove away its clients, causing firm to close within month of article's appearance; article in question, by reporter Laura Jereski, described how MMAR had become powerhouse selling mortgage-backed securities; it said MMAR was reckless in dealing with its clients, that it had contributed to $50 million in losses by Louisiana state pension plan and was under investigation by regulatory agencies; Prof Vincent Blasi, expert in libel cases, notes this latest award is nearly four times greater than previous record award for libel, and reflects effort of jury to send message to media as a whole; there is ample polling data that public is widely dissatisfied with media's performance (M)

headline: Providence Journal Sale Raises Doubts on Autonomy and Hackles in Family
abstract: A H Belo Corp's friendly acquisition of Providence Journal happened so quickly that regrets and recriminations occured only after sale was all but completed; some descendants of Stephen Metcalf, Journal's publisher in 1929, fear that his legacy of honor and integrity has been turned into money and stock in Belo, a Texas media corporation; reporters and editors at Journal-Bulletin, as it is now called, take some comfort from Belo's reputation as copmpany with high standards; photo (M)

headline: Is Paris Fuming? Yes, Despite a Legal Ban
abstract: France is lax in enforcing its tough anti-smoking laws, partly because the French are very attached to a habit that expresses something of their national character; a third of adults in France smoke, compared with about a quarter in US, whose anti-smoking ethos is derided in France as puritanical; however, some people in France are now asserting their right to breathe smoke-free air, and conflicts on the issue are breaking out all over the country; Jean-Luc Michel, who was dismissed as air controller after complaining about colleagues' smoking comments; photo of Michel and of 10 French luminaries smoking (M)

headline: Maybe These Newlyweds Should Keep Separate Homes
abstract: Article by Susan Cartwright, senior research fellow in organizational psychology and Cary L Cooper, professor at University of Manchester, Eng, evaluates union of Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter and pivotal role played by Philip J Purcell, chief executive of the merged company (M)

headline: BRADLEES TO CUT 105 OFFICE JOBS AND CLOSE STORE ON L.I.
abstract: Bradlees Inc says it will cut 105 jobs at its central office in Braintree, Mass, in effort to restore company to profitability; company also says it will close its store in New Hyde Park, LI because of poor sales (S)

headline: Even as cyberappeal grows, everything new is becoming old again.
abstract: Edward Rothstein comment on efforts to cash in on appeal of cyberspace; warns that cyberspace, fast becoming commonplace, will lose its cachet; photos (M)

headline: Spain Ordered To Open Files In Basque Case
abstract: Spain's Supreme Court orders Government to declassify 13 documents as evidence in trials of former officials charged in killings of 27 Basque separatists between 1983 and 1987; victims' families and prosecutors sought declassification (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Inflation Is Benign As Sales Rise Modestly  Consumer prices remained under control in December and for all of 1996. For the year, the core inflation rate, which excludes the volatile food and energy categories, was up only 2.6 percent. Along with an increase of the same size in 1994, that was the lowest core inflation since 1965. Over all, prices were up 3.3 percent in 1996.    And the Government's survey of retail sales confirmed what merchants had suggested for weeks: The holiday season produced gains, but they were smaller than retailers had hoped. Sales climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in December, to a level 4.4 percent above that of December 1995. $(Page D2.$)    Broad Rally in Stocks  The moderate inflation seen in the consumer price report encouraged buying in the stock and bond markets. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 53.11 points, to 6,762.29, its sixth record close in two weeks. Broader indexes also surged. $(D8.$)    Bond prices revived after a two-day slump. Yesterday's economic data eased fears that Federal Reserve policy makers would raise interest rates next month. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.77 percent from 6.85 percent on Monday. $(D18.$)     Struggle for Gold Deposit Increases  A fierce struggle for control of a rich gold deposit in Indonesia intensified, as Placer Dome proposed a $5 billion stock merger with Bre-X Minerals, which made the find in 1995. Bre-X has a competing offer from Barrick Gold of Toronto. $(D2.$)    Acquisition in Chip Industry  In a deal that would unite two strong niche makers of semiconductors, KLA Instruments said that it had agreed to acquire Tencor Instruments for $1.27 billion. $(D4.$)    Barnett to Buy Leasing Company  Barnett Banks agreed to acquire Oxford Resources, the largest automobile leasing company in the United States, for about $570 million in stock. $(D4.$)    Digital Wiretap Plan Reduced  Scaling back its earlier plans for electronic surveillance in the digital age, the F.B.I. released a new proposal that would make it easier for the bureau to place legal wiretaps on advanced telephone networks, but not with the scope previously contemplated. $(A11.$)    Fund Group Accused of Fraud  The S.E.C. accused the managers of the Permanent Portfolio family of mutual funds of violating fund investment policies and wrongly billing investors in the funds for thousands of dollars of expenses. $(D20.$)    Paper Destruction at UBS  Shortly after the Swiss Government ordered its banks to preserve any remaining records of their dealings with Nazi Germany, a suspicious security guard at the Union Bank of Switzerland halted the destruction of a range of World War II-era papers, including some that appeared to document ''forced auctions'' of property in Berlin in the 1930's. $(A1.$)    N.C.A.A. Attacks Gambling Ads  The National Collegiate Athletic Association has threatened USA Today and a number of other newspapers that it will deny them access to the college basketball championships unless they drop gambling ads that mention college sports. $(A10.$)    Shanghai Surprises  To American money managers who visit bustling Shanghai, China looks like a tempting place to invest. Yet when they dig beneath the surface, they find that it remains difficult for responsible investors to do so. Even for fund managers willing to stretch the boundaries of their normal investing precautions, China offers precious few public places to park their cash. Market Place. $(D8.$)    Chrysler Draws From Cars' Images  Chrysler's first corporate ad campaign in four years is continuing with new spots. The new TV ads, created by Bozell Worldwide, describe the genesis of the company's autos, using the tales to make a broader point about Chrysler. Advertising. $(D6.$)

headline: Futures Trading Starts in a Dow Jones Index
abstract: Dow Jones & Co, in marked contrast to court action it took in 1982 to assure that no futures or options would be traded on Dow Jones index, to allow Chicago Mercantile Exchange to begin trading futures on Dow Jones Taiwan Market Index as of today, and tomorrow Pacific Stock Exchange will begin trading options on index, which is designed to track prices in Taiwan market (M)

headline: Seeing Bias in Their Utiity Rates, Mixed-Race South Africans Riot
abstract: Residents of mainly mixed-race neighborhoods around Johannesburg, South Africa, take to streets on Feb 6, blocking roads with debris, throwing rocks and looting stores, to protest what they say is discrimination by South Africa's new Government (M)

headline: Equity Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    8X8 Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., an initial public offering of 2.5 million shares. Montgomery Securities.    Aramex International Ltd., Bermuda, an initial public offering of 1 million shares. Commonwealth Associates.    Birmingham Steel Corp., Birmingham, Ala., 1 million shares. Paine Webber.    CD Warehouse Inc., Oklahoma City, an initial public offering of 1 million shares and warrants. Capital West.    Coral Systems Inc., Longmont, Colo., an initial public offering of 2.7 million shares. Montgomery Securities.    Energen Corp., Birmingham, Ala., 1.5 million shares. Salomon Brothers.    Flanders Corp., Washington, N.C., 1.6 million shares. Gilford Securities Inc.    Healthdesk Corp., Berkeley, Calif., an initial public offering of 1.5 million shares and warrants. Whale Securities Co.    Isonics Corp., San Jose, Calif., an initial public offering of 850,000 units consisting of 1 share of common and 1 warrant. Pryor, McClendon, Counts & Co.    Jenna Lane Inc., New York, an initial public offering of 600,000 units consisting of 2 shares of common stock and one redeemable class A warrant. Walsh Manning Securities.    Price REIT Inc., La Jolla, Calif., 1.5 million shares. Merrill Lynch & Co.    Shaman Pharmaceuticals Inc., South San Francisco, Calif., 2 million shares. Hambrecht & Quist.    Transcrypt International Inc., Lincoln, Neb., an initial public offering of 3.75 million shares. Dain Bosworth.    Source: MCM Corporatewatch.

headline: Under Pressure, Chief Resigns at WMX
abstract: Phillip B Rooney resigns as chief executive of WMX Technologies, succumbing to pressure from Soros Fund Management that had sought his ouster; Dean L Buntrock, founder whom Rooney replaced, is named acting chief executive; Soros Fund Management, which owns 5.2 percent of company's stock, says it will continue to press for ouster of several board members (M)

headline: Ford Will Travel High Road With Adless 'Schindler's List'
abstract: NBC's presentation on Feb 23 of film Schindler's List will be unusual far beyond the fact that broadcast television network will devote three and a half hours during crucial ratings period to a black-and-white film about the Holocaust; film will run without commercial interruptions from advertisers, NBC or local stations; adless program was made possible by decision of Ford Motor Co, in consultation with longtime Ford agency, the J Walter Thompson Co, to become exclusive sponsor of the film (L)

headline: Cyberspace Resumes Fit the Modern Job Hunt
abstract: Many places on World Wide Web offer simple forms to job seekers to prepare electronic resumes; employers, especially big technology companies, want ability to search for 'key words' to indicate person's match for a job (M)

headline: Guatemala Foes Now Train for Peace
abstract: Guatemalan guerrillas and soldiers are being demobilized under United Nations supervision; with long civil war finally over, leftist rebels are moving into encampments to begin uncertain transition to civilian life; photo (M)

headline: Japan's Trade Surplus Continues to Shrink
abstract: Japan's current account surplus dropped 23 percent in Dec from Dec 1995 to 820.7 billion yen ($6.66 billion); 1996 surplus fell to 7.18 trillion yen ($58.3 billion), down 30.9 percent from 1995 (S)

headline: Apple Stock Battered by Forecast of Loss
abstract: Shares of Apple Computer Inc fall nearly 18 percent after company discloses that it would report loss of $100 million to $150 million in what is typically its strongest quarter; announcement suggests that yearlong turnaround effort by chairman, Gilbert F Amelio, may be falling short; but some analysts note that Amelio never promised that company would return to profitability in single year; in further blow to Apple, Canon Inc says it will sell its 20 percent stake in Next Software Inc just before Apple buys it; analysts say Canon is, in effect, betting against Apple, which plans to use Next's software to modernize its operating system (M)

headline: The Perks for Parents
abstract: Letter by Glenn Johnson on Dec 1 article which discussed supposed workplace advantages given to parents, as opposed to the childless (S)

headline: Selling Votes Is Legal, So Russians Shop Around
abstract: Special election will be held in Tula, Russia, on Feb 9 to fill parliamentary seat; candidates are begging, buying and stealing every vote they can find; map; photo (M)

headline: Wall Street Shifts Focus To Earnings
abstract: Wall Street shifts focus to corporate earnings, which have been less than robust, following decision by Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates; concerns center on pricing competition and wage pressures at home, slower economic growth in US and abroad, and fears that many large companies can no longer use restructuring to increase profitability (Market Place); graph (M)

headline: Librarians Seeking a Good Book Turn to Him
abstract: Profile of Bill Ott, editor and publisher of Booklist, the book review publication of American Library Association; Booklist serves as an acquisition bible for public and school librarians nationwide, which spend $75 million a year on books and related reference material, and he is thus an outsized influence on the fortunes of undersized publishers; photo (M)

headline: In Germany, An Echo Of Uproar In Colombia
abstract: Arrest of freelance German operative in Colombia, Werner Mauss, raises questions about personality and style of man who allegedly sent him there--Bernd Schmidbauer, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's senior intelligence aide; incident has also given Germans a rare peak into deeds committed in their name that seem to bypass country's usual regard for rules; Schmidbauer occupies what commentators call a gray world between high office and dubious means (M)

headline: Hiram Walker Plans Kahlua Commercials
abstract: Hiram Walker & Sons, unit of Allied Domecq PLC, will spend $20 million on television campaign for new product based on Kahlua coffee liquor; spots were created by Lois/EJL unit of Lois/USA in Chicago and feature Rolling Stones song 'Brown Sugar' (S)

headline: New Report Indicates Consumers Remain Optimistic on Economy
abstract: Americans' confidence in the economy remained extremely high this month, a report by the Conference Board showed.    The research group said yesterday that its index of consumer confidence stood at 118.4 in February. Although that was slightly below January's level -- which was revised upward to 118.7 from 116.8 -- it exceeded expectations.

headline: SFX Broadcasting Deals
abstract: SFX Broadcasting Inc completes acquisitions of three radio stations in Texas and Connecticut for combined $66 million; company buys KQUE-FM and KNUZ-AM in Houston for about $41 million from Texas Coast Corp, and WWYZ-FM in Hartford for $25 million from Gilmore family (S)

headline: Strong Clothing Sales Spur Rise In 4th-Quarter Earnings at Sears
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co says earnings surged 25 percent in fourth quarter, to $567 million, on sales of $12.04 billion, up 11 percent from year earlier; this is fourth consecutive quarter that Sears exceeded expectations and that earnings rose by 25 percent or more (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article last Sunday about debt ratings of colleges and universities misstated the enrollment of Bennington College. It is 289, not 189.

headline: Birny J. Mason Jr., 87, Dies; Ex-Chairman of Union Carbide
abstract: Birny J Mason Jr, who led Union Carbide Corp during the 1960's, dies at age 87; his photo (M)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             Mar. 14   Mar. 7   Mar. 15          1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   7.1   7.2   7.1       Distillate production, daily   3.1   3.2   3.2       Gasoline stocks   198.2   202.5   207.9       Distillate stocks   103.3   106.9   96.3       Crude imports, daily   7.8   7.5   7.1       Product imports, daily   2.2   2.0   1.5       Crude stocks   304.7   304.6   299.7       Crude production, daily   6.4   6.5   6.5       Refinery utilization (%)   90.4   89.5   89.7          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: Texas Instruments to Sell a Computer Unit
abstract: Texas Instruments reports loss for fourth quarter and sale of its money-losing notebook computer business to Acer Group of Taiwan; loss for quarter was $29 million, compared with earnings of $291 million in year earlier; revenues dropped to $2.5 billion from $3.1 billion; earnings would have been $127 million without one-time factors including charges of $91 million for voluntary retirement program and layoffs, and $117 million in write-downs; sale to Acer will give that company rights to use Texas Instruments, Travelmate and Extensa brand names for three years; sale price not disclosed (M)

headline: Franchisees Back Price Cuts By McDonald's
abstract: McDonald's Corp says that its 2,700 domestic franchisees voted overwhelmingly to endorse its plans for nationwide promotion built around sharply discounted burgers and sandwiches and that program will begin in 55 days; investors fear price war could errupt, affecting entire $100 billion fast-food industry; billions of dollars have been wiped off value of McDonald's and other fast-food stocks since details about discount plan began to emerge; photo (M)

headline: Peru's Police Yield as Red Cross Draws a Line in Hostage Crisis
abstract: Peruvian security forces, bowing to pressure from International Committee of Red Cross, agree to restrict their maneuvers outside Japanese Ambassador's residence while aid workers are providing services to 73 hostages being held by Marxist guerrillas (M)

headline: Correction
abstract: Because of an editing error, an article Thursday incorrectly stated the birthplace of Ignatz Bubis. He was born in Breslau, then part of Germany. It is now Wroclaw, Poland.

headline: Ericsson to Cut Jobs In Subcontracting Plan
abstract: Ericsson AB, Swedish telecommunications equipment maker, will cut as many as 1,400 jobs as it subcontracts some electronic-component production to two US companies and revamps other operations (S)

headline: As Pepsi regroups, it strikes a generational note once again.
abstract: Advertising column describes Pepsi-Cola Co's effort to rejuvenate its flagging overseas sales, with campaign to promote its flagship soft-drink brand with single, unified global voice that will again invoke popular 'Pepsi generation' appeal to youthful optimism and irreverence; campaign, carrying theme 'Generation next,' was devised by BBDO New York; photo (M)

headline: A Specialty Supplier to Chip Makers Is Acquiring Another
abstract: KLA Instruments Corp agrees to acquire Tencor Instruments in tax-free stock swap valued at $1.32 billion; merger terms noted (M)

headline: America Online: The Internet Reacts
abstract: Excerpts from angry entries on Internet bulletin boards and World Wide Web sites that were created to exchange criticism about America Online, which has been unable to accommodate all its new customers since it introduced new flat monthly access charge (M)

headline: Little Fund, Big Gains: Growing Concerns
abstract: Question facing investors in $1 million Van Kampen American Capital Growth Fund, country's best performing stock mutual fund that recently went public, is whether fund can stay ahead of pack once it loses its special status; fund rose 62 percent in 1996 and gained additional 10 percent in January (Market Place) (M)

headline: WET SEAL STOCK DROPS AFTER DISAPPOINTING SALES
abstract: Stock of Wet Seal Inc drops more than 18 percent after investment firm Ladenburg, Thalmann & Co says Wet Seal's same-store sales for November and December were below analysts' expectations; Ladenburg says sales at Wet Seal stores open at least a year increased less than predicted 6 percent; company's stock falls $3.375, to $14.75 (S)

headline: Korean Women Still Feel Demands to Bear a Son
abstract: Many women in South Korea are torn between demands of age-old social tradition that obligates them to bear sons and growing appreciation of females in Korean Society; approximately one of every 12 fetuses is aborted each year because of its sex, leaving country with impending shortage of women; pressure to have sons often comes from women themselves, who feel they will fail husbands by not producing male heir; country has 30,000 fewer girls born each year than would be case if there were no abortions (M)

headline: Disney Says Ovitz Left and Was Paid
abstract: Walt Disney Co spokesman says Michael Ovitz, departing president, left company on Dec 27, a month earlier than expected, and his multimillion-dollar severance package was paid then; shareholder lawsuit was filed to stop severance payment; it contends Ovitz's performance as president for 14 months did not warrant its size, said to total $130 million or more (S)

headline: The Wealth That Isn't?
abstract: James Peale letter on Jonathan Fuerbringer's Mar 2 article on impact of rising value of financial assets on consumer spending (S)

headline: America Online's Strategy Raises Eyebrows
abstract: America Online's fourth-quarter 1996 loss of $155 million raises new questions among analysts over how costly company's business strategy is proving to be, whether it has cash to execute its plans, and how long it will take for company to show steady profits (M)

headline: ESSEF AGREES TO PAY $68 MILLION FOR GENERAL AQUATICS
abstract: Essef Corp to bug General Acquatics Inc for about $68 million (S)

headline: Economic Calender
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: Taiwan Welcomes the Dalai Lama, Much to China's Displeasure
abstract: Dalai Lama, symbol of Tibetan independence, is welcomed in Taiwan by Buddhist leaders; China reacts angrily (S)

headline: In terms of managing mutual funds, must youth be served?
abstract: National Bureau of Economic Research study of performance of growth and growth and income equity mutual funds, 1988-94, finds the younger the manager the better the performance; Profs Judith Chevalier and Glenn Ellison, study authors, say results are not linked to degree of risk taking; cite tendency of funds to dismiss underperforming young managers faster than older managers with poor results; also cite quality education as factor (M)

headline: Teamsters Are Challenging G.E. Chief's Compensation
abstract: Teamsters pension fund offers shareholder resolutions challenging deferred compensation plans for General Electric Co chairman and chief executive, John F Welch Jr, and Pepsico chief executive, Roger A Enrico; seeks to draw attention to what it calls excessive executive pay (M)

headline: Iran Contributed $500,000 to Bosnian President's Election Effort, U.S. Says
abstract: Clinton Administration officials say that even as United States was trying to roll back Iran's influence with Muslim-led Government of Bosnia, Iran contributed at least $500,000 last summer to boost election campaign of Bosnia's President, Alija Izetbegovic (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Olivetti SpA sells its US venture capital holdings and non-Italian operations of Decision Systems International unit for $56 million; Homestake Mining Co reports plans to acquire Santa Fe Gold Corp has received Federal antitrust clearance; Sealy Corp completes sale of its Woodstuff Manufacturing Inc unit to group of investors for $35 million (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: American Express to Cut Thousands of Workers  American Express said that it would eliminate 3,300 jobs, or 4.6 percent of its work force, as it responds to tough competition in the credit card industry.    American Express has already cut 12,000 jobs in the last few years. Steps like those have reduced its annual operating costs by nearly $2 billion, and the company's earnings rose sharply in the fourth quarter. $(Page D3.$)    Honeywell to Buy Controls Maker  Honeywell said that it would acquire Measurex, a maker of controls for the paper industry, for $600 million. The deal would make Honeywell the leading seller of controls and services for pulp and paper plants. $(D2.$)

headline: Albania Calls An Emergency As Chaos Rises
abstract: Albanian Government imposes nationwide state of emergency as anarchy spreads in wake of officially sanctioned pyramid schemes in which hundreds of thousands of people lost their life savings; southern half of country spirals out of control as enraged protestors ransack military warehouses, burn buildings and loot banks and stores in city of Sarande; at least four people are reported killed in gunfire in other areas; Pres Sali Berisha warns iron hand will be used to end violence; Government, faced with police force that has deserted most of posts and disaffected army that has abandoned barracks, says feared secret police will be used to maintain order; unrest has political implications for US and its European allies; map; photo (M)

headline: The Sky's the Limit
abstract: Readers are invited to submit anecdotes about unusual worker demands; drawing

headline: JOSTENS TO SHIFT CALIFORNIA PLANT'S WORK TO TENNESSEE
abstract: Jostens Inc will close its Porterville, Calif, factory and consolidate its operations into one plant in Shelbyville, Tenn; Jostens, which makes yearbooks, class rings and other products, says move will eliminate about 200 jobs in Porterville but create same number in Shelbyville (S)

headline: Construction Spending Rises In Sign of Economic Strength
abstract: Commerce Department reports construction spending rose unexpectedly in November at fastest rate since March 1996; spending increased 1.9 percent in November, to $592 billion at annual rate; outlays for public projects rose 2.5 percent, to $150.3 billion pace; spending on private, nonresidential projects surged 1.6 percent to $152.3 billion; residential construction rose 1.2 percent, to $247.6 billion in November; single-family home construction fell three-tenths of 1 percent, while spending on multifamily homes rose 5.6 percent in the month; graph (L)

headline: ARCHER DANIELS COMPLETES DEAL FOR GRACE'S COCOA UNIT
abstract: Archer Daniels Midland Co completes its purchase of W R Grace & Company's cocoa business for about $470 million in cash and assumed debt (S)

headline: France Reports Decline In Number of Job Seekers
abstract: Number of French job seekers unexpectedly falls 29,000, or 0.9 percent, in December, first decrease since October; number of job seekers totaled 3.09 million in December; unemployment rate put at postwar high of 12.7% (S)

headline: Some Shifts At Apple, But No Layoffs or Unit Sales Yet
abstract: Apple Computer Inc shuffles top management but fails to announce much-anticipated reorganization; co-founders, Steven P Jobs and Stephen Wozniak, will join its executive committee as advisers to chairman and chief executive Gilbert F Amelio executive; other executive changes noted (M)

headline: Shift at ABC News Prepares for a Successor to Arledge
abstract: ABC-TV says it is creating new position for Roone Arledge, longtime president of its news division, in move to prepare a successor to him in that operation; Arledge is named chairman of ABC News, while David Westin, who had been president of ABC Television Network, is named president of news; Westin will now report to Arledge, who until March 6 reported to Westin (L)

headline: '96 Was a Very Good Year for I.B.M.'s Chief Executive
abstract: IBM chief executive Louis Gerstner Jr, took $5,000 cut in 1996 salary and bonus of nearly $5 million, but incentive pay package grew substantially, to extent that total pay rose by 29.4 percent, to $20.2 million from $15.6 million in 1995 (M)

headline: AT&T, BELL ATLANTIC AND DSC SETTLE ANTITRUST SUIT
abstract: AT&T Corp, Bell Atlantic Corp and DSC Communications Corp settle claims related to antitrust lawsuit, in which Bell Atlantic and DSC charged AT&T with designing telecommunications equipment to prevent connection of other manufacturers' equipment, and with seeking to monopolize markets for telecommunications equipment and software for caller identification services; terms of settlement not disclosed (S)

headline: A New Sporty Auto Show
abstract: Sporting goods are on prominent display at North American International Auto Show, Detroit, as auto makers seek to attract both aging boomers and younger buyers (S)

headline: Citibank's Branches Chief For U.S. and Europe Quits
abstract: Rana Talwar, head of Citibank's branches in United States and Europe, resigns to take senior position with Standard Chartered PLC in London; his duties will be assumed by William Campbell, who runs Citibank's branches worldwide (S)

headline: I.R.A. Admits It Planted 2 Bombs in England
abstract: IRA acknowledges detonating two bombs in Cheshire town of Wilmslow; link seen to British parliamentary campaign; bombs disrupted rail traffic, but injured no one (S)

headline: Cable Industry Leaders Downgrade Satellite Threat
abstract: Many cable industry officials attending annual convention in New Orleans acknowledge Rupert Murdoch's ambitious satellite broadcasting service could draw customers away from cable, but say threat has been both exaggerated and misunderstood; although Murdoch's service could eventually offer 500 channels of digital programming, many cable executives believe it will appeal to only narrow slice of viewing audience; move by cable operators, like Time Warner Inc and Tele-Communications Inc, to upgrade systems with digital technology noted (M)

headline: HAL vision
abstract: How close are we to realizing the bold concepts of ''2001: A Space Odyssey''?     Story, Page D4.

headline: A Convention Draws French For Far Right, And Against It
abstract: Tens of thousands of opponents of France's far-right National Front converge on party convention in Strasbourg to demonstrate rejection of leader Jean-Marie Le Pen and all party stands for; with next legislative elections only year away, what to do about National Front is dominant obsession in French political life; political mainstream is divided about how to counter National Front's apparent magnetism; photo (M)

headline: SKYLINE CHILI GETS UNSOLICITED TAKEOVER BID
abstract: Skyline Chili receives unsolicited takeover offer of $7.50 a share for company (S)

headline: Unilever: Not Just Vanilla Anymore
abstract: IF the giant consumer products company Unilever P.L.C. were a football team, until recently it would have epitomized the conservative approach of three yards and a cloud of dust. Its moves had been predictable, and it relied on financial heft rather than on nimbleness to gain a point or two of market share.    Which is why the announcement last week that the British-Dutch company was throwing the equivalent of a bomb into the end zone with the sale of four of its larger businesses took the markets by surprise. Has this stodgy manufacturer of everything from Good Humor ice cream to Dove soap and Q-Tips suddenly become a growth stock?

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Japan Releases Proposal To Liberalize Its Markets  The Japanese Government released a deregulation proposal that is intended to lead to liberalizing the nation's financial markets to make it easier for investors to trade such products as stock options and new types of corporate bonds.

headline: Strong Earnings Lift Stocks, With the Dow Rising 38.49
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 38.49 points to close at 6,765.37, its seventh record in two weeks; market was buoyed by strong corporate earnings reports (M)

headline: Tokyo to Propose Repeal Of Holding Company Ban
abstract: The governing coalition of Japan said today that it would move to repeal the nation's 50-year-old ban on holding companies, giving Japan's plan for financial deregulation its biggest boost.    Japanese corporate managers have long called for lifting the ban, which was imposed by the United States during the military occupation after World War II to break up the conglomerates that were blamed for financing the Japanese war effort.
