Holding companies, Japanese corporate interests argue, will enable businesses to enter new areas, merge with and acquire other companies more easily, and eliminate unprofitable units.

headline: Time Warner Still Trying To Shed Debt
abstract: Time Warner Inc's stock price is expected to continue languishing, despite expectations of continued strong cash flow and earnings, until firm cuts debt by unwinding Time Warner Entertainment, its joint venture with U S West Media Group; troubled cable television firm, 74.5 percent owned by Time Warner, has $5.5 billion in debt; Time Warner has been holding intermittent talks with U S West on deal (M)

headline: BankAmerica Names Head Of Consumer Banking Unit
abstract: BankAmerica Corp says Eugene Lockhart, chief executive of Mastercard International, will become president of its consumer banking division; Mastercard names Robert Selander, who had run its European operations, to replace Lockhart; BankAmerica appointment fills a hole in management team of David A Coulter, who became bank's chairman in May 1996; in October, Thomas E Peterson, head of consumer banking, announced he would retire in 1997, and Luke Helms, his deputy, quit when it became clear that Coulter would not name him to replace Peterson (L)

headline: Foreign Car Makers Seek Low End of Sport Utility Niche
abstract: Foreign auto manufacturers, after years of limited success, are staging all-out assault on sizzling US market for sport utility vehicles; at least 17 Japanese and European companies will introduce new models, in next four years, in market dominated by Chrysler, Ford and General Motors; are aiming for part of market that domestic makers do not control, namely, for small vehicles that sell for less than $20,000; surge represents clear threat to American auto makers, all of which lose money on cars while profiting on sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickups; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Thais Suspend Trading In Shares of All Banks
abstract: Stock Exchange of Thailand suspends trading in shares of all banks and finance companies after Government orders industry to increase its reserves against bad loans; suspension is expected to be lifted March 4 (S)

headline: Clinton's Loyalty Pays Dividends
abstract: News analysis of Helsinki summit meeting reports that Pres Boris Yeltsin repaid Pres Clinton's loyalty to him by minimizing Russian anger and humiliation over NATO's expansion into Eastern Europe; US officials report that Yeltsin, written off by many Russians during his illness, appears much improved since heart surgery and seemed more mentally acute in Helsinki, speaking clearly and wittily, without slurring his words (S)

headline: Shares of Schroders Rise on Bid Rumors
abstract: Shares of Shroders PLC rise 3.7 percent to record 1,750 pence amid speculation that company, Britain's largest independent investment bank, might be target of takeover bid (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.19   5.24   5.25        3-MO. headline: U. Alexis Johnson Dies at 88; Led Arms Talks With Moscow
abstract: U Alexis Johnson, career diplomat and one of shepherds of first strategic arms limitation treaty with Soviet Union, dies at age 88; photo (M)

headline: Dispute at American Airlines Draws Clinton Plea
abstract: American Airlines cancels most of its Friday night overseas flights in face of looming pilots strike; Pres Clinton urges airline and pilots' union to use mediation, holding dispute has huge implications for nation; orders his Administration to weigh potential economic dispruptions; photo (M)

headline: Payout Halts; Northeast Utilities Stock Falls
abstract: Stock of Northeast Utilities falls sharply after company announced suspension of dividends (S)

headline: Follow the Crowd?
abstract: Persons who stand out from group at work are asked to send their best humorous/distressing stories to One The Job, Money and Business, The New York Times; sketch (S)

headline: North Korean Defector's Tale Reminds Japan of a Lost Girl
abstract: North Korean defector reportedly has told Japanese intelligence services about girl who was kidnapped from Japan and taken to North Korea; girl sounds like Megumi Yokota, 13-year-old girl who vanished 19 years ago; Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto has promised to investigate, and incident has again cast spotlight on accounts that North Koreans may have kidnapped 20 or more Japanese over years, taken them back to North Korea and used them to teach terrorists how to pass themselves off as Japanese (M)

headline: Japan Stocks Calmer After A Statement
abstract: Japan's Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka seems to reassure stock market, saying that ministry will watch stock market with serious concern after stocks plunged in early morning trading, sending Nikkei index down about 3 percent; market recovers on Mitsuzuka's remarks, with Nikkei index down 25.66 to 18,093.13 (Tuesday, January 14); Japan's economic outlook for 1997 remains dim, rise in national sales tax is expected to crimp consumption, and budget tightening by Government will curb fiscal spending (M)

headline: Peru Turns A Deaf Ear To Rebels
abstract: Siege of Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima, Peru, by Tupac Amaru rebels has won virtually no sympathy from ordinary Peruvians, despite efforts of rebels to win over public opinion; siege has evoked old fears of violence among Peruvians, who are generally supporting Government; photo (M)

headline: Offshore Drilling Deals
abstract: Transocean Offshore Inc receives contracts valued at $119.8 million for deep-water drilling services using three of its semisubmersible rigs from Texaco Inc and Talisman Energy Inc (S)

headline: On Bosnia's Ethnic Fault Lines, It's Still Tense, but World Is Silent
abstract: Mostar, Bosnia, remains divided despite outside world's efforts to unify it; city, split down middle between ethnic Croats and Muslims, has always been one of country's most visible and dangerous fault lines; its current crisis exposes failure of international peacekeeping effort in Bosnia; peacekeeping force has begun silent retreat from Bosnia, frustrated by repeated refusal of Serbs, Croats and Muslims to honor Dec 1995 peace agreement; commanders say peackeeping force, 30,000 strong, will leave as planned in spring of 1998; map; photo (M)

headline: Apartment Deal For Zell's REIT
abstract: Equity Residential Properties Trust, controlled by Sam Zell, will buy Wellsford Residential Property Trust for $620 million in stock (S)

headline: JOHNSON & JOHNSON TO BUY LENS EQUIPMENT MAKER
abstract: Johnson & Johnson will acquire Innotech Inc for $123.8 million (S)

headline: Year of Intense Activity Looms for Phone Industry, Experts Say
abstract: Outlook for telecommunications industry in 1997 discussed in wake of year of historic legislation, heated suits and major mergers; experts expect deregulation will make business even more competitive; graph; photos (M)ï

headline: AMERICAN PAD AND PAPER TO BUY SHADE-ALLIED
abstract: American Pad and Paper Co to buy Shade-Allied Inc for $51.5 million, broadening its business to include paper used in inkjet printers and copying machines (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Power Company Seen In Deal for British Utility   American Electric Power of Columbus, Ohio, is expected to announce as early as today that it plans to acquire another utility, Yorkshire Electricity of Britain.    American Electric scheduled a news conference to make ''a major announcement.'' It did not disclose the details, but people in the industry said that it would announce that it had reached a deal with Yorkshire. $(Page D2.$)     Key Morgan Stanley Executive Ill   Robert G. Scott, the Morgan Stanley executive who is supervising his company's merger with Dean Witter, Discover, suffered a heart attack while on vacation. Mr. Scott's sudden illness could slow the completion of the merger just weeks after it was announced. $(D4.$)    Animals as Drug Factories   The first products to emerge from the cloning of a sheep by British researchers will probably be animals that can serve as drug factories. PPL Therapeutics, a small biotechnology company based in Edinburgh, Scotland, has the rights to technology for the production of genetically altered mammals that could produce therapeutic proteins in their milk. $(B8.$)     Technology Spreading, Study Finds   Disputing earlier conclusions that the Information Revolution is bypassing much of rural America, a new study argues that communications technology is becoming more equally distributed across the country. $(D6.$)    Raytheon May Sell Appliance Unit   Raytheon said that it might sell its appliance business, which makes Amana stoves and ovens and Speed Queen washers. $(D10.$)    House Calls by Telephone and TV   In a new approach to home health care, nurses at medical centers watch via television as equipment measures a patient's vital signs and conducts other tests. The results are transmitted to the medical center over a telephone or cable TV line. While the technique reduces the number of costly home visits, critics say it erodes the quality of care. $(A1.$)    Hard Feelings Over Beer Ads   The most contentious issue involving ads for Miller Lite used to be whether the beer is ''less filling'' or ''tastes great.'' But now Advertising Age's criticism of a new, off-center campaign, created by the Fallon McElligott agency, has led to a rift between the publication and the agency. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. $(D8.$)    Web Advertising Grows From Inside   While advertising on the World Wide Web surged in 1996, much of that spending came from technology companies advertising on the sites of other technology companies. That makes it difficult to determine the potential of the Web as an advertising vehicle. $(D5.$)    A small but growing group of Internet access companies is going beyond offering set fees for unlimited access by eliminating monthly fees entirely and aiming to make money almost exclusively from advertising. $(D7.$)     Labels on Genetic Engineering   Novartis, the biotechnology giant, is preparing to advocate that all genetically engineered crops and food products made from them be clearly labeled, a practice long demanded by opponents of genetic engineering but strongly opposed by farm and industry groups. $(B8.$)     Performing May Be Better Than Winning   The biggest winners when the music industry hands out the Grammy awards may not be the artists who win but those who perform at the ceremonies. $(D9.$)    Labor's Struggle in the South   While the leadership of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has focused new attention on the South, where labor has had relatively little support, unions there continue to face serious obstacles. $(A10.$)

headline: Stocks Plunge, Then Soar, As Dow Finishes Up 78.12
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 78.12 points, to record 6,703.79, in heavy trading; Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rises 4.65 points, to record 759.50; Nasdaq composite index rises 5.82 points, to record 1,332.02; table (M)ì

headline: Yeltsin and Netanyahu Meet and Talk Business
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu arrives in Moscow on his first official visit to Russia; he meets with Pres Boris N Yeltsin and other Russian officials; their talks focus on improving economic and political ties; photo (M)(

headline: Hard Times For Zaire: It Can't Give Cash Away
abstract: Zairians are refusing to accept new currency denomination, printed by corrupt Government of Pres Mobutu Sese Seko to pay soldiers in effort to halt armed rebellion in country's east; debacle is seen as most visible symptom of much larger crisis, namely, total failure of state Pres Mobutu Sese Seko has led as dictator for 31 years (M)

headline: S.&L. Earnings Were Brisk Last Year
abstract: Office of Thrift Supervision reports American savings and loan industry earned $4.8 billion in 1996, its fourth-best earnings year; says earnings were down 11 percent, from $5.4 billion in 1995; reports fourth-quarter profit totaled $1.5 billion, after $505 million loss in third quarter (S)

headline: For British Health System, Grim Prognosis
abstract: Doctors at St George's Hospital in London say that Government cuts have forced hospital to do away with many acute-care beds and patients have had to wait even as their conditions worsen; problems at St George's are mirrored across Britain, where cold snap and budget crisis have forced cancellation of non-emergency treatment, sent some of sickest patients on long odysseys in search of beds and wreaked havoc on system that has run on shoestring even at best of times; situation has so deteriorated that even some of system's staunchest supporters are beginning to wonder if Britain's beloved system of socialized medicine is in danger of collapse; graph (M)

headline: Prices Lower As Auction Disappoints
abstract: Treasury prices declines on credit markets following poor results of Treasury auction of 10-year notes; chart; graphs (M)

headline: Balloonist Ends 9,600-Mile Flight in India
abstract: American balloonist Steve Fossett makes rough but safe landing in northern India, breaking world records for distance and duration but failing in attempt to fly nonstop around world; thunderstorms, cold and lack of fuel blamed; flight that began in St Louis January 13, covered 9,672 miles and lasted 146 hours 54 minutes; photo; map; 52-year-old securities broker from Colorado has not decided if he will try again next year (S)

headline: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC TO RENAME ITSELF CBS
abstract: Westinghouse Electric Corp will change its name to CBS Corp after it spins off its industrial businesses later this year (S)

headline: In Resilient Tel Aviv, 'Antibodies' to Terror Act Fast
abstract: Three days after suicide bombing in cafe in Tel Aviv, Israel, life has returned to near normal; little evidence remains of trauma as Israelis seem determined to move on after battering from succession of crises and violence; photos (M)

headline: In Hebron Line of Fire: A Savage Incident Feeds Fear of Future
abstract: Arab residents of Hebron describe automatic-weapons attack on marketplace by Israeli Army Pvt Noam Friedman (M)

headline: Card Giant Announces New Job Cuts
abstract: American Express Co to eliminate 3,300 jobs, about 4.6 percent of work force, in 1997; reports fourth-quarter earnings rose 55 percent from year earlier, to $595 million; earnings excluding one-time items rose 13 percent, to $433 million; table (M)

headline: France to Look for Property Stolen From Jews in World War II
abstract: France, pursuing its belated confrontation with its collaborationist past under Nazi occupation, announces formation of committee to identify and locate property stolen from Jewish families during World War II (M)

headline: DIARY
abstract: Diary of business events of week ended Mar 9; graph; photos; drawing (M)ÿ

headline: Accounts
abstract: * AGIP, Rome, to Milano & Grey, Milan, a unit of Grey Advertising, to handle advertising for the gasoline and motor-oil marketer, which had been handled by Thompson Roma, Rome, a unit of WPP Group. Billings were estimated at more than $15 million.

headline: An Inventive Los Angeles Music Station Will Change Format, a Casualty of Radio Economics
abstract: Radio station KSCA-FM in Los Angeles never broke into top 25 in radio rankings but did develop loyal following among listeners; it will soon sign off and be reborn a day later as 11th Spanish-language station in nation's No. 2 radio market; makeover of KSCA seen as parable for changes sweeping radio business; it reflects industry's deregulation, which allows one company to control several stations in one market, as well as skyrocketing station prices and new audience demographics (M)

headline: O.A.S. Rights Panel Censures Mexico Over General's Imprisonment
abstract: Inter-American Commission on Human Rights, OAS panel, condemns Mexican Govt for jailing a general who publicly criticized armed forces; criticism leaves black mark on Mexico's human rights record; panel calls for immediate release of Brig Gen Jose Francisco Gallardo Rodriguez, 50, who has been in military prison since November 1993 (M)

headline: Book : THE LETTERS OF NANCY MITFORD & EVELYN WAUGH
abstract: LETTERS OF NANCY MITFORD & EVELYN WAUGH

headline: SWEDEN'S SPECTRA-PHYSICS ACQUIRES STAKE IN PLUS 3
abstract: Spectra-Physics AB acquires 92 percent of Plus 3 Inc, American software company, for undisclosed sum (S)

headline: SYLVAN LEARNING BUYS EUROPEAN LANGUAGE COMPANY
abstract: Sylvan Learning Systems Inc says it will buy Wall Street Institute International for $26 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: A Japanese Generation Haunted by Its Past
abstract: Article in occasional series on Omiya, Japan, focuses on town's World War II veterans; while nothing in this century has so transformed Japan as war and its aftermath, discussions of it remain virtual taboo in many families; old men are now taking their war secrets with them to grave in Omiya; men--and to lesser extent, women--who endured war years are often deeply upset that young people know so little about those wrenching times, yet they feel unable to open their hearts to those who were not there; map; photos (M)

headline: Buyout Kings Flee Disaster At Denny's
abstract: Comment on outlook for Denny's, financially ailing restaurant chain (Market Watch); graph (M)

headline: Disney, McDonald's Plan Joint Campaign
abstract: McDonald's Corp and Walt Disney Co announce series of promotional campaigns that will be first co-sponsored by companies under a 10-year cross-promotional agreement that took effect on January 1 (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Eastern Group, Alexandria, Va., to FGI Inc., Chapel Hill, N.C., as the first agency to handle advertising for the energy company. Billings have not been determined.    * Compu-Dawn Inc., Cedarhurst, L.I., to Christopher Thomas Associates, Garden City, L.I., as the first agency to handle the computer software company's account. Billings have not been determined.

headline: BEC GROUP TO BUY THE EYEWEAR MAKER BOLLE FRANCE
abstract: BEC Group says it will buy Bolle France for $60 million in cash plus warrants issued to Bolle's controlling family (S)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt     * Capstone Capital Corp., Birmingham, Ala., is selling $65 million of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2002 through Smith Barney Inc. The debentures are priced at 90.30 to yield 9 percent.

headline: Michael Manley, Ex-Premier of Jamaica, Is Dead at 72
abstract: Michael Manley, who dominated Jamaican politics for a generation and became one of most eloquent spokesmen for third-world causes, dies at 72; political career reviewed; photo (M)

headline: Giant Food Stores Goes to Gray Kirk
abstract: Giant Food Stores Inc. in Carlisle, Pa., a unit of Royal Ahold of the Netherlands, which operates the Edwards, Giant and Martins supermarket chains, has named Gray Kirk VanSant in Baltimore to handle its consolidated account, with billings estimated at $6 million to $10 million.

headline: Japan Hesitant About U.S. Antimissile Project
abstract: Clinton Administration says Japan has all but decided not to take part in costly antimissile defense project with United States to avoid offending China and overspending scare military dollars; say US will press ahead with own plans to develop anti-missile systems to protect US forces in Japan from any North Korean or Chinese attack (M)

headline: Social Security and the First Wives' Club
abstract: Comment on complex rules governing spousal Social Security benefits, especially for divorced people (M)

headline: Technology Companies' Stocks Hit by Biggest Selloff Since July
abstract: Technology stocks are swamped in heavy trading in biggest selloff since last July, when entire sector plunged on concerns about possible slowdown in business; few are able to explain decline, but some attribute it to questions about 3Com, which said on Feb 26 that it would acquire US Robotics Corp (M)

headline: U.S. Urges Russia to End Production of Nerve Gas
abstract: Clinton Administration, as it tries to persuade Senate to approve treaty banning chemical weapons, has asked Russia to stop producing lethal nerve gas that has caused concern among Republicans over whether pact can be effective (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY   AAR  Synovus Finl    TUESDAY   Core Inds  Learonal   Lubys Cafeterias  N Car Nat Gas    WEDNESDAY   Clorox  Dow Jones  Pacific Gas & Elec    THURSDAY   Family Dlr Stores   Firstar   Legg Mason   Outboard Marine   Providence Energy    FRIDAY   NONE REPORTED

headline: Sony Is Planning to Create A New York Headquarters
abstract: Sony Corp plans to make New York City into a second headquarters to better supervise its sometimes troubled American operations and keep track of fast-changing American media and technology trends; this could in time strip some power from Sony Corp of America, holding company that has been in limbo since its president, Michael P Schulhof, was ousted more than year ago; move would give Sony executives in Tokyo more control of American operations; Nobuyuki Idei, Sony's president, says new move will lessen control that Sony Corp of America exerts on Sony Pictures and Sony Music; New York headquarters will not have operations functions, just staff responsibilities like finance, law and strategic planning (M)

headline: As Credit Unions Boom, Financial Rivals Cry Foul
abstract: As the Carswell Air Force Base shrank to the vanishing point, its credit union, set up in 1956 with $35 in assets and seven members, was growing into one of the biggest financial service providers in the Dallas-Fort Worth metropolitan area.    Nearly six years ago, the announcement that Carswell was going to be shut, a victim of the end of the cold war, stunned the community and sent shock waves through the economy. But the announcement did not faze the Carswell Federal Credit Union. It simply changed its name to OmniAmerican and kept expanding.

headline: TALKS ARE IN PERIL
abstract: Two pipe bombs placed in trash bins in rundown section of Tel Aviv explode 10 minutes apart, wounding 13 people; photo; Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu says signs point to terrorists, and suggests he may suspend current negotiations with Palestinians if bombing was staged from territory they control; cuts short meeting with US mediator Dennis Ross to visit hospital; no group takes responsibility; police say devices were small and improvised; bombs were placed near former bus terminal in seedy area where thousands of foreign workers live in crowded hotels (S)

headline: Thread Maker Hits A Profit Snag
abstract: Coats Viyella PLC says its chief executive Neville Bain has resigned as company reports 42 percent fall in pretax profit last year after gains in North America failed to offset weakening European market; Coats, Britain's biggest thread maker, says 1996 pretax profit dropped to 83.3 million pounds ($133 million) from 142.6 million pounds in 1995; sales were unchanged at 2.45 billion pounds; Bain will be replaced by Michael Ost (S)

headline: LSB TO ACQUIRE OLD NORTH FOR $30 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: LSB Bancshares Inc will acquire closely held Old North State Bank for about $30 million in stock (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   Personal Income Jan.  Construction Spending Jan.

headline: Canadian Retailer Imperiled as U.S. Rivals Move In
abstract: Near collapse of T Eaton Co--the stately department store chain that filed for protection from creditors in February--has heightened fears that even Canada's most powerful companies are threatened by aggressive American retailers; sales at Eaton's 87 stores have declined about $375 million (US) over last five years, and the company has lost nearly $190 million (US) since 1988; it owes its 4,000 Canadian suppliers around $115 million (US), and banks more than $120 million (US); just as Easton's was weakening, Wal-Mart Stores Inc entered Canada, in two years grabbing dominant share of the market, and specialty retailers like Home Depot Inc have also made successful debuts in Canada (L)

headline: Esquire Editor Resigns After Story Is Pulled
abstract: Will Blyth resigns as literary editor of Esquire after the executive editor, Edward Kosner, decides against printing a story by David Leavitt; Kosner cited the story's homoerotic scenes and vulgar anatomical references (S)

headline: It's the Era of the Civilized Hostile Takeover
abstract: New respectability reigns in corporate takeover game, compared with 1980's, when acquisitions were likened to Wild West shootouts; corporate raiders no longer launch hostile takeovers with high-risk junk bonds and sell acquisitions piecemeal for quick profit; prefer instead to forge strategic alliances that will lead to growth and prosperity in increasingly competitive marketplace; even losers in current crop of takeover battles are displaying gentility unthinkable in 1980's because of more businesslike environment; photos; charts; drawing (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Informix Software Inc., Menlo Park, Calif., to Young & Rubicam San Francisco, to handle the creative, media and strategic parts of its account, previously at Hodskins Simone & Searls, Palo Alto, Calif. Billings were estimated at more than $11 million.    Supercuts Inc., San Francisco, owned by the Regis Corp., to McCann-Erickson San Francisco, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle its consolidated account, with billings estimated at $8 million to $10 million. The account had been divided between McCann San Francisco, for media, and the J. Walter Thompson San Francisco unit of WPP Group, for creative.    Ocurest Laboratories Inc., Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., to Avrett, Free & Ginsburg, New York, to handle the Ocurest Eye Drops account, previously at Carrafiello Diehl & Associates, Irvington, N.Y. Billings were estimated at $6 million.    Cramer-Krasselt, Milwaukee, was named as the first agency to handle two accounts with combined billings estimated at $5 million: Northland Cranberries Inc., Wisconsin Rapids, Wis., to handle juice products, and Alternative Living Services, Brookfield, Wis., to handle its directory services business.

headline: Prudential Fined $1 Million For Document Destruction
abstract: Federal Judge Alfred M Wolin fines Prudential Insurance Co of America $1 million after several incidents of document destruction in Prudential's long-running legal dispute over deceptive sales practices; judge's sanction comes as teams of lawyers prepare for hearing to debate fairness of proposed class-action settlement with Prudential involving 10.7 million life insurance policies sold over 13 years beginning in 1982 (M)

headline: Family in an Accord to Return $15 Million to TLC Beatrice
abstract: Family of late Reginald F Lewis, former chairman of TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc, has tentatively agreed to return some of $15 million that Lewis received from the company in 1992; special board committee at TLC Beatrice recommended payment to settle 1995 lawsuit brought on behalf of food company against Lewis family; suit sought return of $22.1 million payment that TLC Beatrice made to Lewis several months before he died of brain tumor in January 1993; lawyer representing shareholders, former executives of failed firm Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc, declines comment on proposed settlement; investors hold 22 percent stake in TLC Beatrice through company called Carlton Investments LP; former Drexel officers received their shares when Lewis acquired TLC Beatrice in 1987 through $985 million leveraged buyout; TLC Beatrice agreed not to engage in certain transactions with affiliates; Carlton said in 1994 suit that company abrogated agreement in 1992 by paying Lewis $22.1 million, which represented salary and bonuses for five-year period (L)

headline: AVON AUTHORIZES BUYBACK OF UP TO $500 MILLION
abstract: Avon Products Inc says its board has authorized repurchase of up to $500 million of Avon stock in next three to five years; company raises its dividend 7.75 percent, to 31.25 cents a share, from 29 cents (S)

headline: U.S. Bond Prices Stage a Cautious Rally
abstract: Bonds stage mild rally, as buyers emerge to take advantage of lower prices and higher yields after three days of selling in bond market; traders say investors remain cautious; tables (M)

headline: On-Line Ire Is Not Pacified By Agreement
abstract: Many America Online customers remain angry, saying refunds could hardly make up for their lost business and time; some customers are particularly irked by inadequate staffing of telephone lines America Online set up to handle refund requests; company has promised to spend $350 million to increase capacity and says problems will be resolved by June; but even some of most critical customers say they will stick with service until network logjam has been cleared (M)

headline: Auto-Parts Plant Planned
abstract: Budd Co, automotive-parts supplier, will spend $50 million to build manufacturing plant in Hopkinsville, Ky (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: INTERSTATE HOTELS CO., Pittsburgh, a hotel management company, purchased the Chicago Embassy Suites Hotel from the Chicago-based Koar-Shaw Limited Partnership for about $67 million.     MOBIL CORP., Fairfax, Va., said its Mobil Plastics Europe subsidiary was in talks to sell its stretch films business to Illinois Tool Works Inc., of Greenville, Ill., a maker of specialty tools and industrial components.

headline: CHARTWELL LEISURE TO BUILD 20 HILTON GARDEN INN HOTELS
abstract: Chartwell Leisure Inc says it will spend $200 million to build, own and operate 20 Hilton Garden Inn hotels under alliance with Hilton Hotels Corp; first Hilton Garden Inns under alliance will be built at international airport in Albuquerque, NM, and in Santa Fe, NM (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Accustaff Inc acquires Manchester Inc for undisclosed sum (S)

headline: Shares of Horizon/CMS Jump After Takeover Announcement
abstract: Shares of Horizon/CMS Healthcare Corp rise to $16.50 per share on New York Stock Exchange on February 18, or nearly 16 percent, following announcement of planned acquisition by Health-South Corp (M)

headline: Will Bad Loans Kill Japanese Banks?
abstract: Problems that plagued American banks in 1990, driving bank stocks into ground, are coming to head in Japan; index of Japanese bank shares fell 15 percent during final four days of last week, causing plunge in Nikkei stock index; current question facing banks is one of capital; Japanese bank accounting is opaque, so it is not easy to know just how bad off they will be if they wrote off all their bad loans, but general suspicion is they will be be very bad off indeed; graph on performance of Topix index of Japanese banks (M)

headline: Heroes of a new genre seek their fortunes in the kingdom of Silicon Valley.
abstract: Technology column notes that three recent novels have led their heroes deep into Silicon Valley; in each novel, the provincial, safe world the heroes must leave is a world dominated by reigning monarch familiarly known as 'Bill' who offers protection at a price: being part of Microsoft (M)

headline: In Nationalist Droves, Serbs Flock to Renew Faith With Their Orthodox Church
abstract: Serbian Orthodox emerges as ideological and spiritual bulwark of self-styled Serbian Republic in Bosnia, even as it drifts toward economic chaos and political isolation; reasserts itself after decades of repression under fascist and Communist Governments; denounces Pres Slobodan Milosevic for signing Dayton peace accord; many clerics promote in his place Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic, an indicted war criminal; photo; map (M)

headline: SMALL JETS ALTER AIRLINE ECONOMICS
abstract: Bitter dispute between American Airlines and its pilots union stems from growing use of small jets in air travel, where they are replacing turboprop planes on flights that have not usually attracted enough passengers to be served by larger jetliners; American wants to use small jets--also known as regional jets or commuter jets--in its American Eagle subsidiary as it shifts to more point-to-point service, and it insists that they be flown by nonunionized pilots; unionized pilots fear for their jobs (M)

headline: TIME WARNER ORDERS BUDGET CUTS UP TO 5%
abstract: Time Warner Inc steps up its cost-cutting efforts by ordering far-flung units to shave 3 percent to 5 percent off their budgets in next three years (S)

headline: Statoil of Norway Gets Gas Contract From Italy
abstract: Statoil, Norway's state-owned company, and four North Sea partners will sell about $13.9 billion of natural gas to ENI SpA of Italy over 25 years (S)

headline: General Instrument to Split Into 3 Public Companies
abstract: General Instrument Corp, seeking to distance itself from stumbling cable industry, announces it will split itself into three separate, publicly traded companies: Nextlevel Systems Inc, Chicago, General Semiconductor, Melville, NY and Commscope, Hickory, NC; Richard S Friedland, General Instrument's chairman and chief executive, will become Nextlevel's chief executive; shareholders of General Instrument to receive stock in each of three companies on tax-free basis, and executives say restructuring will not result in layoffs (M)

headline: Bond Prices Drop Ahead Of Jobs Data
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities decline for first time this week; price of 30-year bond is down 21/32, to 96 25/32, and yield rises to 6.75 percent from 6.70 percent on Feb 4; graph (L)

headline: Coffee and Orange Juice Rise On Fear of Brazil Dock Strike
abstract: Coffee prices surge on concern that a planned dockworkers' strike in Brazil will slow exports; orange juice prices also rise on Brazilian export concerns (M)

headline: China Asserts Taiwan's Ties To Guatemala Led to Veto
abstract: China says it vetoed United Nations resolution to send peacekeepers to Guatamela because of Guatemala's longstanding diplomatic recognition of Taiwan, which China regards as renegade province; has signaled that it might reconsider veto if Guatemala downgrades ties with Taiwan; China's rare use of veto reflects hardening of political attitudes among Chinese leaders (M)

headline: U.S. Long Shot in Albania Fails to Pay Off
abstract: Clinton Administration privately seeks ouster of Pres Sali Berisha, who first wooed United States as opposition leader promising to drag Albania out of bleak, isolated past; evolution of American ties to Berisha, from early embrace to disillusion, underscore US eagerness to nurture democrats in formerly Communist nations and limitations of policy; officials say Berisha ignored repeated pleas to improve his record and rule (M)

headline: Watching for Banks in the Parade of Financial Mergers
abstract: Stock prices of many Wall Street firms that look like takeover candidates have been bid up sharply; investors looking for good buys should broaden their search for merger targets to commercial banking; industry analysts say trend of bank mergers will continue until there are fewer than 2,000 banks, from current 9,500 banks (M)

headline: Hamas Leader May Be Spared Extradition
abstract: American and Israeli officials explore ways of avoiding extradition to Israel of Mousa Mohammad Abu Marzook, Palestinian Islamic leader imprisoned in New York for more than 19 months; seek to avoid putting him on trial in Israel and risking wave of retaliatory terror attacks (M)

headline: Chancellor to Sell Stock
abstract: Chancellor Broadcasting Co and one of its units, Chancellor Radio Broadcasting Co, plan to raise $200 million by selling two kinds of preferred stock to investors in separate, private offerings (S)

headline: Do the Winners Repeat?
abstract: Carole Gould (Funds Watch) column includes study by Sheldon Jacobs, editor of No-Load Fund Investor, on investing strategy of buying year's top-ranked diversified no-load mutual fund, holding it for year and then replacing it with next year's winner; Jacobs finds that since since 1975 strategy worked 15 times, lagged behind average fives times and tied it once (M)

headline: WISCONSIN ENERGY TO BUY ELECTRIC UTILITY IN MICHIGAN
abstract: Wisconsin Energy Corporation will acquire Eselco Inc for about $71 million; merger terms noted (S)

headline: Internet Security System to Be Tested
abstract: Mastercard International Inc, IBM and Danish bank, Danish Payment Systems, say they have tested system that is first to protect security of credit card transactions on Internet using new industry standard (S)

headline: Before Date Of New Law, Ireland Grants First Divorce
abstract: High Court in Dublin grants first divorce in modern Irish history, 14 months after voters in overwhelmingly Roman Catholic country narrowly approved constitutional change; estimated 80,000 people want divorce, and they and agency seeking to help them are concerned over need for more judges and courts to handle litigation (M)

headline: People
abstract: * Thomas L. Harrison and Michael Birkin were promoted, respectively, to president for United States operations and president for international operations at the Diversified Agency Services division of Omnicom Group, New York. They assume the duties of Peter Jones, who is retiring. Mr. Harrison had been president of the Diversified Healthcare Communications Group, New York, a part of the division, and Mr. Birkin, based in London, had been managing director for the division's European operations. John Wren continues as chairman and chief executive of the division.

headline: APARTMENT INVESTMENT AGREES TO BUY 53% STAKE IN NHP
abstract: Stock of NHP Inc soars more than 29 percent after Apartment Investment and Management Co agrees to buy 53 percent stake in the company for $138 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Ship of Dreams Goes Under in Poland
abstract: Gdansk shipyard where Lech Walesa rallied Solidarity movement and Polish workers began revolution against Communism lies deserted and bankrupt, victim of economic reality of free market; final days as full-fledged shipyard were frittered away in political bickering, with workers unprepared to accept closing and Walesa remaining aloof from situation; photo; map (Gdansk Journal) (S)

headline: AMP IS CUTTING 1,000 JOBS IN A REVAMPING
abstract: AMP Inc to cut about 1,000 jobs, or 2.2 percent of its work force, as part of restructuring plan that includes closing and consolidating plants and streamlining product lines (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.25   5.21   5.51        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.01   5.01   4.95        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.11   5.09   4.81        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.58   6.54   5.52        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.86   6.82   5.98        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.87   7.85   7.14        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   5.84   5.83   5.55          *Estimated daily average, source Telerate  **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Bond Prices Post Steep Losses on Strong Economic News
abstract: Bond prices fall sharply, ending year in which they dropped during much of first six months, recovered most of their losses and then turned down again; yield on 30-year bond rises to 6.64%, from 6.54% (M)

headline: Chrysler Reports Its Second-Best Year Ever
abstract: Chrysler Corp reports fourth-quarter 1996 net of $807 million, 22 percent below year-earlier net of 1.04 billion, but well above Wall Street predictions; net for 1996 was $3.53 billion, compared with $2.03 billion in 1995, making it company's second-best year ever (M)

headline: Auto-Seat Plants Hit by Strike
abstract: Some 500 workers strike two Johnson Controls Inc auto seat plants demanding higher wages and better benefits; Johnson says it will use replacement workers; Ford Motor Co says it will not accept seats made with nonunion labor (S)

headline: COACH U.S.A. TO ACQUIRE FOUR MOTOR COACH COMPANIES
abstract: Coach USA says it will acquire four motor coach companies with combined annual revenues of $52 million; financial terms not disclosed; companies are Gray Line of California, Powder River Transportation, Progressive Transportation and Gray Line of Montreal (S)

headline: From Pollsters in Britain, A Cry in the Wilderness
abstract: LONDON—  Something once thought essential has all but vanished from British politics.

headline: Class-action lawsuits by investors are not turning out exactly as Congress planned.
abstract: Market Place: One year after Congress altered rules under which investors can sue companies for securities fraud, world of class-action lawsuits has indeed changed--though not necessarily in the ways lawmakers intended; for while kinds of lawsuits being filed has changed a bit--investors are suing more for accounting fraud, for example--number of suits has not dropped, a finding that will disappoint supporters of the new law (L)

headline: World Bank Chief Asks Slimmer Staffs and Better Lending
abstract: World Bank's president, James D Wolfensohn, has proposed sweeping reorganization costing up to $400 million that is intended to shake up institution's vast bureaucracy and improve its performance in promoting economic development for poor nations; Wolfensohn has been goading bank's staff to become more nimble and aggressive since he took over 20 months ago (L)

headline: Connecticut Banks Merge
abstract: New England Community Bancorp said today that it had agreed to buy First Bank of West Hartford for $17 million in stock. New England, based here, had assets of $433 million as of Dec. 31, 1996. First Bank has assets of $84 million.

headline: Service Station Chain Being Sold in Britain
abstract: Grand Group PLC will sell auto service station division to Investcorp SA for $772.1 million (S)

headline: A Tale of 2 Economists: Sizing Up the Income Gap
abstract: Prof Sumner M Rosen letter on Louis Uchitelle's Feb 16 article on contrasting views of economists Paul Krugman and Lester Thurow, particularly their explanations for growth of income inequality in United States (S)

headline: Milbank, Tweed Is Accused of a Conflict
abstract: Bucyrus-Erie Co and Bucyrus International Inc, parties in Federal bankruptcy case, are arguing that prestigious New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy represented legal opponents in the case; parties, including company that emerged from bankruptcy, have moved for the court to force the firm to forfeit $1.8 million in fees; controversy is part of complex tale involving prominent financiers, vulture investing and bankruptcy of Bucyrus-Erie; Milbank, Tweed allegedly represented both the company in its bankruptcy and, in a separate matter, principal for one of company's prime financing sources and largest creditors; that executive, Mikael Salovaara, was central figure in many of Bucyrus-Erie's financial transactions, including disastrous 1988 leveraged buyout; Bucyrus International Inc is the company that emerged from bankruptcy of Bucyrus-Erie (L)

headline: Bankers Questioned In South Korean Scandal
abstract: South Korean prosecutors question former head of South Korean bank and two current executives on suspicion of having taken bribes from troubled Hanbo group in return for huge loans; executives are president of Korea Exchange Bank, Chang Myung Sun; the president of Korea Development Bank, Kim Shi Hyung, and former president of Cho Hung Bank, Lee Jong Yun; Shin Kwang Shik, president of Korea First Bank, and current president of Cho Hung Bank, Woo Chan Mok, have been charged with taking $470,000 in bribes from Chung (S)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/   Real estate investment trusts may hold up well in stock market downturns. By Larry Dignan.    MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 8/   The Edgar Lomax Company, largely overlooked by individual investors, has a new fund that focuses on, you guessed it, overlooked stocks. By Timothy Middleton.    SPENDING IT /Page 11/   If you're sued, you just might find a legal defense fund lurking in a homeowners' or other insurance policy. By Joseph B. Treaster.    VOICES /Page 14/   The perils of living paycheck to paycheck as a freelance writer. By Elayne Robertson Demby.

headline: Executive Changes At 3 Agencies
abstract: Recent promotions in advertising industry noted (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.75        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.25   5.20   5.69        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   4.97   5.01   5.03        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.05   5.08   5.00        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.49   6.58   5.64        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.75   6.84   6.02        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.80   7.88   7.22        MUNICIPAL BONDS**   5.80   5.81   5.52          *Estimated daily average, source Telerate  **Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Salomon Brothers and Telerate for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Dow Jones Will Overhaul Telerate Unit
abstract: Dow Jones & Co says it will spend $650 million over next three to four years to overhaul Dow Jones Telerate, its financial information subsidiary, which has been losing ground to more nimble and innovative competitors; financial information service revenue at Dow Jones, which includes but is not limited to Telerate, increased 1.9 percent in 1996, but on an operating basis, profitibility of unit fell by nearly 21 percent; by comparison, revenue from business publishing was up 15.7 percent and operating profit rose nearly 70 percent; over all, Dow Jones says it earned $190 million in all of 1996, up two-tenths of percent from 1995; revenue rose 8.7 percent, to $2.48 billion; company says its fourth quarter earnings were $59.64 million, down from $59.98 million in year earlier quarter; revenue rose to $671.3 million from $612.1 million (M)

headline: For Brokerage Houses, a New Class of Suitor Rides In
abstract: Many Wall Street firms are worried about threat of takeover from banking, insurance and other outside institutions; merger agreement between Dean Witter, Discover and Morgan Stanley Group kicked off wave of speculation about other potential Wall Street deals; some firms that are looking for suitors or could be acquired include Lehman Brothers, Oppenheimer & Co, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Bear, Stearns, Prudential Securities and Paine Webber; drawing (L)

headline: Expansion Control Helps Smooth Airlines' Wild Earnings Ride
abstract: Airlines' new stress on profitability over market share has helped them smooth out industry's historically wide-swinging business cycle and raise fares; industry is expected to report record 1996 profits; big new plane orders raise prospects that airlines may be again increasing capacity too much; graphs; photo (M)9

headline: Swiss to Use Gold for a Holocaust Fund
abstract: Swiss Government proposes setting up $4.7 billion fund and using interest on money to help victims of Holocaust and other calamities; under proposal, Switzerland would increase stated value of its gold reserves to correspond to current world market prices, and use difference as principal for new fund; plan represents boldest financial maneuver yet by Swiss in dispute over country's dealings with Nazi Germany in World War II (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table shows key interest rates

headline: S.E.C. Upholds Resolution Curb
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission, in 3-to-1 vote, upholds its policy that permits corporations to bar shareholder resolutions on workplace issues; decision rejects appeal of group of investors from religious orders, who had sought to overturn SEC policy on shareholder resolutions; suit involves Allied Signal's refusal to report its pay levels at its maquiladora plants in Mexico; five religious orders, cumulatively holding 34,000 Allied Signal shares, had sought the report (S)

headline: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR TO BUY AUDIO-VIDEO MAKER
abstract: National Semiconductor Corp agrees to acquire Mediamatics, a privately held maker of audio and video products for personal computers, for stock valued around $100.3 million (S)

headline: Louis Merriam, 79, A Former Executive
abstract: Louis Merriam, former civic leader in Connecticut, dies at age 79 (S)

headline: Digital Says It Was Again Profitable In 2d Quarter
abstract: Digital Equipment Corp says it regained profitability in its fiscal second quarter after posting loss of $66 million for its first quarter; says net income in second quarter was $31.9 million, compared with profits of $148.8 million in year earlier quarter; revenue in latest quarter was $3.36 billion, down 15 percent (M)

headline: Fed Eases Rules on Expansion And Product Offerings by Banks
abstract: Federal Reserve approves new rules that would make it easier for banks to offer new products and to acquire other financial institutions; new rules apply to bank holding companies regulated by Fed, which have complained for years that Federal application process is too cumbersome; action by Fed is part of broader effort to update its regulations to grant bank companies it supervises same powers enjoyed by banks outside its jurisdiction (M)

headline: HANDY & HARMAN TO BUY OLYMPIC MANUFACTURING
abstract: Handy & Harman plans to acquire Olympic Manufacturing Group Inc from investors group for $53 million (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fed Moves to Increase A Key Interest Rate  The Federal Reserve voted to raise interest rates for the first time in more than two years, firing a warning shot at an inflationary threat that remains hidden over the horizon.

headline: Consumer Prices Up 0.3%; Retail Sales Post Small Rise
abstract: Labor Department reports inflation remained under control in December '96, and that consumer prices rose total of 3.3 percent in 1996, spurred by food and energy prices; Commerce Department survey of retail sales confirms that Christmas '96 holiday season produced meager gains, with sales up only 0.6 percent in December, or 4.4 percent above year-earlier period; graphs (M)

headline: Possible Partners For Airbus Jet Project
abstract: Airbus Industrie says that Alenia SpA of Italy could take as much as 10 percent stake in its superjumbo jet project and that Saab-Scania of Sweden could take as much as 5 percent (S)

headline: Rebels in Peru Leave Door Ajar on Asylum
abstract: The leader of the rebels holding 72 hostages inside the Japanese diplomatic residence in Lima, Peru, said he had not ruled out the possibility of accepting asylum in Cuba, which has offered to receive them.    By not rejecting Cuba's offer outright, the rebel commander, Nestor Cerpa Cartolini, left the door open for the rebels to safely leave Peru and thus raised hopes that the 77-day hostage standoff could be resolved without bloodshed.

headline: Apple Expects A Big Loss For Quarter
abstract: Apple Computer Inc expects to report loss of $100 million to $150 million for its most recent quarter, a much sharper loss than analysts had expected; Apple cites weakness of demand for its Performa line of consumer-oriented Macintosh computers, and short supply of its Powerbook portable machines (M)

headline: Goodyear And Top Rival Cut Japan Tie
abstract: Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co officially closes book on big part of its past, finally acknowledging that oil pipeline, which carries offshore oil throughout California and from California to Texas, that has dragged down profit since 1983 was a mistake from the start; Goodyear announces termination of agreement under which its prime competitor, Bridgestone, had manufactured tires for Goodyear in Japan for more than 20 years; Goodyear has arranged for Sumitomo Rubber Industries Ltd of Japan, which owns Dunlop and Ohtsu brands, to make more than one million tires for Goodyear in Japan each year; Goodyear will make Dunlop tires in US; Goodyear reports fourth-quarter net loss of $408.2 million on revenue of $3.27 billion; chart (L)

headline: UNITED AUTO BUYS DEALERSHIPS IN FLORIDA AND NEW YORK
abstract: United Auto Group Inc., a publicly held automobile dealership, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire nine dealerships in Florida and the New York area for $25 million in cash, $25 million in notes and about $3 million in United Auto common stock. The dealerships, which represent the Chrysler, Infiniti, Lexus, Nissan and Toyota lines, had an estimated $430 million of revenue in 1996. United Auto, which already operates 38 franchises in 7 states, could make additional payments of $4 million or more based on the performance of the dealerships and the value of the stock issued in the transaction. Separately, United Auto, which is based in New York, forecast that its first-quarter earnings would be 17 to 21 cents a share, below the consensus estimate of 25 cents a share. Following the announcements, United Auto's shares slumped $6.625, to $24.75.

headline: Sales of Equity Mutual Funds Slowed Significantly in March
abstract: Investors have slowed their purchases of equity mutual funds this month, as warnings about overpriced stock market have coincided with market volatilty and approaching end of what is traditionally the heaviest period for tax-deferred investing; Investment Company Institute reports that stock funds took in $18.4 billion in February, revised downward from previous estimate of $19.5 billion (L)

headline: New Tools for Public Relations Firms
abstract: Public relations business has leapt to embrace World Wide Web; Web enables public relations operatives to take their messages directly to people in increasingly popular public space; thousands of companies are already putting out press releases and corporate profiles on line; one challenge is that critics of a particular company can just as easily put out derogatory information on Web, thus creating public relations nightmare; many sites on Web take aim at specific companies (M)

headline: Super Bowl marketers set a festive mood, to only mixed results.
abstract: Many of 50 national commercials aired during Super Bowl were infused with relentless celebratory tone, reflecting both consumer ebullience and record spending by marketers for commercial time during broadcast; advertisements too often created effect of watching party rather than being at one as production values distance viewers from spots instead of inviting them in; photos (M)

headline: Chief Molds Phone Giant In Bell Atlantic's Image
abstract: Senior executives of Bell Atlantic Corp will play dominant role in company resulting from merger with Nynex Corp, despite earlier pledges that $23 billion deal would be merger of equals; two senior vice chairmen, James G Cullen and Lawrence T Babbio, will run company's major lines of business in attempt to capitalize on Bell Atlantic's reputation as better-run telephone company; among top staff jobs, Nynex executives fare better, playing key roles in image making, lobbying and employee relations; intramural jockeying and its implications for telephone customers from Maine through Virginia discussed; photos (M)

headline: Uncle Sam May Offer A Reason To Sell
abstract: *Floyd Norris Market Watch column comments on possibility that, as Washington prepares for serious budget negotiations, there will emerge a deal that would give investors a brief oppotunity to sell stocks while paying an amazingly low tax bill; deal would include Republican plan to cut top rate on capital gains taxes from 28 percent to 19.8 percent, and would also include Pres Clinton's proposal to close what he sees as 'loopholes' that let people evade or reduce capital gains they owe (M)

headline: Economic Calender
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  New-Car Sales Dec.    TUESDAY  Factory Orders Nov.    WEDNESDAY  Consumer Borrowing Nov.    THURSDAY  Producer Prices Dec.  Sales of Leading Retailers Dec.  Weekly Jobless Claims    FRIDAY  Employment Dec.

headline: A Disney Import Seeks Tonic for Club Med Losses
abstract: Article on efforts of Philippe Bourguignon, new chief executive of Club Mediterranee and former head of Euro Disney, to turnaround Club Med; says in February, Club Med's shareholders, led by Agnelli family, whose primary holding company controls roughly 13 percent of Club Med shares, hired Bourguignon; notes they lost patience with Serge Trigano, Club Med's chief executive since 1993 and son of Gilbert Trigano, who helped develop concept of vacation villages in 1950's (L)

headline: Developer Is Charged in German Fraud Case
abstract: Prosecutors in Frankfurt announce fraud charges against Jurgen Schneider, real estate developer whose empire collapsed three years ago in one of Germany's biggest corporate scandals; Schneider built shopping and office complexes and then fled country before his company buckled under $3.2 billion in bad debt; prosecutors say he duped banks and creditors with fake invoices and fraudulent rental contracts to borrow money, which he transferred to secret Swiss bank account; Schneider and his wife were arrested in Miami and returned to Germany (M)

headline: WINSTAR ACQUIRES RIVAL MILLIWAVE
abstract: Winstar Communications Inc completes acquisition of its closely held rival Milliwave LP for $115 million in cash and stock, giving Winstar access to broad swath of radio spectrum nationwide (S)ÿ

headline: Guerrilla Group's Commander Joins Talks in Peru Hostage Crisis
abstract: Negotiations to end hostage crisis at Japanese Embassy residence in Lima move forward after commander of Tupac Amaru guerrillas takes part for first time in talks; observers describe talks as constructive; political analysts say Government's immediate goal is persuading rebels to release some of 72 hostages, many of whom are suffering from serious health problems; say most difficult task will be finding creative way to release some of jailed rebels while still appearing to maintain Government policy of not giving concessions to guerrilla groups (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORP., Maynard, Mass., said it had won a contract to supply the Veterans Affairs Department with computer hardware and software. The contract has a potential value of $1.5 billion over five years.     DIMON INC., Danville, Va., said it was negotiating to acquire Intabex Holdings Worldwide S.A., a leaf tobacco dealer with annual sales of about $700 million. Terms were not disclosed.     PHARMACEUTICAL PRODUCTS DEVELOPMENT INC., said its Environ International Corp. unit had acquired Technical Assessment Systems of Washington, a regulatory consulting company, in a cash and stock deal.

headline: The Oscars: Good, Bad And Totally Irrelevant
abstract: Many World Wide Web sites are devoted to Academy Awards on Oscar night (M)

headline: Lee Kuan Yew Apologizes for Remarks That Angered Malaysia
abstract: SINGAPORE—  Seeking to prevent a serious rift in relations with Malaysia, Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's senior minister, apologized "unreservedly" Thursday for remarks that brought a storm of protest from Malaysians.

headline: Belgrade Opposition Takes Control of the City Council
abstract: Serbian opposition coalition takes control of Belgrade City Council, main goal of three months of street protests against Milosevic Government; Zoran Djindjic, 44-year-old philosopher-turned-politician, is elected mayor; photo; new leaders now face task of providing services in rundown city (S)

headline: Merrill Hires Retail Head
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co hires Amy Lane to be managing director of investment group for retail industry (S)

headline: Inside Media Is Sold To Rival Mediaweek
abstract: Inside Media, biweekly magazine, is acquired by rival, Mediaweek; merger terms not disclosed (S)

headline: TRANSCANADA TO GET TWO BUSINESSES FROM ENRON
abstract: TransCanada Pipelines Ltd to buy two gas liquids businesses from Enron Corp for $150 million; says acquisition would increase its gas liquids production about 42 percent (S)

headline: PRIDE PETROLEUM TO BUY 12 RIGS FROM NOBLE DRILLING
abstract: Pride Petroleum Services Inc agrees to pay Noble Drilling Corp $265 million for 12 drilling rigs and one rig hull; Noble says it wants to sell mat-supported jackup rigs, which are used to drill oil and gas wells, as part of a plan to focus on equipment that will drill in deeper waters (S)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT PAGE 4  It's the ultimate defesive play: stocks in companies that handle funerals and related services. By Sana Siwolop.    INVESTING IT Page 4  Own bonds in the Port Authority? There's renewed talk about dismantling the agency. By James Dao.    MUTUAL FUNDS Page 8  Large-cap funds may not be keeping up with the big stock indexes for one simple reason: they're buying smaller stocks. By Juliette Fairley.    SPENDING IT Page 9  Want a quicker tax refund? You can get it, but for a price. By Shelly Freierman.    EARNING IT Page 11  Taking a complaint about the boss to the right person, in the right way. By Susan J. Wells.

headline: Data General Comeback Built on Cost-Cutting and Innovation
abstract: Data General Corp, troubled minicomputer giant, is making comeback, fueled by sales of two new machines and fanatical commitment to cost-cutting; chief executive Ronald L Skates's turnaround strategy gets credit; photo (M)

headline: This Lead Dog Still Barks, but Has a Bit Less Bite
abstract: In-depth profile of Robert L Crandall, combative chairman of American Airlines; at time when American is riding stong industry comback from huge losses of early 90's, as well as heralding big marketing alliance with British Airways, Crandall has experienced setback in deal to buy $6 billion worth of Boeing jets because of labor dispute at American; Boeing deal was contingent on approval of four-year contract by American's pilots, who rejected deal; labor problem underscores likelihood that Crandall will not be moving ahead as rapidly as he would like, either with pilots or with Boeing; in addition, dealings with pilots show Crandall has once again stubbed his toe in labor talks where his hardball positions are often criticized as counterproductive; his photo; cartoon (L)

headline: Applied Magnetics Cancels Hostile Offer for Read-Rite
abstract: Applied Magnetics Corp says it is withdrawing its unsolicited offer to buy Read-Rite Corp, larger rival supplier of disk drive components, because recent declines in Applied's shares had trimmed value of proposed stock swap from $1.76 billion to $1.06 billion (S)

headline: Pepsico to Spin Off Its Fast-Food Business
abstract: Pepsico Inc announces that it will spin off its fast-food unit, including KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell, as publicly traded company that would be second only to McDonald's in fast food market; Roger A Enrico, Pepsico chairman and chief executive, says company will spin off 100 percent of restaurant unit to stockholders, who will receive shares in new company; adds that Pepsico will not assign any of its current $9 billion of debt to new spinoff; says that before the spinoff, Pepsico will sell off its casual-dining businesses, including California Pizza Kitchen and Chevy's Mexican restaurants; in 1995, Pepsico had 28,518 restaurants worldwide, nearly twice McDonald's total of 11,368; Pepsico's systemwide sales in 1995 were $13.8 billion, compared with $15.9 billion for McDonald's; analysts note that although Pepsico's restaurants accounted for more than third of company's sales of $30.4 billion in 1995, they contributed only 22 percent to profits; Pepsico took $520 million charge in third quarter of 1996, largely to revamp international beverage business and eliminate 10 percent of its international work force (M)

headline: Biggest Hospital Operator Attracts Federal Inquiries
abstract: Special report, Health Care's Giant, on Government investigations of business practices at nation's largest health care company, Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, which runs about 350 hospitals and treats 125,000 people a day; Federal agents have raided hospitals and doctors' offices in El Paso, carting off truckloads of billing records; Health Care Financing Administration chief Bruce Vladeck reports review of 'upcoding,' in which hospitals inflate seriousness of illnesses to get higher Medicare payments; civil and criminal investigators also probe referrals by Columbia doctors to medical services in which they have interests; yearlong investigation by The New York Times finds Columbia hospitals submit more and higher bills than comparable institutions, with extra Medicare payments of nearly $50 million in Texas alone in 1995; company, less than ten years old, controls seven percent of nation's hospitals, mostly in Sunbelt; Columbia is Medicare's single largest biller, and Medicare money makes up 36 percent of company revenue; analyses of high billings by Columbia Spring View Medical Center in Kentucky and Cedars Medical Center in Miami detailed; graph; practice of encouraging doctors to invest in hospitals where they practice also probed (L)

headline: Gehe of Germany Wins Bid for British Drugstores
abstract: Gehe AG, Germany wins yearlong battle for Lloyds Chemists PLC, British pharmacy chain, after competing bidder, Unichem, decides not to counterbid; Gehe victory give it control of Britain's second-biggest pharmacy chain, adding about 924 pharmacies to Gehe's chain of 300 stores; also means Gehe will virtually match what is now largest British pharmacy chain, Boots (M)

headline: Next Wave Licenses Approved
abstract: Next Wave Telecom Inc is conditionally awarded nearly $5 billion in contested airwaves licenses it won at Federal Communications Commission auction last year; as a condition of receiving its licenses, Next Wave, a wireless communications company, must within six months reduce its foreign ownership to bring it into compliance with Federal laws that limit foreign companies from owning no more than 25 percent of a wireless license (M)

headline: Displaced Russian Has a New Faith but No Home
abstract: Aleksei I Olenin, former Soviet Army private who was captured in Afghanistan in 1982, embraced Islam and decided to remain after Soviet withdrawal, now faces uncertain future since ruling Taliban fundamentalists could chase out any remnant of Soviet occupation if they capture northern remainder of country; maps; photo (M)

headline: New York Times Company Announces a Promotion
abstract: The New York Times Co says that James C Lessersohn has been promoted to vice president for corporate planning; Lessersohn, who had been managing director for corporate planning, has worked on strategic planning and acquisitions since he joined the company in 1987; photo (S)

headline: U.S. to Auction Bills and Notes
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week comprises today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and two- and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.94 percent and the rate on the six-month issue was 5.01 percent. In when-issued trading the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.85 percent, and the five-year note at 6.16 percent.

headline: IDEXX STOCK PLUNGES $20 A SHARE ON EARNINGS OUTLOOK
abstract: Idexx Labs Inc shares drop sharply after firm says its profits for first-quarter ended Mar 31 will drop sharply from year ago and be far below analysts' expectations (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: Barrick Gold Corp names John K Carrington as director and company president (S)

headline: U.S. Appears To Ease Stance In Global Talks On Phone Deal
abstract: After months of playing hardball in global trade talks, the United States is on the verge of endorsing on Saturday a sweeping agreement that would commit most of the world to opening telecommunication markets to competition, American officials indicated tonight.    Though American officials said that a deal was not absolutely certain, they acknowledged that they were ''very close'' to reaching a final agreement. The United States has been the principal holdout for weeks now, arguing that too many countries have been hanging on to too many restrictions that benefit state-controlled telephone monopolies.

headline: ONE KEY ELEMENT IN ANTI-CUBA LAW POSTPONED AGAIN
abstract: Pres Clinton, hoping to quell anger of major US allies, will indefinitely waive portion of Helms-Burton law that punishes foreign companies for using American property confiscated in Cuba under Castro regime; says he does not want furor in Canada, Mexico and Europe to jeopardize what he describes as emerging international effort to isolate Castro's Communist Government; decision suspends for another six months provision allowing US citizens or corporations to sue foreign company that uses confiscated property; Clinton indicates he will continue suspensions as long as allies press for democratic change in Cuba; recent European Union vote for better human rights record cited; Clinton's attempt at balance brings criticism both from Repr Dan Burton and Europeans who charge US tries to impose its foreign policy on other nations (M)

headline: Disney to Sell Publications Inherited With Capital Cities
abstract: Walt Disney Co puts up for sale publishing businesses acquired in 1995 purchase of Capital Cities/ABC Inc; properties include seven newspapers, consumer publications and trade magazines; sale could fetch $2 billion to $3 billion; Disney reports net income rose 33 percent in fiscal first quarter ended Dec 31 to $749 million, up from $565 million in year-earlier period; is joining with Comcast Corp to acquire control of E! Entertainment Television for $320 million; Comcast, which already owns 10.4 percent of cable network, will raise its stake to 50.1 percent and Disney will own rest as result of purchase of Time Warner Inc's 58.4 percent stake; map; table (M)

headline: Making an Impression Even if You Don't Fit the Mold
abstract: Anecdotes from readers about feeling like outsider on job; drawings (M)ú

headline: Hyperlinks to Irish Auld Sod Update St. Patrick
abstract: Ireland and things Irish have outsized presence on World Wide Web; wide variety of Celtic-themed sites help link Ireland with vast Irish population abroad; table; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TRANS WORLD AIRLINES, St. Louis, announced that it had put a job freeze in effect, but said the plan would affect only administrative and back-office employees and not pilots or other front-line workers.     AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS CORP., Madison, N.J., said its Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories unit had agreed to pay Biomatrix Inc., Ridgefield, N.J., as much as $23 million to market and distribute its knee osteoarthritis treatment in the United States and parts of Europe and the Middle East.

headline: MAGIN ENERGY TO OFFER $58.5 MILLION FOR DISCOVERY WEST
abstract: Magin Energy Inc to acquire Discovery West Corp for some $58.5 million in cash and stock and $10.2 million in assumed debt (S)

headline: Part of Amtrak Back At DDB Needham
abstract: DDB Needham New York wins back national brand advertising part of Amtrak account, which agency lost in Apr review to Ammirati Puris Lintas (S)

headline: And One More Thing: Save This Article, Too
abstract: Advice on how long to retain tax records; key time periods are minimum of three years for all records, six years and forever (M)

headline: Economic Calender
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  None    WEDNESDAY  Housing Construction December    THURSDAY  Weekly Jobless Claims    FRIDAY  None

headline: Big Losses and Bad Accounting Leave 'Subprime' Lenders Reeling
abstract: Subprime lending, risky business of extending credit to millions of Americans with tarnished credit ratings or none at all, is reeling from sudden rash of reports of crooked accounting, bankruptcy and unexpectedly high loan losses among several of industry's prominent players; turmoil is rooted in relentless growth in number of Americans with blemishes on their credit records, making the market far too large to ignore; with everyone, from biggest banks and giant credit companies piling in, competitive pressures have exposed cracks caused by ill-conceived growth strategies, poor management of operations and outright greed and has dampened Wall Street's ardor for their shares; financial problems at Mercury Finance Co, Search Capital Group Inc, TFC Enterprise, Olympic Financial Corp and Jayhawk Acceptance Corp discussed; photo; chart; graphs (M)

headline: Putting Aside the Books But Keeping Insurance
abstract: Many college students give little thought to health insurance mainly because coverage has always been there when they needed it, provided either through their parents or through their colleges; American College Health Assn, grade group, Baltimore, estimates that 11 percent of college students have no health insurance, and experts say those covered through their schools may not realize just how little coverage they have; about third of college students are covered under their parents' plans, and slighly more buy coverage through their schools; problems students face when they leave school noted; photo; chart on coverage (M)

headline: RUBIN HINTS AT END TO LONG U.S. PUSH OF STRONG DOLLAR
abstract: Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin, taking a little air out of rapidly rising dollar, suggests that Clinton Administration has ended its two-year-long effort to drive up dollar against other major currencies, meeting with reporters; Rubin has said repeatedly that 'a strong dollar is in the interest of the United States;' now, in subtly worded change of policy, Rubin says that while a strong dollar is still in America's interest, 'we have had a strong dollar for some time now'; Rubin's comments set off torrent of activity in financial markets; graph shows rise of dollar against Japanese yen (M)

headline: How Jacksonville Put Together A Winner in Only Its Second Year
abstract: Jacksonville Jaguars will compete for berth in Super Bowl just two years after joining National Football League; Carolina Panthers, equally new to NFL, will also compete; Jaguars' early success on field can be traced to business structure that has helped team compete against more established franchises; Wayne Weaver, chairman and chief executive of Jaguars, is retailing entrepreneur; he says he applied rules he learned in the shoe business to his expansion football team; one of these, to hire smart people and give them authority and support, can be seen in his decision to have team's coach, Tom Coughlin, hire players rather than hire general manager to oversee acquisiton of players; another factor in early success of Jaguars and Panthers is NFL's rules that redistributed enough players to make new teams immediately competitive; photos (L)

headline: Country Club in Revolt Over Post-Apartheid Taxes
abstract: Residents of Sandton, wealthy suburb of Johannesburg, South Africa, are in revolt, refusing to pay 233 percent tax increase, calling it too big and too arbitrary; boycott has set off bitter debate about what whites, particularly rich ones, owe new South Africa; has created strange irony of wealthy whites using same crippling weapon of mass nonpayment against new Government that blacks used to make townships ungovernable under old guard; photo (M)

headline: Sports Illustrated Plans Women's Magazine
abstract: Sports Illustrated says it will test women's sports magazine, to be called Sports Illustrated Woman, starting in April; Sandy Bailey will edit test issues (S)

headline: U.N. Chief Calls for a Zaire Relief Force
abstract: Sec Gen Kofi Annan calls for United Nations to send international military force to help deliver relief and to extricate tens of thousands of refugees caught up in spreading warfare in eastern Zaire; says he will try to persuade Security Council to change its mind and drop its earlier hostility to idea; photo; map (M)

headline: USAIR DECLINES TO BUY BACK SHARES FROM BRITISH AIR
abstract: USAir Group refuses to exercise option to purchase British Airways PLC's 24.6 percent stake in carrier; sale of stock is step toward dissolving relationship that had soured after British Air announced alliance with American Airlines (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Timothy R. Volk, executive vice president and marketing services director at KSV Communicators, Burlington, Vt., was promoted to president, succeeding Linda Kelliher, who continues as chairwoman.

headline: Stocks can't continue marching upward, an economist says.
abstract: Economic Scene column on forecast by Dean Baker of Economic Policy Institute on future trend in stocks; says upward trend cannot be sustained; suggests that 7 percent real return enjoyed by investors over last 70 years is simply incompatible with mainstream forecasts of growth of less than 2 percent in gross domestic product over the long haul; drawing (L)

headline: Chechens Hail Today's Vote As Step Toward Sovereignty
abstract: Chechens are anxious that world, and particularly Russia, recognize republic's presidential and parliamentary elections as fair, seeing vote as first step toward independence; have invited 100 foreign observers, most from Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, and pledged to protect them; all 13 presidential candidates favor independence; map; photo (M)

headline: TRIZECHAHN TO DEVELOP 45 ACRES OF DOWNTOWN TORONTO
abstract: TrizecHahn Corporation is selected by Canadian Government to develop large area of downtown Toronto for major entertainment and retail complex (S)

headline: Interest Rate Rise Hinted By Greenspan
abstract: Alan Greenspan, chairman of Federal Reserve, hints that he will raise interest rates next week as precautionary measure to keep nation's six-year expansion on track; economy has enjoyed almost perfect combination of strong growth, low unemployment and stable prices; decision on credit rate will test Greenspan's resolve that monetary policy must anticipate inflationary pressures rather than react to them; Federal Reserve has not changed policy in nearly 14 months (M)

headline: Bull Stumbles As Dow Falls Below 7,000
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls below 7,000, to close down 92.75 points, or 1.32 percent, at 6,927.38; table (M)

headline: People Named In Fraud Case
abstract: Manhattan District Attorney charged 53 people with having paid stand-ins to take exams for stockbroker licenses; names of those charged (S)

headline: Housing Data Help to Push Bonds Lower
abstract: US Treasury prices finish lower in choppy trading; price of 30-year Treasury bond falls 14/32, to 97; bond's yield rises to 6.86 percent from 6.83 percent on March 3; graph (M)

headline: Researcher Says How C.E.O.'s Act Is Linked To Order in the Family
