abstract: Theory, based on data compiled by Frank J Sulloway, science historian and research scholar at MIT, suggest management actions undertaken by a chief executive officer are linked to order of birth in the family; believes first-born children are authoritarian, conformists, assiduously interested in preserving the status quo; adds later-borns are more adventurous and receptive to innovation; Sulloway ignited something of his own revolution last fall when he published Born to Rebel: Birth Order, Family Dynamics, and Creative Lives; birth order of chief executives Gerald M Levin (Time Warner), Louis V Gerstner (IBM), Albert J Dunlap (Sunbeam), Michael D Eisner (Disney), Linda J Wachner (Warnaco), John F Smith (General Motors), George M C Fisher (Eastman Kodak), John R Walter (AT&T) and Roger B Smith, former chief executive of GM discussed; photos (L)

headline: More Uncertain Times Ahead in the Oil Patch
abstract: Oil industry faces continuing uncertainty in 1997 after year of unexpected price swings; number of factors are combining to increase market volatility; photo (M)ï

headline: A Middle-of the-Road Ex-General in the Israeli Cabinet Is a Popular Problem-Solver
abstract: Defense Min Yitzhak Mordechai, who battled hawks in Israeli Cabinet for accord on partial Israeli withdrawal from Hebron, has emerged from tumult as Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu Government's key problem-solver and most popular member; has become Government's point man in dealing with Jewish settlers in West Bank and Gaza; has helped improve ties with Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak and plans to meet with Jordanian King Hussein; has become Clinton Administration favorite; he comments, interview; photo (M)

headline: De Beers and Russia Fail to Reach Pact
abstract: De Beers continues talks with Russia on new marketing pact for uncut diamonds (S)

headline: New Budget: A Primer For Investors
abstract: Brief review of some investment-related proposals Pres Clinton is expected to proffer in his upcoming State of the Union Message (M)

headline: USA WASTE INCREASES OFFER FOR MID-AMERICAN WASTE
abstract: USA Waste Services increases offer for Mid-American Waste Systems to $201 million from $180 million after Superior Oil Co makes competing bid for Mid-American, which is operating under bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: Coffee Prices Take Sharp Fall As Strikes End in Colombia
abstract: Coffee futures prices tumble on commodity exchanges on February 18 as end to week-old strike in Colombia ends threat of export delays (S)

headline: Report of Glut in Heating Oil Pushes Prices to 5-Month Low
abstract: Heating oil futures fall to five-month low on February 4 after report by New York Mercantile Exchange shows high February demand for deliveries in Northeast; natural gas and coffee prices also rise, while wheat prices fell (S)

headline: Matadors 1, Bulls 0 In Strike on Post-Mortems
abstract: Three-day strike by bullfighters ends in Valencia, but continues in 14 other Spanish regions (S)

headline: Stocks Climb; Dow at High Of 7,067.46
abstract: Stock market extends early-year rally on February 18; Dow Jones industrial average rose 78.50 points, to close at record 7,067.46 (M)

headline: Pharmaceuticals Giant Names New Executives
abstract: Glaxo Wellcome PLC says its chairman, Colin Corness, will retire effective May 19 and be succeeded by Richard Sykes, company's deputy chairman and chief executive; says Sean Lance will be named chief executive in 1998 (S)

headline: West Bank Strife Spreads as Israel Awaits U.S. Mediator
abstract: Palestinians rock throwers and Israeli soldiers clash for seventh day in West Bank as Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu awaits arrival of special US envoy Dennis Ross and ponders whether to bring opposition Labor Party into his Government; map; photo (M)

headline: Historic Prison Site Is a Bit Punishing to Tourists
abstract: South Afridan prison at Robben Island is now visited by tourists who line up to see small cell where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for 18 years; photo; map; local charter boat captains, who have been taking tourists on luxury cruises around island for years, are angry at Government's decision to run own ferries and keep exclusive landing rights; Government representative insists nonwhites should profit from state asset; Government's $16 tour on primitive ferry and rickety bus described (S)

headline: Italy's Consumer Prices In Moderating Trend
abstract: Istat, state statistical institute, says Italian consumer prices rose 2.6 percent in December from the similar period last year, and were up one-tenth of 1 percent since November--third straight month in which the inflation rate remained at its lowest since 1969 (S)

headline: Shares of Centennial Technologies Fall 81%
abstract: Shares of Centennial Technologies Inc fall 81 percent on New York Stock Exchange on February 18, to $3.125, after company says it will default on lending agreements and warns it may not be able to pay bills (S)

headline: South Africa's New Army Is All Soft and Cuddly
abstract: South African military allows public look at training of two battalions that are intended for international peacekeeping role; photo; map (De Brug Journal) (S)

headline: The Times Begins Printing New Editions
abstract: The New York Times begins printing regional editions in Washington, DC, and New England areas to replace 110,000 copies of early Times edition printed in New York; new editions, which will allow delivery of later news to areas, are part of Times's effort to raise circulation nationwide (S)

headline: Profits at Honda Tripled in Third Quarter
abstract: Honda Motor Co earnings more than tripled in fiscal third quarter, putting it on track for most profitable year in its 49-year history; Honda benefits from yen's weakness against dollar; group net profit jumps to 61.9 billion yen ($499.7 million) in quarter, which ended Dec 31 (S)

headline: People
abstract: Recent promotions and appointments in advertising industry noted (S)

headline: Bankruptcy Protection Sought for Sammi Units
abstract: Sammi Group files for bankruptcy protection from creditors (S)

headline: BRODERBUND PLANS TO END VENTURE WITH RANDOM HOUSE
abstract: Broderbund Software to buy out Random House's 50 percent interest in their Living Books venture, which was set up in 1994 to market interactive story-telling software (S)

headline: G.M. Sales Tumbled 14% In December
abstract: General Motors Corp reports that its sales of cars and light trucks dropped nearly 14 percent in December 1996 compared with corresponding period a year ago, even as Chrysler Corp reports sales gain; analysts say GM's sales decline underscores company's continuing problems building its restyled models and getting them to dealer lots; December sales for 15 auto makers that announce their sales dropped 7.9 percent, to 746,359 units, compared with same period a year ago; strong sales pushed Chrysler to annual sales record of 2.45 million cars and light trucks (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Consumer Spending Brisk, Raising Fears on Rates  Americans shopped at a brisk pace last month after a surprisingly strong 1.5 percent surge in retail sales in January, Commerce Department figures showed, making it more likely that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates in the near future and sending tremors through Wall Street.

headline: Poland's Top Commander Resists Terms for NATO
abstract: Deputy Defense Min Andrzej Karkoszka acknowledges that as Poland tries to convince US that it meets one of conditions for joining NATO--having its military under civilian control--Poland's top commander, Gen Tadeusz Wilecki, is resisting reduction in his authority (M)

headline: EUROPEAN AIRLINES TO BROADEN ALLIANCE WITH DELTA
abstract: Swissair AG says it and its European partners, Sabena SA and Austrian Airlines, have agreed to deepen their pact with Delta Air Lines Inc with the intention of increasing their share of the trans-Atlantic market (S)

headline: Contract No. 2 at American: Less Reason to Fight
abstract: Analysis: dispute between American Airlines and its pilots has been as much about politics and perceptions of victory as anything else; viewed through that prism, recently announced tentative deal has good chance of winning approval (M)

headline: Cloning Breeds Loathing and Fascination : The Trouble With Dolly
abstract: From physicians to theologians to politicians to ethicists, the world reacted with brooding and soul-searching Thursday to the advent of Dolly, the cloned sheep from Scotland.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Control of Helmsley Empire Expected to Be Contested  With the death of Harry B. Helmsley, his wife, Leona Helmsley, may quickly lose control of Helmsley-Spear, the company at the center of a real estate empire that reaps an estimated $60 million a year in fees managing more than 30 million square feet of office buildings.

headline: Toyota Repurchases 5.7 Million More Shares
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp reports buying back 5.7 million of its shares for 18.10 billion yen ($149.9 million) in last month; plans to buy back up to 100 billion yen worth of shares (S)ï

headline: Mexico Stages Manhunt for Its Top Ex-Prosecutor, Suspected in Body-Planting Conspiracy
abstract: Mexican police hunt for Pablo Chapa Bezanilla, who until December was Mexico's highest prosecutor; his zealous investigations led to imprisonment on murder charges of Raul Salinas de Gortari, brother of former Pres Carlos Salinas de Gortari; Chapa is accused of taking part in conspiracy to plant body on ranch belonging to Raul Salinas to frame him in assassination that Chapa was investigating; this and recent arrest of director of Mexico's federal drug agency deepen quandary for American officials over whom to trust in Mexican law enforcement (M)

headline: 2 Top Hong Kong Officials Fault China's New Policies
abstract: Hong Kong's Chief Sec Anson C Chan and Financial Sec Donald Tsang have begun to speak out against Chinese interference in territory's affairs, as China moves to revoke range of laws protecting civil liberties there (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ahmanson Sweetens Bid For Great Western Financial  H. F. Ahmanson & Company, battling to acquire Great Western Financial, a rival California savings and loan, sweetened its all-stock hostile bid for the company, to $6.6 billion, or about $50 a share.    The value of the revised deal would change with the price of Ahmanson stock, but it appears to top the friendly $6.25 billion offer that Great Western accepted on March 6 from Washington Mutual. $(Page D6.$)    Dow Rises as Nasdaq Falls  Blue chips staged a late rebound, with the Dow Jones industrials closing up 20.02 points at 6,955.48. But losers exceeded winners by almost 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, and the technology-heavy Nasdaq index lost 13.54 points, closing at 1,279.43. $(D10.$)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/   Stocks may be getting pricey. But gold is the lowest it's been in years, making it an inflation hedge worth considering. By Marcia Vickers.    MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 9/   Current disclosure rules make it hard for investors to know when money market funds are buying dubious securities like those of Mercury Finance. By Virginia Munger Kahn.    SPENDING IT /Page 10/   Smart consumers often buy cars with some miles on them. Now the concept is catching on with computers. A look at buying ''pre-owned'' machines. By Laurie J. Flynn.    EARNING IT /Page 11/   A funny thing happened on the way to b-school. Seriously, folks. By Martha Nolan McKenzie.

headline: Correction
abstract: Mutual fund tables on Dec 29 included erroneous ratings from Morningstar Inc for many funds (S)

headline: Bank of New York Is Denied Bid To Double Its State Street Stake
abstract: Massachusetts bank regulators deny application by Bank of New York Co to double its stake in State Street Boston Corp to 9.9 percent, plan that has been widely regarded as step leading to a takeover (S)

headline: By one key monetary measure, Fox could push past both CBS and ABC this fall.
abstract: Fox network defies long odds to establish itself as viable fourth broadcast network, and it is now positioned to push past both CBS and ABC as network most likely to make inroads on dominant financial position held by NBC; its strength is with group most sought by advertisers--viewers 18 to 49 years old, which could affect many millions of dollars in advertising commitments for fall season; even critics of Fox acknowledge that Rupert Murdoch's willingness to spend whatever it took has been chief reason Fox first survived and then thrived; Fox's success is also the result of exceptional timing and highly favorable regulatory environment; drawing (M)

headline: New Leader In Ecuador Is Known For Agility
abstract: Fabian Alarcon, named by Ecuador's Congress as interim president, is consumate deal-maker known for his political agility and not identified with clear-cut policies; he succeeds Pres Abdala Bucaram, ousted for mental incompetence after alienating nation with economic austerity measures (M)

headline: THERAGENICS IN MARKETING DEAL WITH JOHNSON & JOHNSON
abstract: The stock of the Theragenics Corporation jumped 40 percent yesterday after the company said it would give Johnson & Johnson the worldwide rights to market its Theraseed product for treating prostate cancer. Under the agreement, Theragenics, which is based in Norcross, Ga., will continue to manufacture and distribute the device, and Johnson & Johnson, of New Brunswick, N.J., will invest $5 million in Theragenics. Theragenics said the agreement is for seven years, with three-year extensions contingent on certain performance criteria. Theraseed is an implant that releases doses of radiation to destroy tumors. The device has been used in the United States since 1987. Theragenics' stock was up $7.375, at $25.50, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: MARRIOTT INTERNATIONAL UNIT SELLING 29 PROPERTIES
abstract: Marriott International Inc subsidiary will sell 29 of its residential communities for elderly to Host Marriott Corp in deal valued at about $540 million (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: *  Barrielle Sales Corp., Great Neck, L.I., to Vogt/Wein, Westport, Conn., to handle advertising for its nail and personal-care products, which had been handled by Barrielle. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

headline: Wal-Mart Canada Is Putting Cuban Pajamas Back on Shelf
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores' Canada unit, caught in no-win position of violating American or Canadian law, says it has decided to resume sales of pajamas made in Cuba, in direct defiance of American laws that seek to isolate Government of Fidel Castro; Wal-Mart says its Canadian subsidiary deliberately defied instructions from headquarters to obey American law and cease all trade in Cuban goods; Treasury Department, which is charged with enforcing American embargo against Cuba, says it is 'reviewing' Wal-Mart's action and declares that 'we will enforce the embargo' (L)

headline: Staples Deal May Face F.T.C. Challenge
abstract: Federal Trade Commission is considering challenge to Staples Inc's planned $3.4 billion acquisition of Office Depot Inc unless the companies can convince antitrust officials that merger will not cause consumer prices to rise (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY   Agree Realty  Synovus Finl    TUESDAY   Household Intl  Nicor

headline: Veba of Germany to Trade on Big Board
abstract: New York Stock Exchange announces listing of German electric utility, Veba AG (S)

headline: Do Checks Need 3 Days To Clear?
abstract: Federal Reserve has asked Congress to amend 1987 law and allow banks three business days rather than two to clear local checks, as way to curb check fraud; consumer advocates oppose change, saying banks already have ability to clear checks electronically in one day, and that by holding on to money longer, banks will make millions of dollars in extra interest and consumers will bounce more checks (M)

headline: Pepsi-Cola Tops Super Bowl Ad Poll
abstract: Survey conducted after Super Bowl XXXI shows that Pepsi-Cola was the most-recalled advertiser by viewers of the game (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.25   5.22   5.16        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.05   5.07   4.86        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.16   5.19   4.98        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.34   3.37   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.53   6.61   6.40        30-YR. TREAS. headline: Biggest Danish Bank In Swedish Expansion
abstract: Den Danske Bank buys 76.9 percent stake in Oestgoeta Enskilda for 2.2 billion kronor ($286 million) from Lundbergs; will bid 50.5 kronor a share for remaining Oestgoeta shares (S)

headline: Bidders on Gulf of Mexico Oil Ready to Let Good Times Roll
abstract: More than 1,000 people crowded ballroom of Hyatt Regency in New Orleans, La, on March 5 and put in bids totaling $1.24 billion, highest amount in 12 years, for rights to explore for oil and gas in Gulf of Mexico; winning bids totaled $824 millin, up 58 percent, from $520 million, last year; high bids reflect growing excitement in deep waters in Gulf of Mexico, as well as firm prices and strong demand for oil (L)

headline: Stock Prices Move Down On Rate Rise
abstract: Stock prices declined on New York Stock Exchange on March 25 following decision by Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates; Dow Jones industrial average lost 29.08 points, to close at 6,876.17 (M)

headline: World Helps to Rebuild Bosnia, but Work Is Slow
abstract: World Bank and European Union say efforts to rebuild Bosnia have gone as well as can be expected, year after US and other donors pledged nearly $2 billion in aid, although much of country remains in tatters; say considerable progress has been made in developing programs to repair infrastructure, and that decimated economy is twitching back to life; acknowledge progress has only partly filtered through to most Bosnians, especially those forced from homes and those who have no houses or jobs to return to (M)

headline: Pohang Steel to Buy Businesses From Sammi
abstract: Pohang Iron and Steel Co agrees to buy businesses from debt-ridden Sammi Steel Co for 719.4 billion won ($827 million) (S)

headline: A Very Important Korean Playing Hide-and-Seek
abstract: High-ranking North Korean defector Hwang Jang Yop reportedly has arrived in Philippines, from Beijing, where he took refuge in South Korean Embassy six weeks ago, but whereabouts remain mystery; may be staying at mountain resort city of Baguio, 155 miles north of Manila; map (M)

headline: P.G.&E. to Buy Valero Energy, A Marketer Of Natural Gas
abstract: P.G.&E. Corp, seeking to strengthen itself as nation's largest utility, announces that it will acquire most of Valero Energy Corp for $722.5 million in stock; P.G.&E. will acquire Valero Natural Gas unit of Valero Energy, but Valero will spin off its other major subsidiary, Valero Refining and Marketing Company, before deal; Valero Natural Gas operates a 7,500-mile gas pipeline system and eight natural gas processing plants; but real prize for P.G.&E. is group created by Valero that markets natural gas and electricity around country (M)

headline: Does More Time on Line Mean Reduced TV Time?
abstract: America Online contends that homes that subscribe to its on-line service watch 15 percent less television than average home; cites study by Nielsen Media Research; at least one network television research executive questions results of survey, based on relatively small sample size--262 homes; in fact, Nielsen study, which America Online commissioned, did not draw direct correlation between on-line use and declines in television viewing; Paul Lindstrom, vice president with Nielsen, says question of what caused apparent discrepancy in television viewing time does not matter; says what was significant was that on-line services give advertisers another way to reach homes with viewers who are tougher for television to reach (M)

headline: Italian Port Is 'Tired of Seeing These Albanians'
abstract: Albanians who make their way across Adriatic to Brindisi, Italy, face uncertain reception; Italian authorities, struggling to keep up with sudden emergency, are dispersing new arrivals to ad-hoc processing centers set up in other parts of country; about 8,000 Albanians have immigrated to Italy since violence began in small Balkan country; photo (M)

headline: U.N. Report Warns of Problems Over Dwindling Water Supplies
abstract: Report, prepared for UN Commission on Sustainable Development, warns water shortages in next century are likely to restrain economic and social development and be source of potential conflict between countries (M)

headline: SUMMIT TECHNOLOGY TO RID ITSELF OF VISION CENTERS
abstract: Summit Technology Inc says it will sell or spin off its money-losing Summit Vision Centers (S)

headline: Canadians Compete for a Merger and Gold
abstract: Fierce struggle for control of Bre-X Minerals Ltd's huge Busang gold project in Indonesia, one of world's richest gold deposits, intensifies as Placer Dome Inc, Canadian mining company, offers proposal to merge with Bre-X, competing with recent proposal by Barrick Gold Ltd to merge with Bre-X, obtaining control over 67.5 percent of project (M)

headline: 2 of Mobutu's Rivals Draw Closer to a Fight to Rule Zaire
abstract: Pres Mobutu Sese Seko is expected to return to Zaire on March 21 after spending most of last several months in France for cancer treatment; Mobutu's Government is taking its last gasps of power; opposition leader Etienne Tshisekedi and rebel leader Laurent Kabila are expected to vie for power; photo (M)

headline: EAGLE FINANCIAL IN STOCK DEAL FOR MIDCONN BANK
abstract: Eagle Financial Corp to buy Midconn Bank for about $49 million in stock (S)

headline: Casino Giants Roll, but It's No Sure Thing for the Others
abstract: Casino gambling industry faces highly competitive year in 1997 after ups and steep downs of 1996; analysts see industry giants continuing to prosper; photos (M)ÿ

headline: Jose Domecq, 82, 'The Nose' Of Spanish Clan's Sherries
abstract: Jose Ignacio Domecq Gonzalez, renowned as El Nariz (The Nose) for his ability to sniff out the nuances in the creation of his clan's highly regarded sherries, dies at age of 82; photo (M)

headline: A Warm Day in the Country, Shattered by Gunfire, Blood and Horror
abstract: Israeli children and teachers recall scene of sudden horror on sunny day, as Jordanian border guard opened fire on group of schoolgirls visiting Jordan Valley on class trip; seven girls were killed; photo of grieving survivors on return to Beit Shemesh (S)

headline: Frito-Lay Puts Account in Review
abstract: Frito-Lay Co puts advertising account of its Doritos snack chips in review; account has been handled by BBDO New York (S)

headline: How Schwab Builds One Fund From Many
abstract: Cynthia Liu, portfolio manager at Charles Schwab & Co, describes how she selects the funds included in the company's funds of funds; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Loses 15.49 Points; Nasdaq Index Is Off 5.19   Stock prices declined, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing down 15.49 points, at 6,804.79, depressed in large measure by three stocks: Eastman Kodak, Philip Morris and I.B.M. For the week, the Dow lost nearly 2 percent.

headline: LAIDLAW TO RECORD $550 MILLION GAIN IN 2D QUARTER
abstract: Laidlaw Inc will record second-quarter gain of $550 million because of sale of its Canadian and US trash-handling operations to Allied Waste Industries for $1.6 billion (S)

headline: German Media Giant Struggles to Revive Digital TV Venture
abstract: Kirch Group has invested more than $1 billion over last year to start Germany's first digital television service, DF-1, which offers broad selection of pay-per-view movies and other services by satellite; service has attracted only 30,000 subscribers, fraction of the 200,000 that company hoped to capture, and Kirch lost important partner when Rupert Murdoch decided not to exercise option to acquire 49 percent of DF-1; Kirch must now scramble to line up money and partners he needs to prevent his adventure in digital television from unraveling (M)

headline: 2 Cable Networks To Adjust Accounts
abstract: Showtime and Sci-Fi Channel announce advertising decisions for their accounts (S)

headline: Swedish Plan to Sell Bank Stake Is Reported
abstract: Swedish Government is reported to be considering selling quarter of Nordbanken AB to Investor AB, a Swedish holding company controlled by Wallenberg family; move would precede linkup between Nordbanken and Skandinaviska-Enskilda Banken AB, in which Wallenberg family already has 15 percent stake (S)

headline: Pact for Peru Hostage Crisis Is Said to Be on the Table
abstract: Mediators between Peruvian Govt and leftist rebels holding scores of hostages outline tentative agreement to end standoff, by which rebels would give up their captives and leave Peru in exchange for chance at early parole for some of their jailed comrades; diplomat says that two sides have not completely agreed to all the points but that mediators believe agreement could serve as bridge for peaceful way out of crisis, which is nearing its 100th day; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Kollmorgen Corp to merge its Macbeth color instruments business with Gretag AG's color control systems unit in joint venture to be taken public on Swiss stock exchange; new company will be called Gretag Macbeth Holdings AG (S)

headline: ROCKWELL INTERNATIONAL CORP. (ROK,N)
abstract: Rockwell International Corp says its net income in fiscal first quarter fell to $179 million from $192 million year earlier before its divestiture; says operating results in latest quarter were up 18 percent because of strong sales in electronics systems division; first-quarter revenue increased 8 percent, to $2.6 billion (S)

headline: Critics Doubt Nextwave's Leap of Faith in Wireless Market
abstract: Nextwave Telecom Inc has been granted 63 Government licenses to offer new type of wireless telephone service, called personal communications services; industry analysts wonder how company will be able to pay the $4.2 billion for the coveted licenses, let alone realize its dream of building a nationwide PCS network to take on AT&T Corp and Sprint Corp; Nextwave's chairman ad chief executive, Allen B Salmasi, says company will raise $650 million in public and private financings; but Nextwave has already delayed one stock offering for several months; if Nextwave defaults on its license payments, FCC would reclaim licenses and sell them again; industry executives say this could delay or even preclude emergence of new competitor in wireless telephone business; three small companies have already defaulted on their payments and lost total of 19 licenses (M)

headline: Insecure or Jobless, Europeans Renew Protests
abstract: Worker unrest is resuming in much of Europe, sparking demonstrations against job and social-welfare spending cuts; protests come as governments struggle to cut budget deficits in preparation for currency union; workers are pressing politicians to concentrate more on social and political side of European integration and less on fiscal austerity (M)

headline: Before Bullfight Season, Matadors' Strike Looms
abstract: Spain braces for bullfighters' strike on eve of main season, after negotiations between Government and bullfighting industry break down; at issue are Government rules to prevent shaving down of bulls' horns, which makes animals easier prey for matadors (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   9.00        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.13   5.07   5.13        3-MO. headline: AMP TO TAKE 4TH-QUARTER CHARGES OF $195 MILLION
abstract: AMP Inc, a leading maker of electrical connectors, says it will take fourth-quarter charges of $195 million, primarily for revamping plan that was approved earlier by its board (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Weatherby Health Care shifts advertising accounts from ih-house to McKay Fried & Partners (S)

headline: Nenad Dusan Popovic, 87, Aide To Tito Who Defected to West
abstract: Nenad Dusan Popovic, leading economic expert in Tito's Communist Yugoslavia who defected in 1961 to teach and write in exile at Syracuse University, died on Feb 25 at age 87 (M)è

headline: Yeltsin Pledges Housecleaning and Reform
abstract: Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin emerges after months of illness to give state-of-the-nation address; promises to clean house in his administration and speed up free-market reforms; tone suggests that Anatoly B Chubais will soon rejoin Cabinet with mandate to improve management of economy; Yeltsin insists he is back in charge, fiercely castigates administration and Parliament for inaction and ineptitude during his illness and promises y bold measures; speech is viewed as inaugural address he was too ill to give last summer; economic desperation is illustrated just after speech, as 60-year-old man sets himself afire in Red Square; he is hospitalized with severe burns (M)

headline: U.S. Machine Tool Orders Fell in November
abstract: Association for Manufacturing Technology and American Machine Tool Distributors' Assn report United States manufacturers decreased orders for machine tools in November by 22.8 percent, to estimated $647.0 million (S)

headline: The puzzle of making the Internet into a competitive broadcast medium.
abstract: Denise Caruso article questions value of adding digital video windows to World Wide Web sites; discusses Progressive Networks Inc's plan to offer product that delivers video and other media to computers via Internet in transmission stream that approximates instant playback (M)

headline: Peru Rebels Abandon Talks, Saying Police Are Plotting Assault
abstract: Marxist rebels holding 72 hostages at Japanese Ambassador's house in Lima say they are abandoning negotiations to end crisis because they believe Peruvian police are digging tunnel beneath residence as prelude to military assault (S)

headline: INLAND STEEL INDUSTRIES TO DISMISS 450 WORKERS
abstract: Inland Steel Industries says it is dismissing 450 salaried workers, or 2.9 percent of its work force, after reporting lower fourth-quarter earnings; company says fourth-quarter profit from operations fell 28 percent, to $17.9 million; company takes charge of $17.1 million to dismiss workers (S)

headline: Why Wall Street Bonuses Were So Big
abstract: In 1996, even the dullards in the financial markets found it easy to make money. Blue-chip stocks soared despite an up-and-down year in the bond market. Driven by the bullish stock market. Wall Street chalked up huge profits issuing a record-shattering $193 billion in new stocks and bonds. Most Markets around the world shared in the bounty.

headline: Rheinmetall Buys Stake In Kolbenschmidt
abstract: Rheinmetall AG buys minority stake in Kolbenschmidt AG for undisclosed price and is seeking control of auto parts maker (S)

headline: At End of a Miner's Rainbow, A Cloud of Confusion Lingers
abstract: Investors and others are examining mysteries surrounding Bre-X Minerals Ltd, small Canadian company that reported discovery of greatest gold strike in history, in jungles of Indonesia, only to have claims deflated, special report, Gold or Glitter?; mysteries have deepened following sudden death of Michjael T de Guzman, Filipino prospector and partner in venture, who plummeted from helicopter while en route to meeting with prospective partner to explain why new tests had shown hardly trace of 200 million ounces of gold he and Bre-X reportedly found in Busang area of Indonesia; even though Bre-X never made penny of profit from venture and financed operations solely from sale of stock, it attracted hordes of investors; company is currently struggling to retain credibility; its stock, which soared after disclosure of find, plummeted more than $3 billion on March 27, after drilling samples failed to show deposits; photos; map (L)

headline: Personnel Changes At 3 Agencies
abstract: Personnel changes are announced at three ad agencies: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications, Trone Advertising and Harris Drury Cohen (S)

headline: Though Global Flight Falters, Balloonist Still Sets a Record
abstract: Balloonist Steve Fossett reaches India in effort to circumnavigate globe in hot-air balloon; is preparing to end flight because of low fuel supply; will still set record as longest ballon trip in history; map (M)

headline: The distinction between copies and originals is becoming meaningless on the Web.
abstract: Technology column on Internet as vast network of copies, held together by copying; one value of Web may be not in receiving a unique or private object, but in receiving a reproducible and public one; if Web lives up to economic expectations and does not collapse into libertarian chaos, it will partly be because of its replicative powers, not despite them; drawing (M)

headline: HARRIS AND GE POWER SYSTEMS FORM VENTURE
abstract: GE Power Systems and Harris Corp form venture, GE Harris Energy Systems, to provide energy management systems and services to utilities and industrial customers (S)

headline: U.S. Robotics Ships Modems
abstract: US Robotics Corp says it has begun shipping new high-speed modems that allow customers to retrieve information from computer networks and Internet at nearly double the speed of current modems (S)

headline: Biotechnology: Ways to Rein in the Risks
abstract: Strategies for reducing risks of investing in volatile biotechnology stocks discussed; many of companies in field have limited capital and expect years of research and operating losses; graph; photo (M)

headline: Cable Operators Losing Ground To Programmers
abstract: Rise of satellite broadcasting services as alternative to cable television is giving even small programmers new clout in lobbying to be carried by major cable operators; power balance has tilted even more decisively toward established networks, which can now put through hefty annual rate increases with impunity; cable operators like Time Warner and Tele-Communications Inc continue to wield enormous power over start-up networks (M)

headline: Israeli Wounds 6 Arabs in Hebron Rampage
abstract: Israeli soldier with history of mental problems opens fire on crowded Palestinian market in Hebron, wounding six Arabs and delaying completion of agreement on transfer of power in area to Palestinians; is identified as 22-year-old Pvt Noam Friedman, characterized as lonely and troubled person who was expelled from religious institute because of psychiatric problems and whose Army enlistment was postponed because of them; he is disarmed by Israeli soldiers and taken into custody; says Palestinians are haters of Israel; Israeli and Palestinian leaders vow to press peace efforts despite violence; Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu expresses regret for 'criminal act' in telephone call to Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, who warns Palestinians against retaliatory violence; shooting in marketplace described; photos (M)

headline: Coffee Prices Take Sharp Fall As a Strike in Colombia Ends
abstract: Coffee prices tumble after dock workers in Colombia end 10-day strike, allowing thousands of bags of coffee to flow into world market (M)

headline: Zimbabwean Tribal Elders Air a Chief Complaint
abstract: Installation of female chief, Sinqobile Mabhena, by one Ndebele tribe village, has caused furor in Zimbabwe, where chiefs dispense law and traditional beliefs in equal doses; her nomination to succeed father was opposed by other chiefs, who hold woman can not be war leader; map; photo (M)

headline: Russia Accepts Eastward Growth Of NATO, but Only Inch by Inch
abstract: Russia embarks on new tactic regarding eastward expansion of NATO, having concluded that expansion is virtually inevitable, and will seek to make process as diplomatically painful as possible for West; goal is to persuade alliance to drop idea of expansion after admission of Poland, Czech Republic, Slovakia and Hungary, and even those nations would be accorded second-class NATO status under current Russian plan (M)

headline: 4 Are Killed in a Suicide Bombing in Tel Aviv
abstract: Blast touched off by suicide bomber rips through crowded Tel Aviv cafe, killing bomber and three other people, wounding dozens and striking new blow at tottering Israeli-Palestinian peace; bomber is is not identified, but there are unconfirmed reports he is Palestinian from near Hebron; bombing breaks yearlong lull in suicide attacks; Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu puts blame for bombing squarely on Yasir Arafat and his Palestinian Authority; Arafat spokesman rejects charge; photos (L)

headline: H.I.P. Unit Decides To Review Agencies
abstract: Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York places advertising account of its consolidated insurance plans into review; account had been divided among several agencies on regional basis (S)

headline: Treasuries Dip As Durables Top Estimates
abstract: Prices of Government securities decline in response to unexpectedly strong manufacturing report and weight of fresh supply of Treasury debt (M)

headline: U.S. Banks' Earnings in 1996 Highest Ever
abstract: FDIC reports that commercial banks earned $52.4 billion in 1996, highest level ever, and 7.5 percent over 1995's $48.7 billion (S)

headline: CRESCENT REAL ESTATE TO ADD TRAMMELL CROW CENTER
abstract: The Crescent Real Estate Equities Company agreed yesterday to buy the 50-story Trammell Crow Center office building in Dallas for $162 million in cash. Crescent, based in Fort Worth, said it would buy the building and its mortgage from two pension funds, the California Public Employees Retirement System and the Teacher Retirement System of Texas. The 1.13 million square-foot building is 80 percent leased. Its rents average $21 a square foot, compared with the more than $30 a square foot average rent at Crescent Office Towers, a building Crescent owns in Dallas, the company said. This gives Crescent the potential of raising rents at the Crow property. Crescent is controlled by the billionaire investor Richard E. Rainwater.

headline: CPC TO SPIN OFF ITS CORN-REFINING OPERATIONS
abstract: CPC International Inc will spin off its corn-refining business and focus on its food brands; terms of spinoff to shareholders are not disclosed (S)

headline: Rebel Albania Port Prepares to Repel Government Attack
abstract: Rebel leaders in Vlore, Albania, begin organizing for battle against Government; Pres Sali Berisha's last remaining southern outpost, Gjirokaster, falls to local residents who storm army base and seize weapons; rebels across south ignore 48-hour amnesty period, as does Berisha's forces; map; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             Feb. 21   Feb. 14   Feb. 23          1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   7.3   7.3   7.4       Distillate production, daily   3.2   3.2   3.2       Gasoline stocks   203.1   206.3   210.4       Distillate stocks   106.1   107.7   103.0       Crude imports, daily   7.3   7.4   6.1       Product imports, daily   1.7   1.9   1.6       Crude stocks   305.4   304.9   300.2       Crude production, daily   6.4   6.4   6.5       Refinery utilization (%)   88.8   88.3   88.9          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: Fastening Your Seat Belt For a Bumpy Marriage
abstract: Question and answer about difference between prenuptial and postnuptial agreements; photo (M)

headline: Securities Gains Help Lift Bankers Trust Net
abstract: Bankers Trust New York Corp says its earnings rose 17 percent in fourth quarter, to $147 million; says net income for all of 1996 more than doubled, to $612 million (S)

headline: Rights Group Buys Air Time on 'Ellen'
abstract: Human Rights Campaign, homosexual rights organization, purchases time on stations affiliated with ABC-TV to run commercial during the April 30 episode of sitcom Ellen, when title character will disclose she is lesbian (S)

headline: With Mexican Food Tamed, Big Business Looks Abroad
abstract: Pillsbury Inc, through use of high-technology tools, some key acquisitions and lot of marketing talent, has taken just few years to become world's biggest maker of Mexican-style foods, such as tacaos, tortillas and salsa; because of high profits in this $1.6 billion food market and intense competition, Pillsbury and other food giants such as Campbell Soup Co, Nestle SA, Pepsico and Kraft Foods, are taking aim at mainstream American palate; these companies are reaching out with new sauces and other products; in boldest move yet, food giants, armed with their homogenized recipes, have started to popularize 'Mexican' cuisine around the world with what one industry spotter has dubbed 'Gringo food'; photo at test kitchen at Pillsbury; chart on market for Mexican-style food (L)

headline: On the Books, More Fact and Less Fiction
abstract: Recent report from Goldman, Sachs finds that with sharp decline in corporate write-offs, income reports public now sees tell more accurate story about companies' operations; says balance sheets 'are cleanest that they have been in most investors' professional lives'; one major reason company reports are getting cleaner is Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB), which has made great strides in tightening rules that corporations must obey to earn clean opinion from their auditors; investors, however, are cautioned that that handful of accounting gimmicks persist and they can seriously distort company's value; chart (M)

headline: Two Million Patent Filings To Be Made Available Free
abstract: International Business Machines Corp (IBM), in bid to showcase its own technical prowess and make Internet more useful, to announce that it will make the contents of more than two million United States patent filings dating back to 1871 available to general public free on World Wide Web; people with access to Internet will be able to use site to search patents by various categories, including subject, inventor and key words (M)

headline: U.S. Treasury and Other Debt Planned for Auction This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.05 percent and that on a six-month bill was 5.16 percent.

headline: The Tiny Surprises of Large-Company Funds
abstract: Some big-cap stock funds are not keeping up with market benchmarks because they have invested sizable portion of assets in stocks of smaller companies; this has hampered their performance in bull market of last few years, when blue chips have been all the rage (M)

headline: DIARY
abstract: Photo of a deserted Wall Street and New York Stock Exchange on Feb 17, President's Day

headline: DEPUY BUYING MAJORITY STAKE IN FRENCH MANUFACTURER
abstract: DuPuy Inc agrees to buy majority stake in Landanger-Camus, a French maker of orthopedic products, for about $144.6 million (S)

headline: Joe Camel, spokes-beast to the smoking set, is trying menthol.
abstract: Advertising column describes campaign to introduce Camel Menthol cigarettes; print advertisements are by Mezzina/Brown Inc; introduction of Camel Menthol is emblematic of continued marketing activity by American cigarette industry, with $50 billion in annual sales, despite intensifying efforts by anti-smoking groups (M)

headline: Telephone Pact To Alter Rates And Services
abstract: Global telecommunications trade agreement signed over the weekend in Geneva, Switzerland, should mean lower prices and better voice, data and video services for US telecommunications customers; agreement, signed by more than 60 nations, is expected to remove many countries' barriers to foreign ownership of telecommunications companies, resulting in greater competition; map; chart (L)

headline: BANCORP HAWAII TO PAY $183 MILLION FOR CU BANCORP
abstract: Bancorp Hawaii Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire CU Bancorp, the holding company for California United Bank, in a deal worth about $183 million. Under the agreement, CU Bancorp shareholders will get rights to $15.34 a share in cash or Bancorp Hawaii stock. Between 60 percent and 80 percent of CU Bancorp stock will be swapped for Bancorp Hawaii stock. CU Bancorp's shares rose $1.125 yesterday, to $14.375, in Nasdaq trading. Bancorp Hawaii edged up 50 cents to $45.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. CU Bancorp, based in Encino, Calif., has total assets of about $844 million. Bancorp Hawaii, of Honolulu, has 160 sites and total assets of about $14 billion.

headline: Albania's Government and a City Prepare for Showdown
abstract: Albanian troops are preparing for confrontation with secessionists who have taken control of southern port city of Vlore; map; photo (M)

headline: Instead of Flood of Competition, the Communications Act Brought a Trickle
abstract: Analysis of failure of year-old Telecommunications Act to spur competition; cable television rates are rising, cable firms are retreating from phone business and regional Bell phone companies are scaling back plans to enter television business, while long-distance carriers are moving very slowly into local phone service (M)

headline: Tower Automotive Agrees to Pay $625 Million for A.O. Smith Unit
abstract: Tower Automotive Inc to acquire A O Smith Corp's Automotive Products Co for $625 million cash (S)

headline: Ford Is Said to Be Close To Selling Rental Car Unit
abstract: Team Rental Group Inc is expected to announce its acquisition of Budget Rent a Car Co from Ford Motor Co for more than $350 million in stock and cash; Ford is latest auto maker to leave car rental industry, and selloff is not over; Chrysler Corp has put Dollar Rent-a-Car and Thrifty Car Rental up for sale; Ford is exploring options for Hertz; that would leave only Value in hands of automobile maker, Mitsubishi Motors; pressure has risen on owners of car-rental companies to operate more profitably to make up for loss of generous tax breaks since new tax laws went into effect; Team Rental, which went public in 1994, is largest Budget Rent a Car franchisee, with 156 locations, and owns 13 Budget used-car sales lots; it is taking on far larger company in Budget, which has annual revenue of $1.5 billion; Budget lost more than $100 million in 1995 and is said to have been marginally profitable last year; Budget acquisition would provide Team Rental with steady inventory for its used-car operation (M)

headline: U.N.'s Costs Are Leveling Off, Chief Financial Officer Reports
abstract: Joseph E Connor, senior financial officer of United Nations, says that spending for 1998 and 1999 would come in under budget if dollar remained relatively stable and inflation subdued; says UN could spend less than $2.48 billion it has budgeted for two years (M)

headline: Q&A / Jacques Rupnik : Albania's Illusions:Life as a Lottery
abstract: The outburst of anti-government violence in Albania is the latest case of Balkan instability, apparently caused by the failure of democracy and prosperity to emerge faster from the ashes of Communist rule. Jacques Rupnik, director of research at the Center for International Studies in Paris, talked with Joseph Fitchett of the Herald Tribune about likely scenarios in the Albanian crisis.

headline: January Retail Sales Rose 0.6%, Slightly Less Than Expected
abstract: Commerce Department reports retail sales rose six-tenths of 1 percent in January; says consumers spent $209.1 billion last month, six-tenths of 1 percent more than in December and 4.9 percent, with no adjustment for inflation, above January 1996 level; Labor Department report shows number of people visiting unemployment offices for the first time tumbled last week to lowest point since mid-summer; says 15,000 fewer claims, to 309,000, were reported last week; graph (L)

headline: Expanding and consolidating, Golden Books takes six floors at Seventh Ave. and 57th St.
abstract: Golden Books Family Entertainment Inc signs 15-year lease for 112,500 square feet of office space at 57th Street and Seventh Avenue; National Urban League signs 20 year lease for almost 49,000 square feet of office space at 120 Wall Street; Credit Suisse First Boston leases additional 286,000 square feet of office space at 11 Madison Avenue (M)

headline: Student's Death Widens Protests in Kenya
abstract: Thousands of students march through streets of Nairobi, Kenya, for fourth straight day in widening revolt over mysterious death of student leader Solomon Muruli; photo (M)

headline: Economy Warms Up, and Eyes Turn to the Fed
abstract: As analysts grow more optimistic about economy's vigor, talk in many quarters has now turned to how long inflation-wary Federal Reserve can wait before tightening policy; overall economic picture is, however, far from clear; preliminary Christmas tallies have shown disappointing results for many retailers; at same time, Government and various private groups are issuing statistics about other aspects of economy that almost without exception surpass expectations; some private economists comment on economic outlook (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table shows key interest rates

headline: After 30 Years, the Palestinians Take Over in Hebron
abstract: Palestinians take over in Hebron in carefully coordinated transfer of authority from Israeli forces; Palestinian residents crowd onto grounds of former Israeli military headquarters that they regarded as symbol of their oppression; they string up Palestinian flags and paint storefronts to mark beginning of new era; in heart of Hebron, where Israeli forces remain in control, there are scuffles between Israeli troops and Arab residents; 80 percent of Hebron is now in Palestinian hands; local officials expect Yasir Arafat to make triumphal visit to city in near future; photo (M)

headline: Despite Fear, Albania's Intelligentsia Mainly Stays
abstract: Thousands of educated Albanians, many of whom were persecuted under Communist dictatorship of Enver Hoxha, have already gone into exile; others with dreams of democratic future refuse to leave despite shock of last two weeks of violence (M)

headline: SATELLITE COMMUNICATIONS COMPANY PLANS STOCK SALE
abstract: Iridium World Communications Ltd, which plans to create network of low-orbit communications satellites, sets initial public offering of 10 million shares expected to raise $188 million; firm is indirect subsidiary of Motorola Inc (S)

headline: Geoffrey Swaebe, 86; Former Envoy to Belgium
abstract: Geoffrey Swaebe, former US Ambassador to Belgium, dies at age 86 (M)

headline: To Rate Hospitals, She Dons a Wig and Practices Her Cough
abstract: Work of Barbara Gerber, consultant hired by doctors and hospitals to rate their services by posing as patient, described; health care providers are increasingly turning to undercover consumers in bid to improve reputations and attract patients; table; photo (M)û

headline: W. R. GRACE FINDS BUYER FOR SPECIALTY POLYMERS UNIT
abstract: W R Grace & Co agrees to sell its Grace Specialty Polymers unit for $147 million in cash to National Starch and Chemical Co, a subsidiary of Unilever NV; Grace says it will acquire Schurpack Inc; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: An Information Revolution Revives Its Economy
abstract: San Diego has been transformed in just five years into vital entrepreneurial center for wireless industries; it has spawned garage start-ups and attracted giant multinationals doing research, marketing and manufacturing; employment in telecommunications in region jumped 65 percent in 1996 from previous year; San Diego is attractive to wireless industry because of engineering talent left over from declining military industry and proximity to University of California at San Diego as source of skilled workers; is now home base of new digital cellular transmission standard known as CDMA, the fastest-growing wireless technology in United States; consortium of 14 companies established Center for Wireless Communications at university campus; it has embarked on design of broadband wireless network that members hope will transform nature of all kinds of business and home communications; photo (L)

headline: Auditors Raise Question of T.W.A.'s Continued Operation
abstract: Trans World Airlines says auditors included qualification in annual report raising questions about carrier's ability to continue as going concern; publicizes statement in tandem with an announcement of plans to raise $50 million in private offering (M)

headline: In Mexico, an Uneven Recovery
abstract: Outlook for Mexican economy in 1997 discussed; recovery from disastrous slump that followed 1994 devaluation of peso has been unexpectedly rapid, but mixed; key issue is whether consumers will resume sustained spending; photo (M)

headline: Technology Stocks Plunge, Extending Monthlong Slide
abstract: Technology stocks fall sharply, extending monthlong decline and widening performance gap between that sector and larger market; technology-dominated Nasdaq 100 index plunges 10.48 points, or 1.23 percent, to 841.03, while Dow Jones industrial average rises 56.19 points to close at 7,000.89; table shows favorite stocks (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Fall Sharply, Then Regain Most of Loss  Before a late rebound, the stock market almost opened 1997 the same way it ended 1996 -- with a big drop. The Dow Jones industrial average, down more than 88 points at 3:29 P.M., regained nearly all of that by the end of trading. The index ended the day down 5.78 points, at 6,442.49. That followed a 101-point drop on Tuesday.    There was no obvious cause for the turnaround, but traders said it came with strong program buying that helped to push up large stocks across the board. $(Page D6.$)     Dividends rose rapidly last year, but not enough to keep up with share gains. $(D4.$)     Bank of New York Stake in Rival   Bank of New York said that it would seek to raise its stake to 9.9 percent in State Street Boston, a rival in the business of processing securities. Analysts speculated whether it was the start of a takeover bid. $(D2.$)    Morgan Stanley Names Fund Chief   Philip N. Duff, Morgan Stanley's chief financial officer, has been tapped to be chief executive and president of Van Kampen American Capital, the big mutual fund company that Morgan Stanley acquired last fall, company executives said. $(D3.$)      Purchasing Management Index Up   Manufacturing picked up strength in December, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported. Its index rose to 54 points from 52.7 in November, surprising economists. $(D3.$)    That report sent bond prices down sharply. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond jumped to 6.73 percent from 6.64. $(D15.$)     De Beers to End Russian Pact   De Beers Consolidated Mines of South Africa, which sells about 75 percent of the world's diamond production, confirmed that it would end a marketing agreement with Russia, the largest diamond producer. $(D2.$)    Malone's Move to Control Liberty   Watchers of John C. Malone, left, say the king of convoluted cable deals is at it again. He wants to obtain control of Liberty Media by gaining access to shares owned by the estate of Bob J. Magness, Liberty's largest shareholder, without putting up cash. To that end, the board at his behest has authorized a stock dividend.  Market Place. $(D6.$)    Canada's Wheat Board Criticized   A number of Canadian farmers think that the Canadian Wheat Board, which has a monopoly on selling wheat and barley from Western growers, has too much power. $(A4.$)    F.D.A. Steps on Mad Cow Disease   The Food and Drug Administration proposed a ban on the use in feed of tissue from a wide variety of animals to prevent the spread of mad cow disease, should an outbreak occur in this country. $(A14.$)    A Sport-Utility Printer?   In a new ad campaign for printers, Hewlett-Packard gently pokes fun at its own engineers in an effort to make its technology seem more accessible. In one ad, an announcer jokes that the only thing the printer cannot do is mow the lawn. But engineers reconfigure it and soon it zips around a field. Advertising. $(D4.$)

headline: A Way To Gauge Tax Effects
abstract: Funds Watch column notes that Morningstar Inc, which tracks stock funds, recently added three-year tax-efficiency ratings for all diversified domestic stock funds, to help investors see how much of fund's returns are lost after shareholders pay taxes on income and capital gains distributions (M)

headline: Bayer Has Strong Year, Aided by Foreign Results
abstract: Bayer AG says 1996 net profit rose 13.5 percent as strong dollar bolsters foreign sales and profits; net profit rose 2.74 billion marks ($1.61 billion), from 2.42 billion marks in 1995; pretax profit rose 6.7 percent, to 4.464 billion marks from 4.18 billion marks; sales rose 9 percent, to 48.60 billion marks ($28.6 billion), from 44.58 billion marks in the previous year (S)

headline: 3 Swiss Banks Plan To Establish Fund For Nazis' Victims
abstract: Switzerland's three largest banks, Credit Suisse, Swiss Bank Corp and Union Bank of Switzerland, announce that they will set up 'humanitarian fund for the victims of the Holocaust' with initial worth of around $70 million; gesture, coming after months of pressure from American Jewish groups, is apparently intended to head off threats from them and from New York institutions of sanctions against Swiss banks; banking officials say it represents first time since World War II that Swiss commercial banks have offered their own money in connection with long-running effort by Jewish groups to seek compensation related to Switzerland's close financial relationship with Nazi Germany (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.19   5.15   5.21        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.07   5.05   4.87        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.19   5.18   4.84        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.37   3.37   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.61   6.56   6.07        30-YR. TREAS. headline: Insatiable Appetite of Handbag Addicts
abstract: LONDON—  What's up with handbags? The women who shop can't get enough of them. Handbags are like shoes. People develop obsessions about them. Right now, half the fashion world seems to be sharing that obsession.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: Bay Networks Inc, Santa Clara, Calif, appoints David Rynne, former chief financial officer of Tandem Computers Inc, as its new chief financial officer, succeeding William Ruehle, who earlier resigned; GE Capital Services, Mason, Ohio, names Kathryn V Marinello president; Liz Claiborne Inc, New York, appoints Elayne Fleischman Aschkenes president of company's dress division (S)

headline: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC TO CLOSE BELGIAN PLANT, CUT 225 JOBS
abstract: Boston Scientific Corp will close Belgian heart-catheter plant and dismiss 225 workers as part of reorganization (S)

headline: DEATHS AT RALLY RATTLE CAMBODIA
abstract: Grenade attack kills at least 10 people and wounds more than 200 at opposition political rally in Phnom Penh, Cambodia; is worst attack since establishment of fragile democratic Government in 1993; target of attack is reportedly opposition leader Sam Rainsy, who escaped with only minor injuries; he blames one of country's two feuding co-Prime Ministers, Hun Sen, who has frequently threatened opponents with violence; degeneration of country's fragile democracy in recent months into cold war and violence between Hun Sen and other co-Prime Minister, Prince Norodom Ramariddh, discussed; photos (M)

headline: PIMCO PLANS TO BUY STAKE IN OPPENHEIMER CAPITAL
abstract: Pimco Advisors L.P. agreed yesterday to acquire Oppenheimer Group Inc.'s one-third stake in the institutional money manager Oppenheimer Capital L.P. for $265 million in preferred stock and assumed debt. Pimco, a bond fund manager, has been trying to increase its equities money management business. About 73 percent of Pimco's $110 billion in assets is in bonds. Oppenheimer Capital oversees about $48 billion in assets, 78 percent of which are invested in stocks. The transaction would create one of the largest investment firms in the United States, with $158 billion under management.

headline: WABASH TO ACQUIRE FRUEHAUF TRAILER ASSETS
abstract: Wabash National Corp, largest United States maker of truck trailers, says it agreed to acquire retail network and other assets of rival Fruehauf Trailer Corp for about $49 million; Fruehauf filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in October (S)

headline: Sharansky Ends Russian Trip With a Visit to His Old Prison Cell
abstract: Israeli Trade Min Natan Sharansky ends his trip to Russia after visiting Moscow prison where he spent 16 months; Sharansky, former Soviet dissident, was arrested in 1977 (M)

headline: At Macworld, Apple failed to regain believers among the once-faithful.
abstract: Technology column claims Apple Computer Co's opening-day performance at recent Macworld exposition in San Francisco was a disjointed disappointment, indicating that Apple remains a company in chaos; says Apple's emphasis on glitz rather than progress and its lack of discernable marketing message have plagued company over last year; drawing (M)

headline: Executive Quits At Euro Disney
abstract: Euro Disney says that Xavier de Mezerac, finance director credited with bringing company's costs under control, had resigned after two years 'to explore career opportunities outside the company' (S)

headline: Mexican Rebels Vow a Long, Hard Battle
abstract: Three commanders of Popular Revolutionary Army, in clandestine news conference outside Mexico City, say they believe their movement is gaining support and that they are planning long-term resistance against Mexican Government; photo (M)

headline: 3 Things Matter: Location, Location and Feng Shui
abstract: Tung Chee-hwa, who will head Hong Kong after Britain cedes colony to China, turned to master of fung shui, Chinese art of harmonizing people and their environment, to help locate government offices; advice and benediction of feng shui masters are widely sought, in virtually any situation, in Hong Kong; photo (M)

headline: S.E.C. Delays New Order-Handling Rules
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission says some aspects of its new order-handling rules will take effect on Jan 13, rather than on Jan 10; most important change is that Nasdaq stock market will phase in requirement to display quotations from electronic services like Instinet rather than making change immediately; such electronic services, which are now accessible only to brokers and institutional investors, often have better prices than are visible on Nasdaq system (M)

headline: McDonald's Posts a Gain of 12% in Profits
abstract: McDonald's Corp says its earnings rose 12 percent in fourth quarter, to $410 million, from year earlier; revenue rose 8.9 percent, to $2.82 billion; latest quarter's results include $48.7 million charge for steps to strengthen company's business in United States (S)

headline: Vacuum of Power Pulling Neighbors Into Zaire Conflict
abstract: Rebel advance in Zaire is drawing new participants into conflict as fall of longtime dictator Mobutu Sese Seko appears ever more likely; neighboring nations and insurgent groups from throughout Central Africa are scrambling to get involved on one side or other; growing coalition of forces contributes to fight against Mobutu, who let Zaire be used as staging point for covert actions against neighbors; Angola, spurred by Zaire's long support for Angolan rebel Jonas Savimbi, reportedly ships military supplies and exiled Zairian rebels to join rebellion; maps; photo (M)

headline: Mexico Repays Bailout by U.S. Ahead of Time
abstract: Pres Clinton says Mexico has repaid the $12.5 billion it borrowed from Washington to stave off financial collapse two years ago, and done it three years ahead of schedule; this ends one of Clinton's riskiest overseas ventures and releases Mexico from tight economic controls imposed by Washington; Clinton says United States ran profit of more than half a billion dollars on the loans; celebration is held at White House, and Clinton recalls how Congress opposed emergency package for Mexico, prompting him to lend cash from funds under President's control; Sen Alfonse D'Amato, who made several attempts to stop transfer of funds to Mexico, issues terse statement attributing quick repayment to 'vigilant Congressional oversight'; cost of repaying loan was high for Mexican workers because of austerity programs imposed as condition of loans; photo (M)

headline: Whether or not it deserves it, the music industry is getting its own daily press.
abstract: Tiny items on music entertainers, all collected from daily music news reports, are future of music media industry, which is fast becoming world dominated by tidbits reported fresh every day; nearly every music publication is starting some sort of daily information hot line in a scramble to get the first word in: to review an album first, to interview a musician before any else, to discover a trend, to get juiciest gossip, to hear the most inside information; drawing (L)

headline: Germans and Czechs Try to Heal Hatreds of the Nazi Era
abstract: Germany and Czech Republic move to break cycle of aggression and revenge that began with Nazi dismemberment of Czechoslovakia in late 1930's, signing bitterly contested declaration that acknowledges wrongs each committed against other over 50 years ago; photo of Czech Republic Prime Min Vaclav Klaus with German Chancellor Helmut Kohl; map; photo (M)

headline: Coffee Surges on Supply Fears As Strikes Loom in Colombia
abstract: Coffee futures prices surge on concerns that planned strike in Colombia could disrupt exports; coffee for Mar delivery rises 7.60 cents, to $1.5865 a pound (S)

headline: Jesse Jackson Sets Up Office To Monitor Corporate Action
abstract: Rev Jesse L Jackson announces plans to open office on Wall Street in February that would seek to cajole, persuade and pressure American companies to hire and promote more blacks and members of other minorities, name more of them to corporate boards and award more business to companies owned by members of minorities, speech to group of black executives at World Trade Center; Donald J Trump says he will donate office space to Jackson's civil rights group, Rainbow/PUSH Coalition, in 40 Wall Street, a building Trump is renovating (L)

headline: 3-Company Pact on Internet Technology
abstract: 3Com Corp, Cascade Communications Corp and International Business Machines Corp say they cooperate in effort to provide systems to speed access to Internet and intranets (S)

headline: 3 Retailers Report Weak Holiday Sales
abstract: Some of nation's large retail chains report disappointing sales for end of 1996; CompUSA Inc says its sales for last three months of year rose 1.5 percent, far below analysts' predictions; J C Penney Co says December same-store sales rose 6.2 percent, but profit margins were weak; Dayton Hudson Corp reports 4.2 percent rise in same-store sales in December, but says full holiday season sales will be flat; analysts note that markdowns might have inflated sales at end of month, but they also cut profit margins for many retailers, and result may be poor earnings; graph (M)

headline: Ban Expiring, Haitians Fear Return of the Tontons Macoute
abstract: Ten-year ban against involvement in politics by officials of deposed Duvalier family nears expiration, and prospect that former leaders of Tonstons Macoute may soon re-enter public life has Haitian Government scrambling to take countermeasures; old lawsuit against Duvalier family and entourage has been revived, and Pres Rene Preval has warned of renewed threat, even as aides seek to reassure population that they have nothing to fear (M)

headline: Thai School:A Family Affair
abstract: BANGKOK—  As urban growth chisels away at the traditional Thai family, one school is calling students, along with their parents and grandparents, to the hills.

headline: Jacques Coe, 103, Dies; Oldest Active Broker
abstract: Jacques Coe, believed to be nation's oldest active stockbroker, dies at age 103 (M)

headline: CAPSTONE ANNOUNCES $22.6 MILLION IN NEW INVESTMENTS
abstract: Capstone Capital Corp says it will invest $14.7 million in six existing health care operations and plans to invest $7.9 million in four health care operations under development (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co will quit selling computer software and start selling 35-millimeter cameras in all its department stores by midyear (S)

headline: VW Says Income Doubled Last Year
abstract: Volkswagen A.G. said yesterday in a preliminary report that its net income surged to 678 million marks ($401 million) in 1996, more than double the 336 million marks posted in 1995. Sales rose to 100.1 billion marks, compared with 88.1 billion marks a year earlier.

headline: Telecommunications Concerns to Merge in Japan
abstract: Japan Telecom Co, domestic telephone company, says it will merge with privately held International Telecom Japan Inc; merger would create Japan's second-largest telecommunications carrier after Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp and could be first in wave of consolidation in Japan's telecommunications industry (M)

headline: Making the Label Reflect the Flavor
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission seeks to require mutual funds whose names include specific investment, such as stock or bond, to invest 80 percent of assets accordingly, up from current 65 percent; move could spur shift by funds to generic names, making selection even harder for investors (M)

headline: Tories Are Accused On 'Mad Cow' Study
abstract: British Government is accused of having suppressed year-old report that found slaughterhouses guilty of practices that can contribute to the spreading of mad cow disease and E. coli bacteria poisoning; Bill Swann of RSPCA says he was told finding would give industry a battering; Prime Min John Major says in raucous Parliamentary debate that report was 'routine' (S)

headline: Norway's No. 5 Bank Increases a Bid
abstract: Fokus Bank, Norway's fifth-largest bank, increases its stock and cash bid for Boligog Naeringsbanken to 2.059 billion kroner ($307 million) after country's biggest bank, Den Norske Bank, makes competing all-cash bid earlier in the day (S)

headline: U.S. Proposes Deeper Cuts In Atom Arms To Russians
abstract: United States has told Russia that it is willing to negotiate deeper cuts in long-range nuclear arms to ease Russian fears that West seeks military edge; proposal could lay basis for accord on goals of future arms talks at Pres Clinton's summit meeting with Pres Boris N Yeltsin and is also intended to prod Russia to ratify Start II treaty (M)

headline: Political and Corporate Elite Soak Up Big Ideas at Davos
abstract: World's business and political elite are set to gather for World Economic Forum, Davos, Switzerland; Davos meeting and smaller forums around world through year have become powerful attractions, with hundreds of business leaders paying $20,000 per company to attend and pursue contracts and contacts with top politicians and pundits; Prof Klaus Schwab, who created forum, set rules that chief executives represent their firms and that politicians not get honorariums; graphs; table; photos (M)

headline: Chase Appoints Economist
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp names John Lipsky as chief economist and director of research for Chase's Global Bank; he succeeds Richard C Aspinwall, who is is named director for public policy research, new post (S)

headline: Sony Names New Head at Columbia-Tristar
abstract: Sony Pictures Entertainment names Kenneth Lemberger president of Columbia-Tristar Motion Picture Group (S)ÿ
