headline: GE CAPITAL SERVICES ACQUIRES ITALIAN FACTORING FIRM
abstract: General Electric Co says its GE Capital Services subsidiary had acquired Barclays Factoring SpA of Milan, Italy (S)

headline: In Tokyo Scandal, Profits Were for the Birds
abstract: Arrest of Tatsuo Tomobe, member of Japan's Parliament, in connection with bogus banking scheme is embarrassing main opposition party and adding to general public sourness toward politics (M)

headline: Salomon Says Its 1996 Profit Nearly Doubled
abstract: Salomon Inc reports fourth-quarter 1996 net of $228 million, compared with $168 million in year-earlier period; net for 1996 was $907 million, compared with $457 million in 1995 (S)

headline: SHIVA STOCK PLUNGES ON LOW EARNINGS EXPECTATIONS
abstract: Stock of Shiva Corp declines 44.8 percent after company says it expects fourth-quarter earnings to be well below Wall Street's expectations (S)

headline: In Era of Belt-Tightening, Modest Gains for Workers
abstract: American workers won modest wage gains in 1996 that were largest since 1990, keeping ahead of inflation for only second time in decade; many economists expect gains to continue; hourly wages, in current dollars, are rising at annual rate of 3.8 percent, about 0.5 percent above inflation rate, to average of $11.98; there are no signs that raises are proving inflationary, even in tight labor markets with low unemployment; graphs; photo (L)

headline: Is U.S. Less Hospitable?Boom in Foreign Students Seems to Be Over
abstract: WASHINGTON—  For more than four decades, American colleges and universities have had a seemingly irresistible appeal to students from other countries, and the education of foreign students in the United States has been a growth industry.

headline: Outsider Put At the Helm Of Mercury
abstract: William A Brandt Jr replaces John N Brincat as president and chief executive of Mercury Finance Co, which is struggling to avoid bankruptcy; Brandt is outside corporate turnaround specialist with reputation for being creative at devising out-of-court resolutions to corporate disasters; company says it has been served with warrant from Justice Dept to search financial records at its headquarters in Lake Forest, Ill, for evidence of fraud and other illegal activities; Brandt meeets with creditors, hoping to arrange new short-term loans that will allow Mercury to resume paying commercial lenders on schedule; Brandt disputes Wall Street predictions that Mercury will soon file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy; photo (M)

headline: CONRAIL POSTPONES MEETING TO AVOID COUP
abstract: Conrail Inc says it will hold its annual shareholders meeting on Dec 19, 1997, seven months later than normal; pushing meeting date back is seen as a defensive tactic should Norfolk Southern Corp, hostile bidder for railroad, seek to win control of board (S)

headline: Service Corporation Drops Bid for Rival Funeral Home Chain
abstract: Service Corporation International, which has built the world's largest funeral home chain through aggressive acquisitions, drops hostile $3.2 billion bid for Loewen Group, its largest rival; says Loewen's value has diminished in light of some recent large acquisitions and several defensive measures; main reason appears to be that Service Corp is unwilling or unable to pay enough to overcome strong objections from Ray L Loewen, Loewen Group's founder and chief executive (M)

headline: Stocks Higher in Japan
abstract: Japanese stocks are up at the midday break on Jan 6 (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes noted (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Atlantic Richfield Co will spend $300 million to build plant in Carson, Calif, to make polypropylene, widely used plastic; KCS Energy Inc signs letter of intent to sell natural gas pipeline system to partnership of MCN Energy Group Inc and Copano Field Services LLC; Diana Corp sells its Atlanta Provision Co to Colorado Boxed Beef Co for $14 million; Bombardier Capital Inc acquires Norrail Inc for undisclosed price (S)

headline: Lamar Buys a Rival For $167 Million
abstract: Lamar Advertising Co will acquire Penn Advertising Inc for about $167 million in cash (S)

headline: New Inflation-Indexed Note Receives a Strong Response
abstract: Treasury's first auction of inflation-indexed bonds meets stronger-than-expected demand from large institutional investors; median yield is 3.40 percent; Treasury securities prices rise; 30-year bond rises 8/32, to 94 30/32, to yield 6.90 percent; graph (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: America Online to Give Refunds and Credits  America Online agreed to give millions of dollars worth of credits and refunds as compensation for the network traffic jams that have been frustrating its customers.    Threats of lawsuits by many states and an outcry from subscribers had clouded the company's prospects, and the announcement lifted the stock sharply even though the deal could be costly. $(Page A1.$)    Ford Profits Increase  Ford Motor reported higher earnings for the fourth quarter and all of 1996, despite continued losses in the European and Latin American divisions. $(D4.$)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Harbour Petroleum Co says it sold its 100 percent interest in Jenner and Cessford gas fields in eastern Alberta, Canada, for $22.1 million; no buyer is disclosed (S)

headline: ENERGY GROUP LOOKING FOR ACQUISITION IN AMERICA
abstract: Energy Group says it plans to buy American power generator after it is spun off from Hanson PLC in Feb (S)

headline: American Radio in Deal
abstract: American Radio Systems Corp agrees to buy Cincinnati radio station WGRR-FM from Dalton Group for about $30 million (S)

headline: Sidney W. Dean Is Dead at 91; Served as Trustee of City Club
abstract: Sidney W Dean Jr, longtime trustee of City Club of New York, dies at age 91 (M)

headline: With Merged Strength Comes Conflict With Retail Brokerage Houses
abstract: By combining Dean Witter's national network of retail stockbrokers with Morgan Stanley's investment skill, merger should significantly strengthen new company's mutual fund offerings; but it will create conflicts among people who sell the funds; merger will create a company that offers 306 funds with assets of $146 billion, placing it fifth among US mutual fund companies; but tangle of relationships produced by the merger could, at least temporarily, weigh down the new mutual family (L)

headline: Morgan Stanley Earnings Up 15.8% in First Quarter
abstract: Morgan Stanley Group Inc says earnings rose 15.8 percent in three months ended Feb 28; firm earned $316 million, up from $273 million in quarter a year earlier; chart (M)

headline: To Have and to Hyphenate: The Marriage Name Game
abstract: Laura Pedersen-Pietersen article offers advice for newlyweds on surname issues; notes many working women, marrying after starting careers and earning credentials under birth names, are choosing not to take husbands' names; drawing (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp receives about 710,000 ITT Corp shares in response to its $6.5 billion tender offer, which it extends until March 28 (S)

headline: U.S. Report on Human Rights Faults China, Nigeria and Cuba
abstract: Clinton Administration's annual report on human rights in 193 countries concludes that despite US efforts, human rights performance worsened last year in China, Nigeria, Cuba and Myanmar; finds that Russia's record is 'mixed' (M)

headline: Settlement in Bond Case
abstract: Nicholas A Rudi Jr, who advised Jim Florio when he was Governor of New Jersey, agrees to pay $86,000 to settle civil charges by Securities and Exchange Commission that he accepted kickbacks to help bank, Camden County Municipal Utilities Authority, win $237 million municipal bond contract; Rudi settles case without admitting or denying wrongdoing (S)

headline: Taiwan Exports Fall 3.4%
abstract: Taiwan's exports fell 3.4 percent in January from a year earlier; exports declined to $10.3 billion from $10.7 billion a year earlier (S)

headline: McDonald's will play Monopoly before rolling the dice on its new price-cutting strategy.
abstract: Beginning March 5, McDonald's Corp starts its sixth big promotion based on board game Monopoly; promotion is scheduled to run through April 3; three weeks after that, McDonald's will start price-slashing efforts known as Campaign 55 after the year Ray Kroc opened his first McDonald's; in a vote last week, nearly 90 percent of McDonald's 2,700 domestic franchisees approved discounting strategy (L)

headline: Prices of Treasuries Drop; Long-Bond Yield at 6.84%
abstract: Prices of Government securities decline in late trading after initially gaining ground; traders are apparently wary about economic data this week; 30-year Treasury falls 21/32, to 95 22/32, to yield 6.84 percent, from 6.78 percent on Friday; graph (Credit Markets column) (M)

headline: Microsoft Set for Another Move In Forging Links to the Internet
abstract: Bill Gates of Microsoft is set to introduce Office 97, new version of company's software bundle for office computing; analysts expect real star of show to be Outlook, new application that is thought to show progress Microsoft has made in linking its traditional products with Internet, crucial element in company's effort to keep sales rising rapidly (M)

headline: Dow Climbs 76.58 to End Above 7,000
abstract: Stock prices soar, sending Dow Jones industrial average above 7,000-point level for fourth time this year, largely on a rise in the technology sector; Dow closes at 7,008.20, up 76.58 points (M)

headline: Bidding for Thomson Is Heating Up
abstract: Alcatel Alsthom SA and Dassault Industries say that they have jointly submitted notice to French Govt of their intention to bid for state's majority stake in military electronics maker Thomson-CSF (S)

headline: Computers Turn Design On Its Prototypical Ear
abstract: Three-dimensional computer-aided design and manufacturing programs are being used to produce wide variety of consumer products, including electric guitars, dinnerware and carpet cleaners; systems used, commonly called 3D CAD/CAM, allow users to design and display parts on computer screen and even rotate them 360 degrees; designers have long realized limitations of working with two-dimensional designs; now they have CAD/CAM programs that can approximate a solid part, and computers powerful enough to run them; diagram, graph; chart (M)

headline: Bill Sale Today Is Only Offering Listed by Treasury This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.00 percent and a six-month bill was 5.06 percent.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: US Filter Corp, provider of industrial water and waste-water treatment equipment, acquires Sidener Supply Co and Pori International Inc for undisclosed terms (S)

headline: Radar Jammer Is Criticized In U.S. Study
abstract: Report by General Accounting Office criticizes Airborne Self-Protection Jammer, Navy radar-jamming device used in Bosnia to protect Marine Corps fighter pilots against missile attacks, for flawed performance; say device has suffered long history of lackluster testing and on-and-off production (S)

headline: HILTON HOTELS TO TAKE A 5 PERCENT INTEREST IN LADBROKE
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp to take 5 percent stake in Ladbroke Group, which holds the rights to the Hilton name outside the United States (S)

headline: Martha Stewart to Buy Her Company
abstract: Martha Stewart will buy most of her company, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia LLC, from Time Warner Inc to gain more control over direction and marketing; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: In American Eagle, Union Sees a Threat
abstract: Pilots at American Eagle, American Airlines Inc's commuter line, will put up with no second-guessing of their abilities even though they earn only a third to a half as much as $120,000 a year that pilots average at American Airlines; as 9,000 American Airlines pilots--in pay and prestige among the princes of the industry--define threats to their jobs, they point to more than just company's managers; and rather than seeing American Eagle, already nation's largest commuter airline, as a way to funnel more passengers to their airline, American pilots see 2,000 pilots at American Eagle bearing down on them; AMR Corp, parent company of both airlines, wants to accelerate American Eagle's already rapid growth by adding as many as 67 medium-sized jets to current fleet of 205 turboprops; American pilots say that these pilots and jets will take over many more of their routes; photo (L)

headline: From Co-Ops to Rentals To More Like Condos
abstract: Grand Cove complex in Edgewater, NJ, built as cooperative and then turned partly into rental housing, will be sllling apartments next month--this time to be more like condominium (M)

headline: Some EU Countries Fear Effects of Fiscal Dumping : Europe Struggles With Tax Policy
abstract: BRUSSELS—  For the economically depressed region of Liege in eastern Belgium, the factory making balloon catheters for angioplasties was a ray of hope in an otherwise bleak landscape, providing 200 jobs in an industry with a bright future.

headline: INTEL'S PURCHASE OF A STAKE IN AVID SENDS STOCK UP 21%
abstract: Avid Technology Inc shares rise 21 percent after Intel Corp buys 6.75 percent stake (S)

headline: Raytheon Considers Sale of Appliance Unit
abstract: Raytheon Co weighs sale of its appliance operations (S)

headline: Challenged by New Labels, Denim's Big 3 Fight Back
abstract: Levi Strauss, VF Corp and Guess Inc, biggest purveyors of jeans, are finding their market invaded by hotter, more fashion-conscious manufacturers; after years of growth, their total market share shrank last year by more than three percentage points; fashion houses, including Tommy Hilfiger, Calvin Klein, Mossimo, Ralph Lauren and Donna Karan, have all spewed out new designs; cottage industry of tiny companies concentrated in Los Angeles has sprouted, offering offbeat cuts and zany touches that younger consumers love; two of biggest buyers of mainstream brands, J C Penney Co and Sears, Roebuck & Co, have come out with their own wildly popular lines; table; photo (L)

headline: New President Of AT&T Sees A Profit Drain
abstract: John R Walter, who was named president and heir apparent to AT&T Corp's chairman and chief executive, Robert E Allen, in November, warns analysts that company's earnings could plummet as much as 30 percent this year because of unrelenting competition and billions of dollars AT&T will need to spend to move to new markets, like local phone service; also says that AT&T plans to cut $2.6 billion in costs next two years--a campaign that will necessitate substantial jobs cuts; insists company does not plan to lay off more than 17,000 employees it announced that it would cut early last year; but several analysts predict that company will have to increase that number to meet its cost-cutting goal (L)

headline: South Africa's Ugly Rugby
abstract: Andre Markgraaff is under pressure to resign as coach of South Africa's national rugby team after television news plays tape of someone identified as him repeatedly referring to black Government officials with racial slur (S)

headline: Passenger Use of Sabena Grew 3.2% Last Year
abstract: Sabena, Belgian national airline, carried 3.2 percent more passengers in 1996 than in 1995 (S)

headline: Irish Inquiry Set on Store Chain's Political Gifts
abstract: Irish Government will seek information about $5.7 million distributed in recent years to past and present members of Parliament by Dunnes, largest chain of department stores in Ireland; High Court Justice Brian McCracken will have the power to subpoena witnesses, including Charles J Haughey, former Prime Minister; preliminary investigation has disclosed that Haughey's wife, Maureen, received about $30,000 from Dunnes as campaign contribution to her husband, and published reports say that ranking official of Mr Haughey's party, Fianna Fail, received $1.7 million (M)

headline: Kurdish Rebels in Turkey Are Down but Not Out
abstract: Stephen Kinzer reports on Turkish Govt's war against Kurds; finds that Kurdish rebels are down but not out; reports that six-day tour of southeastern Turkey suggests that army has dealt powerful blows to rebel group, killing many guerrillas and forcing most of rest across border to sanctuaries in Iran, Iraq and Syria; many villages once torn by conflict are now at peace; but throughout region, may Kurds still resent Govt's refusal to accept their ethnic identity; with Kurdish newspapers closed, Kurdish politicians in jail and hundreds of Kurdish civilians murdered by mysterious death squads, Kurdish Workers Party is only surviving orgn that upholds concept of Kurdish identity; photo; map (M)

headline: Paribas of France Returns to Profitability
abstract: Compagnie Financiere de Paribas SA returned to profitability in 1996 as strong banking and investment revenues offset surge in charges; net profit was 4.35 billion francs ($763 million) in 1996, recovering from loss of 3.99 billion francs ($700 million) a year earlier (S)

headline: Europe's Cheap Phone Calls (Via U.S.) to Cost More
abstract: European Union is expected to authorize governments to impose heavy sales taxes on callback services, which cut cost of international phone calls for European customers by dialing them through United States, where rates are much lower; France and Germany plan to impose taxes immediately; US-based services hold Europeans will not be able to collect taxes (M)

headline: Hutu Refugees Trapped in Zaire Between Tutsi and the Crocodiles
abstract: Over 100,000 desperate Hutu refugees have fled to makeshift camp near Ubundu, Zaire, pursued by Tutsi-led rebels; rebels, led by Laurent Kabila, maintain that their goal is to overthrow Zaire's longtime dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko; they also want to break up huge concentrations of Hutu who have sought refuge in Zaire since Rwanda's own civil war in 1994 and hunt down those who took part in massacres committed against Tutsi; many among fleeing Hutu have been armed by Zaire's Government as counterinsurgents; map; photo (M)

headline: S.E.C. ASKED TO REVIEW GREAT WESTERN DEAL
abstract: H F Ahmanson & Co is asking Securities and Exchange Commission to review terms of Washington Mutual Inc's agreement to acquire Great Western Financial Corp; Ahmanson says Washington Mutual cannot use pooling-of-interest accounting method because it plans to repurchase shares on open market in addition to buying treasury shares (S)

headline: New Bricks, Same Old Walls For Europe's Poor Nations
abstract: There is new divide--some call it latter-day iron curtain--between have and have-not nations of Central and Eastern Europe; only in former does joy remain seven years after collapse of Communism; Poland, Hungary and Czech Republic, more prosperous and stable, are cruising toward Western Europe, while much poorer Bulgaria, Romania and Albania languish in doldrums; for former, entrance into NATO and European Union is matter of when, not if; for latter, legacy of Communist rule and reluctance to undertake market reforms have left faltering economies awash in corruption; graphs; map (M)

headline: Pepsi Gets $50 Million Deal For Major League Baseball
abstract: Pepsi-Cola Company signs up as national sponsor of Major League Baseball in deal valued at estimated $50 million over five years, with $1 million annually in licensing fees to be divided among teams; baseball officials view agreement as triumph, coming more than two years since signing other national sponsors; details of contract discussed (M)

headline: Kohl, in Russia, Sees End of Dispute Over NATO
abstract: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl predicts that standoff over NATO's expansion in Eastern Europe will end this year; remarks come at news conference in Moscow, where Kohl is in talks with Pres Boris N Yeltsin, who is expected to press Western leaders to grant Russia a special security arrangement in return for its agreement not to oppose NATO expansion (S)

headline: MEDIQ TO ABSORB RIVAL IN $138 MILLION DEAL
abstract: Mediq Inc will acquire rival medical equipment maker, Universal Hospital Services Inc, for about $138 million (S)

headline: All hail Jules Verne, patron saint of cyberspace.
abstract: Edward Rothstein Technology column pays tribute to Jules Verne, whose science fiction anticipated so many devices and events; says latest example of his prescience and imagination is his recently discovered novel, Paris in the 20th Century, which he wrote in 1863; drawing (M)

headline: Air France Plans More Cost Cuts
abstract: Air France says it will cut costs by 15 percent in next three years in effort to stay competitive with its European rivals; new cuts come on top of 20 percent reduction in previous three-year period (S)

headline: Microsoft Taking a Stake in Video Games
abstract: Microsoft says it has taken minority stake in Digital Anvil, interactive software gaming company formed by Chris Roberts (S)

headline: MCI Earnings Up Despite Lag in Long-Distance Business
abstract: MCI Corp reports fourth-quarter net income rose 6.7 percent, to $303 million, up from $284 million in 1995 period; GTE Corp reports earning $784 million in quarter, up from loss of nearly $4 billion in 1995 period (M)

headline: Domino's Pizza Narrows Review
abstract: Domino's Pizza narrows review on its advertising account, with billings estimated at $75 million; will divide account, formerly handled by Grey Advertising, into creative and media assignments (S)

headline: SUNBEAM CORP. (SOC,N)
abstract: Sunbeam Corp posts fourth-quarter loss from continuing operations of $2.19 million, compared with $1.7 million operating profit in 1995 period; posts net loss of $234.7 million, compared with 1995 earnings of $100,000; table (S)

headline: As Lima Talks Hit Snag, Some Ex-Hostages Are Complaining
abstract: Captives freed from Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima, Peru, by Tupac Amaru rebels say Government is overlooking them as key source of information; several opposition politicians, who have advocated negotiated settlement since release, say they have gone from being hostages to being victims of Peruvian Government surveillance; talks with rebels are again stalled, two days after Government negotiator, Education Minister Domingo Palermo, contacted guerrilla leader, Nestor Cerpa Cartolini, to arrange face-to-face meeting; reportedly collapsed over Cerpa's demand that Government proposal include provisions for release of more than 400 members of rebels' organization, who are being held in Peruvian jails (M)

headline: UNITED ASSET TO ADD PACIFIC FINANCIAL TO AFFILIATES
abstract: United Asset Management Corp says it will acquire Pacific Financial Research Inc for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: Dollar Rises Against the Yen But Closes Lower vs. the Mark
abstract: Currency Markets column; dollar rises against Japanese yen after report on United States employment points to strong economic growth with little inflation; tables (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GTS Duratek Inc signs letter of intent to acquire Scientific Ecology Group from Westinghouse Electric Corp for $28 million and 156,986 shares of its common stock (S)

headline: Alternate Routes to Finding Popular New Cars
abstract: Advice on strategies for buying new cars that are in high demand and short supply; shopping via Internet and fax cited; photos (M)

headline: Algerian Links Rebels to 'Foreign Interests'
abstract: Algerian Pres Liamine Zeroual, responding to wave of rebel violence exceptional even by his country's standards, blames traitors manipulated by 'foreign interests' for killing and vows to 'battle against the terrorist groups until their final eradication,' 20-minute speech to nation; photo of grieving woman (M)

headline: Fort Worth Publisher Trying to Buy Paper
abstract: Richard L Connor is trying to form a group to buy Fort Worth Star-Telegram; was recently dismissed as its publisher (S)

headline: The Rescuer of Swiss Bank Ledgers
abstract: Christoph Meili, night watchman at Union Bank of Switzerland who stopped shredding of old ledger books and documents that might shed light on Holocaust, has been lionized as 'document hero' by Swiss press, but he has lost his job and is under police investigation; photo (M)

headline: Albanian Parties Trade Charges in the Pyramid Scandal
abstract: Albanian Government, trying to duck political fallout unleashed by collapse of several pyramid investment schemes, is promising to help pay its citizens at least some of money they lost in Central Europe's latest get-rich-quick scams; governing Democratic Party, after week of violent demonstrations, is also trying to shift blame for crisis onto left-wing opposition; photo (M)

headline: No Rush, Yet, to the Web
abstract: While home pages on Internet are springing up rapidly for mutual fund companies, including some funds that allow investors to by and sell shares using their home computers, investors are staying away in droves; study, Investor Internet Adoption Study, commissioned by Twentieth Century Mutual Funds and Benham Group, concludes that 'mutual fund Web site proliferation may be slightly ahead of shareholder demand for on-line services; chart (M)

headline: U.N. and U.S. Pressed on Rights Stance
abstract: Human rights groups are stepping up pressure on Pres Clinton and new United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan to make protection of people around world against violence and abuse higher priority; groups' efforts coincide with preparations for annual meeting of United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva (M)

headline: 'I Feel I've Lost A Child,' King Says
abstract: Visit by King Hussein to bereaved Israeli families of seven schoolgirls shot dead by Jordanian soldier described; widespread admiration among many Israelis for Hussein's visit seemed to many to be separate from political strains with Jordan caused by Israeli Governmment's decision to build new Jewish neighborhood in East Jerusalem; photo (M)

headline: Dollar Drops to Lowest Point In Four Weeks Against Yen
abstract: US dollar drops to four-week low against Japanese yen; dollar settles at 120.69 Japanese yen (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Listing of key United States interest rates

headline: LINCOLN NATIONAL TO BUY VOYAGEUR MUTUAL FUNDS
abstract: Lincoln National Corp says it will buy mutual fund business of Voyageur Cos for about $69 million in stock (S)

headline: Record Year in TV For Political Billings
abstract: Television Bureau of Advertising survey puts 1996 spending on political television commercials at record $400 million, up 34 percent from 1992 (S)ø

headline: British Hotel Company Sells 25 Properties
abstract: Queens Moat Houses PLC sells 25 hotels to group of managers backed by Hambro European Ventures Ltd for 91.5 million pounds ($149.3 million) (S)

headline: Economic Calender
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  U.S. Productivity 4th Qtr.

headline: F.T.C. Accord on Wall St. Deal Is Seen
abstract: Morgan Stanley Group Inc says Federal Trade Commission will not contest $10 billion merger between Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter, Discover & Co on antitrust grounds (S)

headline: French Police Arrest 250 Men Linked to Child Pornography Ring
abstract: Police across France detain more than 250 people and confiscate some 5,000 videocassettes in major operation against child pornography; men charged include two school directors, two teachers and several other people who work with children; raids are coordinated by task force in Nice (S)

headline: Stratton Oakmont Ordered to Liquidate
abstract: Federal Judge John E Sprizzo rules court-appointed bankruptcy trustee should liquidate Stratton Oakmont Inc, which sought to reorganize as merchant bank; Securities Investor Protection Corp sought liquidation, holding investors are missing securities because of unauthorized trading by Stratton (S)

headline: AUTOTOTE SELLING OFF EUROPEAN LOTTERY BUSINESS
abstract: Autotote Corp to sell its European lottery business, Tele Control, to Scientific Games Holdings Corp for approximately $25 million (S)

headline: Treasury Prices Fall on Strong Jobs Report
abstract: Treasury securities prices fall; 30-year bond falls 27/32, to 95 22/32, to yield 6.84 percent (M)

headline: Stay-at-Home Spouses Get I.R.A. Break
abstract: Married couples with one nonworking spouse will be able to invest up to a combined $4,000--up from $2,250--in individual retirement accounts under provision of a law that takes effect in 1997; will be on par with couples with two wage-earning partners; cartoon (M)

headline: Executives on the go can expect to shell out more for air fares, hotels and car rentals next year.
abstract: Business travel experts say hotel rates are climbing 5% or more, and air fares are increasing 5% to 7% for business travelers; note that because of downsizing, upper-echelon execs are now making many of business trips formerly assigned to middle managers (S)

headline: Delta to Buy Only Boeing Jets for 20 Years
abstract: Delta Air Lines says it will buy only Boeing jets for next 20 years, and announces initial order for 106 aircraft worth $6.7 billion; it also announces options to buy additional 124 jets worth $8.3 billion; Delta agreement parallels one signed last November by American Airlines, which has also committed to long-term relationship with Boeing; executives at Airbus Industrie, European jet manufacturer, voice their disappointment (M)

headline: Imperial Tobacco Is Buying Rizla
abstract: Imperial Tobacco PLC to buy Rizla International, Dutch cigarette paper maker, for 168 million pounds ($277 million) and 17 million pounds of assumed debt (S)

headline: Spain's Santander Hopes to Become No. 1 in Latin America
abstract: Banco Santander, Spain's largest bank, is seeking to expand its global reach by making bank a major player in Latin America; Santander's strategy is being orchestrated by Emilio Botin, 62-year-old chairman, and his 35-year-old American-educated daughter, Ana Patricia; photo of Botins; map shows Santander's global reach (L)

headline: KISTLER WINS $100 MILLION LORAL SATELLITE CONTRACT
abstract: Kistler Aerospace Corp gets $100 million Space Systems-Loral contract for 10 communications satellites launchings aboard Kistler's re-usable aerospace vehicles (S)

headline: Californian Wins Middle Market and Ruffles His Rivals
abstract: Article on Jess Jackson, who owns fastest-growing and most successful wine-making business to appear in California in 20 years; says from few acres of grapes in early 1970's, Jackson now controls more than a dozen wineries--including his flagship, Kendall-Jackson--stretching from all the choice growing regions of California to Europe and South America; Jackson's empire is now among top 10 wine businesses in the country, with sales of about $200 million in 1996 from Kendall-Jackson alone; tables; photos (L)

headline: ARIZONA SHOPPING CENTER PROJECT INCREASED
abstract: Developers Diversified Realty Corp says that it had acquired additional 299,751-square-foot portion of Arizona shopping center project from Vestar Development Co for $38.8 million (S)

headline: A Disney Cartoon Becomes a Morality Play for Paris
abstract: Animated movie The Hunchback of Notre Dame becomes number two box office draw in Paris; reviewers, apparently willing to forgive Walt Disney Studios for taking huge liberties with the Victor Hugo novel that inspired the movie, draw moral parallel between the story and August 1996 incident in which police beat down doors of a Paris church and hauled out more than 200 illegal immigrants who had sought asylum from France's tough expulsion laws (M)

headline: Pacific Telesis and 2 Other Bells In Dispute Over a TV Venture
abstract: Pacific Telesis Group is clashing with its corporate partners over future of Tele-TV, their ambitious but troubled phone company venture into television; executives familiar with Tele-TV say other partners, Bell Atlantic Corp and Nynex Corp, want to shut down company and fold its operations into Bell Atlantic; but Pacific Telesis, which plans to introduce wireless cable television service in Los Angeles, Calif, this spring, is insisting that partners continue to finance Tele-TV, at least through its introduction (L)

headline: 1996 Sales Fell For Renault's Truck Unit
abstract: Renault Vehicules Industriels, unit of France's second-largest automobile maker, says full year sales fell 16 percent (S)

headline: Playing the Trade Card
abstract: David E Sanger analysis of Clinton Administration's growing reliance on World Trade Organization as a tool of foreign policy, not just on issues like insuring free markets and fair enforcement of trade rules abroad but also on political matters, which is what is ultimately at stake in US efforts to bar China from WTO until it dismantles its huge state-owned enterprises (M)

headline: Banc One Is Said to Plan Bid Of $7 Billion for First USA
abstract: Banc One Corp is expected to announce that it will acquire First USA Inc for about $7 billion; industry experts say deal is likely to spur further consolidation in credit card industry; First USA has grown faster than nearly any other card issuer; rapid growth is often seen as precursor to problems in banking, but First USA's management is widely seen as among most sophisticated in card industry, and its computerized credit analysis systems are among most advanced; deal would vault Banc One to rank third in credit card market, after Citicorp and MBNA Corp, with $33 billion in credit card loans (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Support for Strong Dollar May Be Ending, Rubin Hints  Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, taking a little air out of the rapidly rising dollar, suggested that the Administration has ended its two-year-long effort to drive up the dollar against the world's other major currencies. Mr. Rubin has said repeatedly over that time that ''a strong dollar is in the interest of the United States.'' Yesterday, in a subtly worded change of policy, he said that while a strong dollar was still in America's interest, ''we have had a strong dollar for some time now,'' a phrase he used three more times.     The comments by Mr. Rubin set off a torrent of activity on world financial markets and knocked the dollar down just before it hit 125 yen, a four-year high. For the day, the dollar settled in New York at 122.60 yen, down 0.94 yen from Thursday. Against the mark, the dollar ended at 1.6568, up a slight 0.0064 from the day before. $(Page 1.$)    TCI Names New President  The board of Tele-Communications Inc. appointed Leo J. Hindery Jr. president. That title was previously held by John C. Malone, who remains chairman and chief executive. In recent years, Mr. Malone had withdrawn from daily management, leaving that responsibility with Brendon Clouston, president of the company's giant cable operations. The move was seen by analysts as part of an effort to bolster the shares of Tele-Communications, which have lagged badly in a bull market, as have those of other cable companies. In December, as part of that effort, Mr. Malone announced that the company would begin a sweeping program to cut costs, reduce debt and improve net income. $(36.$)    N.A.S.D. Reviews Data Purging  The National Association of Securities Dealers will review as many as 3,000 items of data involving brokers' disciplinary histories that it mistakenly purged from a data bank. $(36.$)    Stock Market Takes a Bumpy Ride  A fickle stock market soared, sputtered, and then soared again, with the Dow Jones industrial average ending sharply higher. The session showed once again how jittery the market can be in reaction to a news headline. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 82.74 points, or 1.22 percent, to close at 6,855.80, just 28 points shy of the closing high it set on Jan. 21. For the week, the Dow was up 42.71 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent. Broader market indexes fared even better. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 9.41 points, to 789.56, a new high. And the Nasdaq composite index was up 11.31 points, to 1,357.71, after technology issues rebounded from a weeklong decline. $(38.$)    Bonds Rise on Jobs Report  Investors who have kept to the sidelines of the bond market this week returned en masse after the Labor Department released employment figures that indicated that growth in wages was slow. The 30-year Treasury bond gained 20/32 , to a price of 97 12/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, slipped to 6.70 percent, from 6.75 percent on Thursday. For investors, the gain was about $6 for each bond with a face value of $1,000. $(38.$)     German Phone Alliance Ends   Cable and Wireless pulled out of its German telecommunications alliance with Veba and received 2.21 billion marks, or $1.3 billion, for its share in the venture, leaving Veba and RWE, the group's other member, to seek ''a new international partner.'' The new Cable and Wireless strategy is to concentrate on the British and Continental markets, while Veba plans to focus on Germany. $(36.$)    Energy Prices Fall on Mild Weather   Energy prices fell sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange, dragged down by growing expectations that a mild winter in the Northeast would keep inventories of heating fuels high. Energy prices fell after the National Weather Service forecast that mid-February temperatures would continue to be above normal in the Northeast, the biggest market for heating oil. On other markets, coffee prices rose and copper fell. $(34.$)     Family Member Quits Dow Jones Job   An outspoken member of the family that controls Dow Jones & Company has quit his job there. William Cox 3d, who had been in charge of sales and marketing for Dow Jones Global Indexes, has been unhappy with the performance of Dow Jones stock. $(36.$)

headline: Chaos by Design: How Albanian Retained Power
abstract: News analysis reports that Albanian Pres Sali Berisha appears to have deliberately created armed chaos in Tirana in order to defend himself against popular rebellion; strategy of opening weapons warehouses to gunmen for 'revolution on cue' seems to have worked for now, at great cost to country, allowing Berisha to keep reins of powerful secret police and state media; photo; Western diplomat notes that late Communist dictator Enver Hoxha would have approved (S)

headline: LUCAS VARITY BUYS CALIFORNIA AUTO PARTS COMPANY
abstract: Lucas Varity PLC has acquired SBC Ltd and Kinetic Parts Manufacturing Inc for undisclosed amount (S)ê

headline: U.N. Workers Leave City As the Rebels Gain in Zaire
abstract: United Nations has evacuated all foreign aid workers from eastern Zairian city of Kisangani, leaving thousands of Rwandan refugees to uncertain fate; UN officials say increasingly feeble Zairian Govt can no longer guarantee their security in Kisangani; move comes day afer United Nations Secretary General called for international peacekeeping force in eastern Zaire; evacuation sets back UN effort to save Rwandan Hutu refugees in region from disease and starvation; map (M)

headline: Martin Opening Office in Charlotte
abstract: Martin Agency will open creative office in Charlotte, NC, its second outside its Richmond headquarters; new office will be headed by John Boone as vice president and associate creative director, as David Oakley as senior copywriter (S)

headline: Nielsen Alternative Gets Financing Help
abstract: AT&T Corp and Procter & Gamble Co, two big television advertisers, will help finance efforts of Statistical Research Inc to develop its Systems for Measuring and Reporting Television (SMART), audience measurement system meant to compete against Nielsen Media Research (S)

headline: Dow Average to Replace 4 Stocks To Better Reflect the U.S. Economy
abstract: Dow Jones & Co announces it will replace 4 of 30 stocks in closely watched Dow Jones industrial average--first change in the index in nearly six years; company says moves--to be effective March 17--reflect growing role of technology, health care and financial services in the economy, but changes clearly represent effort, as well, to get rid of some losers in the index; joining the Dow are Hewlett-Packard, Johnson & Johnson, Travelers Group and Wal-Mart Stores; leaving are Bethlehem Steel, Texaco, Westinghouse Electric and Woolworth; chart (L)

headline: Asher/Gould and Lowe Change Executives
abstract: Asher/Gould Advertising names Joel Hochberg president and chief operating officer, succeeding Bruce Silverman, who resigned; Hochberg was executive vice president and general manager at Los Angeles, Calif, office of Foote, Cone & Belding; at Foote, Cone Los Angeles, Thom Miller, senior vice president and group director, has been promoted to succeed Hochberg as general manager; Lowe Group unit of Interpublic Group of Companies in London and New York is shifting executives as part of a restructuring of Lowe & Partners Worldwide to add regional operations for Latin America and Asia-Pacific market to operations for North America and Europe; Jose Eduardo Cazarin becomes president for Latin America; Adrian Holmes becomes chairman and chief creative officer for Europe, and Jerry Judge becomes chief executive for Europe; Judge becomes co-chairman at Lowe Howard-Spink, sharing title with Paul Weinberger, who is also being promoted to executive creative director; Tim Lindsay, managing director at Lowe Howard-Spink, becomes chief executive there, succeeding Judge; Lindsay's successor as managing director is Paul Hammersley, who had been executive vice president for Lowe Group in North America (M)

headline: Bonds Ease, Ignoring Good Price Data
abstract: Treasury prices fall despite report of consumer prices that showed inflation under control; price of 30-year Treasury bond drops 13/32, to 100 22/32; graph (M)

headline: Taco Bell and Saab Cars Shift $250 Million In Accounts
abstract: Taco Bell Corp names TBWA/Chiat Day to handle creative portion of its advertising account, with billings estimated at $200 million; account was formerly handled by Bozell Worldwide; Saab Cars USA selects Martin Agency as agency of record; account, with billings estimated at $50 million, had been handled since 1990 by Angotti, Thomas, Hedge (Advertising) (M)

headline: NPC INTERNATIONAL ACQUIRES 126 RESTAURANTS
abstract: NPC International Inc says that it acquired 126 restaurants from Pizza Hut Inc for $56 million (S)

headline: Federated's Chief to Leave In the Spring
abstract: Allen I Questrom says he will step down as chairman and chief executive of Federated Department Stores Inc in May and be succeeded by James M Zimmerman, currently president and chief operating officer; Zimmerman will be succeeded as president by Terry J Lundgren, who will also become chief merchandising officer (M)

headline: Courtly Ritual Greets Albright On Capitol Hill
abstract: Madeleine K Albright, nominee for Secretary of State, is treated warmly at day-long confirmation hearings before Senate Foreign Relations Committee; is praised by Sen Jesse Helms, conservative Committee chairman and longtime critic of State Department; she vows to bring new energy and advocacy to job if confirmed; says US should be authors of 'history of our age,' but should be judicious in its interventions while not hesitating to act in world; photos (M)

headline: Harold Osrow, 80; Built a Much Better Broom
abstract: Harold Osrow, chairman of Osrow Products, company he founded to produce an array of novel household items he helped invent, died on March 20 at age 80 (L)

headline: Uncovered Short Sales Fall 2.6% On the New York Stock Exchange
abstract: Number of open positions on short sales on New York Stock Exchange falls for first time since July '96; short interest fell 2.6 percent in monthlong period ended January 10, with open positions dropping 75.2 million--from 2.9 billion to 2.8 billion (S)

headline: Airbus in Talks With South Koreans
abstract: Airbus Industrie holds talks with Samsung Aerospace Industries, Korean Air, other South Korean firms about taking part in its project to develop jumbo jet to compete with Boeing Co (S)û

headline: Irish President's Decision Not to Run Again Unsettles Politicians
abstract: Pres Mary Robinson's decision not to seek second seven-year term throws Irish politics into turmoil; politicians, who face parliamentary election this year, must wonder whom they should back in presidential election, also to be held this year; main question is whether candidate for what is largely ceremonial post should be person not directly involved in Irish Republic politics (M)

headline: Freeh's Attack on Saudis Surprises Other Aides
abstract: Clinton Administration officials say that when FBI Dir Louis J Freeh and Atty Gen Janet Reno voiced their frustrations this week about lack of Saudi cooperation in investigation of terrorist bombing last summer that killed 19 Americans, it came as shock to just about every senior official in Administration; senior State Dept officials say they were not told about Freeh's plan to criticize Washington's closest ally in Persian Gulf or of Reno's decision to underscore his complaints the next day; officials say that criticism of Saudi Arabia by nation's two top law enforcement officials might have opposite of its intended effect on country that has been sensitive to perception that it is caving in to Western pressure (M)

headline: First Woman to Head F.D.I.C. Is Leaving
abstract: Federal Deposit Insurance Corp chairman Ricki R Helfer is leaving her post after two and a half years; she was first woman to head a Federal banking agency (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Table shows key interest rates

headline: Dollar Is Up Against the Mark On Rate Bets in the 2 Nations
abstract: Dollar rose against mark on March 19 for first time in four days, settling at 1.6816 marks; rose to 122.82 Japanese yen, but fell against British pound, to $1.5892 (S)
